HEADLINE: Destination: Spring;
5 Restless Writers Head Outside And Report Back On What They Found There

BYLINE: By Jon Nordheimer 

 BODY:
Whatever the calendar says, spring really begins with the first irresistible urge to head outside. Our senses quickened more by instinct than the outward signposts of the season, we shed the deadness of winter and we get going.
Barely greening trails, muddy as often as not, are blazed anew by the first hikers of the year. Roads and pathways fill with runners and cyclists sharpening their skills for a long race or rally, or just airing out their lungs at long last. Shore towns, shut down tight just yesterday, begin to primp for a summer that's still months away. At nurseries and garden stores, long lines form at cash registers as suburban farmers dream of harvesting the perfect tomato. Weekday road warriors get into their cars, roll down the windows, hopefully, and just drive, heading nowhere but away. 
 There are countless places across the state to indulge the pleasant restlessness of spring. Some of them, of course, are genuine, board-certified "destinations." More often, though, they are simply places that fit right, that suit individual styles. We asked five New Jersey writers where they go when they head back outside; here are their destinations.
 POWER tools whine in a boatyard. A boardwalk concession booth opens with a rusty clatter. Workers sprucing up summer cottages scrape gutters clean of leaves and twigs. Boats and houses lashed by saltwater and wind are slapped with fresh paint.
After a long winter's sleep, the shore is coming to life again. But each year, that sleep gets shorter.
By early spring, if the weather is sunny and warm, a growing number of people are already visiting beach resorts on weekends, walking the boardwalk, eating in restaurants or taking a boat out for a spin.
Back in the late 1950's, when I first worked as a lifeguard at an ocean beach club, there were only two seasons at the shore: the crush of activity between Memorial Day and Labor Day, then an unbroken hibernation for the next nine months.
Which suited the locals just fine. With the crowds and traffic gone, the boardwalk concessions shuttered and beach bungalows boarded up, they had the shore to themselves.
I had spent previous summers at beaches on Long Island and Cape Cod, but had never lived through a coastal winter until the fall of 1959, when a summer romance lingered past Labor Day. I spent that winter in a little community of Victorian homes called Island Heights on the Toms River in Ocean County.
I've been coming back ever since, and now make it my permanent home.
I'm not the only one.
The four counties that make up the Jersey Shore have a year-round population of about 1.4 million, more than double that in the 1950's, when the region did a booming summer business but was an economic backwater for the rest of the year. Newcomers like myself have discovered not only that summers are cooler than they are nearer New York, but that winters are warmer and autumn delicious, and that spring ushers in a splendid ripening well ahead of areas to the north.
But another big change was fostered by the growing population. Businesses like restaurants and shops can now remain open through the year, So city dwellers who feel the need to get away for the weekend for some fresh air and tranquility, exercise or partying, have available at the shore an infrastructure that has helped extend the summer season to the fat parts of spring and autumn.
Surer signs of spring than robins are "summer" residents arriving to open a house in Bay Head, Long Beach Island or Stone Harbor. Plumbers and house cleaners are in short supply this month.
The rapidly growing ranks of boat owners have their own rituals to usher in the season. On a sunny April weekend, marinas, yacht clubs and boatyards hum with the chores of spring -- power washing, scraping and painting, brightwork polishing. Starting those chores early pays off, because rivers and bays that will be cluttered with traffic in summer are sublimely uncrowded now.
A cold spring rain can make beach resort towns look as deserted and dreary as they are in January, when only the gulls walk the high tide line. But warm weekends bring out the crowds, visitors eager to get a head start on summer.

HEADLINE: THE NATION: Bootstraps;
'Not My Job.' 'Not Our Job.' So Whose Job Is It?

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
A GREAT battle was joined in the first 100 days of Speaker Newt Gingrich and Republican rule, and if you believe it was over taxes or welfare or the deficit, you are only a little right. The real struggle is over a vastly more important issue: who owes what to whom. This most hoary and basic of all social debates is usually afforded the reverence and inattention of great art: People know it's there and mostly, they ignore it.
 Whatever else happened in the last three months, the debate became impossible to ignore. For the last 60 years, the United States's version of the contract between man and society was clear: society's purpose was man's betterment. The incoming legislature has its own Contract, and it is not too much to say that it stands that concept on its head. 
 Until lately, that Government's duty was to set a minimum standard for civilized society, then raise the oppressed and the needy to that level. Now comes the Republican antithesis: what makes a civil society is not some mass standard, but each individual's freedom to pursue his own happiness -- and learn from the pain of his mistakes.
 The debate has usually come out of the museum case at times of widespread discontent, and this time public uneasiness with government -- and anger at those who conduct it -- is at a historic high. The debate was most recently joined on Friday, when Mr. Gingrich proclaimed his intention to "totally remake" the Government, after President Clinton threatened a "pile of vetos."

 
 
The Welfare Example
 Sure, this is deep stuff, but it is not only some joust between woolly-headed theorists. It is the subtext of dozens of the bills that the House churned out during the past three months. It is the core of the debate over welfare: Democrats insist that decency and equity require Federal standards for aid and a guarantee of help to all who qualify. Republicans say Federal standards and guarantees caused the welfare mess by easing the pain and stigma of illegitimacy and divorce. Their solution is a "Personal Responsibility Act" that wipes out the entitlement.
 The same ideological divide defines almost every political issue these days. Affirmative action? One side believes society has a duty to compensate for a legacy of discrimination. The other believes Federal dictates have hamstrung individual initiative. Ditto disputes over Federal regulations, or grazing rights, or pollution standards. Even tax cuts, Mr. Gingrich might argue, aren't political plums but an effort to siphon money away from Government's social agenda and back to the individual.
 In the sound-bitten parlance of this Congress, this is a battle between the we-are-all-guilty liberal apologists for the welfare state and the let-'em-starve Fagins of modern conservatism. Yet the real dispute -- where to draw the boundary between individual and collective interests -- is hardly so simple.
 America was founded on nothing if not the principle of individual freedom and responsibility. The pioneer and the cowboy are part of the national mythology. But mythology it is. Modern society is built on Government grants of collective rights: Social Security, access to the disabled, pensions to veterans and more.
 That being said, the last few years have seen a growing consensus that lack of individual responsibility, not an excess, is at the root of America's social crisis. On teen-age illegitimacy, fatherless homes and the mindless violence of urban society, Mr. Gingrich and President Clinton sound alike: social norms and structure have collapsed; actions are not seen as having consequences; role models are nonexistent. The dispute is over why this is so, and how to fix it. Here, the gaps are yawning.
 Most Democrats and some intellectuals tend to blame a culture of immediate gratification, an increasingly rootless society and an economy that no longer offers the unskilled jobs that once kept poor families afloat. They note that most other advanced nations are suffering similar spikes in illegitimacy and crime.
 Most important, they argue that the solution is a new compact -- to rebuild neighborhoods and communities and promote common moral and social foundations. It is an activist approach, led by founders of the communitarian movement like Amatai Etzioni of George Washington University and the Harvard political scientist Michael Sandel. William Galston, Mr. Etzioni's partner and co-author in the communitarian movement, is among the President's senior domestic advisers.
 Mr. Clinton has embraced communitarian tenets in his own designs for welfare reform, his efforts to create a national consensus on abortion and illegitimacy, and even his national service program.
 The new Republican order argues that activist government is not the solution, but the problem. In addressing illegitimacy, poverty and similar woes, the argument goes, Government has destroyed the notion that people are responsible for much of anything. Moreover, they say, the bureaucracies rarely help their individual clients. And so the new order's solution is to stop cushioning individuals from the other forces that once maintained civil society.

 
 
Both Ways, Please
 Opinion polls suggest that voters like the strength and simplicity of the Republican return to individual struggle. But clearly, they also worry that it conceals a mean streak that would punish the vulnerable. Thomas Mann, an the Brookings Institution analyst of government, states the public mood succinctly: "Americans want people to pull themselves up by their bootstraps," he said, "and they want government to help them."
 There is a thin line between rugged individualism and looking out for No. 1. The new Republican disdain for the crutch conveniently overlooks the most sweeping and by far the most expensive collective responsibilities in all Government, Medicare and Social Security. In the political castes, the very real arguments that Medicare has promoted a wasteful dependence on government, or that Social Security sped the breakup of the traditional family, are mentioned only in whispers.
 Democrats do not hesitate to conclude that the real impetus to the individual responsibilities movement is not ideology or reasoned analysis, but old-fashioned selfishness. Still others suggest that the new individualists are sugar-coating the state of society in the days before the Federal Government expanded society's collective duties. Stanley Wenocur, a professor and author at the University of Maryland in Baltimore, has studied the rise of modern social work, and says that the Federal Government took on welfare during the Depression for a simple reason: states and cities were too poor to provide anything but abysmal conditions.
 "We had a lot of suffering. A lot of suffering," he said. "We had an enormous amount of poverty: workhouses, serious social conditions. People died at earlier ages. There was a lot misery."
 The purest advocates of the conservative view allow that. An entire generation of dependents may simply pitch over should their Government props be kicked from beneath them, they say. But they add that that may be the price of teaching their children to stand by themselves. And they say that the situation could not get much worse.
 "We've made it possible for a teen-age girl to survive with no husband and no job," said David Boaz, the executive vice president of the Cato Institute, a libertarian organization. "That used to be very difficult. If we had more stigma and lower benefits, might we end up with 100,000 bastards every year rather than a million children born to alternative families?"

HEADLINE: THE WORLD: Unlucky Bucks;
In New Diplomatic Struggles, Money Is An Unreliable Ally

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
HERE'S one of the hard truths of the new world of economic diplomacy: Twenty billion dollars doesn't buy as much gratitude as it used to.
 If it did, American officials would not be sweating this week over whether Mexico, fresh from a $20billion American bailout, would undercut the savior of its economy by voting against President Clinton's effort to win an indefinite, worldwide extension of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. 
 For weeks, the Administration has been twisting arms in Mexico City, trying to get the Government there to abandon its position -- endorsed by much of the third world -- that the treaty perpetuates the status quo between the nuclear haves and have-nots. Gently reminded that their country would be in national bankruptcy now if President Clinton had not rammed through an emergency financial aid package, the Mexicans have begun to hint a compromise might be possible.
 Another big beneficiary of American largess in recent years, Russia, is more recalcitrant. Last week President Boris N. Yeltsin rejected, yet again, Washington's warnings against providing Iran with $800 million to $1 billion in light-water nuclear reactors, a sale that will give the Iranians an enormous amount of nuclear expertise that the Administration fears will be used in their fledgling nuclear weapons program. The reactor sale would bring Russia at least $100 million more in hard currency than President Clinton is asking Congress to provide for the next fiscal year, and the deal is worth twice as much as the largely American-paid programs to convert Russia's military factories and dismantle its nuclear arsenal.
 Together, Mexico and Russia point up vexing problems with the new brand of dollar diplomacy: It creates fewer moral obligations than Washington would like to think, and oftentimes there is a roomful of other bidders. In the more optimistic opening days of the post-cold war era, it was easier to talk in one breath about the expansion of free markets and the spread of democratic -- read American -- values, as if they were nearly synonymous.
 Sometimes. Often, though, markets and national interests trip over each other. As a senior Administration official said, "the problem is that your foreign policy can look like an afternoon at Sotheby's."

 
 
Going Down
 As any currency trader will tell you, it is a problem that is likely to get worse. The alarmingly swift decline of the dollar on foreign exchange markets recently -- a 13 percent drop since Jan. 1 -- should be resounding as loudly in the State Department as it is at Treasury.
 In the few corners of the world where military might still prevails as the ultimate currency of American power, Secretary of State Warren Christopher doesn't need to spend much time back in the business pages, checking the foreign-exchange tables. But the decade-long slide of the dollar has had a subtle but perceptible impact on American influence, especially in those regions where the two big gainers of the currency sweepstakes, Japan and Germany, wield their clout.
 Such changes are hard to measure; money and power are never fully interchangeable. But one reason neither the Japanese nor the Germans are screaming too loudly about the rise of their currency -- even though it makes their exports more expensive -- is that they know there are hidden benefits to be reaped.
 Look almost anywhere in Southeast Asia. Over the next decade, the competition for the best footholds is a competition for strategic investment -- putting the right car factories in southern China (and sometimes bribing the right officials), buying into the partnership in Indonesia tied to the country's ruling circle, scooping up India's best software talent. Almost all of those deals are done in dollars, for all its recent weaknesses still the currency, used in more than half the world's international transactions.

 
 
Power Currencies
 "It is pretty obvious that it just became 13 percent cheaper for the Japanese to build their base camps," said Jeffrey Garten, the Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade, who has led the charge to get American companies into big emerging markets. The same could be said for the Germans, and it's not for nothing that President Suharto of Indonesia spent time this month in Germany, presiding over the signing of deals with Siemens, Audi and Bayer.
 And for Germany and Japan, it's cheaper to provide foreign aid. For a while the United States and Japan were in a neck-and-neck race for the title of the world's biggest aid provider. Now, thanks partly to the dollar's fall, it's not even close.
 The power conveyed by strong currency is also felt in Europe, where the race to the East is going to the holders of German marks. Already the rise of the mark is creating resentments all over Europe, where Germany's strength is attracting jobs and investment at the expense of Spain, France and other neighbors. "What everyone knows is that in financial terms, at least, Germany can now call the tune on the economic integration of Europe," said David DeRosa, who heads currency trading at Swiss Bank Corporation in New York.
 Of course, the United States has always offered something beyond money: educational opportunity, open trading borders, an ideology and life style with selling power, military muscle -- areas where the Japanese do not compete. But as one Asian diplomat here noted recently with some derision, "good music, great movies and the Seventh Fleet" do not make up for investments that might narrow trade deficits.
 A weak dollar is hardly all bad: American exports are now cheaper than at any time in memory, and higher prices for imports can save jobs in marginal American industries. But some argue that Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin's insistence that a strong dollar is "in the national interest" is wrongheaded; push the dollar low enough, and Japanese and German industry will feel enough pain to get interested in opening markets and solving basic problems.
 Mr. Rubin insists that he would never use the dollar as a trade weapon. He also contended last week that the question of whether a weak dollar is undercutting American influence abroad "has not come up in any discussions I've been involved in" within the Administration. That itself is a remarkable observation about a White House that views its considerable advances in promoting free trade and nurturing emerging markets as its greatest foreign policy success.

 
 
No Deal
 It is also a White House that has been stymied in its efforts to bend market forces to meet its political objectives. When President Clinton banned Conoco Inc. from entering a $1 billion deal with Iran last month, the French happily stepped in. The Administration is also putting more pressure on Russia , warning that if the Iran reactor sale goes though, old and new nuclear coopoeration agreements may die on the vine.
 But the effort to induce China to improve its treatment of dissidents through "economic engagement" has failed to produce results. And the White House watered down a recent proposal for a "code of conduct" for American firms abroad, fearing that strict rules could put them at a disadvantage.
 Those experiences are all reminders that markets rarely care much about human rights, nonproliferation and the spread of democracy except to the extent that they lower costs and promote stability. Democracy's idea of a great vacation is a trip to ancient Athens; capitalism would rather hop on the next plane to Singapore.

HEADLINE: The World;
U.N.: Reason, in Small Doses, May Stop Genocide

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS

 BODY:
THE Security Council paused for a moment of silence on Thursday to mark the date a year ago when the Presidents of Burundi and Rwanda died in a plane crash, setting off 100 days of genocidal violence in Rwanda that took hundreds of thousands of lives. When the minute ended, the Council quickly moved on to its next order of business: a formal valedictory on Somalia, a somber statement about lessons learned in a peacekeeping operation gone awry.
 In Somalia, Rwanda, Liberia, Mozambique, Angola twice -- and now, again, Burundi, where some kind of international intervention may be necessary to save a moderate center from both Hutu and Tutsi extremists -- the United Nations is accumulating a lot of experience in failing to head off grotesque little wars. 
 Wary of intruding where unwelcome and perennially reluctant to see any national interest in catastrophes far from home, the most powerful members of the United Nations are also learning, paradoxically, how much more it costs to pick up the shattered pieces of countries than to prevent conflict. But this reality has changed few minds, perhaps because political considerations outweigh humanitarian instincts until heart-wrenching, televised scenes become domestic prods to international action.

 
 
Antibiotics to Carnage
 In recent weeks, as reports began to circulate of massacres of hundreds of majority Hutu people in Burundi by minority Tutsi militias and possibly troops of the Tutsi-led army, Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali stepped up his pleas to the Security Council for preemptive action. The United States, France and Germany, all Council members -- plus Belgium, the former colonial power in the East African region -- have been talking about what might be done, but without producing an action plan. A long delay in responding to violence in Rwanda a year ago is widely understood to have emboldened rampaging Hutu militias there, followed by vengeance-seeking Tutsi. Such delays send a message.
 "In 1993 the international community ignored thousands killed in Burundi the first time," said Alison DesForges, Rwanda consultant to Human Rights Watch, referring to violence that followed the assassination of Burundi's first elected Hutu President. "Planners of genocide in Burundi thought, we can go ahead with this. Then came the slow response in Rwanda in 1994, which encouraged people in Burundi again. And other parts of the world see this."
 As early as February, a high-level Security Council mission went to Burundi and made three innovative, nonmilitary suggestions to meet the scaled-back possibilities of the age: Set up an impartial judicial system, train impartial civilian police and investigators and establish good government in the provinces.
 Such suggestions may sound timid in the face of genocide. But these gestures are not nothing. If leading nations are not willing to commit troops (which countries in trouble might not want, in any case) the powerful can at least supply antibiotics to combat the disease of disintegration.
 But even then they have to factor in local sensibilities. Failure to do so risks charges of neocolonialism. Burundi, for example, took exception to the Security Council mission's characterization of its situation as "potentially explosive" and said in a letter to the Secretary General that the country already had a judicial system, police and provincial administrators. The Security Council warned Burundi that it could be brought under the criminal tribunal already set up for Rwanda -- which began its public work last week -- if ethnically based crimes continued.

 
 
Wary of Intervention
 Nongovernmental organizations, increasingly pivotal in delivering on pledges of nonmilitary assistance, are generally acutely aware of the sensitivities of small nations, however indefensible their actions. In Burundi, for example, major relief groups have cautioned against bringing outside military troops into the country too soon.
 Furthermore, though human rights groups and relief organizations are among the staunchest supporters of quick action in tension-ridden societies, there is concern among experts on Africa that disasters with common symptoms -- streams of displaced people, outbreaks of disease and widespread starvation and deaths -- have left the false impression that the roots of crisis may be the same in all or most African countries. Misreading the differences may mean misdiagnoses.
 Somalia, which has been unable to form a working coalition government to rebuild the country, has been ruled by regional clans for much of its history and lacks an impartial civil service. But Rwanda and Burundi are not tribal in social structure and have a history of strong central, provincial and local government.
 "Rwanda is not a failed state," says Ms. DesForges. "It was very efficient in mobilizing genocide. It used its administrative hierarchy, military hierarchy and militia structure. It was organized down to units of 10 households."
 Mr. Boutros-Ghali says clues to impending disaster are detectable long beforehand. "Genocide does not happen spontaneously," he wrote last week on the opinion page of the International Herald Tribune. "Genocide is planned and perpetrated by cynical leaders who believe they can get away with it -- and profit from it. In most cases there are abundant danger signs long before the killing begins."
 One of those dangers, a diplomat from Burundi said last week, is the collapse of confidence in a country's leaders and their ability to guarantee security. People unsure of their safety are fertile ground for propaganda and rumor. "The problem of Burundi now is a problem of confidence," he told reporters.
 Lionel Rosenblatt of Refugees International agrees, but asks: "How do you help a society deal with this? Our international tools are not very good. It does not fall into anyone's job description."
 When a pogrom begins, a sense of panic only grows as escape routes close. Last week, Tanzania, traditionally a welcoming country, began to push back refugees from both Burundi and Rwanda.
 To grapple with these psychological precursors to violence and retribution, say refugee groups, the United Nations and Western embassies in Africa and elsewhere, it is important to support the introduction of independent and objective radio broadcasts to provide reassuring information and counter hate-mongering like that of the Rwandan Hutu radio Milles Collines, which fueled genocidal rampages.
 In Burundi, the United States Ambassador, Robert Krueger, has been turning over evidence of atrocities he collects in remote areas to the local press because, he said, reporters have not been writing about attacks by extremists on either side. The American Embassy also backs a government program to send teams of legislators and officials into every administrative district to assess causes of violence, which may be political, economic or criminal as well as ethnic. Accurate information is a powerful weapon, diplomats say.
 But with all the suggestions now on the table, what was that most important lesson from last week's Security Council statement on Somalia? Without local commitment, all else may be useless. "The people of Somalia," the statement said, "bear the ultimate responsibility for achieving national reconciliation and restoring peace to Somalia."

HEADLINE: The World;
Guatemala's War: Ideology Is the Latest Excuse

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: GUATEMALA

 BODY:
TWO centuries before the modern-day massacres of Mayan Indians by the Guatemalan army, King Charles III of Spain was troubled by the massacres with which his soldiers had smothered the Mayan revolts of 1760 and 1764. So he dispatched a special church envoy to Guatemala to find a way to bring peace to his turbulent colony of vast sugar and indigo plantations.
 But the emissary, Archbishop Pedro Cortes y Larraza, found only an enduring resistance by the Mayas to their virtual slavery, and he wrote back that these "wretched people" have "an aversion and absolute hate for anything Spanish." 
 The Archbishop's report is now merely a footnote to the 300-year history of 30 Mayan rebellions, not counting the current civil war, which has taken the lives of more than 100,000 Indians and is now sputtering to an end.
 But it suggests that Guatemala required neither Karl Marx nor the Central Intelligence Agency to be consumed by class and ethnic war, and that the Guatemalan army, currently in the news because some of its officers received secret C.I.A. payments, is essentially finishing the job that the conquistadors started.
 The cross and the sword have been replaced by modern counterinsurgency tactics, but the essential driving forces of Guatemalan history remain the same. Land-hungry Indian peasants become squatters on the lands of the wealthy, who pay the police to make the Indians "disappear." Local army officers rule their provinces as a dictator might, mobilizing Indians as militias at the point of a gun, and dealing in contraband like stolen cars and rare timber woods. The wealthy press the Government to keep their taxes low while schools, sewage and health care for the Indian majority remain abysmal, far behind the standards of most of Latin America, let alone the industrialized north. One American diplomat said conditions in the Guatemalan interior were deteriorating and could eventually rival Haiti's.
 While nearly half of the 9.7 million Guatemalans, like most of their fellow Latin Americans, are descended from unions between the Spanish colonizers and indigenous Indians, the other half are considered of pure Indian heritage -- and these people "remain largely outside the country's political, social and economic mainstream," according to a recent United Nations human rights report. Guatemala's overall literacy rate is 52 percent, but only 29 percent of the Indians can read and write.

 
 
The Very Few Rich
 With the exception of a microscopic white minority, who own the sugar and coffee plantations and do business with international companies, almost everyone who isn't an Indian is a mestizo, or in Guatemalan parlance, a "Ladino." Dress and an acute language barrier (the Indians speak 23 distinct regional tongues) distinguish the Mayas from their fellow Guatemalans more than the color of their skins.
 Guatemala's sharp ethnic divide and vestiges of the colonial social order constitute the crucial backdrop rarely mentioned during the Congressional hearings and public debate about what the C.I.A. did here. While Americans often treat a C.I.A.-sponsored coup in 1954 as the root cause of four decades of guerrilla warfare, Guatemalan analysts take a longer view.
 In a column published last week in the Guatemalan newspaper Prensa Libre, Jorge Guzman wrote that the newest C.I.A. scandal echoed the long history of foreigners "invading" Guatemala, beginning with "the arrival of a thousand Pizarros." He noted that "even the Franciscan Friar Diego De Landa, who lived among the Mayas for 30 years, implanted his faith by torture."

 
 
No Prompting Needed
 Revelations that Col. Julio Roberto Alpirez, who had long been a paid C.I.A. informer, was implicated in the murders of an American innkeeper as well as an Indian guerrilla leader who had married an American have touched off investigations by the Clinton Administration and Congress. The Administration has promised a review of every member of the Guatemalan military who received payments from the C.I.A. over the last 15 years.
 But whatever information emerges about the extent to which American agents supported or condoned Guatemalan intelligence officers in their war against the guerrillas, their Indian supporters and vast numbers of peasants living in the areas of conflict, the fact remains that Guatemalans do not need prompting to kill one another.
 "I don't fear the C.I.A. that much," said a student activist who wore a long mask to hide his identity as he asked pedestrians in downtown Guatemala City for donations to finance a student anti-Government march. "The repression is Guatemalan."
 Guatemala's cycles of violence go back to the early 16th century, when Hernan Cortes sent his deputy, Pedro de Alvarado, with a force of 120 cavalry, 300 infantry and an auxiliary unit of Mexican Indian fighters to conquer a Mayan people weakened by their own divisions. The conquistadors slashed and burned their way through the highlands, and then created cheap pools of labor through church-controlled "congregaciones" not unlike the strategic hamlets the Guatemalan army created in the 1980's.
 The Mayan resistance persisted through the colonial period in many forms. When not rebelling, the Indians resisted Spanish efforts to destroy their culture, usually by wrapping their traditions into those of their oppressor. When the Spanish gave them chickens to eat, they sacrificed them to their pre-Columbian gods. They acknowledged the Catholic saints, but as variations of their own deities. One bizarre religious cult persists throughout the country in which a pipe-smoking Indian named Maximon is saint-like in every respect except for his penchant for drinking hard moonshine.
 Modern Guatemalan political history began not with the coup of 1954, but with the so-called "liberal revolution" of 1871. With Mexican financial backing, General Justo Rufino Barrios took control of the Government and then expropriated most communal Indian, as well as church, properties.
 A proud collector of guitars, bulls and books, General Barrios was an adherent of 19th century European liberal thinking about free markets and free trade. For him, the traditional Indians stood in the way of progress, a notion that permeates the modern Guatemalan army, which he founded. When an Indian insurgency broke out, he burned crops to starve the rebels and forcibly resettled Indians who backed them.
 The "liberal era" persisted until October 1944, when young army officers inspired by Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal staged a coup. The reformist Government founded agrarian cooperatives for the peasantry, and tried to bring the Indian majority into the Ladino mainstream by launching a Spanish-language literacy campaign in Mayan communities.
 Washington cautiously supported the reformist Government, until the 1950 election of Colonel Jacobo Arbenz, who lurched the "October Revolution" far to the left.
 Arbenz promised to soothe ancient antagonisms with a sweeping land reform. But he misjudged how the international tensions generated after World War II would first eclipse his efforts and then intensify the Guatemalan impulses toward both repression and rebellion. By surrounding himself with Communist Party advisers, accepting arms from Czechoslovakia and building a port to compete with United Fruit's facilities, Arbenz challenged the United States at the height of the cold war.

 
 
The 1954 Coup
 President Eisenhower's C.I.A. organized a Guatemalan invasion force and bombed Guatemala City in 1954. Arbenz panicked, his Government quickly collapsed, and forces that had been building over so many centuries were unleashed with a new fury. In the decades that followed, Marxist guerrillas, most of them Ladinos, established footholds and, by the early 1980's, had succeeded in recruiting tens of thousands of land-hungry Indian peasants to their cause.
 And the Guatemalan army, ever the defender of the status quo, was ready to fill its traditional role -- and then some.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: Faster. Farther. Higher.;
Faking It on Broadway

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

 BODY:
THE most powerful man on Broadway has some trouble keeping good help. It's easy to see why.
 Sir Andrew Lloyd Webber is, of course, the composer of "Jesus Christ Superstar," "Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat," "Cats," "Evita," "Starlight Express," "The Phantom of the Opera," "Aspects of Love" and "Sunset Boulevard." He's also the owner of a media conglomerate, the Really Useful Group, that produces his shows, owns theaters in Europe, is moving into movies and had a pre-tax profit of more than $70 million last year. 
 That puts him up near the economic stratosphere that Steven Spielberg and David Geffen fly in. But his behavior is more in the feisty -- and sometimes bizarre -- traditions of Broadway hypemeisters like David Merrick or Florenz Ziegfeld, for whom business was always personal.
 Ten days ago, Sir Andrew's chief of North American operations was caught inflating box-office figures for two weeks of "Sunset Boulevard" performances -- the weeks that its star, Glenn Close, was on vacation. Sir Andrew's response was to release a letter blaming the whole thing on the executive, Edgar Dobie, and calling the idea "idiotic." But it concluded by saying that Mr. Dobie's decision to have the understudy, Karen Mason, rather than a guest star cover for Ms. Close "far outweighs his mistake" and that "accordingly, I have refused to accept his resignation."
 Despite the public drubbing and the non-sequitur reasoning -- why weigh a good casting decision against fraud? -- Mr. Dobie is apparently still at work. For Really Useful, this is probably a good thing; Mr. Dobie has been well-liked on the Great White Way, which sometimes feels like a high-stakes kindergarten.
 The squabble grew uglier five days later when an angry letter from Ms. Close to Sir Andrew leaked out. She expressed disgust with the attempt to suggest that she was not crucial to the show and said she felt like quitting immediately. But the next day, she and Sir Andrew issued a joint statement saying they had patched things up.
 Neither Mr. Dobie, Sir Andrew nor Ms. Close returned calls seeking interviews.
 What remained unclear was why such a silly mistake was made, and how people who pay public relations firms so handsomely could have let the fight get so out of hand.
 Broadway is not a large industry; it sold $356 million worth of tickets last season, which gives it about the same gross income as, for example, the Starter Corporation, which makes sports jackets and caps. (It makes another $600 million a year from touring shows.) But it's got that Rialto romance, and it drives much of New York's tourist industry, so the handful of big producers and stars are heavily watched.
 It also may be the only industry where everyone knows, week by week, how their rivals are doing. Every show reports to Variety how many people bought tickets and how much they paid. With an educated guess about running costs and a little pencil work, it's possible to figure out whether your worst enemy is making money or not -- and to give him a sad shake of the head as you pass each other in Shubert Alley.
 That makes for some pretty desperate egos.
 "Sunset" has been a virtual sellout since it opened in November. For the two weeks Ms. Close was gone, 5,462 seats -- about 20 percent -- were unsold. Mr. Dobie gave or sold them at deep discounts to charitable organizations. So the chairs were filled. The lie was telling Variety that they'd been sold at full price.
 Be it said, there's no crime involved. The official box office treasurer's report, which is used to pay royalties to authors and profits to investors and therefore is subject to criminal fraud statutes, had accurate figures: ticket receipts were $569,720, not the $724,780 reported to Variety. Mr. Dobie just didn't realize that an enterprising Variety reporter could get hold of a box-office report.
 Rival Broadway producers -- refusing to let their names be used -- expressed doubts that Mr. Dobie had acted without consulting anyone back in Britain. And some wondered: why hadn't Really Useful just bought the tickets? It would have cost $300,000, but most would have returned to the company's own pockets, and a lot of mess would have been avoided. Unless, the more cynical reasoned, the mess made headlines, which sell tickets.
 And to be fair, no producer was exactly morally outraged. Many, like Cy Feuer, who began putting on shows in the 1940's, resent the practice of opening their books.
 "In the grand tradition of show business, he lied to Variety?" Mr. Feuer said. "I'd give him a raise."

HEADLINE: The World;
Europe's Leaders See Green

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER 

DATELINE: BERLIN

 BODY:
AT the United Nations conference on climate change last week, which called for a new accord to limit emissions of greenhouse gases, the debates revealed one striking difference between the northern European countries and the United States.
 Because the European countries are so much more thickly settled than the United States, there is a much higher consciousness here of the urgency of environmental problems and of the need for joint action to confront them. The political success of Green parties has awakened other parties, even some of the most conservative, to the importance that voters attach to environmental issues. And politicians find it easier to denounce environmental criminals in a part of the world where many of the criminals have been Communist regimes rather than powerful corporations. 
 Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who is considered one of Europe's more conservative leaders, set the tone. The greenhouse effect "threatens to thwart our efforts toward economic development and increased prosperity," he told the conference. "By 1997, we must have agreed on a climate protection protocol which covers all greenhouse gases, lays down clear objectives and target dates for their reduction, and determines all measures necessary to achieve this aim."
 In the United States, by contrast, "there is no constituency" pressing for new limits on the gases that are slowly warming the earth's atmosphere, lamented Under Secretary of State Timothy Wirth, who headed the United States delegation. "This issue is just not on the radar screen in the United States. It's a very frustrating position to be in."
 Even at top levels of government, the tone of public rhetoric on environmental topics is much sharper and more urgent in Europe than in the United States. Some American industrialists attribute this not so much to altruism as to a calculation that global environmental restrictions would cost producers in Europe less than those in America, thus producing a trade advantage.
 Adam Markham, an official of the World Wildlife Federation who has worked on both sides of the Atlantic, offered this explanation: "Because the United States is so big, many Americans feel isolated from other countries. Europeans are constantly discussing which policies in one country are having effects on other countries. In the United States there's a feeling that everything needed to control environmental destruction can be decided at home, that there's no real need for international instruments." STEPHEN KINZER

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
New York, Lost and Found

BYLINE: By PAUL GOLDBERGER 

 BODY:
WHEN Mayor Robert F. Wagner signed a bill 30 years ago this month to create the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission, he intended to stop, or at least slow down, New York's notorious tendency to sell off its greatest architectural works for a mess of pottage. If the law could have assured no more disasters like the demolition of the old Pennsylvania Station in 1963, its framers would have been happy.
 But the law has done much more than keeping the wreckers away from famous buildings -- so much more that it may be the single most influential piece of legislation affecting land use in New York since the first zoning laws went on the books in 1916. The law, which decreed that buildings important to the city's "cultural, social, economic, political or architectural history" be preserved unless a compelling legal case could be made for their demolition, has changed the nature of planning and architecture in the city and in the whole country. It has been copied by cities and towns around the nation, and it has been the legal platform on which a whole culture of historic preservation has been built. 
 When New York decided that it was the proper role of government to save valued buildings, other cities followed -- slowly at first, and then, after the Supreme Court upheld the constitutionality of the landmarks law in 1978, with more determination. Before New York got into the preservation business in 1965, two years after Penn Station was torn down to make way for a new Madison Square Garden, only two other major cities, Charleston and New Orleans, had done anything to save historic buildings, and their laws applied only to specific historic districts. New York's law gave the landmarks commission the power to cast its net over the entire city.

 
 
Saved from the Dumps
 And cast it did. From a tentative start, the commission grew bolder and bolder, to the point where 1,021 individual buildings have now been designated as city landmarks. Penn Station may have been carted off to the dumps, but Grand Central Terminal, the New York Public Library, the Plaza Hotel and skyscrapers from the Woolworth Building to Lever House will be with us forever.
 And the establishment of 66 historic districts has had an even more sweeping effect on the cityscape: with 20,178 brownstones and row houses and loft buildings from SoHo to Brooklyn Heights to the Upper West Side protected under these blanket designations, the mold of the urban form has quite literally been set. No zoning law could have saved the elegant limestone townhouse blocks of the Upper East Side from the pressures of redevelopment in the boom of the 1980's; landmark designation was the only tool that kept that neighborhood together.
 By now landmarking is such an established concept that the real problem facing the commission is not skepticism over the idea of saving historic buildings, but the belief that the commission has already designated everything worth saving. After all, 1,021 is a lot of buildings, and that list includes virtually every New York structure in the architectural history books. What more is the landmarks commission to do?
 Plenty. As the city evolves, so does the very concept of landmarking and the sense of what saving history actually means. The buildings that are now designated landmarks are largely, though not entirely, the solid, grand buildings of the haute bourgeoisie; they represent the architectural legacy of the people, largely European immigrants, who built New York in the 19th and early 20th centuries.
 But the New York taking shape now is a very different city, and it may well leave a different architectural legacy. The landmarks commission has begun in the last few years to pay more attention to architecture in poor and working-class neighborhoods, and to acknowledge that there is both historic and esthetic value to many buildings that are not Beaux Arts palaces of granite and limestone. In the coming years the commission will have the challenge of seeing that the roster of landmarks continues to reflect the cultures shaping the city's history now.
 And then there is the question of the city's newer buildings. Since the landmarks legislation makes buildings eligible for designation once they are 30 years old -- the exact age of the commission now -- the whole question of the architecture of the 1960's is coming into play. For years it has been fashionable in architectural circles to denounce the skyscrapers and apartment buildings of the 1960's as worthless commercial trash -- but the Art Deco buildings of the 1930's were once called that, too. Will time mellow our views of the 1960's as it has mellowed our views of the '30's? Will anything from the decade that gave New York Lincoln Center and the Pan Am building be worth designating? The commission will soon have to decide.
 There is yet another challenge. Preservation may seem an established part of life in New York and other major cities, but to many people -- from right-wing ideologues to property owners outraged at having to get approval for minor changes to their buildings' facades -- it represents an unfair intrusion into individual rights. The anti-regulatory spirit of the Republican Congress is no friend to preservationists.
 Indeed, if most landmarks legislation were Federal rather than local it would probably already be a target of the Republican Contract With America, which has made it a goal to dilute Federal environmental legislation. Localities are not immune to the current anti-regulatory mood; the backlash can't bode well for the security of landmarks in many communities. Paradoxically, historic preservation is inherently conservative -- what is it, after all, but keeping the best of the old? -- yet because preservation interferes with the free market, it has traditionally been seen as part of the liberal agenda.

 
 
End of the Urban Frontier
 Perhaps because New York has always been a city more comfortable than many with governmental intervention in the free market, there seems little danger that the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission's mandate will be reduced, whatever the national mood. In fact, 30 years of the landmarks commission have brought about a sea change in New York. Until the commission was established, New York had always been a city that tore itself down and built itself up relentlessly, with little sense of a history; it was an urban frontier, the last century's equivalent of Silicon Valley, a place that thinks only of a future, and never of a past.
 The establishment of the landmarks commission was the moment when this ferocious and adolescent city first admitted that there were parts of itself worth handing down to future generations. It was a rite of maturation. If the creation of New York's skyscrapers marked the beginnings of the city's role as one of the world's great and powerful urban centers, the establishment of the landmarks commission marked its move into a kind of adulthood.
 No longer was New York content merely to make and then let circumstances destroy; like the child who stops wanting to tear down his sand castle at the end of a day at the beach, the city began after 1965 to ponder the notion of permanence. That is the real legacy of the 30 years of landmarks legislation: for better or for worse, New York began to think of itself not as a place that continually remakes itself anew, but as a mature city.

HEADLINE: BANK REGULATORS TAKING CLOSE LOOK AT LENDING RISKS

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 8

 BODY:
Increasingly concerned that American banks are taking more risks, top regulators are moving to rein in aggressive competition among banks seeking to make business and consumer loans.
The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, a Treasury Department agency that oversees the nation's 3,400 federally chartered banks, announced today that its most experienced credit analysts would form a committee to double-check whether the nation's large banks are taking excessive risks. The committee will work with the agency's bank examiners, who already conduct periodic reviews of banks' business practices. 
 Banks are charging many customers, particularly large companies, interest rates that barely exceed the banks' own borrowing costs. Banks are also offering more generous terms on loans, like longer periods for repayment. There is even some evidence that banks are offering more loans to companies and people with bad credit records, although regulators disagree on the extent to which this is a problem.
In recent months, Eugene A. Ludwig, the Comptroller of the Currency; Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, and other regulators have been giving speeches to bankers urging restraint. But the actions of the Comptroller's office, in creating a new credit-review committee, raises those relatively mild warnings to a new level.
If the new committee or the examiners find excessively risky loans, the examiners responsible for the bank will ask -- or, if necessary, order -- changes in bank lending policies, Mr. Ludwig said in a speech to bankers today.
He also warned in the speech about a trend among banks to issue credit cards, auto loans and second mortgages to borrowers with such bad credit histories that they previously had to turn, in some cases, to finance companies and other lenders catering to risky borrowers.
Separately, the Federal Reserve has urged its bank examiners to be thorough. "I am concerned that there has been some pursuit of market share at the risk of not getting properly compensated for the risk in the loan," John P. LaWare, the Federal Reserve governor who heads the central bank's committee on bank regulation, said in an interview on Friday.
Mr. LaWare said he was concerned about banks' offering low interest rates and generous loan terms but was less worried that banks might be making loans to customers with bad credit histories.
Bankers have also begun talking among themselves about their fears that intense competition for business is forcing them to take too many risks and causing some of them to lose sight of more cautious practices instituted after the collapse of the commercial real estate market in the late 1980's.
Banks and their regulators have been on a roller-coaster ride in recent years. Lax regulation was blamed for allowing much of the savings and loan debacle of the 1980's -- which wound up costing taxpayers $200 billion as the Government seized and shut insolvent institutions.
When banks and savings institutions then adopted much stricter standards during the economic downturn of the early 1990's, they were blamed for causing the credit crunch that left many small and medium-sized businesses struggling to find loans.
The regulators' new worries this year follow shifts in bank activities prompted by rising interest rates. Banks have sought to increase their commercial lending as profits on Government securities have dwindled. At the same time, the most creditworthy companies have been raising money by selling notes and bonds instead of seeking bank loans.
While regulators do not have the power to dictate specific standards of creditworthiness or profit margins on loans, they have considerable influence over bank policies.
Mounting evidence reinforces the regulators' concerns. A recent survey by the National Association of Home Builders found that 61 percent of its members were able to borrow money to build homes without lining up buyers in advance.
"Banks that wouldn't talk to us a couple years ago are calling us," David F. Seiders, the group's chief economist, said.
The latest indication of aggressive bank lending came late Friday afternoon, when the Federal Reserve announced that automobile loans rose at an annual rate of 10.5 percent in February, while outstanding balances on revolving consumer loans -- mainly credit cards -- shot up at an annual pace of 22 percent.
According to the text of Mr. Ludwig's speech, which was released in advance to the press, Mr. Ludwig told the chief executives of the nation's largest banks at a closed-door meeting today in Naples, Fla., that examiners would recommend specific measures to banks with particularly inadequate credit controls. He labeled these banks as "outliers" -- that is, banks that were the exceptions rather than the rule.
"In those cases, I hope we can depend on management to act voluntarily," the text said. "However, where we find outliers and where these outliers maintain low credit standards we will not hesitate to require appropriate changes in policy."
Until now, most of the evidence of aggressive lending practices has been anecdotal. But in his speech, Mr. Ludwig provided detailed information gathered over the last year by a team of analysts at his agency.
Their analyses show that banks first cut their profit margins for loans to companies with creditworthy AA ratings, then cut them for loans to less creditworthy companies with BB ratings. In each case, according to Mr. Ludwig's text, the reductions in profit margins were followed by banks' moves to allow more generous terms on other loan features.
Christopher L. Snyder, the president of the Loan Pricing Corporation, a Manhattan financial data company, said banks had become more generous on terms like the maturity of loans, offering five-year loans to companies that several years ago would have received only two-and-a-half year loans. Longer-term loans are more risky because more can go wrong at the borrowing company as each year passes.
Regulators generally say that financial institutions are controlling risks somewhat better now than they did in the late 1980's. Mr. Snyder said, for instance, that banks were now more cautious about lending large sums to a single borrower, choosing instead to resell parts of large loans to many other banks. "The thing that kills banks is big exposures to specific borrowers," he said.
Yet credit card issuers have become particularly aggressive, Mr. Ludwig said. "Some issuers are targeting consumers with less-than-stellar credit reports, because they know these customers are likely to carry larger balances," the text of his speech said. "But these banks should also remember the fact that when the economy weakens, these are often the first customers adversely affected."

HEADLINE: A New Weapon In an Old War -- A special report.;
Latest Tactic Against Abortion: Accusing Doctors of Malpractice

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN 

DATELINE: PHOENIX

 BODY:
Dr. Brian Finkel, whose practice consists mostly of performing abortions, sounds matter of fact when he talks about the bullet-proof window in his office, the bullet-proof vest and helmet he wears walking to his car, the guns he carries, the years of demonstrations outside his office and the threats he has received.
But he sounds thoroughly outraged -- and, in his own bluff way, hurt -- when he gets on to the subject of John Joseph Jakubczyk, general counsel to Arizona Right to Life, and the newest anti-abortion strategy: malpractice suits against the doctors who perform abortions. 
 "John Jakubczyk is a lawyer, an officer of the court, who has abused his professional power to harass me and intimidate my patients," Dr. Finkel said. "The suits he filed against me have dirtied my name. They have made me uninsurable for most insurance carriers. They made me pay legal fees to defend myself. I am committed to providing women with a service they need, but I have begun to wonder if it's worth it. You get hit about the head with a two-by-four long enough and you finally say, ouch, that hurts."
While abortion-malpractice lawsuits are a new phenomenon in much of the country, they are almost routine for Mr. Jakubczyk, who has filed nine of them in the last decade. Besides two against Dr. Finkel, Mr. Jakubczyk has also filed malpractice claims against the local Planned Parenthood affiliate, the A-Z Women's Center, a doctor at Abortion Services of Phoenix and a doctor at the Family Planning Institute.
So far, Mr. Jakubczyk has had little success. He lost the only case that went to trial. Most have been dismissed or withdrawn. And in one case against Dr. Finkel, the judge thought the charges so flimsy that he fined Mr. Jakubczyk for filing a frivolous suit, but the fine was later overturned by an appeals court.
"The problem is, even if they lose, they win," said Dr. Finkel, who has faced six abortion malpractice suits, some filed by other lawyers than Mr. Jakubczyk, which were all dismissed. "Whatever happens in court, they've had the press conference, and I've been damaged. I'm paying $25,000 a year for insurance now, and I'm not allowed to practice out of state, all because of this developing art form of legal misconduct."
In response to Dr. Finkel's complaint, the Arizona bar is investigating whether Mr. Jakubczyk's lawsuits violate ethical standards.
Like any other surgery, abortion carries its risks. And there is nothing new about an occasional malpractice suit when a doctor's bad care has caused severe injury or death.
What is new is the number of abortion malpractice suits now being filed -- and who is filing them. Increasingly, lawyers associated with anti-abortion groups, rather than malpractice specialists, are seeking out claims against doctors who do abortions.
According to J. Thomas Smith, a partner in a new law firm devoted to abortion malpractice, only 86 abortion-malpractice verdicts have been issued in the last 10 years. While no one knows how many current cases will end in verdicts, Life Dynamics Inc., an anti-abortion group in Denton, Tex., that is encouraging such suits, says it is involved in 80 cases.
 
Legal Advice
A Wide Variety Of Services
 Many new cases go beyond traditional malpractice claims. Life Dynamics, which attracted 125 people to Dallas for a two-day seminar last year on abortion malpractice, has provided much of the impetus and legal research for expanding the kinds of cases brought against doctors who do abortions.
For example, it offers research and expert witnesses on post-abortion trauma who say women often suffer the same kind of long-term psychological problems after abortions as soldiers do after wars, a concept that was examined and rejected by both former Surgeon General C. Everett Koop and the American Psychological Association.
Life Dynamics advises lawyers to consider charging doctors with battery if the woman's formal consent can be challenged.
In a mass mailing to doctors, Life Dynamics advised them to tell women of studies tying abortions to a higher risk of breast cancer and asked them to refer any patients who have had an abortion and are now diagnosed with breast cancer to Life Dynamics for "inclusion in a proposed class-action lawsuit."
Mark Crutcher, the president of Life Dynamics, said his group had more than 600 lawyers in its "Abmal" network, 40 percent of whom, he said, support abortion rights. The network offers lawyers ads soliciting clients ("Don't be a victim for the rest of your life"), expert witnesses, courses to teach women how to testify effectively, dossiers on abortion doctors and even a loan of the medical instruments used in abortion for lawyers to use in showing a jury what was done.
"There are more women than we ever dreamed of getting killed, raped, assaulted and severely injured," Mr. Crutcher said. "We've got over 2,500 examples."
Life Dynamics is not the only group encouraging these suits. In Pensacola, Fla., Mike Conroy says his organization, Legal Action for Women, gets about 10 calls a day on its toll-free line, 1-800-U-CAN-SUE, from women who say they have been injured by an abortion.
Mr. Conroy's group, like Life Dynamics, refers women to lawyers who will handle such cases, and both groups provide materials to hand out to women leaving abortion clinics.
Last year, several lawyers from different states established a firm, Swendsen, Amshoff, Donovan & Smith, to handle abortion malpractice work. Ted Amshoff, of Louisville, Ky., said the firm had 20 open cases, including 4 in which women died as a result of abortions.
 
Motives
Legal Harassment Or Honest Claims
 Many abortion doctors, clinics and women's advocacy groups see the new malpractice suits as a form of harassment motivated by anti-abortion ideology.
"These are bogus lawsuits," said Pamela Maraldo, president of Planned Parenthood Federation of America. "Where there is malpractice, where a bad doctor is injuring women -- of course we want that stopped. But in the current war-zone climate of bombings and shootings at abortion clinics, with the active campaigns to threaten doctors who perform abortions, I can't believe these lawsuits are aimed at protecting women. I believe they are part of an overall strategy to take away women's right to choose."
In a 1992 anti-abortion manual, Mr. Crutcher urged support for abortion malpractice suits "to protect women, but also to force abortionists out of business by driving up their insurance rates."
But the lawyers who handle abortion-malpractice cases -- Mr. Crutcher is not a lawyer -- say filing lawsuits to harass doctors would be an abuse of the courts. They say they are filing the cases not as anti-abortion advocates , but simply as advocates for injured women.
And, they say, they have a strong incentive to avoid frivolous claims, or harassment suits, since the cases are handled on a contingency basis, with the lawyers getting paid only if they win money for their clients.
"I bring cases only where there was a failure to meet the standard of care, and a woman was injured as a result," said Mr. Jakubczyk, who spoke at the Life Dynamics seminar. "For every woman for whom I file a claim, there are many more I tell that no matter how bad their abortion left them feeling, they don't have a case. People see me as John Jakubczyk, pro-life advocate. But in these cases, I'm just John Jakubczyk, representing a woman."
Ted Amshoff, a Louisville, Ky., a partner in Swendsen, Amshoff, who would not discuss his his personal views on abortion, calling them irrelevant to his legal work, said some of the women he represents had found other lawyers unwilling to handle their cases for fear that they would be seen as opposing abortion.
"I would think it would be a meeting ground for both sides to try to identify doctors who are not providing good care to women," said Mr. Amshoff, who has served as counsel to Kentucky Right to Life. "If this office alone has four death cases, and others where a hysterectomy and colostomy were needed, there's something wrong."
 
No Man's Land
Personal Dilemmas Over Abortion
 In the bitterly divisive landscape of abortion, there is a no man's land, occupied by women who oppose abortion on moral or religious grounds, but nonetheless choose it when they find themselves pregnant. Anti-abortion groups, doctors and abortion-rights groups alike say those women are most likely to sue.
The whole malpractice issue turns abortion politics on its head, sending women who have chosen abortions to lawyers who oppose them.
And malpractice litigation has created some strange alliances. Dr. Warren Hern of Boulder, Colo., has for years been a prime target of the anti-abortion movement, both because he is an outspoken advocate of abortion rights and because he performs late abortions.
But Dr. Hern, who wrote the most widely used textbook on abortion, supports many malpractice claims.
"There's a lot of bad medicine being practiced out there in the name of choice," said Dr. Hern, who estimates that lawyers interested in filing abortion-malpractice suits now account for about 5 percent of the sales of his textbook. "I testified in an Oregon case against a doctor who really did not do well by a patient. As a society, I think we've been in denial about the risks of abortion, both because of ideology, and because of economics. There are a lot of respectable doctors doing a lousy job. It's not a sin to have a complication, but it is a sin if you have not tried to prevent it. And it's a very serious sin if you abandon it."
Even with the best care, Dr. Hern and others said, 5 to 10 percent of first-trimester abortions are incomplete, leaving behind a few grams of tissue, or even the whole fetal sac. More rarely, abortion causes perforation of the uterus, hemorrhage or infection. Without proper follow-up care, such complications can cause serious injury.
Some anti-abortion lawyers are now filing claims based more on emotional than physical injuries. In one Phoenix case, for example, Mr. Jakubczyk charges that Dr. Joel Bettigole performed an abortion on a patient who did not want one.
"From her point of view, she went in, mixed up and confused, and didn't get any real counseling," Mr. Jakubczyk said. "From her point of view, she changed her mind, and withdrew her consent. She began to cry and scream, and they told her to shut up or she'd scare the other girls."
Dr. Bettigole would not discuss the case because it is in litigation.
"All I can say is that it never happened," he said. "I don't remember this particular patient, but I know it never happened because I have never treated any patient like that."
While that case and others like a pending Tennessee case against Planned Parenthood raise the question of valid consent, they are largely based on claims for emotional injuries and post-abortion trauma.
The Tennessee case involves a 15-year-old who became pregnant by the son of a Planned Parenthood official.
"The girl's mother had been shot and killed by her stepfather, and her grandmother got custody of her," said Mr. Smith, the Swendsen, Amshoff lawyer handling the case. "Her dad said come live with him or he would kill himself. She said she couldn't and he did kill himself. Four months later, she got pregnant, and the boy said, 'Have an abortion or I'll kill myself.' She wanted the baby, had already chosen a name. But she got pulled into having an abortion. Within a week she was admitted to the emergency room, crying uncontrollably. She's been in psychiatric care for more than a year now."
Planned Parenthood said it could not discuss the case while it was pending, but disputes the the lawsuit's account. And mental health experts say any girl who lost both parents so brutally might have emotional problems, abortion or no.
Mr. Smith said that, for him, abortion malpractice is both a legal specialty and a ministry.
"A great many women are injured by abortion, but in the past, very few have filed suit," Mr. Smith said. "So as a lawyer I see it as potentially a very lucrative specialty. And as a byproduct, it's a form of ministry. I've been working with this little 15-year old for a year, and it's a way of ministering to the second victims of abortion, the women who've been damaged."
The religious overlap was plain in a prayer request Mr. Smith made to Operation Prayer Storm, a group he describes as "a loose coalition of 25 ministries seeking revival and an end to abortion."
Last April, Operation Prayer Storm sent out to those on its mailing list requests to pray for students who want prayer at school graduations, to stop the Federal Government from mandating "religion free" workplaces and for Swendsen, Amshoff to "get revelation of ALL information they need in each abortion malpractice case."
Swendsen, Amshoff lawyers have appeared on the evangelist Pat Robertson's television show, the 700 Club, in a segment that also featured a Life Dynamics ad.
Just who provides the money for the abortion-malpractice campaign of Life Dynamics remains a mystery. Mr. Crutcher, 47, said his organization depended on donations. He would not identify any donors, but said some had gave more than $100,000. He said the group spent more than $1 million last year to support a staff of seven and a steady barrage of mass mailings.
Mr. Crutcher said Life Dynamics would not take a share of the court awards in any cases it helps with.
If the Phoenix experience is any guide, the new abortion-malpractice suits will take a toll, even on doctors who are not found to have committed malpractice and on their insurers.
"In the mid-80's, when John Jakubczyk was head of Right to Life here, we were one of the abortion clinics targeted to be closed down," said Constance Bennett, the former executive director of the Family Practice Institute. "It was like being under siege. Demonstrators hatcheted the roof, they Super Glue'd the doors shut, they broke in and chained themselves to the tables. We were burglarized. I got death threats, and my dog was drowned in the pool.
"In the middle of all that, John Jakubczyk filed his first abortion-malpractice case, against one of our doctors, for a perforated uterus. The doctor was investigated and exonerated, but the insurance company paid about $5,000 to settle."
By all accounts, that is the only money Mr. Jakubczyk has ever recovered in these cases.
