HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Rockies Open Their Wallet For Two Stars

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

DATELINE: HOMESTEAD, Fla., April 8

 BODY:
Jerry McMorris of the Colorado Rockies has served recently as the lead negotiator in the baseball owners' effort to place a serious drag on player salaries. Today McMorris's Rockies erupted in the most extravagant spending spree of their three-year history.
In the face of hefty free-agent unemployment and severe salary slashes for many players who have found jobs, the Rockies joined their high-revenue, big-spending brethren by committing $35.15 million worth of contracts to the free agents Larry Walker and Bill Swift. 
 Walker, who will be the Rockies' right fielder, agreed to a four-year deal worth $22 million, a $5.5 million average that exceeds his $4,025,000 salary with the low-revenue Montreal Expos last year. Swift, a 21-game winner for San Francisco in 1993 who skidded to an 8-7 record last season, accepted a three-year, $13.15 million package after completing a three-year, $7.95 million contract with the Giants.
Swift was one of a raft of pitchers who completed new agreements today. Most of the others did not avoid the salary-slashing spree.
Jim Abbott, who was not tendered a contract by the Yankees, signed with the Chicago White Sox for one year at $2 million, down from $2,775,000. He could earn an additional $750,000 if he starts 28 games and pitches 180 innings. Terry Mulholland, who had a $3.35 million salary with the Yankees, joined the Giants for $1.25 million. And Tom Browning, whose salary with Cincinnati last year was $3.5 million, signed with Kansas City for $300,000.
The Baltimore Orioles, scrambling to keep up with the moves of the high-spending Yankees and Toronto Blue Jays, added Kevin Brown to their pitching rotation for one year and $4,225,000, the same salary he had with the Texas Rangers last year. The Orioles also signed Doug Jones ($1.15 million, down from $3.25 million) and Jesse Orosco ($400,000, down from $700,000) for their relief corps.
The Rangers replaced Brown with Bob Tewksbury, to whom they gave $1.5 million, a $2 million drop from his $3.5 million with St. Louis. Orel Hershiser, a member of the Los Angeles Dodgers for his entire 12-year career, moved to the Cleveland Indians for $1.4 million. He had been working under a three-year, $10 million contract.
The Florida Marlins, the Rockies' expansion partners in 1993, spent some money, too, enrolling two pitchers for their rotation. John Burkett, Swift's teammate in San Francisco who had a $3.55 million salary, received a two-year deal for $6.9 million, and Bobby Witt accepted $1.8 million after having had a $3.25 million salary with Oakland.
The Marlins also signed a hometown player, the 40-year-old Andre Dawson, for his 20th and final season. Dawson, racked by knee ailments, will receive a farewell salary of $500,000. The past two years, Dawson had a $9.3 million contract with Boston.
Witt was a one-day resident here at the Players Association's camp for jobless men. Just as today's workout began, he arrived in street clothes and returned the $75-a-day expense money he had received Friday.
"Congratulations, we'll miss you," Judy Heeter, the union's licensing director, said.
Witt was not the first camper to get a job. Outfielder Mike Devereaux was on his way out of the Homestead Stadium parking lot after the initial workout Friday when he learned he would be joining the Chicago White Sox for $800,000 (down from last year's $3,375,000 with Baltimore).
After today's workout, Dave Stewart announced that he, too, was leaving camp. He had agreed to return to the Oakland Athletics, for whom he won 20 or more games for four successive seasons, for a $1 million salary, a pay cut of $3.25 million from what he earned with Toronto last season.
Elsewhere in camp, the voices of unemployment spoke. They were filled with hope, uncertainty, anxiety.
Howard Johnson sat in the clubhouse, looked around the room and said: "If you walked around the room, almost to a man, guys would say they'd rather not be here. It's not the greatest thing in the world to be here."
Johnson talked about mild interest from Japan that didn't intrigue him and a more promising recent contact with a major league club.
"The thing I have to keep dealing in my mind with is we worked hard all winter to get ready for a season we didn't know would open," he said. "All the anxiety of the strike, then it's over and you come here and you have three weeks and there's a realistic possibility nothing will happen. Now what do you do? In my heart, I'm not ready to quit."
Johnson talked of the signings back-up that created "an avalanche of players trying to hook on with the right team."
"In the back of everybody's mind," he added, "in three weeks when camps break, what's going to happen? Guys will go into forced retirement."

Cardinals Acquire Cooper
 ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 8 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals acquired the All-Star third baseman Scott Cooper from the Boston Red Sox today, making a trade that had been rumored for months.
Boston got outfielder Mark Whiten and pitcher Rheal Cormier in the deal, while St. Louis also got reliever Cory Bailey.
Cooper, 27, who grew up a Cardinal fan and still lives in a St. Louis suburb, hit .282 with 13 homers and 53 runs batted in last season. His acquisition means Todd Zeile will move to first base.
Whiten, 28, hit .293 with 14 homers and 53 r.b.i. Cormier, 27, was 3-2. Boston will try Terry Shumpert, Luis Alicea and Tim Naehring at third.

HEADLINE: County's Congress Members Speak Out

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
FOR members of both parties, the first 100 days of the 104th Congress have spelled change -- and the experiences of the four United States Representatives from Westchester are no exception. At the Capitol here last week, the veteran Republican member of the county's contingent reported that he was finally realizing a long-cherished dream after 22 years. Two incumbent Democrats said they had discovered, embarrassingly at times, what it felt like to be on the minority side of the aisle. And a Republican newcomer to Congress observed that she could not have picked a better time to come to this city.
For Benjamin Gilman, a Republican who has served the 20th Congressional District since 1972, last November's Republican sweep meant that he could finally ascend to the chairmanship of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, a post he had coveted for many years as a member of the minority party. A middle-of-the road Republican, Mr. Gilman said the last three months in Congress had given him "the opportunity to shape policy rather than just react." 
 Nita Lowey -- a Democrat from the 18th District who held on to her appointment from the last session to the powerful House Appropriations Committee -- said the last 100 days have meant watching in frustration as student loan plans, safe and drug-free school programs, summer job bills and heating assistance for the elderly "got zeroed out" by the Republicans "with the flick of a finger." This session of Congress, the third-term legislator said, "hasn't been a happy time."
Eliot L. Engel, a Democrat from the 17th District who is serving his fourth term in Congress, said this time around has been marked by several difficult moments -- like the time he mistakenly entered the majority staff office of the House Committee on Economic and Educational Opportunities only to realize there wasn't a familiar face in the crowd. "I was shell shocked the first few weeks," Mr. Engel recalled. "It has taken time to adjust to the changes."
Sue Kelly, the Republican who is serving her first term as a representative from the 19th Congressional District, used terms like "gee whiz" and "neat" to describe the current session of Congress and said she was especially pleased with the Republicans' progress on welfare reform. "If I had to pick a Congress to be in," she said, "this is the one." Mrs. Kelly was elected to the post long held by the Republican Hamilton Fish Jr., who retired at the end of the last term.
In a period marked by a sea change in politics and programs, the four legislators, like the current Congress, said they were holding fast to their ideals and to their independence and would not be swept along by party sentiment alone.
The two Republicans said that even though they espoused their party's major principles, they also would pursue their own agendas. And although the two Democrats were frustrated and angry at the Republican sweep -- as were others in their party -- each said they were confident that a way could be found to realize at least part of their goals.
For Mr. Gilman, who has gained a reputation as a consensus builder, this session -- his 12th in Congress -- has meant an opportunity to put his moderate brand of Republicanism to work at a time when the more conservative elements of the party appear to dominate. A self-styled party independent, the 72-year-old legislator said he governs "under no one's thumb, including that of Newt Gingrich -- far from it."
He added, "Independence has been a hallmark of my career, and will continue to be."
His greatest achievement to date in this session, he said, is passage in the House of the National Security Revitalization Act, which calls for, among other things, a greater role for Congress in foreign policy. Mr. Gilman has criticized President Clinton for committing troops to overseas missions without fully consulting Congress. The bill has yet to go before the Senate.
Mr. Gilman -- who represents all of Rockland County and parts of Orange, Sullivan and Westchester Counties, including Greenburgh and part of Yonkers -- supported welfare reform and opposed term limits, which he said "put a straightjacket on voters."
He added: "It's nice after more than 40 years to know you have the votes on key issues. That has been a major change."
For the 46-year-old Mr. Engel, change has meant "groping around for a new role" in recent months, now that the Democrats are out of power for the first time in the legislator's career both here and in the State Assembly in Albany.
These days, Mr. Engel concedes that he has a new and harder edge to his personality. He described himself as "on a crusade" and said he has "squared his shoulders" for the continued fight with Republicans.
"The G.O.P. is driven by right-wing zealots who want to undo 60 years of programs that protect American workers and children," said Mr. Engel, whose district covers areas of the Bronx and lower Westchester, including part of Pelham, Mount Vernon, New Rochelle and Yonkers. "They want to take us back to the days before the New Deal."
His vocabulary, too, is more peppered this session, with "mean spirited" as a frequently used term to describe the opposition.For example, he says, "Theirs is mean-spirited legislation."
"Welfare reform is mean spirited."
"They call it a Contract With America, but I call it a contract on America."
Mr. Engel's tougher stance has paid off at times, despite Republican opposition. He was among a group of Democratic legislators who averted a plan to cut more than $11 million in Federal funds from New York City's nutrition program for the elderly.
Representative Engel serves on the House Committee on Economic and Educational Opportunities and the Committee on International Relations. He is also a member of the Congressional Human Rights Caucus, the Democratic Study Group on Health and the Long Island Sound Caucus. He is co-chairman of the Albanian Issues Caucus and is an executive board member of the Congressional Ad Hoc Committee on Irish Affairs.
Mrs. Lowey, also irritated by the Republican agenda, said she felt heartsick watching some programs that she had supported go down. But she also said, "The idea is to get the job done, and if you can't do it one way, you do it another."
One way was to garner the news spotlight early in the session for continued financial support of public broadcasting. Mrs. Lowey held up hand puppets of Bert and Ernie, two "Sesame Street" characters, during a House Appropriations subcommittee hearing in January and found herself on the front pages of newspapers across the country hammering home the message to Congress that public broadcasting benefited poor children as well as middle- and upper-class youngsters. Mr. Gingrich, the House Speaker, has said public broadcasting caters to an elite audience.
The 57-year-old Mrs. Lowey represents parts of the Bronx and Queens, Eastchester, Harrison, Mamaroneck, part of Pelham, Rye Town, Rye City, Scarsdale, part of Mount Vernon, part of New Rochelle, part of White Plains and part of Yonkers.
She is co-chairwoman of the bipartisan Congressional Women's Caucus and said she was working to preserve a woman's right to choose an abortion and favors programs that promote women's health and educational equity.
As a member of the House Appropriations Committee, which finances health, labor and education programs, Mrs. Lowey supports spending tax dollars for breast cancer and other types of biomedical research, education programs like student loans and the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.
Confident that voters will soon tire of Republican cutbacks, Mrs. Lowey said that in the meantime she will focus on bipartisan efforts to effect change. "Everything here is based on relationships," she said. "We can still get things done."
Representative Kelly's agenda also includes women's issues, but from her basement offices at the Capitol last week, she described a sharply different agenda from Mrs. Lowey's.
Mrs. Kelly said a revised welfare bill was the surest way to help poor women move up economically. "Instead of a handout," she said, "women need a hand up."
Women on welfare also need jobs so they can set an example for their children to follow and finally break the generation-to-generation cycle of dependency on Government programs, she said.
But while she followed the Republican agenda on most issues, she said she had "no trouble being my own woman," adding that she ran in the election without the official support of the local Republican leadership.
She said that during the current session of Congress she had parted ways with many fellow Republicans on the issue of nutrition programs. She joined Democrats in her support of nutrition programs for the elderly, which recently became part of the Older Americans Act.
Mrs. Kelly -- who represents Bedford, Cortlandt, Lewisboro, Mount Kisco, Mount Pleasant, New Castle, North Castle, North Salem, Ossining, Peekskill, Pound Ridge, Somers, Yorktown, part of White Plains, Putnam County and part of Dutchess County -- has been appointed to the Transportation and Infrastructure, Small Business, and Banking and Financial Services Committees.

HEADLINE: Secret Guatemalan Military Unit, Linked to C.I.A., Dies and Is Born Again

 BODY:
The following article is based on reporting by Clifford Krauss in Guatemala City and Tim Weiner in Washington and was written by Mr. Weiner.
The enormous building under construction on Seventh Avenue in downtown Guatemala City is supposed to be an icon of reform -- the headquarters of a new civilian intelligence service. 
 Officially, that new service will replace the disbanded, despotic unit known as "the Archivo," whose ranks have included the Guatemalan colonel and C.I.A. agent linked to the 1990 slaying of an American citizen.
But the Archivo -- which for years spied on and sometimes murdered Guatemalans -- is still in business, though under a different name, foreign diplomats and a former Guatemalan Defense Minister say. And death-squad killings, torture and the arbitrary detention of peasants, students, academic figures and political leaders are still going on Guatemala, the United Nations mission there reported in March.
The half-completed building is a freeze-frame image of where things stand today within Guatemala's intelligence services -- somewhere between brutal repression and unrealized reform.
The Clinton Administration suspended most of the covert aid flowing from the Central Intelligence Agency to the Guatemalan military last week, preserving only a counternarcotics program. But the deep and tangled connections between the C.I.A. and its "assets" in Guatemala continue to enhance the military's dominance as civilians try to secure control of the nation's politics.
The question of who paid for the building seems to be a sensitive one. A construction company executive working on the project, Jesus Garcia, said it would be a Defense Ministry office. Asked where the money came from, he laughed nervously. Not the Defense Ministry, he said, but "another agency that I can't identify, exactly." A senior State Department official involved in Guatemala policy, asked if any American money went toward construction of the building, replied: "I don't think I can get into that. There shouldn't be."
The State Department official said the question could only be answered by the Clinton Administration's sweeping investigation of C.I.A. involvement in Guatemala -- an elaborate search for facts that has proved so difficult that one senior White House official called it "a total nightmare."
The C.I.A.'s direct financial support for Guatemala's military intelligence services totaled roughly $30 million during the Reagan, Bush and Clinton Administrations, according to United States intelligence officials. As the cold war wound down and Central America ceased to be a battlefield between the superpowers, it fell from a peak of about $4.5 million in 1989 to about $1 million this year.
The Administration is now assessing what the agency received in return for its money and what role the C.I.A. should play in Guatemala's future.
 
Partnership
The C.I.A.'s Goal: Trade and Gather
 The C.I.A. and its defenders in Congress and the State Department say the agency's Guatemala station worked hard to instill professionalism and discipline in hundreds of intelligence officers in the Central American nation, which has the worst human rights record in the region. But critics say the agency's efforts were offset by its abundant support for a military that was essentially waging war against civilians.
The C.I.A.'s role in Guatemala was also to supply information for policymakers in Washington. That effort is now being viewed in a harsh light.
Faced with appeals in 1990 and 1991 to find the officers who ordered the killing of Michael DeVine, the American innkeeper murdered in Guatemala, the C.I.A. could not provide the information that its own agent, Col. Julio Roberto Alpirez, was implicated in the killing.
In 1992, the C.I.A. turned to its sources inside the Guatemalan military for information on human rights problems. That reliance helped produce an agency report that Senator William S. Cohen, a Maine Republican and a member of the Senate intelligence committee, described last week as "deliberately designed to mislead" the United States Congress.
The same critics in Congress and the State Department who say the C.I.A has undermined human rights policy on Guatemala say the agency did good work when its focus shifted from the war on Communism to the war on drugs in the early 1990's.
An estimated 70 tons a year of Colombian cocaine flow through Guatemala en route to the United States. Under the agency's guidance, the Guatemalan military has infiltrated cocaine-trafficking organizations and stopped some big shipments, State Department officials say.
"The only reason to have a C.I.A. station down there is because of the war on drugs," said Thomas F. Stroock, the Ambassador to Guatemala from 1989 to 1992. "But if you're going to interdict drugs, you have to use the agency involved in the country. Unfortunately, in Guatemala, that's the army.
"At the same time you're beating these people over the head because of human rights, you're using them to stop drugs," he said. "It's a dilemma."
The Guatemalan military has the power to stop United States drug operations any time it wishes. At least 10 current and former Guatemalan military officers have been identified by the United States Drug Enforcement Administration and other agencies as suspects in cocaine trafficking. And "officers strongly suspected of trafficking in narcotics rarely face criminal prosecution," according to a recent State Department report.
In one recent example, a lieutenant colonel in the Guatemalan Army, Carlos Ochoa Ruiz, was indicted in Florida on charges of shipping more than 1,000 pounds of Colombian cocaine through Guatemala. In March 1994, the highest-ranking justice in Guatemala, Epaminondas Gonzalez Dubon, president of the Constitutional Court, ruled in favor of Colonel Ochoa's extradition to the United States. A few days later, four men assassinated the justice.
 
Personnel
The Hard-Liners And Their Heirs
 The public revelations about the C.I.A.'s relationships with senior Guatemalan military officers have deepened tensions between two factions in the army, the hard-liners and the modernizers.
Diplomats and analysts say both groups have poor human rights records and share the goal of maintaining strict order through repression to preserve military control. Both have long ties to the C.I.A.
But while some members of the old guard are involved in traditional economic crimes like car theft, smuggling timber and working in concert with drug smugglers, the modernizers tend to steer clear of those areas. "The hard-liners are out of Godfather I, and the modernizers would fit in Godfather III," said a South American diplomat, speaking on condition of anonymity. "They prefer clean businesses like telecommunications, banks and property."
The old guard fervently opposes any meaningful form of civilian rule. Although Guatemala has had a civilian President since 1986, the army and military intelligence services still wield power in every domain of public life.
The modernizers also want to protect the military's immense power but realize that it needs to adapt to the changing political mood in Central America and to the end of the cold war. In the late 1980's, they grasped that international criticism of the army's human rights violations -- it has killed some 110,000 Guatemalans during the last three decades -- required at least the appearance of civilian leadership and skilled use of the language of democracy.
The idea was that the people need a little political breathing space, although they should be arrested if they got out of line. "Let the trade unions organize, let students demonstrate and repress them only selectively," is how Jennifer Schirmer, an American anthropologist, sums up their philosophy. Ms. Schirmer has interviewed dozens of officers for a forthcoming book on the Guatemalan military.
A turning point for the modernizers came in the late 1980's, in part from conversations that Hector Gramajo, then the Defense Minister, said he had with the C.I.A.'s station chief. The station chief from 1988 to 1991 was a former National Security Council staffer with a geopolitical flair. The former station chief still serves as a C.I.A. officer but is now based at the agency's headquarters.
General Gramajo, now retired from the Army said he advised the station chief to win over the hard-liners with money and military equipment.
The station chief, while still supporting the modernizers, took his advice. After December 1990, when the United States angrily cut off overt military assistance to Guatemala because of the military's stonewalling in the DeVine case, the C.I.A. continued to send covert aid, disbursing an estimated $10 million before that support was suspended last week.
Based partly on information supplied by the station chief, the policy of the United States evolved to support the modernizers in the military, analysts say. "The C.I.A. wants information from everybody, but when it tries to promote officers it seeks to promote the modernizers," said Gabriel Aguilera Peralta, a political scientist who heads International Relations and Security Studies at the Latin American Faculty of Social Sciences, a Guatemala City think tank. An Administration official who monitors Guatemala agreed with Mr. Aguilera's analysis.
The modernizers are the reason why "the Archivo doesn't exist by that name, but it continues to exist," Mr. Aguilera said. "The modernizers in the army want to legalize it and institutionalize it."
 
Reshaping
Disbanded Agency Makes a Comeback
 In 1993, President Ramiro de Leon Carpio announced that he was abolishing the Archivo, which kept files on thousands of Guatemalans, tapped their telephones, read their mail and occasionally committed political assassinations.
"Officially, the Archivo doesn't exist," said General Gramajo, now a conservative presidential candidate. "But it does exist -- until a new organization replaces it."
He added that the new, supposedly civilian intelligence organization, whose creation still has not been approved by the Guatemalan congress, already "has too much military orthodoxy" imbedded in it.
President de Leon Carpio, who was once the Government's human rights ombudsman, has recently become more supportive of the military -- particularly since the assassination of his cousin, a former presidential candidate.
Last week he denied what the C.I.A. has tacitly affirmed -- that Colonel Alpirez was in the agency's pay and that the C.I.A.'s Guatemala station penetrated the highest ranks of the military. He rejects repeated reports by human rights groups that clandestine jails still hold political prisoners in Guatemala.
But the United Nations mission in Guatemala reports that between Nov. 21, 1994, and Feb. 21, it received reports of 22 political assassinations, 10 attempted assassinations and 68 death threats against priests, labor leaders, teachers, public prosecutors and human rights campaigners.
Meanwhile, hundreds of workers toiled on the enormous building one block south of the old Archivo headquarters, where death-squad vans have come and gone through military and civilian governments for the last two decades.

A student collected money for a protest march, wearing a hood over his face to hide his identity from security agents. (Rachel Cobb for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Burmese Military Steps Up Drive Against Major Drug Trafficker

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: CHIENGMAI, Thailand, April 9

 BODY:
Khun Sa, the Asian drug baron who is responsible for much of the heroin on the streets of the United States, is facing a wave of attacks by the Burmese Army intended to destroy his rebel army.
The military Government of Myanmar, the country formerly known as Burma, has massed thousands of soldiers along the vast stretches of northeastern Myanmar controlled by Khun Sa and his well-armed 20,000-man army. 
 The Burmese Army has confirmed that dozens of its soldiers have been killed and hundreds wounded in fighting in the last few weeks. Diplomats say Khun Sa's forces are reported to have suffered a similar number of casualties.
Khun Sa clearly understands that the threat he faces this year is far more serious than any before, and he has staged a series of spectacular attacks intended to persuade the Government to call off its forces. On March 20 his army attacked the Burmese border town of Tachileck, destroying military compounds, killing several soldiers and forcing more than 1,000 people to flee.
Khun Sa -- who is half Chinese and half Shan, a Burmese ethnic minority -- says he is fighting for the independence of the Shan people.
He says he does not produce heroin but only taxes drug traffickers who cross through his area of control. But law enforcement officials around the world say he is above all a heroin dealer, whose narcotics empire is one of the world's largest.
Myanmar is the world's largest producer of opium, and Khun Sa is accused of refining and smuggling huge amounts of the drug to the United States, Western Europe and Asia. He has been indicted in the United States on narcotics charges.
The Burmese military Government once faced a dozen ethnic insurgencies along its borders. But in the last three years it has negotiated peace settlements with most of its separatist opponents and crushed others. In February it overran the headquarters of another large ethnic insurgency, the Karen, forcing thousands into Thailand.
With success against the Karen and recent arms shipments from China, their principal ally, the Burmese military leaders set their sights on Khun Sa. The attack on his forces should be welcome news for the United States, which has long sought the destruction of a narcotics empire responsible for much of the heroin smuggled there.
At the same time, Washington does not want to be seen as an ally of the Burmese military leaders, who formally took power after crushing a nascent democracy movement in 1988. The leader of the democracy movement and the winner of the 1991 Nobel Peace Prize, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, is in her sixth year under house arrest in Yangon, the Burmese capital, once known as Rangoon. Diplomats there have suggested that the decision to attack Khun Sa and his rebel army is an effort to persuade the United States and other nations to stop treating Myanmar as a pariah state.
"We are sacrificing a lot of blood and sweat to continue the campaign against Khun Sa," said Lieut. Col. Kyaw Thein, a spokesman for the military Government. "We would like to expect some positive reaction, not only from the United States but from all around the world."
But American officials are not impressed, because the Burmese military turns a blind eye to opium growing by other ethnic groups, most notably the Wa, who signed a peace treaty with the Government in 1989.
Thailand, which long provided sanctuary to Khun Sa and his forces, has has cut off much of the cooperation this year in hopes of closer economic ties to Myanmar.

HEADLINE: Treasury to Auction Only Bills

 BODY:
The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.
By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.66 percent and a six-month bill was 5.81 percent.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL TECHNOLOGY;
Between a Hacker And a Hard Place

BYLINE: By PETER H. LEWIS 

 BODY:
Matt Blaze, a researcher for the AT&T Corporation, had never thought of himself as an arms exporter. But just before he was to fly to Europe recently on business, Federal Customs agents at Kennedy International Airport in New York detained him for more than an hour while they puzzled over the "munitions" device in his carry-on bag.
When the head Customs official was summoned to the room where he was being questioned, Mr. Blaze realized the Orwellian scope of the Federal export laws governing technology that safeguards international business communications. 
 "Are you the guy who wants to export the fancy gun?" the Customs man asked, peering at Mr. Blaze's papers.
"It's not a gun, it's a telephone," Mr. Blaze said. The small box connected to a handset was in fact a scrambling device to thwart hackers, corporate spies and even foreign governments from eavesdropping on his calls back to the United States. But because the device can also thwart American law-enforcement, military and national security agents from eavesdropping on terrorists, drug dealers or foreign agents, the Federal Government defines it as "munitions" -- right up there with rockets, nuclear warheads and fancy guns.
While Mr. Blaze produced the required license at the airport, the Customs official was clearly unfamiliar with this twist in United States export law. "Why do you need a license to export a telephone?" he asked.
"Good question," Mr. Blaze recalls thinking.
Good question, indeed, in the view of a growing number of American companies that want the equivalent of seat belts and air bags as they hit the global information highway in search of new markets and international partners.
Alarmed by accounts of hackers making off with credit card numbers and computer passwords and of saboteurs intercepting trade secrets, American businesses are being advised -- often by the Government itself -- to encode their sensitive electronic information with data-encryption hardware or software. Such equipment scrambles phone calls and electronic mail into gibberish that remains unintelligible to anyone not holding the key to the code.
But at the same time, the Government prohibits businesses from providing their overseas customers or partners with the most advanced American-made cryptographic tools needed to safeguard their communications. It fears that the American technology could be used to break American laws, though few examples of such cases involving encryption have been made public.
There's just one problem: The export policy is honored mainly in the breach. Each day, copies of highly sophisticated cryptographic programs are transmitted out of the United States over computer networks, carried out unseen in laptop computers or secure telephones, or simply sold to foreign citizens in America's software and computer stores. The same technology is already in wide use overseas, available to anyone connected to the Internet global web of computers.
The Software Publishers Association, a trade group in Washington, said it had found more than 150 foreign encryption products equivalent to those that American companies were barred from exporting.
Some Federal officials say the Government may relax the export-control policies in coming weeks, in part to make it easier for traveling executives like Mr. Blaze to take security devices on business trips. But for now, critics say the export restrictions have businesses caught between hackers and a hard place.
"They impede American businesses from having secure global communications," said Bill Moroney, president of the Electronic Messaging Association, a trade group in Washington. "Faced with this dilemma, companies can do it and violate U.S. laws somehow, or not do it and suffer."
The Federal Government says it has ample reason to worry about the consequences of letting American encryption technology into the hands of criminals or hostile governments, but can't discuss its concerns.
"It is a source of deep frustration that a lot of issues around our policies on encryption are classified," said Tom Kalil, a director of the White House's National Economic Council. "We can't talk about them other than to say, 'Well, if you knew what I knew, you might think differently.' "
The argument finds limited sympathy in the corporate world.
"I empathize tremendously with the Government's fear of not being able to crack codes, but what it really comes down to is that export controls don't stop crooks from exporting encryption," Mr. Moroney said. "They only stop United States software companies from having a global market."
The Government is also said to be considering backing down from a two-year standoff with American industry over the so-called Clipper technology. Clipper, designed by the Government, is a family of powerful encryption products to which the Government holds the code keys in escrow in case law-enforcement officials want to conduct court-authorized wire taps.
The Government has allowed export of Clipper-based systems, but American companies and their foreign clients have been loath to use a system to which the F.B.I. or the National Security Agency could obtain a back-door pass key.
The Government is now said to be leaning toward endorsing a commercially developed cryptography system in which a trusted third party -- not the Government -- would hold a spare copy of the code keys. These keys could be made available to law-enforcement officials bearing a warrant. Such a system would still be unpalatable to many privacy advocates, who argue that they have a right to private communications beyond the ear of Uncle Sam.
American companies that want to build their own forms of strong encryption into their products include I.B.M., Digital Equipment, Microsoft, Sun Microsystems, Apple Computer, Lotus Development, Novell and nearly every other company making hardware or software for the so-called information highway. They say that the Government's export restrictions cost them hundreds of millions of dollars in lost sales and drain millions more in extra development and administrative fees. They also say the United States risks losing its historic leadership role in data security technologies.
"We have had a lot of problems selling overseas because consumers in major enterprises are very well aware of network security issues now," said Ray Ozzie, president of Iris Associates of Cambridge, Mass., and developer of a popular program called Lotus Notes. "They know that the product we sell them abroad has less information security than the one we sell in this country."
The Commerce Department is currently surveying American software and computer companies to determine what economic harm, if any, has been sustained by companies as a result of the export restrictions. Results of the survey are expected to be released in July.
For a Federal license to use the most advanced American encryption technology, businesses must often struggle through endless red tape -- and even then run the risk of rejection. That puts them in a quandary, said the director of network security for a multibillion-dollar corporation based in the Middle West. Like most executives interviewed for this article, he spoke on the condition that neither he nor his company be identified.
"We end up importing foreign encryption tools so that we can communicate with our partners overseas," he said. "Or, we get around the policy with a wink and a nod."
Since breaking the law is so easy and so commonplace, it might seem an option. But those choosing that route proceed at their peril. In San Jose, Calif., a Federal grand jury has been hearing testimony for more than a year to determine whether Philip Zimmermann, a cryptographic software developer, should be prosecuted for export violations.
At an informal hearing at a recent computer conference near San Francisco, six members of a Government task force listened as a procession of petitioners -- including several corporate security managers, representatives of high-tech companies and privacy advocates -- appealed for quick relief from what they described as impractical, ineffective and harmful restrictions.
The result of the Government policy "is that computers on networks are less secure than they should be," said John Gilmore, an executive with Cygnus Support, a software support company in Mountain View, Calif. "Unless the policy is changed, we will continue to see plenty of large- and small-scale intrusions like Kevin Mitnick's."
Mr. Mitnick, who was arrested in January after a two-year Federal manhunt, is accused of breaking into many private computers and taking information that would have been useless to him had it been encrypted.
Mr. Mitnick was unusual, law-enforcement agents and security experts acknowledged, because he apparently did not seek to profit from his collected data. In an era when financial data and intellectual property are often more valuable than physical property, computer networks are an attractive target.
"I know for a fact that hackers are paid to get information," said James Bidzos, president of RSA Data Security of Redwood City, Calif., whose company's technologies are at the core of many popular encryption systems. "People have made offers to us to break into other people's systems, or they want to retain us to decrypt information they got from someone else's computers."
Mr. Ozzie of Iris Associates said he agreed that current policies do not work. "But that doesn't mean they have no basis in logic," he said. "The fact is, law enforcement and national security interests rely on access to unencrypted data. What are they going to do?"
As for Mr. Blaze, he said his days as an arms exporter were over, at least until the laws change.
"My conclusion from all this is that it just isn't possible for an individual traveler to follow all the rules," he said. "Even having gone through the process now, I still have no idea how to obtain, let alone file, the proper forms, even for a device that's already been determined to be exportable."
"The next time," he added, "I'm just not going to take it with me."

GRAPHIC: Photos: U.S. law restricts the export of encryption software that can be used to protect the privacy of computer communications. But the law is hard to enforce, because there are so many ways to carry the software out of the country, including packaged software like Viacrypt PGP; a portable computer; a CD-ROM or floppy disks, or even a mailing label, below, bearing the computer code for a powerful encryption program. (Photographs by Naum Kazhdan/The New York Times)
 
Chart: "An Alternative to Clipper Chips"
 Corporations, individuals and the Government have been trying to agree on standards acceptable to everyone for protecting data and telephone transmissions. The Government has proposed a system based on "key escrow" technology - known as Clipper j- but advocates of privacy have resisted its adoption, saying it potentially gives the Government to much ability to monitor private communications. Now a system called commercial key escrow, where decoder keys are kept on file by a trusted third party, may soon be proposed to address both the concerns of privacy advocates and teh Government's interest in monitoring transmissions for reasons of national security.
 
THE CLIPPER SYSTEM
 
Microchips, called Clipper chips, are installed in computers and telephones.
 
A key that can break the code of each chip is then created and split in two. Each half, which is created and split in two. Each half, which is useless by itself, is deposited with two government agencies.
 
When someone wants to send a message or make a call, the chip encodes and locks the message and ecnloses a copy of the chip's serial number.
 
Law enforcement officials armed wiht a warrant can record the message and use a "family key" that decodes the serial number of the chip that made the transmission, but not the message itself.
 
The agents provide the custodial agencies with the serial number of the chip so that both parts of the decoder key can be retrieved and used to decode the transmission.
 
COMMERCIAL KEY ESCROW
 
The system uses software instead fo microchips or other hardware to encode messages.
 
A "data recovery center," either part of a company whose employees need to send coded messages or an outside firm, creates a public and a private encryption key for each person using the service. The public key is given to the user, while the private key remains on file with the center.
 
When sending a message, the public key encrypts the transmission and the indentity of the sender. The name of the data recovery center is sent along with the message, but unencrypted.
 
Law enforcement officials with warrantgs can record messages and then use the I.D. of the data recovery center contained in the transmission to obtain the private key to decode the message.
 
Some privacy advocates argue this system gives the Government the oversight it wants, but keeps the tools for decoding transmissions in the hands of private individuals and corporations. Others say any key-escrow system is unacceptable.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk

HEADLINE: Rethinking Welfare: Work Requirements -- A special report.;
Jobs Program Participants: Still Poor and in Need of Aid

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER 

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO

 BODY:
Araceli Cobarrubias, a 23-year-old single mother of three with a ninth-grade education, still struggles with English. But in the past three weeks, while politicians in Washington have been making speeches about people like her, who are on public assistance, she has been using a vocabulary that would gladden the hardest-line anti-welfare crusader.
"I have to market myself," said Ms. Cobarrubias, whose only job was as a part-time saleswoman in a clothing store nine years ago. "I don't want my kids to be on welfare." 
 She considers herself lucky to be learning how to get off welfare in a San Diego jobs program that aims to usher more welfare recipients into the workplace, so their dependence on public money can be reduced if not eliminated altogether. "I would like receptionist," she said. "I can use phones."
While the program has been lauded by welfare policy experts for doing more than many other welfare-to-work programs, San Diego's success over the past seven and a half years has nonetheless been modest. Because of budget limitations and exemptions for mothers who are disabled or have children younger than 3, only a small minority of welfare recipients receive the special job assistance.
While most of those who pass through the program eventually find work, their paychecks remain extremely small -- the average wage is $5.75 an hour, without benefits -- and many jobs are part time, or temporary. Most of the workers scrape by and are able to insure health care for their children only by remaining on public assistance.
But now Republicans in Washington want to dramatically increase the number of people leaving welfare for work.
The welfare bill that has passed the House, and now goes to the Senate, sets out ambitious new targets in which states must push half of all single-parent recipients into work or training directly related to a job over the next eight years, or lose up to 5 percent of their Federal money. But the bill offers no new money for job training or child care.
Here in San Diego, the people who will be expected to carry out any new policy, from top welfare officials to front-line social workers to the welfare recipients themselves, all say that the system is badly broken. But they are also unanimous in describing the Republican goals as unrealistic.
"Get real," said Hawley Ridenour, a welfare official who directs the San Diego jobs program, part of California's Greater Avenues to Independence, or GAIN. "In today's economy, we're not going to be able to close 50 percent of the cases. A woman with two kids and an 11th-grade education isn't going to get a $12-an-hour job. She's going to get a $4.50-an-hour job. And guess what: She's still poor, and she's still on welfare."
Karol D. Lightner, a GAIN social worker, has 90 clients, mostly single mothers, white, black and Hispanic, with few job skills, many without high school diplomas, all of whom she has to try to get into the work force. Some cannot read or write or speak English. Among them are recovering drug addicts, alcoholics and victims of domestic abuse.
"I tell them, 'You can do it, don't let the system defeat you,' " Ms. Lightner said. " 'Get off welfare. This is no life for you. This is no life for your kids.' "
Between appointments with clients at her downtown San Diego office the other day, she worried aloud: "If they cut child-care funding, what am I going to do with these people? I can't help them get jobs. The first time they get a kid with chicken pox -- bam! They're home for two weeks, and they're out."
Many recipients, she noted, never even show up for the program and are unlikely to hold jobs for long. "There is so much chaos in their lives," Ms. Lightner said. "I had a client tell me, 'Karol, I can't make it to training, I'm being evicted.' Another woman had gang members threatening her family. She had to be home to protect her kids."
Some people do not have the resources even to try, Ms. Lightner said. "There is so much passivity in the welfare system," she said. And, she added, there are some who refuse to join the program, even though they risk losing benefits. Each month, 145 people have their checks reduced for failing to participate.
Because of the exemptions, only 38,000 of the county's 67,000 welfare recipients are eligible for the jobs program. The program gives priority to people who have been on welfare the longest and to volunteers. But the $22 million budgeted is only enough to offer the special assistance to 11,000 recipients at one time, who usually must stay in the program until they find work.
 
The Search
Get a Job, Any Job
 Recently, even as some Republicans in Washington were comparing welfare recipients to alligators and wolves in captivity who become dependent on food handouts, 21 welfare mothers were attending their first GAIN-sponsored Job Club meeting in Chula Vista, just south of San Diego.
They were seated around a long table in a room plastered with signs: "Welfare Dependency -- It's Finally Over," "Change Your Life -- For Good" and "It Pays to Work," with a picture of a pot of money at the end of a rainbow.
The philosophy here is hard-nosed: Get a job, any job, no matter how low-paying, or how grinding, no matter that it may be temporary. Education and training are secondary.
The Job Club leader, Cris Medrano, who wore an "It Pays To Work" button with her pearls and navy blue suit, warned the women that it would not be easy.
"We have the highest unemployment," she said. "People are moving out of California to find work." And with the global economy, she said, the competition is all the more fierce.
She told the women that they could eventually lose their welfare benefits if they did not find work.
Most of the women stared at her with blank expressions. Some looked terrified.
Patricia Jackson, a 28-year-old single mother of three, and a recovering drug addict, spoke up.
"People do get dependent on welfare," she said. "If someone had said to me 10 years ago, 'O.K., Mrs. Jackson, if you don't get a job in three years, you're out,' I might have done it." Looking at the women around her, she asked, "But where are we going to work?"
Mrs. Medrano answered firmly, "We're going to teach you how to market yourselves."
Over the next days, she taught them how to write a resume, fill out a job application and prepare for a job interview. Wear navy blue to interviews, she told them. And "power jewelry," like post earrings. Many of the women said, with embarrassment, that they did not have power jewelry or suitable interview clothes, in any color.
They were all good at something, Mrs. Medrano said. She had everyone make a list of their qualities that might appeal to employers.
Mrs. Jackson wrote: "Hard-working, motivated, enthusiastic, considerate, polite, punctual, trustworthy, good personality."
Parents who are not disabled, or caring for disabled children, or who are not excused for other reasons, are expected to participate in GAIN once their youngest child is over 3.
Mrs. Jackson, whose children are 11, 9 and 2, had volunteered. "My son, Andre -- he's 11 -- he tells me, 'We're the poorest family on the block; when are you going to get that job?' "
GAIN pays for child care as well as transportation to the program for participants. Once they start working, they can deduct child-care costs from their earnings and receive other allowances, so their welfare checks are not reduced dollar for dollar and they are rewarded for their efforts.
But when welfare recipients earn over a certain amount a month -- $1,337 for a family of three -- they stop receiving A.F.D.C. checks altogether. They are still eligible to receive child-care benefits and Medicaid for another year. But it is in the second year, when they have to handle those costs themselves on low-paying jobs, that many mothers find themselves back on welfare. The daunting prospect of losing medical insurance and child-care assistance, officials say, deters many from even making the effort to become independent.
 
The Obstacles
Sick Children, No Experience
 A lot of people on welfare work at least part time, with or without a job program. But an extensive study of the San Diego program begun in 1988 and released last year by the nonprofit Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation in New York, found that GAIN did make a modest increase in a person's likelihood of getting a job. At some point over a three-year period, 62 percent of GAIN participants were employed; 56.5 percent of similar recipients in a control group were employed at least temporarily.
While GAIN participants increased their earnings by 22 percent, they still earned only $1,172 more over three years, on average, than other welfare recipients, according to the study. But such averages mask the fact that a few participants were far more successful while others failed to earn extra money.
With a $22 million budget for the county, the program is expensive. But, according to the study, over time the program paid for itself, with the government getting back a net $1.40 for every net dollar spent since it can reduce welfare payments to those who work.
In California's most successful work program, in Riverside, earnings went up 50 percent, to $3,113 more than other welfare recipients earn, and over time the county saved $2.84 in benefits for every dollar spent. In the past year, San Diego has adopted Riverside's emphasis on pushing recipients directly into jobs, rather than giving many of them extensive training or education, and welfare officials here say they hope their results will improve similarly.
There are always people leaving and entering the system, and GAIN did not make a significant reduction in the caseload. By the end of the third year, 49 percent of those in the program were still on A.F.D.C., while 52 percent of those not in GAIN were still on A.F.D.C., according to the study.
It is impossible to estimate how much it would cost to achieve the ambitious Republican work goals nationally, said Judith Gueron, president of the group that did the study. She said that running a program like California's GAIN on a national scale, with its modest achievements, would cost several billion dollars.
"None of the programs work miracles, but they do make a difference," Ms. Gueron said. "They move people forward. People who are looking for easy solutions don't understand the complexity of the problem."
A visit to the Chula Vista GAIN office revealed some of the obstacles involved in getting parents on welfare into work. Of 26 people scheduled for Araceli Cobarrubias's Job Club last month, 13 showed up on the first day. With no absences allowed, only nine were left at the end of the two weeks.
"People are sick, or their child is sick," said Nancy Spellman, the Job Club leader and a social worker. "Or their grandparent died for the fourth time. They don't have transportation. A lot of people have court cases -- like DWI's -- and a lot of emotional problems."
Ms. Cobarrubias, who is raising two sons, 9 and 6, and a daughter, 4, passed Job Club with flying colors. She has prepared her first resume, listing under skills "multi-line phone," meaning that she can handle a telephone with more than one line. In the apartment where her children share the one bedroom, and where she sleeps on the living room sofa, she has stood in front of the bathroom mirror, as Mrs. Spellman had told her to -- and said aloud: "I can, I am."
She has been videotaped for the job interview she hopes she will get soon.
"Nancy said I have a beautiful smile," Ms. Cobarrubias, who wore a Sesame Street sweatshirt and blue jeans, said shyly.
Ms. Cobarrubias had come a long way, Mrs. Spellman said. "When she came in, she didn't think she could do anything."
Recently, Ms. Cobarrubias listened as Rose Escalante, a job-service worker, read aloud a list of 14 jobs newly available in the area through the state employment agency. There were positions for an engineer, a mechanic, a painter, a bookkeeper, an accounts-receivable clerk, and an administrative assistant experienced in Lotus and WordPerfect.
Ms. Cobarrubias said she did not know anything about computers. "I want to learn typing," she said.
One job that might have been a possibility, as a $5.75-an-hour housekeeper, required six months experience with a floor-waxing machine. "I don't know how to use a wax machine," Ms. Cobarrubias said apologetically.
She said she had applied for a job on her own at the Burger King across from the GAIN office. "They're not hiring now," she said.
She said she had also put in applications at Jack in the Box, at Target and Payless stores, and at the Chula Vista mall.
"They said they were going to call me, but they haven't called," she said. But she added that she was not discouraged. "If there is a job, I will get it."
Ms. Escalante assured the women that there were plenty of jobs that are never advertised. The trick is getting on the phone, and finding them, she said.
Mrs. Spellman said that many of the women have so little confidence that picking up the phone and asking somebody, anybody, even McDonald's for a job is overwhelming.
 
The Hopes
'I Want to Be Important'
 Many mothers in the jobs program here talked about how badly they wanted to get out of the system -- and into the world of work.
"I want to be handing you my business card," said Rosalind Texeira, an energetic 26-year-old single mother of four, and a high school dropout, who hopes to become a medical assistant. "I want to wear high heels. I want to be sophisticated. I want to be important. I want my kids to say, 'My mom's working.' "
But she is already worrying about how she would manage if she did get a full-time job. "They want $60 to $70 a week for child care," she said.
The prospects for many of these women may be influenced as much by broader trends in the job market as by their own efforts, in an era when jobs for the unskilled are less available and pay less than ever.
"It's a tough, tough market," Ms. Escalante said. With Chula Vista only six miles from the border, she added, prospective GAIN workers compete for jobs with Mexicans with green cards who live in Tijuana, where costs are much cheaper, and commute to San Diego and the surrounding area.
Welfare officials say that from 500 to 600 people in the GAIN program get jobs every month, although many have trouble holding onto the jobs for reasons like poor work habits, hardships at home or lack of seniority.
In Chula Vista the other day, Consuelo Fregoso, a 41-year-old mother of three, who does not speak English, was starting a new job search. She said she had been laid off after two months from a $4.25-an-hour job packing candy in a factory. It is not unusual for 50 people to show up at that factory in the morning looking for work, GAIN workers said.
Ms. Lightner, the social worker, said that one of her clients attended a one-day job fair held last year by a Mervyn's department store that was opening in the area. There were 4,500 people vying for 200 jobs. Ms. Lightner's client did not get hired.
Still, there are plenty of inspiring stories. Ms. Lightner talks about Leticia Gonzalez, a mother of three teen-age sons, who had a sixth-grade education, little English and 10 years in the welfare system when she came to GAIN five years ago.
GAIN sent Ms. Gonzalez to truck-driving school. She took English classes at night, and still managed to cook and clean for her family. Today, at 34, she is earning $10.15 an hour, with benefits, as a truck driver. Her welfare case is closed.
Ms. Gonzalez is looking toward the future. "In 10 years I'm not going to be so strong the way I am right now," she said. "I told my big boss I want to learn computers so I can do something different. Anything is possible if you have a goal."
But she is the exception. She has two things a lot of other single mothers lack -- the physical strength to do what has traditionally been a man's job, and relatives willing to look after her children.
Success in the jobs program is more often measured by people like Geraldine Elliget. At 54, she is raising a 13-year-old son alone. Last November she got her first job in 15 years -- as a $4.30-an-hour, part-time, temporary cashier at Kmart. "I was so happy," she said.
She is still at Kmart. And last week she got her second raise, to $4.80 an hour. She says she hopes to get enough hours to earn about $600 a month, with half her pay going to the welfare agency. She does not receive health benefits at work, which is why she says she does not see how she can get off welfare in the foreseeable future.
Still, she said, she is grateful simply to be working. "You come home -- your back hurts, your feet hurt," she said. "But you just feel good. You were productive. You contributed something."
In his office in San Diego, Mr. Ridenour, the GAIN official, had praise for the women who enroll in the jobs program -- for women like Ms. Cobarrubias.
"She is a success," he said, referring to the simple fact that she had completed the program. "But even if everything works for her, she is still going to be a welfare client. Because a single woman with three children, who has to pay for child care, can't live off $6 an hour. That is an economic reality that goes beyond the welfare cycle we want to break."

Graphs: "The Results of a Welfare-to Work Program"
Here are the results of a survey of former welfare recipients in a welfare-to-work program in four California counties from 1988 to 1990.
 
Participants were contacted two to three years after taking part in the program and asked their work status.
 
Those who reported that they were not working and not looking for a job (the last and largest category shown) were asked to give the "most important reason" for this. Those responses were then classified by researchers into broader categories. (Source: "GAIN: Benefits, Costs, and Three-Year Impacts of a Welfare to Work Program," Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation, Sept. 1994.)
 
Chart: "RETHINKING WELFARE: The Push for Work"
 
The goal: To push more recipients into the workplace and foster self-sufficiency.
 
The proposal: In bill passed by the House and now before the Senate, states must place half of all adult welfare recipients in jobs by 2003, or be penalized by a reduction in Federal funds.
 
Current law: States are encouraged to meet more modest employment goals, with Federal funds provided to support education and training.
 
State experience: Strong efforts in several states to prod more recipients into the workplace have had limited success. They require large up-front expenditures for training and other help, though some save money over time by allowing reduced welfare payments.
 
Budget implications: Experts call the goals unrealistic, especially since no extra Federal money for job training is provided. Modest sums may be saved as more recipients earn more on their own.

HEADLINE: THE MCA SALE: THE GLITTERING PRIZE;
Seagram Deal Buys Glamour And a Cash Cow Called Music

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 9

 BODY:
After weeks of hectic negotiations, yet another wealthy company, Seagram, has put billions of dollars on the line to get into one of the hottest and fastest growing businesses in the world -- music.
Music? Isn't MCA Inc., the entertainment conglomerate that Seagram is buying control of, all about movies, with its Universal Pictures producing huge hits like "Jurassic Park"? Well, yes and no. 
 As anyone familiar with the economics of the entertainment business knows, movies dazzle, but the money that is pumping up many entertainment groups, and in many ways subsidizing the ups and downs of film making, is coming from the recorded music business.
"Film stars still come with the highest level of glamour," said Al Teller, chairman of the music group at MCA (which once stood for the Music Corporation of America). "That's sort of where the aristocracy resides in this town. The emotional reality is one thing, but the economic reality is very different."
With the announcement tonight that it will pay Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, $5.7 billion for 80 percent of MCA, Seagram quickly becomes a major player in the entertainment world -- on several fronts. [Page D8.]
Add up the albums sold and the profits generated and you have a cash machine that is outperforming the combined might of Hollywood.
"You can go in and make an album for next to nothing and if it gets on the radio and catches on, you're totally in Fat City," said Cliff Burnstein of Q Prime, a management company in New York whose acts include Metallica, Def Leppard and Hole. "This is totally a money machine."
Michael P. Schulhof, the head of Sony's entertainment group, acknowledged: "The low-margin side of this business is movie making. Music is turning out huge amounts of cash."
The music recording business, in fact, is going through its most profitable period in history, a remarkable trend of soaring cash flow and booming global expansion. The international markets are generating most of the industry's growth, increasingly because of overseas artists that the big music companies are cultivating.
All the major companies receive most of their revenues from big-name American performers. Still, some of Sony Music's top-selling albums last year were by Patricia Kaas and Francis Cabrel in France. Mariya Takeuchi sold more than three million albums in Japan for Time Warner.
At many of the big entertainment conglomerates, like MCA, Time Warner and Sony, the music business is not only more profitable than film, but more consistently profitable.
MCA, which Matsushita acquired five years ago for $6.6 billion, does not break out operating data by division, but people close to the company say the pretax operating income of the film business tumbled to $130 million last year from $200 million in 1993. And now it is facing a possibly costly disaster with Kevin Costner's newest movie, "Waterworld," which has reportedly cost an astounding $165 million to make -- as Seagram undoubtedly knows.
Meanwhile, MCA's music group pumped out roughly $220 million of the group's overall operating income of $400 million, these people said, and it is bounding ahead at a double-digit clip this year.
Time Warner's film group had a huge year in 1994, generating $565 million in pretax operating income on $5 billion in revenues. Yet the company's music labels, including Warner Brothers, Elektra and Atlantic, churned out $720 million in operating income -- on just $4 billion in revenues -- in spite of some well-publicized executive turmoil.
"We are self-funding," said Jerry Gold, the chief financial officer of Time Warner's music group, the biggest in the industry. "We generate excess cash, and that goes to the corporation."
The Columbia and Tri-Star film studios owned by Sony produced an embarrassing $2.7 billion write-off last year and a $510 million operating loss in the fourth quarter. But its recording operations, acquired from CBS seven years ago, sparkled, producing roughly $550 million in operating income on about $4.5 billion in revenues.
Those figures explain why Viacom, Inc., which bought Paramount Communications last year for $10 billion, is now believed to be eager to build or buy a music business.
Of all the entertainment conglomerates, the Walt Disney Company has done the best job of parlaying its film business into a huge money maker without a big music operation, but it still generates significant income from recording. The top-selling album in 1994, with nearly five million sold, was Disney's "Lion King."
"There are no record companies that lose money," said David Geffen, a co-founder of Dreamworks SKG who sold Geffen Records to MCA five years ago for $545 million. "There are six major companies in that industry, and they all make money. All of the economics of the record business are better."
A few key factors explain the differences between the film and music businesses. A movie now typically costs $50 million to produce and market, while an album typically costs a few hundred thousand dollars. A big record company puts out a few hundred album titles a year, distributing its risks widely, while a movie company puts out a couple of dozen films.
Movie companies must often wait years before they see revenue from a film, while music companies start reaping rewards within months and many albums sell strongly for years. Consumers buy nearly 12 million albums each week, and the largest component of those sales is CD's, which generate about $3 of profit apiece, far more than cassette tapes.
Mr. Gold of Time Warner pointed out that one reason the international business was so promising was that most sales of albums overseas were still on tape cassettes; the switch to CD's in coming years will increase profitability.
The movie business is growing increasingly complex, with a growing percentage of revenue coming not from the box office but from videos, cable, CD-ROM's and merchandise. That is a key reason that film making, with all its difficulties, is still regarded as having strong long-term prospects in these heady days of riotous expansion in the media industries.
But the economics of the music business are still unusually compelling and, more important, are expected to remain so. Only a tiny number of performers -- like Madonna -- can command multimillion-dollar contracts, and those are usually spread over a number of albums. Movie stars, on the other hand, can get that much for a single film.
Take the album "Metallica," which cost a relatively extravagant $1 million to make four years ago when it was produced by Elektra, a Time Warner label. Mr. Burnstein said more than 13 million copies had been sold worldwide. That means it has produced gross revenues of a little more than $100 million.
That is roughly equal to a movie that brought in $200 million in box office revenues. However, most movies that bring in that much money cost tens of millions of dollars to make.
One rock band that Mr. Burnstein's firm manages, Veruca Salt, produced an album last year called "American Thighs." He said the album was likely to sell at least 500,000 units, producing about $4 million in revenues for the recording company, Geffen Records. Not bad for an album that cost $6,000 to make.
Figures like that make the movie industry envious and make it question its own bloated financial structure.
"It's very simple: the inflation of production costs in movies is out of control," said Jonathan Taplin, the producer of "The Last Waltz" and other films and the former tour manager for the Band and Bob Dylan.
He added that the accounting for movies was notorious for piling on so many extraneous costs that movies, unlike albums, rarely produced net profits.
"If you've ever seen a movie account statement, it's malarkey," Mr. Taplin said. He also pointed out that the music business, unlike movies, relied on a stream of fresh talent.
"The recording business is creating new artists every week," Mr. Taplin said. "There are 30 or 40 new breaking bands a year," while in the movies, a a blockbuster star breaks through only once every few years.
Among the other important differences between music and film are that actors almost never sign multiwork deals, while in music that is the norm, and that music fans tend to be much more reliable customers than fickle film viewers.
"Once you're truly established in the music business your sales base is fairly predictable," Mr. Teller of MCA said. "You can count on some level of sales performance. In film, you start from scratch each time out."
Mr. Schulhof commented: "Every film is one-off. Each film is almost like a new business."

The success of the album, "American Thighs," demonstrates the profit potential of recordings as opposed to expensive-to-produce films. (Paul Merideth)(pg. D8)

HEADLINE: Big Investor Talked, Grace Listened

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
The board room shake-up at W. R. Grace & Company, effected with stunning speed last month, has not yet run its course. But the effort by dissident shareholders to force change at the $4 billion specialty chemical and medical services company is already seen as a watershed in the annals of corporate governance.
The Grace episode has raised eyebrows across the country, not only because the company agreed to make sweeping changes, but because the fight was led by a shareholder -- TIAA-CREF -- that in most respects was more than satisfied with its investment and that in the past had tended to prefer private diplomacy to a public fight. 
 Instead of taking on a company that was performing poorly, the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association/College Retirement Equity Fund decided to push a company that was doing well to do better. The importance of this shift in emphasis is magnified because TIAA-CREF is the world's largest pension fund, with more than $66 billion in stocks alone.
"In the case of Grace, what has happened here is really important," said Robert Monks, a principal at Lens Inc., a Washington money management firm governed by the philosophy that shareholder involvement can increase value.
To Mr. Monks, TIAA-CREF's leading role in the battle with Grace's board represents the passage of shareholder activism from the ideologically driven positions taken by many public pension funds, most notably the California Public Employees' Retirement System, to one that is based on economics.
"CREF is creating the correlation between governance and value," he said. "They have a lot of money invested in the company, but a lot of money in Grace hasn't been made yet. They became involved in order to make money. Ultimately, trustees at other pension funds are all going to have to look at governance the same way."
In recent years pension funds have increasingly sought to put pressure on underperforming companies, most recently at Kmart. What TIAA-CREF did with Grace is a further refinement.
"CREF is taking a very sophisticated approach by judging a company against itself, and what it could be," said Jon Lukomnik, New York City's Deputy Comptroller for pensions. "More power to them."
The implications could be far reaching, because as a way of increasing value for its 1.7 million participants TIAA-CREF has initiated a program that intends to broaden its scrutiny of the companies already in its portfolio.
This month, B. Kenneth West, the former chairman and chief executive of Harris Bankcorp Inc., joined TIAA-CREF as senior consultant for corporate governance. He has a $1 million budget to broaden the fund's scrutiny.
"Our new program involves systematically looking at the corporate governance practices of our portfolio holdings," said John H. Biggs, TIAA-CREF's chairman and chief executive. "We have not done that, and in my view that is where there are corporate governance changes that could affect companies."
The fund is already focusing on its next target, Nucor, a steelmarker based in Charlotte, N.C. TIAA-CREF, which owns more than 900,000 Nucor shares, wants the company to diversify the composition of its board, now made up of five white men -- three current Nucor executives, the other two retired.
As for W. R. Grace, TIAA-CREF made its initial investment in 1990 and had long regarded the board as too big, too old and too in-bred.
But despite a doubling of its investment in January 1994, the fund did not press for changes on Grace's board, because the restructuring strategy pursued since late 1992 by J. P. Bolduc, who was then the president and chief executive, appeared to be on track. When Mr. Bolduc abruptly resigned on March 2, CREF's confidence in Grace's management was shaken.
Less than two weeks after discussions with the company, CREF formally proposed a mandatory retirement age of 70 for board members.
On March 17 the company relented, announcing that J. Peter Grace Jr., the company's 81-year old chairman, would not stand for re-election. The company also said that the size of the board would be cut to 12 from 22 and that Mr. Bolduc's successor, once selected, would be able to replace half the remaining directors.
That commitment was upheld on Thursday, despite an emotional and intense lobbying effort by Mr. Grace and others to have it overturned.
"We hoped Grace would do that, but I didn't think they would," Mr. Biggs said. "We didn't really know quite where their board was going to come out."
The circumstances surrounding TIAA-CREF's role in spearheading the attack on W. R. Grace were fairly unique, but the fund has made plain that it intends to take a more active and, if need be, more public stance advocating shareholder rights.
Although Mr. Biggs said the fund had been an "active player" in corporate governance for 15 years, a decision was made two years ago to rachet that activism up a notch. And with $61 billion of its $135.7 billion in assets invested in equities, TIAA-CREF has more than enough muscle to make its own case. Unlike most pension funds, all of CREF's assets are internally managed. But roughly three-quarters of its stock portfolio is in indexed funds.
And, as Mr. Monks suggested, good citizenship was not necessarily the primary factor motivating CREF to make the change. Rather, it has sharpened its focus on companies it invests in as a way of making more money for its participants.
The first indication of TIAA-CREF's new vigor came with the publication in 1993 of a Policy Statement on Corporate Governance that was mailed to each of the 1,600 companies that CREF, the College Retirement Equities Fund, invests in.
The next year was spent seeing which companies were paying attention. In preparation for the 1995 proxy season, last year the fund filed 26 resolutions at various companies, an increase from the 10 to 20 that Mr. Biggs said had been the norm.
And last month, as the battle with Grace was reaching its zenith, TIAA-CREF tapped Mr. West from Harris Bankcorp for the corporate governance job.
Mr. West will be taking a close look at the corporate governance practices at the 30 or so companies in which the fund has a stake of $100 million or more. The scrutiny will probably expand to another 200 to 300 in 1996, Mr. Biggs said, "and then we will see what the payoff is."
"Big state pension plans are not paying any attention to the companies below the most visible New York Stock Exchange-listed firms," he said. "We are the only ones who are going to be doing it."
To Mr. Biggs, the odds are good that the new effort will more than justify an annual budget of $1 million.
TIAA-CREF prefers to discuss its differences with individual companies privately first, a practice Mr. Biggs said would continue. Over the course of the last few months, quiet diplomacy with companies has led the fund to withdraw 15 of the 26 proxies it submitted for consideration at annual meetings this year.
Companies that resist will be fought, even ones that TIAA-CREF acknowledges have been star performers.
"I don't think everybody is going to be delighted to have us come in and talk with them," Mr. Biggs said. "But I would say we are coming to them in good faith, that they can believe we are going to be fair, and won't go to the press."
Samuel Siegel, vice chairman of Nucor, is one executive who was less than delighted to hear from Mr. Biggs's fund.
"Nucor is a company that has had spectacularly good investment results, and we are very happy with it," Mr. Biggs said. "But it has a tiny board all of whom, in effect, are insiders. If they had some independent people come on the board they would have a safeguard they do not now have."
Such advice is a novelty at Nucor, which had never received a shareholder resolution until it got one from TIAA-CREF.
Mr. Siegel, a board member since 1968, does not see eye to eye with Mr. Biggs.
"If we were to do what CREF wants, we would either have to fire existing board members or make the board larger," he said. "We don't think either of those things are in the best interest of the company."
By keeping the board small, Mr. Siegel added, "we are saving our shareholders hundreds of thousands a year." The issue comes to a vote on May 11.
