HEADLINE: Market Place;
In a bottom-line economy, will temporary staffs be permanent?

BYLINE: By Robert Hurtado 

 BODY:
TEMPORARY staffing companies like the Olsten Corporation have attracted more interest from some investors as American companies continue to try to cut costs by substituting part-time workers for permanent ones.
In fact, Olsten's stock has risen more than 12 percent since March 20, closing Friday at $35.50. But the stock has been volatile this year, trading between $31.125 and $38.875. 
 The recent run-up has not made Olsten too expensive for F. Thomas O'Halloran, an analyst at Dillon, Read. "I still think it will outperform the market this year," he said, adding that he saw no special reason for the price spurt.
Major companies in the temporary-staffing business include Manpower Inc. and Kelly Services. But Olsten's revenue mix is considered more balanced by some analysts because a large part of its business is in health care. About 47 percent of its total 1994 revenue of $2.3 billion was derived from supplying nurses and other health care workers and the remaining 53 percent from placing people in office jobs.
The company ranks third in the nation, behind Kelly and Manpower, in supplying temporary workers, a field that has expanded rapidly because of business trends in recent years.
"Companies have come to rely on flexible labor pools that can quickly be adjusted to stay in sync with the rise and fall of business demand," said Stephen L. Handley, an analyst with Smith Barney. "Just-in-time labor will continue to be a growth industry through the 1990's, making Olsten a stock that will do well this year and beyond." Mr. Handley thinks the stock will reach $45 to $48 in the next 12 months.
Olsten principally caters to Fortune 500 companies, providing a wide range of office skills, including accounting, legal and computer services. The company, which has 600 offices in the United States, Britain, Canada and Mexico, placed more than 500,000 employees and increased sales by 24 percent in 1994.
Olsten has gained long-term accounts in part with a system that requires the placement of its own managers at client companies to oversee the use of the temporary workers. It has about 150 of these partnership arrangements, which now account for about 20 percent of its staffing-services business and include companies like Lotus Development, Nike, TRW and General Electric.
Staffing services has been a cyclical business, dependent on a growing economy. But some analysts say that the redesign of many companies may make temporary workers a permanent fixture; suppliers like Olsten, they say, will be able to weather future recessions much more easily than in the past.
But others are not sure. "The fortunes of temporary staffing companies will always be tied somewhat to an expanding economy," said Judith G. Scott, an analyst with Robert W. Baird & Company in Milwaukee. "However, the deep-seated structural changes in the workplace provide an impetus for growth throughout the business cycle."
Olsten's insurance for a softening economy is in health care staffing, primarily the use of temporary nurses in people's homes. As a result of its 1993 acquisition of the Lifetime Corporation, Olsten dominates home-care staffing, about double the size of its nearest competitor, Interim Systems.
Government contract reimbursement covered 60 percent of Olsten's health care billings, with Medicare accounting for nearly half of that.
To reduce its reliance on government contracts, Olsten has been diversifying its health care business. For example, it is providing management services to hospital-based home health groups like the Columbia/HCA Corporation.
Last year, Olsten had a proft of $1.61 a share, in contrast to a loss of 67 cents in 1993 resulting from expenses related to the acquisition of Lifetime. William Sutherland, an analyst with Janney Montgomery Scott in Philadelphia, estimates that Olsten will make about $2.05 a share in 1995.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
The Price Is Right as Talent-Hungry Clubs Snap Up Free Agents Cheap

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

DATELINE: MIAMI, April 9

 BODY:
Starting last summer, they fought over a salary cap or some other system (S.O.S.) that would let baseball club owners regain control of player salaries. One mammoth strike later, the owners didn't get what they wanted, but they have what they wanted.
In two days of frenzied contract signing, operating without any imposed or negotiated constraints, clubs clearly showed they are capable of exercising self-control without the aid of an artificial control. The most stunning example of their efforts can be seen in the drastic pay cuts 17 free agents accepted in signing Friday and Saturday. 
 Last season those players, who include two former most valuable players, two Cy Young award winners and four players who have pitched no-hitters (one a perfect game), had salaries totaling $54.4 million. Their salaries for the 1995 season total $16.5 million.
"I don't think they've ever needed anything except a little more adherence to a budget," Joe Bick, an agent who represents 2 of those 17 players, said today. "It's as simple as that as far as I'm concerned. Like any business, if they set a budget and stick to it, there's plenty of money in the game for everybody."
The owners and other club officials argued that the answer is not that simple, even though some cited their budgets as the reason they offered players reduced salaries.
They pointed out the unusual circumstances that now exist -- the heavy economic losses the clubs suffered during the nearly eight-month strike, the large number of players available as free agents and the desire of players to get jobs before the season starts two weeks from Tuesday night.
Further, they maintain that a salary cap or its payroll-tax relative is needed to keep richer clubs, like the Yankees, Toronto Blue Jays and Atlanta Braves, from collecting the best players and creating superteams, while their poorer brethren struggle with low payrolls and uncompetitive teams.
Even so, people on the players' side were asking today what all the fuss has been about.
"What it's shown me is the strike really wasn't about economic issues, in the sense that the clubs always have been able to control salaries," Jim Bronner, a veteran player agent, said. "They just haven't been able to control their will to control the salaries. The idea that a salary cap or a luxury tax was essential turns out not to be true. The clubs have shown they can control salaries without them. It makes it that much more clear this was a power struggle to reduce the power of the union."
Ever since salaries started escalating with the advent of free agency in 1976, owners have asked the players to help them protect themselves from themselves.
Last Dec. 22, when the owners declared an impasse in negotiations for a new collective bargaining agreement and said they were unilaterally implementing a salary cap, Jerry McMorris of the Colorado Rockies, one of the clubs' chief negotiators, was asked why owners can't modify their spending behavior.
"It never has happened," he replied.
McMorris's free-agent signings were the exceptions during the weekend. Although he has become the lead negotiator for the owners in their quest for wage control, he bucked the trend and signed two free agents, outfielder Larry Walker and pitcher Bill Swift, for a total of $35.15 million.
"We have the support," McMorris said at the Rockies' training camp in Tucson, Ariz., referring to the tremendous fan support the team has had in its first two seasons. "Other owners know that, and I'm not worried about that. It wouldn't be fair to our fans, or meet our competitive desires, to sit on our hands."
On that impasse night in December in Washington, McMorris had talked about how the owners are fiercely competitive, saying: "Everybody wants to win. Everybody thinks they're a player away."
But other clubs are obviously trying to resist the temptation of championship dreams. To a large extent, the players who had their salaries slashed are older players, some facing the end of their careers. Still, baseball has never seen anything like it.
The Texas Rangers, seeking a starting pitcher, targeted Bob Tewksbury, and they paid no attention to the $3.5 million salary he had with the St. Louis Cardinals last season.
"It wasn't difficult," Doug Melvin, the Rangers' general manager, said, explaining his plan. "We have a budget. It was a matter of how much money I had left and that was it."
Tewksbury, 34 years old, catapulted himself toward the salary stratosphere with a career-best season in 1992. But a poor second half of the strike-shortened 1994 season left him with little leverage for bargaining this year. Bick had another free-agent pitcher, Terry Mulholland, who had a poor season with the Yankees.
"It wasn't unexpected," Bick said about the pay cuts. "We all pretty much knew going in anybody with an earned run average like Bob's and Terry's were going to pay the price."
Tewksbury took a $2 million pay cut and signed with the Rangers. Mulholland accepted $1.25 million from the San Francisco Giants, a huge drop from his 1994 salary of $3.35 million.
The Florida Marlins, like the Rockies an expansion team in 1993, spent $3.8 million on three free agents who last year had salaries totaling a shade under $11 million. More than half the reduction was in Andre Dawson's salary, which will be $500,000 for his final season.
"We've always been aware of what our budget is," Dave Dombrowski, the Marlins' general manager, said. "Generally, the only thing I can say is right now everybody is in severe financial problems because of the strike so they have been forced to make some moves they probably would rather not have made. Maybe clubs will learn from it."
Bud Selig, the acting commissioner and chief campaigner for payroll constraints of some sort, thinks more than education is needed.
"It cannot be left to go unfettered," he said. "It clearly needs a mechanism to keep the leagues competitive."
Dombrowski said that before anyone draws any conclusions from the recent signing experience, he has to consider the brief signing period created by the strike.
"They're looking for jobs quickly," he said.
Don Baylor, the manager of the improved Rockies, suggested that the length of the strike had an effect on the players' mind-set.
"Guys got shaken," he said. "It really affected some players."
Bronner viewed the circumstances from both perspectives. The clubs, he said, "are not having any trouble now saying we don't have the money; it's not in our budget." The players, he said, "want to play badly enough that they have accepted the lower salaries."
Bronner added: "I haven't heard any players complaining about what's going on. The idea of movement is important to them. If the owners work with this system, they can make it work like they want another system to work. But it doesn't have the artificial restraint they were trying to impose with the other system."

LENGTH: 604 words

HEADLINE: Tremors in China

 BODY:
Chinese leaders declare the looming succession to Deng Xiaoping as China's paramount leader a nonevent. Mr. Deng has already retired, they say. His successor, President Jiang Zemin, is already in place, surrounded by a collective leadership team.
Few serious China watchers take these declarations seriously. Judging by their actions, neither do the Chinese leaders who make them. Behind the facade of collective leadership, they are already positioning themselves for an uncertain future. 
 There is not much the United States can do to affect who comes out on top in Beijing. But Washington needs to think now about how American interests might be affected by a troubled succession or the abrupt policy changes it could produce.
Last month's session of China's nominal legislature, the National People's Congress, provided tantalizing signs of political ferment. For years, the congress tamely ratified the policies and appointments submitted by the Government and Communist leadership. This year, more than a third of the delegates broke ranks to vote against a Jiang Zemin nominee for vice premier and almost as many voted against a major banking law.
This show of dissent reflected the efforts of the congress's chairman, Qiao Shi, to pry open China's airless political system. Besides Mr. Qiao, other well-known figures have conspicuously raised their political profiles, as if to remind colleagues that potential alternatives exist should Mr. Jiang falter.
Competing factions also seem to be reviving the Stalinist ploy of targeting corruption investigations to damage rivals. The Beijing political world was startled recently when one probe brought down a close family friend of Deng Xiaoping.
Washington is largely a spectator to these events, but it need not be a helpless one. While doing all it can to keep present relations with China on a smooth course, it needs to respond quickly to signs of personnel and policy change.
The Clinton Administration should resist the entreaties of Jiang Zemin for a Presidential visit in the near future. This would be seen as an endorsement of Mr. Jiang's leadership bid. The Administration should also avoid committing itself to high-level representation at the United Nations women's conference in Beijing this fall. Washington should offer no encouragement to China's crude attempts to restrict participation on political grounds.
No matter who emerges at the top, there is little chance of regression to Mao-style socialism. But while economic reform will continue in name, there could be important variations in content. Washington should continue working to integrate China into the world trading system under equitable rules. Still, as Mexico has taught, it is foolhardy to assume that any "emerging market" will enjoy uninterrupted growth, doubly so when that market is yoked to a rigid, personality-driven political system. The Administration errs when it subordinates other interests, like human rights, to the mirage of boundless commercial opportunities.
China's foreign and military policies could also be affected by succession politics, since military leaders are likely to be key political power brokers in the next few years. With this in mind, Washington needs to assess carefully Beijing's recent burst of belligerence in the disputed waters of the South China Sea. America is not directly involved in the boundary dispute but has an interest in discouraging Beijing from reckless behavior.
It is, of course, possible that the succession to Deng Xiaoping will turn out to be a nonevent. Washington would be foolish to count on it.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Essay;
Gambling Fever

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: HARPERS FERRY, W.Va.

 BODY:
At the age of 14, I was standing on a landing in the stairwell at Joan of Arc Junior High School in Manhattan, watching a crap game, when I felt the heavy hand of a teacher on my shoulder.
My protest that I didn't even have a bet down was unavailing; four of us, all seniors, were branded as gamblers. The shaming punishment: though permitted to be graduated, I was refused a place at commencement and denied a diploma. 
 That was back when gambling was viewed as wrong; when bookies and numbers racketeers were considered the scum of society; and when a lust for something-for-nothing was looked upon as a weakness of character.
Today, state-sponsored gambling is the national pastime. Nearly 100 million casino visitors, video gamblers and sports bettors wager close to a half-trillion dollars -- with $40 billion going to the "house."
And today, aboriginal Americans are exploiting those of us who followed in neon casinos on their reservations. The tribes are becoming a nation of croupiers, in league with national gambling interests, while pretending ill-gotten profits are used primarily to educate their children.
The "gaming industry" -- none of its pious proponents call it the gambling racket -- is the source of the greatest sustained, bipartisan political hypocrisy of our time.
Liberals, professing a horror of regressive taxation, turn a blind eye to the way state-sponsored gambling redistributes income upward, and how new casino permissions snatch welfare checks to fatten per-share earnings of casino stockholders.
Conservatives, ostensibly upholders of public morality, approve government advertising campaigns to entice citizens to gamble in lotteries and play the ponies at off-track betting parlors.
Gullible voters were sold this notion: since many people liked to gamble anyway, why not turn gambling's profits to public benefit?
But the result is the gambling epidemic, with its associated money laundering by criminals, corruption of public officials and "cannibalization" of local economies. Thanks to the public blessing of gambling by government, the moral stigma was removed and the high roller has become a folk hero.
The media cannot escape their share of the blame. From the hysterical hype of the Publishers Clearing House to the front-page and prime-time publicity given sweepstakes winners (nobody covers the losers), we have glorified the pernicious philosophy of something-for-nothing.
Nothing is for nothing. Crime always goes hand-in-hand with gambling. Here in the relatively poor state of West Virginia, a former governor confessed to taking bribes from racetrack operators and a lottery director was jailed for rigging a video lottery contract. Disgusted, church groups recently leaned on legislators to reject riverboat gambling, and the pols suddenly realized that a pro-casino vote could be a loser.
Now the media are at last awakening. Gee-whiz stories touting the craze are out and hard reporting of the spreading addiction is in.
The Economist cast into doubt the claim that gambling salvages local economies. USA Today headlined: "Nation raising 'a generation of gamblers,' " focusing on the ring corrupting schools in suburban Nutley, N.J. The best reporting was in Sports Illustrated's detailed expose of the gambling addiction rampant in the nation's colleges.
But television news is still gambling's friend. With young gamblers relying heavily on the sports ticker that runs at the bottom of CNN's Headline News, that network has a special responsibility to show how the lives of many students are being ruined by the compulsion its ticker helps feed. A "Gambling is for suckers" crawl among the scores would do for starters.
Will the pols sense the coming voter revulsion at the "painless" revenue source that failed? Representative Frank Wolf of Virginia has introduced a bill to establish a "National Gambling Impact and Policy Commission"; let's see if the casino lobby can buy the votes to avert scrutiny and restigmatizing.
The yen to gamble is a personal weakness, but state-sponsored gambling is a banana-republic abomination that undermines national values. My gratitude goes to that tough teacher at Joan of Arc who stopped me before I started.

HEADLINE: Mysteries, of Course, But Ruth Rendell Also Sees Real Evil

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL 

DATELINE: LONDON, April 9

 BODY:
On the occasion last fall of Ruth Rendell's 30th anniversary as a mystery writer, her British publisher, Random House UK, gave a party to show its appreciation for her work (and for all the money she has brought in over the years). The house also presented Mrs. Rendell with the bookends of her productive career so far: special-edition copies of her first novel, "From Doon With Death" (1964), and her latest one, "Simisola" (1994).
The first marks the debut of her Chief Inspector Reginald Wexford of the town of Kingsmarkham, in the case of a strangely dull murder victim with one intriguing, and fatal, secret. And the latest catches up with him, after many years, investigating the disappearance of a young black woman in a Kingsmarkham racked by unemployment, racism and hopelessness. 
 In her typically forthright way, Mrs. Rendell, 64, said recently during an interview in her London apartment near Regent's Park that she had included an especially large dose of social realism, a familiar element for her, because the Wexford series was "beginning to get into the doldrums."
She continued: "I thought I would really try to examine unemployment and racism in this country, and try and give a picture of what life is like in a place like Kingsmarkham today. It's gotten very bad: the great gulf in England between the rich and the poor, unemployment, violence and the huge incidence of stealing and general dishonesty."
Mrs. Rendell, a slender woman with a rather severe face that is entirely transformed by her smile, has never been one to shy from unglamorous themes. Her books often feature uncannily sympathetic portraits of troubled characters hovering one way or another on the margins of society. Many of them suffer from delusional romantic obsession, a sense of injustice or a single misstep that spirals out of control. Some are simply ordinary people driven to extremes. One book, "Judgment in Stone," begins this way: "Eunice Parchman killed the Coverdale family because she could not read or write."
"Simisola," which came out in the fall in Britain, isn't scheduled for publication in the United States until next fall, so American Rendell fans will have to make do with her other recent book, "No Night Is Too Long" (Harmony). Written under Mrs. Rendell's pseudonym, Barbara Vine, the book is about a young man who gets away with murder -- or maybe not.
Mrs. Rendell always seems to have a book coming out. So far, there have been 16 Wexfords, 16 other Rendell mysteries, 5 short-story collections and 7 Barbara Vine novels. And although she has said that writing for her is a rather neurotic business, a kind of perpetual self-analysis, she sometimes produces two books a year, one per identity. "I'm not saying I like it all or I like it all the time," she said, "but I do like it, you know."
Under either name, Mrs. Rendell is extraordinarily acclaimed, having amassed fistfuls of awards, including Edgars from the Mystery Writers' Association in the United States and gold, silver and diamond daggers from the Crime Writers' Association in England. Though her books regularly make best-seller lists in Britain, they sell modestly in the United States: usually between 10,000 and 30,000 copies each. Her appeal, her publishers say, is growing with each book, but not in Grish-am-size quantities.
Her books have also found their way to American television, in an Inspector Wexford series on the Arts & Entertainment network and in a dramatic adaption of "A Dark-Adapted Eye," which was shown during the winter on PBS. In the latter, a woman retraces the bizarre murder committed by her aunt, hanged for her crime a generation earlier; in a particularly creepy touch, the reader isn't sure until the end who the victim was.
The Vine books are generally billed as "novels of psychological suspense," and they are different from the Rendell books: "softer, and more feminine," the author says. She took on her pseudonym about a decade ago, with the idea for "A Dark-Adapted Eye" swimming relentlessly in her head, along with a persistent feeling that it was not the kind of book she was used to writing. The new name -- "Barbara" is her middle name; "Vine" her great-grandmother's maiden name -- freed her, she said, from her usual self.
"It's more than another name; it's another identity. Once I was Barbara Vine, I could do something else."
Mrs. Rendell rejects the classic mystery in which the suspects are corralled by a Poirot-like detective, who spins a dazzling narrative ("But you, Mademoiselle, knew he would be out that afternoon, because he never took tea on weekends!") before dramatically unmasking the unlikely killer. And although she admires the books of her great friend P. D. James, she has little patience with some of the mystery genre's best sellers.
"I don't like Agatha Christie," Mrs. Rendell said. "She wrote very badly, her characters are not real, and they are repeated over and over, although I will acknowledge that she has the most wonderful ideas. I used to read Dorothy L. Sayers, but now I find her snobbery and her racism distasteful."
Writers like Sayers have been accused, perhaps unfairly, of creating male detectives as idealizations of their own romantic fantasies, but Mrs. Rendell said she was not the least in love with Chief Inspector Wexford. Sometimes she even gets a little sick of him, she said, and has to quell the impulse to kill him off: "It comes and goes, you know."
But that hasn't stopped readers from writing to declare their own love for Wexford, occasionally asking the author to dispatch his wife, Dora, so they can take her place. Mrs. Rendell, who has no secretary but always writes back, usually replies that Inspector Wexford is happily married.
So is his creator, although she and her husband, Don, were divorced in 1975, after 20 years of marriage. They remarried two years later, this time for good, and Mrs. Rendell does not want to go into the details. "We wished to be divorced, very much," she said. "But I think we really did not know anybody else that we would have settled down with happily." She speaks frequently to their grown son, a social worker in Colorado, but suspects that the warm relationships in her family are the exception, not the rule.
"Of course, my family isn't very big, is it?" she said. "I'm inclined to think that most families don't work out, and that most trouble does begin in families."
Mrs. Rendell, who says she is far more interested in murderers' motives than in their methods, does seem almost disappointingly normal for someone with such an understanding of the odd and the skewed. But it all makes sense to her.
"I don't think I could say that I don't know myself," she said. "We all have feelings of obsession or compulsion. I know why I do things. I think some of the reasons are quite strange, but I would look at them and examine them, and ask myself why I did that. I don't have fantasies and I don't have daydreams. How can I? I put them all in my writing."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The novelist Ruth Rendell, creator of Chief Inspector Reginald Wexford. (Jane Bown)

HEADLINE: Fujimori Is Well Ahead in an Election Exit Poll in Peru

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, April 9

 BODY:
President Alberto K. Fujimori appeared poised to win a second term in Peru's elections today, according to an early and unofficial survey of voters leaving polling places, but rival candidates continued to charge that the voting had been compromised by fraud.
A national exit poll by the Apoyo group, Peru's leading polling organization, indicated that Mr. Fujimori had won 61 percent of all votes, thus avoiding a second round of balloting. Final results will not be known until Monday. 
 Mr. Fujimori's closest rival, Javier Perez de Cuellar, a former Secretary General of the United Nations, had less than half as many votes, with 26 percent, the exit survey indicated. Twelve other candidates split the remainder of the votes.
Mr. Perez de Cuellar and five other candidates said Saturday night in a letter delivered to an observer team of the Organization of American States that they believed the election had been tainted by a ballot fraud scheme uncovered on Thursday in the city of Huanuco, about 150 miles northeast of Lima. Fifteen people were arrested for trying to alter more than 3,000 voting tally sheets in advance of the election,
Mr. Perez de Cuellar said that he had received information that the fraud extended to other cities across the country and that he believed Mr. Fujimori was directly involved because the tally sheets were discovered at the home of a top organizer of Mr. Fujimori's party, Change 90 -- New Majority.
But Peru's National Election Board said Saturday night that the Huanuco fraud was an isolated case and the work of common criminals trying to earn extra money.
"Inexplicably, the National Elections Board has reduced the fraud to a criminal act supposedly meant to favor congressional candidates, exempting the principal beneficiary of the fraud, President Alberto Fujimori, from any responsibility," the rival candidates said in the letter.
Carlos Chipoco, Mr. Perez de Cuellar's campaign manager, said in a television interview this afternoon that the exit polls were just that: "exit polls that have been shown to be wrong before."
Local and international observers said that voting at polling places across Peru was orderly today and that there was no immediate evidence of fraud, although many polling centers opened an hour later than the scheduled 8 A.M.
"Today, we had a quiet process," said Santiago Murray, head of the O.A.S.'s observer team. "All the reports I am getting from the field are normal irregularities that happen on every voting day."
Mr. Murray said the O.A.S. was "very concerned" about the voter fraud case in Huanuco but that the group was convinced the Government had acted quickly and responsibly in investigating it.
More than 100,000 army troops and national police officers were posted at polling places in Lima and other major cities and rural areas to guard against possible fraud and terrorist attacks, but no major incidents were reported.
"At this time, we can say that this has been more or less a clean election with a few minor irregularities in the opening of voting centers, but this we don't feel will affect the outcome," said Orlando Moro, a spokesman for Transparencia, a local good government group.
Opinion polls taken days before the vote showed Mr. Fujimori well ahead, and political analysts attributed his seeming victory to his success in revitalizing Peru's economy and crushing the Shining Path guerrilla insurgency.
Mr. Perez de Cuellar campaigned on a theme of creating new jobs and social programs for the poor but his crusade was eclipsed by Peru's border war with Ecuador in February and tactical mistakes, like starting his campaign too late and failing to establish himself as a viable alternative to Mr. Fujimori.
In San Juan de Lugrigancho, a large shantytown where residents waited in long lines to vote, Juan Rudas, 32, a ceramics worker, said he voted for Mr. Fujimori because of the "peace and economic opportunity he has brought to Peru." Asked if he was concerned about the allegations of voter fraud, Mr. Rudas said: "I don't think Fujimori was involved. It's a local situation that the other candidates are exaggerating to try and win."
In the middle-class Lima neighborhood of Jesus Maria, Maria Rojas, 21, said, "Perez de Cuellar is an excellent man and a great diplomat, but I voted for Fujimori, principally because of the peace he has brought to Peru."
Voting is mandatory in Peru, and failure to do so can lead to a $17 fine, a large sum for a worker who earns the minimum wage of $45 a month.
In the legislative race, the Apoyo exit poll indicated that Mr. Fujimori's Change 90 party had won 46 percent of the 120 congressional seats and Mr. Perez de Cuellar's party, Union for Peru, 16 percent. The remainder went to other parties.

HEADLINE: DOLLAR PLUNGES AGAINST THE YEN; JAPAN INTERVENES

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Monday, April 10

 BODY:
The dollar crashed to a postwar low in trading this morning and recovered modestly only after the central bank swept in to support it.
After closing in New York trading on Friday at 83.82 yen, the dollar plunged this morning to 80.15 yen, a startling drop of more than 4 percent. In late afternoon trading, the dollar was at 82.90 yen. 
 The dollar was trading at about 82 yen in the early morning. But in a dramatic sequence of events, the Minister of Finance for Japan, Masayoshi Takemura, called for a "fundamental review" of the global exchange rate system, and almost immediately after that, the dollar plunged to 80.15 yen.
The Bank of Japan, the central bank, then intervened in the foreign exchange markets by buying dollars with an equivalent of more than one billion yen. Though it was a small amount, the move came on thin trading and spurred some momentum, and the dollar rose slightly.
Mr. Takamura, Japan's Finance Minister, said, "I want the United States to feel responsible and make a clear stance to defend the dollar," the Reuters news agency reported.
Mr. Takamura is expected to stress the issue when he meets with the United States Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin, in Indonesia later this week, at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum. The dollar is also likely to be on the agenda when the Group of Seven -- the United States, Japan, Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada -- meet in Washington later this month.
"Everyone was talking about seeing the dollar going down to 80 yen, and if everyone believes it, that can be almost self-fulfilling," said Christopher J. R. Calderwood, senior economist at BZW Securities (Japan) Ltd. "We're seeing something of a speculative bubble in the yen."
In a sign of discontent by the public, two entertainers won the governorship posts in Tokyo and Osaka in elections during the weekend. Economists said it was possible that those results contributed to jitters in the foreign exchange markets today. The Ministry of Finance and Japanese business leaders have been calling for a lowering of the discount rate in Japan to halt the strengthening yen, which makes Japanese exports difficult to sell abroad.
Yet the Bank of Japan has so far resisted these calls, intervening in the market instead to lower the rate at which banks borrow from the central bank. The Japanese Government said it would introduce a fiscal package on April 14, and economists said they expected the package would include various economic measures, including a cut in the discount rate of at least half a percentage point. The stock market immediately reacted to the news. The Nikkei index of 225 issues rose by more than 150 points in midday trading, and closed up 443.59 points, or 2.82 percent, at 16,163.09.
But economists said the Government's plan would not necessarily offer a remedy to the strong yen. Instead, a coordinated effort on the part of Japan, the United States and Germany would be a more effective measure, they said.
Yet, a coordinated effort does not seem likely soon, and so the foreign exchange markets seem to be sending an ultimatum to the Japanese Government to do something. After Germany raised its key interest rate, traders and investors expected Japan to do the same, and its reluctance to act suggests a real weakness, economists say.
"The Government is in such disarray, it's almost anarchy at the moment," said Mineko Sasaki-Smith, senior economist at Morgan Stanley Japan Ltd. "We're at the point where the market has been effective in sending a signal to the Japanese Government that they would like to see some action by the Government."
Japan's official discount rate currently stands at 1.75 percent, and economists said one reason that the Bank of Japan had been reluctant until now to cut the rate was because it wanted to avoid switching economic policy immediately before the elections on the weekend.
The United States appears hesitant to nudge up its key rate, though Mr. Rubin has said several times recently that a weak dollar is not in the national interest. But he has declined to provide an indication of what the Administration might do to help halt the dollar's drop.
"The Clinton Administration has a hidden agenda," said Ms. Sasaki-Smith of Morgan Stanley. "It wants to push Japan policy makers to the corner to come up with a more effective means to stimulate demand."
The dollar has been weak primarily against the yen, the German mark and the Swiss franc. It has not weakened against the currencies of other big trading partners, including Mexico and Canada and other Asian and European countries.

HEADLINE: Lingering Shortage Of Air Controllers Plagues New York

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

 BODY:
Fourteen years after most of the nation's air-traffic controllers were dismissed for striking, the office that handles New York's three major airports is still so understaffed that controllers work mandatory six-day weeks and officials are drawing up contingency plans to cut flights during the anticipated summer rush.
Federal Aviation Administration officials say they believe the agency will opt to pay even more overtime, rather than resort to what they call a "ground delay program," which would inevitably lead the airlines to cut flights in and out of Kennedy, La Guardia and Newark airports. 
 But they add that more overtime is not a solution to their long-term staffing problems. The controllers have worked mandatory six-day weeks since August, using up three quarters of a $1.5 million overtime budget so far this year.
Last year, in part because of the controller shortage and high traffic levels, the office recorded 50 operational errors, up from 16 the year before. Most of the violations brought planes closer together than the minimum required separation of 1,000 feet in altitude and 3 miles horizontally; some errors caused planes to stray out of the proper airspace. No accidents resulted.
Nationally, the F.A.A. says it has nearly the number of controllers it needs, but in the New York region there has long been a shortage, in part, the controllers union says, because of the high cost of living and the difficulty of the work created by three flight patterns.
Until August, managers handled the shortage by simply not filling all the seats in front of the control consoles. But the increase in errors, two of which were witnessed by a regional administrator on tour, led to a staffing increase of about 15 percent, to 53 controllers during the day and 58 at night.
The office that handles flight control for the New York area, in Westbury, L.I., is the New York Tracon, for Terminal Radar Control. The Tracon covers an area of 140 miles by 150 miles, between Montauk point, Kingston, N.Y., the Delaware River and Trenton, N.J.
It handles planes at La Guardia, Kennedy, Newark, White Plains, Teterboro, Long Island-MacArthur and 44 smaller fields. Local controllers in the airport towers hand off planes to the Tracon, and the Tracon hands them off again to another air traffic post, the New York Center, which is in Ronkonkoma.
On Aug. 22, Arlene B. Feldman, who had recently been appointed as regional administrator, was touring the Tracon, a darkened room about 100 feet by 80 feet, with walls and ceiling of acoustic panels. Just then, a controller inadvertently directed an airplane under his control into the airspace of another controller.
As procedures require, the controller was relieved of his post, said Phil Barbarello, the president of the Tracon chapter of the National Air Traffic Controllers Association, the union formed after President Reagan broke the previous union by dismissing most of its members in the 1981 strike. But with no one else handy, Mr. Barbarello, who was accompanying Ms. Feldman on the tour, took over at the circular green radar screen himself.
Shortly afterward, said Mr. Barbarello, the automatic equipment in the sector he had just taken over sounded a conflict alert alarm, a speaker that beeps a little like the alarm on a truck moving in reverse; a Concorde departing from Kennedy was moving too close to a Piper Cherokee.
Three days later, the center began using overtime to increase staff levels, reducing the practice of combining two geographic sectors for one controller to handle, and adding a second controller to most sectors.
The effect was not only to drive down the error rate, but, according to the union and the center's management, to improve operations at the three airports.
The average time between push-back from the gate and takeoff fell at Newark to 13.5 minutes from 15.1 for the two months beginning Aug. 23 last year compared with the two months beginning June 23, according to data from the Air Transport Association, the trade association of the airlines. At Kennedy, it fell to 14.2 minutes from 18.8 minutes and at La Guardia, to 13.7 minutes from 14.9.
The union, calculating an average aircraft operating cost of $35 a minute, estimates that cutting the delays saved $7.5 million on the ground for the two-month period.
Adding controllers has also sped planes in the air, the union says; with more controllers on duty, they have been able to fill requests by faster planes to overtake slower planes, or to fly more direct routes, both of which require extra instructions between the cockpit and the ground. They have also been able to direct planes to cruising altitude more quickly, allowing faster travel and fuel economy, officials say.
To reduce overtime, the Tracon needs 244 controllers, rather than its present staffing of 195, said a report in January by a special F.A.A. study team. Last month the F.A.A. suggested to the controller's union that all controllers' vacations be canceled this summer. Now, said F.A.A. managers and union officials at the center, they are working instead on a contingency plan to impose the "ground delay program."
The holds, said Michael J. McCormick, the F.A.A.'s assistant air traffic manager at the Tracon, would be "like the ones for major weather events," except that they would be scheduled far in advance and last for weeks. The result would be to "spread demand to the airports over a longer time."
The center would not cut the flights itself, but officials there say that when they impose ground delays, the airlines are certain to cancel 170 to 200 flights that were supposed to stop in New York on their way to other destinations, because those planes must still fly the rest of their trips. The three airports record about 6,000 "operations," or takeoffs plus landings, a day, equalling 3,000 flights.
The plan is to be presented to F.A.A. regional officials today, and to headquarters officials on Friday. At F.A.A. headquarters in Washington, Monte R. Belger, Associate Administrator for Air Traffic Services, said in a telephone interview on Friday that more resources would probably be found, but that it was a stopgap measure.
He said that neither service nor safety would be reduced.
Many controllers say that eight months of mandatory six-day weeks, even at overtime pay of $50 an hour, is more than enough in a high-stress job. Mr. Barbarello, the union president, complained in a letter recently to the Transportation Secretary, Federico F. Pena, that this was a "Band-Aid solution" and that more hiring is needed.
At the Air Transport Association in Washington, John R. Ryan, a vice president, said, "They don't want to be working six-day weeks, and we don't want them working six-day weeks, and we need a long-term solution. What we don't need is a demoralized work force up there."
Air traffic controllers, who are Federal employees and forbidden to strike, had complained of understaffing and job fatigue even before Aug. 3, 1981, when about 13,000 of the nation's 17,000 controllers walked out in a demand for a shorter workweek, as well as better wage and retirement benefits. Two days later, President Reagan dismissed about 11,400 who had failed to return, and later fought efforts to hire any of them back for the F.A.A.
Mr. Belger said that his office had recently approved the hiring of 10 of the controllers dismissed for striking in 1981, five for the Tracon and five for the New York Center. In addition, he said, the F.A.A. had found "8 to 10" controllers around the country who would be willing to move to New York.
The former strikers, who used to work in New York, could be on the job within months after re-hiring.

HEADLINE: Clark Accepts Increased Bid From Ingersoll

BYLINE: By SUSAN ANTILLA 

 BODY:
Less than two weeks after snubbing a hostile bid for $1.34 billion by the Ingersoll-Rand Company, the Clark Equipment Company yielded yesterday and accepted an improved offer of $1.46 billion.
The merger, approved by the boards of both companies, would create an industrial giant with combined sales of nearly $5.5 billion and more than 40,000 employees. 
 "It strikes me as pretty quick, but at the end of the day, I guess Clark recognized that it was a goner," said George Kellner, a partner at Kellner, DiLeo, a New York arbitrage firm that had purchased shares of Clark. "And Ingersoll is probably as good a buyer as any."
The cash merger, at a price of $86 a share for Clark stockholders, represents a slight premium to Friday's closing price of $84.125 for Clark. The initial Ingersoll bid of $75 to $77 a share was made in mid-March, and was rejected by Clark's board.
Clark, based in South Bend, Ind., manufactures construction machinery, forklifts and truck transmissions, among other products. Ingersoll, of Woodcliff Lake, N.J., makes air compressors, vacuum pumps, mining equipment and other industrial machines.
Ingersoll took its bid directly to Clark's shareholders, going public with its offer after the close of trading on March 28, when Clark had closed at $53.125. By the close of trading the following day, Clark shares had soared to $81.25 as investors placed bets that Clark, one way or another, would be forced into a sale at an even higher price.
A $77-a-share tender offer was begun by Ingersoll on April 3. Clark management, in the meantime, communicated with a number of potential suitors, none of whom was apparently able to match the price at which Clark was trading after the news of the Ingersoll offer.
After initially rejecting the offer, Leo J. McKernan, Clark's chief executive, agreed to meet with James E. Perrella, his counterpart at Ingersoll, on Friday evening at the St. Regis Hotel in Manhattan. By 12:30 P.M. yesterday, the Clark board was meeting at the St. Regis to vote on the proposed merger. Two and a half hours later, the Ingersoll board met in the offices of its law firm, Simpson Thacher & Bartlett.
"It might trade at a slight discount to the deal price Monday," said James Pierce, an analyst at PNC Financial, which owns shares of Clark. After a merger is announced, the stock of the target company often trades slightly below the deal price as takeover speculators bail out, not wishing to tie up their money waiting for the deal to be consummated, he said.
Mr. Kellner added, however, that the outside possibility of another bidder might push the stock up from Friday's close, meaning that Clark could trade in a range of $84.125 to $86. "There is always the chance that someone comes from left field," he said.
Mr. Pierce said, "The odds are not very great for a competing offer." Still, a number of analysts have mentioned Deere & Company as a possible suitor for Clark. Deere's management has said that it is interested in making acquisitions, and the company has $245 million of cash and marketable securities on hand.
Ingersoll could have bid as high as $95 a share without having diluted its earnings, said Tobias M. Levkovich, an analyst at Smith Barney. "However -- and there is a big however here -- there is a concern that if you pay a fairly full price, you might be doing that at the peak of the economic cycle," he said.
Mr. Levkovich said that given the uncertainties of the economy, $86 a share "seems reasonable -- they're not paying top dollar at the top of the cycle."
Economists are divided as to whether heavy industry will enjoy a soft landing from the economic recovery, a benign downturn or a recession. The last possibility would mean that Ingersoll had purchased Clark at the worst possible point in the economic cycle.
Clark's chief executive, Leo J. McKernan, in a statement yesterday, said the merger "delivers fair value to our shareholders and also provides our employees with excellent opportunities within the framework of a fine company like Ingersoll-Rand."
A person close to the deal said that it was "unresolved whether McKernan would continue in an active role or not, but that it was Ingersoll's intention to hold on to "the operating management" of Clark. Later this week, Clark is expected to file documents with the Securities and Exchange Commission that will, among other things, outline the severance agreements of top executives who will not be remaining at Clark.
Asked whether jobs would be lost in the merger, this person replied, "Their businesses are great; their management seems great, but their headquarters may be superfluous."
Joanne Tremulis, a spokeswoman for Clark at the Chicago office of the public relations firm of Burson Marsteller, said Clark's management team was on the way back from New York to South Bend and could not be reached for comment.
But any bidder emerging at this point would have to take on an additional nuisance cost. Under the terms of the deal, Ingersoll would be paid a $35 million breakup fee by Clark in the event that the merger did not take place, said Robert Friedman, the Simpson Thacher law partner in charge of the transaction from Ingersoll's side. With 17 million shares outstanding, that would cost a new bidder $2 a share from Clark's coffers to complete the deal. And, of course, another bidder would have to better the price that Ingersoll is willing to pay.
The shares of Ingersoll-Rand closed Friday at $33.125, down 25 cents, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: California's Democrats Avert Split Over Affirmative Action

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. 

DATELINE: ACRAMENTO, Calif., April 9

 BODY:
With President Clinton leading the way, the Democratic Party of California managed to avoid a public split here this weekend over what to do about affirmative action.
It adopted a "yes, but . . . " approach to the issue, vowing to hold the line on special economic and education programs, yet pointedly stating that affirmative action "does not mean quotas or arbitrary preferential treatment." 
 But while that approach kept the peace here in Sacramento this weekend, the affirmative-action issue will almost surely rise to bedevil the party -- and Mr. Clinton -- on another day, maybe every day until Election Day 1996.
California is the birthplace of the movement to ban affirmative action by putting it to a public vote. Polls indicate about two of every three Californians favor such a ban, including a majority of Democrats.
California also happens to be the "must-carry" state in Presidential politics. And the odds are, at least at this point, that both Mr. Clinton and affirmative action will be on the 1996 California ballot.
So an interesting and probably instructive political exercise unfolded when Mr. Clinton flew here for a Saturday address to the annual convention of the California Democratic Party and, not incidentally, to kick off his campaign to win the Golden State in '96.
He did not speak definitively on the affirmative-action issue, which he has his aides studying, but he gave a pretty good indication of where he was headed and a pretty good indication of where he would like to see California and the rest of the country head.
First, he counseled civil debate. "Don't scream," he told the 2,100 delegates. Then he put in a plug for "angry white males" -- his words -- saying with surprising frankness that this was a "psychologically difficult time" for them. And finally, he laid out his vision of what the affirmative-action debate should cover.
"We don't have to retreat from these affirmative-action programs that have done great things for the American people," he said. "But we do have to ask ourselves: Are they working? Are they fair? Has there been any kind of reverse discrimination?"
The conventioneers, mostly representing the more liberal and active spectrum of the party, found this approach reasonable enough and erupted in applause.
Among top party leaders, only Willie L. Brown Jr., the powerful black Assembly Speaker, was openly critical.
"Disappointed, absolutely," he said.
But then Mr. Brown, ever politic and civil, called the President "principled." And this morning, after less than 15 minutes of civil debate, the convention unanimously passed a resolution that condemned efforts to ban affirmative action but -- to use Mr. Clinton's mollifying conjunctive -- also gave a nod to angry white males.
Affirmative action, the resolution's lead clause prominently stated, "does not mean quotas or arbitrary preferential treatment."
Imola Henry, a black Los Angeles teacher who wrote much of the resolution, said it was a "reflect-but-don't-retreat" approach to affirmative action.
Will the rest of the party find it reasonable enough and buy it? Will it work as a national approach? And what about the Republicans?
One veteran Democratic consultant here, Ron Gray, called it "a tough sell to voters, even to Democratic voters."
As for Republicans, even before Mr. Clinton arrived in Sacramento, they were spoiling for an affirmative-action fight.
The state's Republican Governor, Pete Wilson, is an all-but-announced Presidential candidate and an all-out opponent of affirmative action. Last fall, he adroitly rode Proposition 187, the hotly disputed immigration-control ballot initiative, to a re-election victory that once seemed all but impossible. Now he sees the affirmative-action issue in a similar political light, a way to drive a wedge straight into the ideological heart of the traditional Democratic coalition, not just in California but all over the nation.
Pointedly, just as Air Force One was landing here on Friday, Mr. Wilson's office announced that he planned to abolish all state boards and panels that monitor and promote affirmative action.
Bill Press, the California party chairman, immediately tried to head off what would be the next day's lead headline in The Sacramento Bee: "Demos, Wilson Square Off in Affirmative Action Fight."
"This convention is not about affirmative action," he declared. "This convention is about Bill Clinton."
As it turned out, it was about both.

HEADLINE: PULSE;
Conventions

 BODY:
Unlike New York City's tourism industry, which has turned around as the city inched out of the recession, the convention business has yet to bounce back. The Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, the premier site for large shows, has been trying for years to reverse a decline in attendance; the number of events dropped by a third from 1989 to 1993. And in 1994, the center saw increases in shows and attendance. Center officials say they are finally beginning to crack the stubborn issues that have hobbled the hall since it opened: high costs, tough union rules, mob intrusion and thefts. And now, with the improved economy, officials expect to see the city's convention business follow the upswing of the tourism industry.

Dollar Plunges Again; Bank of Japan Intervenes
 The dollar crashed to a postwar low in trading this morning, falling more than 4 percent to 80.15 yen before the Bank of Japan swept in to support it. 
 Japan's Finance Minister, Masayoshia Takemura, said Washington needed to act more decisively to support the dollar and said he would press Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin when they met in Indonesia later this week. Page A1.
 
Deal Struck on MCA, But Questions Abound
 Seagram and Matsushita announced the precise terms of the sale of MCA: Seagram will pay $5.7 billion for 80 percent of the entertainment company, which includes Universal Pictures, MCA and Geffen Records. Now the questions are who will run MCA, and what will Seagram do with its 15 percent stake in Time Warner. Seagram is also getting into one of the fastest-growing businesses in entertainment, music. A1 and D8.
 
An Air-Controller Shortage
 The shortage of air traffic controllers in the New York area is so severe that a mandatory six-day week has been instituted. Local officials say flights into the area might have to be reduced during the summer, but F.A.A. officials say it is more likely that the agency will provide more money for overtime to avoid a "ground delay program." Nationally, the F.A.A. says, it has nearly the number of controllers it needs, but in the New York region there has long been a shortage. A1.

Restraint From Baseball Owners
 In two days of contract signing, without imposed or negotiated constraints, clubs showed that they were capable of exercising self-control. A stunning example of their efforts can be seen in the drastic pay cuts they required of 17 free agents who signed over the weekend. Since salaries started escalating with free agency in 1976, owners have asked the players to help them protect themselves from themselves. C6.
 
Uncertainties for Chinese Peasants
 Many of China's peasants are better off than 5 or 10 years ago, but their margin of economic safety remains perilously thin. Soaring farm costs and land policies that could take away their livelihood overnight have done little to add stability in the countryside. A4.

Smoking Rules for Restaurants
 New York City restaurants are scrambling to comply with smoking regulations that take effect today. Some restaurateurs say they worry about the impact the regulations will have on business. Under the new law, smoking will be permitted at the bar of a restaurant if the dining tables are at least six feet away or if the bar area is separated from the dining area by a floor-to-ceiling partition. B1.

Apple Clones On the Way
 Having licensed the Macintosh operating system, Apple Computer is about to face the consequences as the first Mac clones come to market. Some industry analysts have called the strategy Apple's only hope for increasing its 11 percent share of the personal computer market and for mounting a credible challenge to Compaq, Packard-Bell and other computer makers. Laurie Flynn: Executive Computer. D7.

Software to Listen By
 Progressive Networks is expected to introduce Real Audio Player today. The groundbreaking software program lets World Wide Web browsers choose audio clips from a menu and begin listening to them immediately. D6.
 
Hoping for a Home Run
 Using new motion-capture technology to record body movements and an image scanner to record facial expressions, Acclaim Entertainment says its baseball video game, starring Frank Thomas, will provide the most realistic action of any video game. D6.
 
'Open Skies' Talks Resume
 The United States and Britain resume long-running negotiations on ending restrictions on airline services between the two countries. D2.

 Dropping its "new traditionalist" advertising campaign, Good Housekeeping will ask people to pay more attention to its editorial content. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. D10.

HEADLINE: Carol Bellamy Is Appointed Unicef's Head

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, April 10

 BODY:
Carol Bellamy, the director of the Peace Corps and a former New York City Council President, has been named executive director of Unicef, the United Nations Children's Fund, the United Nations announced today.
Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali selected Ms. Bellamy over several European candidates, including Elizabeth Rehm, the former Defense Minister of Finland. Anne-Marie Lizin, a Belgian politician, was also nominated by the European Union. 
 The job has been held by an American since the agency was founded in 1946. The United States contributes about 25 percent of the budget for Unicef, which provides aid for children worldwide in education and other areas of child development.
The United States originally backed William H. Foege, a physician and the former director of the Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta, to replace James Grant, the previous Unicef executive director, who died on Jan. 28.
But the United States offered new candidates, including four women, after Mr. Boutros-Ghali made it clear that he wanted to appoint a woman to the position. He has been under pressure to increase the number of women in management roles at the United Nations.
The European Union had lobbied strongly for the post, led by France. It argued that the 15-nation group collectively donated more money to Unicef than did the United States. Although two of the European Union's candidates were women, Britain continued to support Rochard Jolly, the British deputy director of Unicef who has been serving as acting executive director, for the position.
Ms. Bellamy spent five years in the New York State Senate in the early 1970's and in 1976 became the first woman to be president of the New York City Council, a position she held until 1985.
She was defeated in a close race for state Comptroller in 1990 by Edward V. Regan, and then lost out to H. Carl McCall for an appointment to the position following Mr. Regan's resignation. She also lost a primary race for the United States Senate in 1992.
She was appointed director of the Peace Corps in 1993 by President Clinton. For two years, beginning in 1963, she had been a volunteer in Guatemala for the Peace Corps, which sends volunteers to more than 90 countries.
Before being appointed Peace Corps director, she worked at a Wall Street investment firm.
As executive Director of Unicef, Mr. Grant was credited with saving millions of young lives by promoting simple, low-cost methods to prevent the spread of disease and to treat debilitating conditions like diarrhea.
Unicef is facing a series of problems however, including a corruption scandal in its headquarters in Nairobi, Kenya. It also has had unfavorable management reviews and audits, including criticism of a practice of paying salary supplements for officials in some countries in which the program operates.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Biography

Dollar Recovers as Officials Argue Over Responsibility
The dollar recovered to 84.02 yen in New York after one of its most sharp declines in modern times earlier in the day, falling 4 percent to 80.15 yen. The drop intensified a bitter round of finger-pointing by America's main economic rivals about who bears the responsibility for fixing the problem. 
 American officials and their counterparts abroad debated whether to intervene, but apart from Japan's central bank, they did not act. Still, traders became fearful of losing billions if they were caught short, and they began a buying spree that brought the dollar back somewhat. A1.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
AS DOLLAR FALLS, ECONOMIC POWERS BLAME EACH OTHER

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 10

 BODY:
The dollar recovered today from a terrifying ride, and the market gyrations intensified a bitter round of finger-pointing by the United States' main economic rivals about who bears responsibility for fixing a problem that threatens to reshape financial relationships around the world.
The dollar, which had plunged in Tokyo this morning to a postwar low of 80.15 yen, rebounded to settle at 84.02 yen in New York trading late in the day, up from 83.82 yen Friday. 
Government officials and traders alike said it was unclear whether the rebound marked the end of a three-month-long concerted attack by speculators, or was just a lull in a longer decline.
Either way, the gyrations have exposed a wide rift among leaders of the world's three most powerful economies -- the United States, Japan and Germany -- concerning both the causes and the solution of the dollar's decline at a time the American economy looks healthier than it has in years.
Last week, Germany's Finance Minister said his country and other Western nations could not make up for "national deficiencies," an allusion to Washington's huge budget and trade deficits.
Today, the criticism came from Japan's Finance Minister, Masayoshi Takemura, who told Parliament in Tokyo, "I want the United States to feel responsible and make a clear stance to defend the dollar."
Mr. Takemura then rattled the markets further, questioning whether the system of free-floating exchange rates, adopted in 1973, should be reconsidered so that governments had greater influence over the value of their currencies.
"We also need to think whether we can leave the current exchange-rate system as it is now," said Mr. Takemura, a politician with no economic experience, who gained his portfolio last year as part of a political compromise that brought the current Japanese Government to power.
As he spoke, the dollar had already begun one of the most precipitous declines in modern times, a selloff that at one point sent it tumbling 4 percent in a few hours and set off alarms at finance ministries around the world.
In a quick round of consultations, American officials and their counterparts abroad debated whether to intervene in the markets again, buying dollars. The Japanese acted, but the rest did not -- perhaps mindful of Washington's experience last week, when it moved to prop up its currency, only to see it overwhelmed by speculators who drove it back down.
This time, only the anticipation of central-bank intervention seemed to be needed. Traders feared losing billions if they were caught out of the markets, and began a buying spree that brought the dollar back to a level just above where it had closed Friday.
Indeed, the dollar advanced against other leading leading currencies today, as well. It made its biggest one-day gain against the German mark since August, rising to 1.41 marks from 1.3779 on Friday.
These market pyrotechnics only underlined the contrast with actions of the big economic allies in the mid-1980's, when world capitals were filled with talk of "coordination" among the economic powers to adjust the exchange values of their currencies. No one uses that word anymore. And in the absence of a united front, the markets are moving according to their own logic and passions.
"There is really nothing called coordination anymore, in any sense," said John Williamson, a senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics in Washington. "The G-7 has lost whatever abilities it had as an institution," he said, referring in official shorthand to the Group of Seven, some of the world's leading industrial nations. "There is a lot they could do to prevent crises like this if they wanted to, but there seem to be little incentive to do so."
That is certainly true in the United States and Germany. For President Clinton, a 16.4 percent decline in the value of the dollar against the yen in the last three months is worrisome but not a political liability, unless the rising price of imports brings on inflation or unless stock and bond markets in this country begin to suffer. Mr. Clinton has barely mentioned the matter in recent weeks -- he said recently that he could only get into trouble commenting on the markets -- and none of his likely Republican opponents in next year's election has taken up the issue.
Moreover, the President's advisers contend that the dollar has not declined against most world currencies, only against the yen and the mark. The decline against the yen has been the more spectacular, and they cite this as evidence that the problem lies in Tokyo and will not be resolved until the Japanese open their markets, allowing a narrowing of a trade deficit that runs $60 billion a year.
While the dollar rose sharply against the mark today, there is no political urgency in Germany to send the dollar higher. Rather, there seems a willingness to absorb some higher unemployment rates -- touched off by German companies that move production elsewhere -- in return for the power that a strong currency gives Germany over its European rivals.
Presumably, the Japanese Government is under great pressure at home to stem the yen's rise. At these levels, few Japanese manufacturers who produce primarily for export, particularly the makers of automobiles and electronics equipment, can eke out a profit; even after squeezing down the profit margins they would accept during the last few years, most are geared to produce goods at roughly 100 yen to the dollar.
As a result, Japanese business has been demanding official action, and Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama has said he will announce an economic-stimulus program by Friday to help small and medium-size companies, in particular. But such programs have been announced in the past and have rarely done much good.
No one in the Japanese Government is seriously talking about stimulating imports -- the one step that would most likely affect the dollar -- because they know that this is a two-edged sword. At times like these, Japanese companies are forced to make their money in the domestic market, where their income is in yen, not in devalued dollars. That, in turn, means that they are more resistant than ever to opening markets to foreign goods, as Washington wants.
Moreover, the trade deficit has been around so long that negotiators could commission a statue in its honor, so evidently other forces are at work. Many economists and officials guess that Japanese are making a worldwide move back to keeping their assets in yen, rather than recycling their trade surpluses back into dollars. For example, as soon as the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company completes its sale of 80 percent of MCA, the movie studio, $5.9 billion that it has kept in Hollywood will return to Japan.
What American officials do not know, and are desperately trying to determine, is whether Japan's powerful Finance Ministry is secretly happy to see the yen at these levels, because it gives the country so much more financial influence elsewhere in Asia.
Nor do they know if Mr. Takemura's comments today calling for greater Government control over exchange rates was his own, off-the-top-of-the-head idea, or whether it marked an effort by the bureaucrats who run his ministry to seize more control for themselves.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Weighing Goldman, Sachs's role in the Rockefeller Center trust.

BYLINE: By Stephanie Strom 

 BODY:
INVESTORS in Rockefeller Center Properties Inc., a real estate investment trust, might want to think twice about approving a proposed amendment to its charter.
The management of the trust is recommending that shareholders discard a provision of the charter that prohibits any entity from beneficially owning a stake larger than 9.8 percent of the total shares outstanding. 
 That would clear the way for Goldman, Sachs & Company and its $1 billion Whitehall Street Real Estate Fund L.P. to buy a 19.9 percent stake in the trust.
But what management does not say in the proxy outlining the amendment is that by winning the support of just one-tenth of 1 percent more of the trust's shareholders, Goldman could control the destiny of the trust and by extension the destiny of Rockefeller Center, one of the country's most fabled, but fickle, developments.
The Mitsubishi Estate Company owns 80 percent of 12 Art Deco buildings at Rockefeller Center and almost all 12 acres of the prime Manhattan real estate on which they sit. The Rockefeller family owns the other 20 percent.
The trust owns the $1.3 billion mortgage on Rockefeller Center, the terms of which have been nigh impossible to meet as the Manhattan commercial real estate market has crumbled.
Goldman first got into the picture by underwriting the initial public offering of the trust in 1985, which raised the money to make the mortgage on Rockefeller Center. And last December it bailed the trust out of a cash squeeze unrelated to Rockefeller Center, when Goldman bought $150 million of floating-rate notes and Whitehall purchased $75 million of debentures with an interest rate of 14 percent.
But that debt also made Goldman a shareholder in the trust by giving it and its Whitehall affiliate the right, in the form of warrants and stock appreciation rights, to buy a 19.9 percent stake in Rockefeller Center Properties at $5 a share -- or a 75 percent discount to the price that the shares of the trust fetched when Goldman took it public.
Under the Rockefeller Center Properties charter, any large transaction affecting the trust must be approved by at least 80 percent of its shareholders. If the amendment is approved and Goldman buys 19.9 percent of the stock, it will be able to block any significant proposal not to its liking unless virtually every other shareholder -- and there are 60,000 of them -- votes in favor of it.
If, for instance, a buyer like Mitsubishi came along and offered shareholders $9 a share for their holdings, which would enable the buyer to buy back the mortgage at a discount and give shareholders a premium to the $6.625 each share fetched yesterday, Goldman would have the ability to say no and make it stick. And if the trust had an opportunity to refinance the debt that gives Goldman a current return of roughly 20 percent a year , Goldman would at the least have a powerful protest vote. Some shareholders fear that Goldman might be willing to oppose anything that threatened that handsome return. After all, Goldman can cash out of its shares five years from now and still make money, but the trust's regular shareholders would benefit more from an immediate sale.
Richard M. Scarlata, president and chief executive of Rockefeller Center Properties, conceded that the amendment he and management had proposed would give Goldman "a very significant vote."
But he insisted that Goldman could not control the destiny of the trust, "not if the other shareholders vote the other way. Goldman would represent 19.9 percent, while the other shareholders would control 80.1 percent of the vote."
But shareholders might be less comfortable with such slim protection -- one-tenth of 1 percent of the stock of the trust plus one share, or 38,261 shares, from Goldman's domination.
Of course, Goldman could behave otherwise. "When it comes time to negotiate with Mitsubishi and the Rockefeller Group, having Goldman with a 20 percent position and a seat on the board is a big plus," said Fred Carr, principal in the Penobscot Group Inc., which analyzes publicly traded real estate trusts.
"But," he added, "Goldman's interests are not 100 percent parallel with the other shareholders, and there might come a time when they find themselves in a zero-sum relationship."
Mr. Carr and others are worried about Goldman, because they compare the role of the firm in the continuing Rockefeller Center drama to its part in the reorganization of Cadillac Fairview Inc., a bankrupt Canadian property developer. Whitehall owns a big chunk of the Cadillac Fairview senior debt, and in angling to get a hefty return on its investment it has stepped on the toes of some of Goldman's clients who stand behind it in the line of creditors waiting to be repaid.
Those clients, which include the California Public Employees Retirement System, known as Calpers, Fidelity Management and Research, the Trust Company of the West and Mutual Series funds of the investor Michael F. Price contend that Whitehall has pursued its interests at their expense, which is considered the height of bad form in the client-conscious world of investment banking. Calpers and Fidelity have reportedly reduced their business with Goldman in a huff over Whitehall's behavior in the Cadillac case.
