HEADLINE: Rethinking Welfare: Deterring New Births -- A special report.;
State Aid Is Capped, but to What Effect?

BYLINE: By MELINDA HENNEBERGER 

DATELINE: CAMDEN, N.J.

 BODY:
At 16, Naikeya Haley decided to have a second child despite the state law that denied her extra welfare benefits because she was already receiving aid.
"It was a planned pregnancy," said Ms. Haley, who is now 17. The law that kept her from collecting $102 more a month "doesn't make any difference to me," she said flatly, other than to make it that much harder to provide for her family. She and her two daughters live on $322 a month, and stay with friends. 
 Almost immediately after limiting new welfare payments in 1993, New Jersey officials began saying that the "family cap" was dramatically reducing the birth rate among welfare mothers. The law served as a model for similar policies in the works in nine other states. And now Republicans in Congress want to copy it, too. A bill that has passed the House and is now before the Senate would prohibit use of Federal money to give extra benefits for new babies born to families on welfare who already have children.
But researchers who have studied the New Jersey experience, and most of the several dozen recipients interviewed for this article, say they are not at all convinced that the state policy keeps women from having babies. Some raised questions about whether the state can -- or indeed should -- regulate complicated sexual and reproductive decisions.
Now, New Jersey welfare officials are themselves backing away from their earlier contentions, saying it may be too soon to prove any effects on childbearing.
"We don't have the numbers" to show a link between the cap and a decreasing birth rate, said William J. Maguire, director of Camden County's Family Development Program, which enforces the cap.
Even those who support the policy are saying that it was never intended to lower the birth rate, but simply to encourage welfare recipients to make more responsible decisions.
The law, which went into effect in August 1993 under former Gov. Jim Florio, was almost immediately pronounced a triumph by New Jersey officials. After only two months, the state released numbers suggesting that births to welfare mothers had already fallen by 16 percent, and officials began congratulating themselves on their overnight success.
But over time, that 16 percent drop dwindled to about 10 percent as the state belatedly became aware of births that had not been reported earlier. It appeared that many mothers saw no reason to report the new births since their welfare benefits were not being increased.
And now even that lower number is being questioned, both because of a continued reporting lag and because some officials argue that the number of women who have more children while on welfare is so small that the important-sounding 10 percent drop may not mean much. Nationally, the average recipient of Aid to Families with Dependent Children, the main Federal welfare program, has 1.9 children.
The Department of Health and Human Services in Washington estimates that under the proposed national policy of denying extra benefits for new children, about one million children would be affected after five years, and ultimately 2.2 million. Currently, about 10 million children receive A.F.D.C. benefits.
In the first year that the cap was in place in New Jersey, the state denied cash benefits to 6,267 children born to existing A.F.D.C. recipients. There are 123,000 families receiving cash benefits in the state, and that number has stayed constant since the cap was put in place.
The numbers suggest that the cap saved the state more than $2 million that year, but state officials said they had not calculated the exact savings, both because they were relatively modest and because saving money was not the goal of the program. Also, the cap had been adopted as part of a broader law that increased spending on job training, child care and economic development, which pushed up the state's overall welfare spending.
Even as the rest of the country seems to be rushing to replicate the New Jersey experiment, most welfare officials here say they have adopted a wait-and-see attitude about the impact.
"We got a little burned with some of the early numbers," said William Waldman, New Jersey's Human Services Commissioner, who says he has mixed feelings about the program. "So we've been reticent to give them out."
 
 
The Concerns
Will More Women Have Abortions?
 In Congress, the cap has become one of the most divisive elements of the proposed legislation because some Republicans who support other get-tough measures in the package fear that this disincentive for childbearing may work all too well, encouraging more poor women to seek abortions.
In fact, it is all but impossible to tell whether the cap is driving up the abortion rate because state statistics are not available for the period after the cap went into effect.
A few New Jersey mothers said they would seriously consider abortion as a result of the law if they got pregnant again while on A.F.D.C.
"If I got pregnant again and they still had that law, I wouldn't" have the baby, said Betzaida Bermudez, 22, who was taking a short break from a computer class in Camden that she hopes will help make her independent.
"I guess I'd just have an abortion," she said, adding that she knows too many women who have had more children under the law but now find themselves unable to provide for them.
But Rudolph Myers, an anthropologist who is the state's project manager for evaluating the cap, said there was no evidence of the kind of decreased birth rate that would signal a marked increase in abortions.
"At first look, it looked like an astronomical drop in birth rates, like natural disaster demographics," Mr. Myers said, but now the numbers have leveled off. "I'm a little uncertain as to what this means. But it's kind of a stretch to imagine this made A.F.D.C. mothers stop conceiving children."
 
 
The Goals
Encouraging Responsibility
 Those who work more directly with welfare recipients seem even more skeptical that the policy has changed behavior. And state officials suggest that the program's goals have always been more symbolic or political than practical.
Of the stated Republican goal of reducing the number of births to unmarried welfare mothers, Mr. Waldman said: "We never set that as a goal of the program. And I wouldn't ever say people have children just to get more money from welfare. But a lot of what we do is very patronizing, and the idea was fundamentally that people should make responsible decisions just like people who are not on welfare."
Frank G. Spencer, a county official whose office in desperately poor Camden has a commanding view of the Philadelphia skyline, explained the policy as a way to extend equal responsibility to families on welfare.
"My employer doesn't give me an increase based on how many children I decide to have," he said. "There's only a picture of one child around here because that's all I can afford to educate."
And Mr. Maguire, of the Camden program, suggested that the family cap was actually a trade-off for conservatives who then went along with other aspects of the state's welfare overhaul, like more support for job training, child care and economic development.
"It was a necessary first step to appease----" he said, then broke off and started again. "It was a first step toward a more conservative mentality."
One true believer in the value of the controversial policy is its creator, Wayne R. Bryant, a New Jersey State Senator. Mr. Bryant, a Democrat, bristles that the law does not, as some critics suggest, tell welfare recipients that they cannot have more children, but simply encourages them to make responsible decisions. And he curtly dismisses the argument that under the policy, children will inevitably be hurt.
"If the kids are suffering because parents are irresponsible" in having children they cannot afford, he said, "they'll still suffer if we give them the money because the parents will still be irresponsible."
A recent convert to the cap is Judi Whitney, deputy director for Camden's program.
"Being a minority myself, I know the strength of poor people has been a strong work ethic," said Ms. Whitney, who is black. "But in our efforts to help, we've taken away from them what had been their inherent strength, which is to believe they can take care of their family."
"Do I think the birth rate is down as a result of the program?" she asked. "I don't know. I think the jury is probably still out. But is giving something always better than nothing?"
"Some parents have tried to keep things afloat on the extra $64," she continued, referring to the amount that recipients once received for any baby beyond a second child; they had received $102 for a second child born while on welfare.
"And that doesn't even provide Pampers and clothes for a new baby," Ms. Whitney added. "Five years ago, I thought, 'Oh my God, this will hurt the child.' Now I definitely don't believe that. If anyone is doing the hurting, I don't think the government is."
 
The Women
'Ground Beef Is Overrated'
 But a number of women like Cloran Davis, who had a fourth child last year while on A.F.D.C., said they nonetheless felt that the law was intrusive and unforgiving.
"They're telling us we can't have children, and I don't think that's right," said Ms. Davis, 26, of River Edge, N.J.
"It wasn't planned, but I wasn't going to abort her," Ms. Davis said. "Sixty-four dollars is not going to change my love for my child, and if I would have aborted her, it wouldn't have comforted my soul. Nobody ever said it was enjoyable to be on welfare. You just learn that a pound of ground beef is overrated."
Ms. Davis has worked at several jobs, including stints as a typist and in the stock room of the shoe department at Macy's, and has been schooled as a chef, but says that the cost of child care is a major problem.
"Far from me to say I'm the most educated person in the world, but we can't just stop and go to work when child care costs $300 a month for just one child, and that was my whole check," she said. State and Congressional leaders, she concluded, "don't know what it's like to have to wonder and struggle."
She added, "I'm not angry at anyone, but they just don't understand."
Other women spoke of some possible effects of the cap that were wholly unintended by lawmakers.
Melinda Thomas, 21, a mother of three, said, "I don't get nothing for my baby" in A.F.D.C. But she said she was not too concerned about losing $64 a month.
"The money just goes to paying bills anyway, so it really doesn't matter," she said. "Now food stamps, that does."
And Jessica Delgado, who has an infant daughter, said she thought welfare workers had tried to pressure her to terminate the pregnancy.
"They were telling me, 'Do you think you need to have another child?' said Ms. Delgado, a mother of two. "They treat you like they own you. But you can't buy my kids. If I have to start stripping, that's what I'll do" to support them.
Most women ridiculed the idea that they would have a child to get $64 a month more in welfare benefits, though many also said they were not so sure that other women were not having babies in the mistaken belief that it would make their lives easier.
But among researchers, there is even less consensus.
June E. O'Neill, the recently appointed director of the Congressional Budget Office, who was hired last year by the New Jersey Attorney General's office to assess the family cap, said the net change in income under the policy was quite modest, because other benefits, like food stamps, still increased along with family size.
Still, in following the cases of 4,500 New Jersey welfare mothers randomly assigned to family cap and control groups, Ms. O'Neill found that those affected by the cap had 20 percent fewer children. And she disputed the premise that many births go unreported for any length of time because she said mothers still had an incentive to collect extra food stamps and other non-cash benefits.
"It's like saying, 'If there's a discount on dresses, will more people buy them?' " she said. "In a birth, there are obviously some differences, but some people will" be affected by the economics of the situation in deciding whether or not to have a child.
"To say people have children without thinking about how to support them is a farfetched notion," Ms. O'Neill said. "Some are totally out of control, but a significant percentage know what they're doing."
Michael Laracy, a senior program associate with the Annie E. Casey Foundation in Baltimore, which studies public policy affecting the poor, and a former New Jersey welfare official, argues that there are so many other factors involved in decisions about sex and children that it is all but impossible to say how big a role economics actually plays in decisions about childbearing -- especially because the financial disincentive is relatively modest.
Mr. Laracy also said that no one had measured the adverse effects of the cap, like how many families had become homeless as a result.
Rutgers University researchers conducting a five-year study for the state of the effect of the cap have warned against drawing premature conclusions about it.
Whatever the researchers may find, some of those who are directly affected by the policy say it mostly translates into unpaid bills, dirty laundry and sacrifices of "extras" like vitamins and school supplies. And if it has only marginally changed their lives, they said, they do not feel it is for the better, at least in the short term.
At Camden Community College, welfare mothers preparing to take their high school equivalency examination were racing each other in working on ratios and doing pie charts.
"To me, they're still having babies whether they get $64 or not," said one of the students, Marilyn Dejesus, 27, who has two children. "It's going to be more hungry people in the streets, that's it."
Crystal Deloatch, 30, who has one daughter, just sighed and kept her eyes on her notebook. "Then they wonder why there are so many bad mothers," she said.

HEADLINE: What to Do With the Coliseum? Giuliani and M.T.A. in Deadlock

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY 

 BODY:
Nine months after the Giuliani administration and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority promised to cooperate in getting the most out of the old New York Coliseum, the two sides remain deadlocked over what to do with one of the most valuable pieces of potential development property in New York City.
At the heart of the stalemate is a basic disagreement. The M.T.A., which owns the site, wants to rent out the building in roughly its current condition and thus quickly begin a flow of cash to the transit system. 
 But Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and his aides are holding out for an extensive development plan that they hope would produce more jobs in the long run and that might include rebuilding the site and perhaps reconfiguring what planners see as one of the more jumbled intersections in Manhattan.
There has been no shortage of suitors for the site since a deal with the developer Mortimer B. Zuckerman collapsed last July.
Sears, Roebuck & Company, the giant retailing chain, has expressed interest in leasing the site for its first store in Manhattan, and 11 others responded to an M.T.A. request for formal proposals for the four-story space on a three-year lease. The proposals ranged from a roller skating rink to a movie production studio. One company was willing to pay $7 million a year in rent. But the city and the M.T.A. are at odds over the length of a lease.
At a time when both the city and the transportation authority are going through wrenching budget cuts, critics say the impasse represents a huge waste of money. The building remains virtually empty, with only a few trade shows each year.
"Virtually every week, the city announces a new round of service cuts or discovers yet another gap in its budget," said Ruth Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, who favors a long-term lease of the property. "It is unconscionable to allow this asset to go to waste."
Situated on the southwestern quadrant of Columbus Circle, the Coliseum is considered by many critics to be an uninspired remnant of the 1950's. In the early 1980's, as the Jacob Javits Convention Center was about to open, officials of the Edward I. Koch administration sought proposals for razing the Coliseum and an office building next door and building on the site.
The proposal chosen, a $455 million plan by Mr. Zuckerman to build a huge residential, retail and office complex, became bogged down almost immediately in lawsuits from planners and civic groups. By the early 1990's, after the real estate market collapsed, the plan had been scaled back several times, and it was abandoned last year.
So far, M.T.A. officials say, one of the highest rent offers for the space has come from the Related Companies, a real estate concern that wants to use the Coliseum for retail stores. The company is willing to pay about $10 million a year but only if given a 10- to 15-year lease.
Last month a broker with Garrick-Aug, a Manhattan-based retail leasing company, wrote to the M.T.A. on behalf Sears, saying that the retailer was "extremely interested in 250,000 to 300,000 square feet for a full-fledged department store." The proposal was for a minimum of 20 years at $6.2 million to $9 million a year.
Such undertakings require city approval, and the Giuliani administration has said that a 10-year lease is too confining. Forrest R. Taylor, a spokesman for John S. Dyson, the Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, said last week that the city "saw no reason to rush into something."
Recalling the Zuckerman project as "a protracted struggle," Mr. Taylor said, "When that ended, we had an opportunity to pull back, take a good look so that we could make a careful analysis to see how the Coliseum should be used in the future."
The Giuliani administration says it will make a formal recommendation to the M.T.A. board on the best use of the Coliseum once city officials have reviewed an economic and urban planning analysis of the Coliseum and its neighborhood.
M.T.A. officials were told to expect the review in early 1995, but they are still waiting. In more than one meeting, Mr. Dyson, who also sits on the M.T.A. board, has traded accusations with the M.T.A. staff over whom to blame for the delay.
In an interview, Mr. Taylor said the study would be ready "soon."
The M.T.A. is eager to rent the building for 10 years or more to pay for subway and bus improvements. But Giuliani aides have rejected the agency's plea three times over the past few months.
One M.T.A. board member, Peter S. Kalikow, said: "When we are cutting projects like the renovation of the 72d Street subway station from the capital program, then I have to ask what we are waiting for. We have an asset that is now earning zero."
He said that he understood the city's interest in seeing a project that would produce the most in tax revenue and jobs, but that his first concern was generating revenue for the transit system.
"I look on the Coliseum as strictly an adjunct to the M.T.A.'s capital program," said Mr. Kalikow, a real estate developer who was appointed to the board last fall by Mario M. Cuomo, then the Governor. "The Coliseum would have been of most value if we had been able to sell it. The next-best value comes from a long-term lease. It's that simple."
Last December, it seemed as if a truce had been declared between the city and the M.T.A. With the city's blessing, the M.T.A. decided to test the interests of potential tenants for a three-year lease of the exhibition hall. Under a partnership arrangement with the city, the agency has had the right to make a three-year deal, but officials have not accepted any current offers in the hope they could persuade the city to agree to a longer-term lease.
Among the companies submitting proposals for a three-year lease was Colossal Events Inc., a New Jersey-based concern that offered to pay nearly $7 million a year.
Last month, the M.T.A.'s chairman, Peter E. Stangl, renewed pleas to the city to go along with a long-term lease, saying in a letter to Mr. Giuliani that "annual rents under a three-year lease could be anywhere from $9 million to $3 million less than what would be attainable under a long-term lease."
M.T.A. officials denied that Mr. Stangl's letter to the Mayor was a sign that the agency had dropped the idea of signing a three-year tenant.
"All of the proposals are still under review," said John Cunningham, an M.T.A. spokesman. "We are not closing any doors."

HEADLINE: Public Gives Congress Good Marks, but Is Mixed on Gingrich

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 10

 BODY:
If the latest parade of opinion polls is any gauge, much of the public is enthusiastic that Republicans are getting more done in this Congress than Democrats did before. But at the same time, they say they have reservations about parts of what the aggressive new Congress is doing.
And their feelings toward the architect of the party's agenda, Speaker Newt Gingrich, are emphatically mixed.
Most of those trends appear in three surveys conducted in late March and early April for The New York Times and other news organizations. They suggest that Mr. Gingrich's brisk manner and attack-dog speaking style do not wear as well as the party he has lately come to symbolize. 
 That said, many who appear not to care much for Mr. Gingrich personally still give him decent marks as a strong leader with a coherent political vision. And many rate him a crucial factor in whatever political success the Republicans are enjoying.
For the most part, the polls record a sense among the public that the Republicans have run Congress effectively during their first 100 days in power. For example, a poll of 800 adults conducted for Time magazine and Cable News Network on March 29 and 30 showed that 58 percent said Republicans had done a good or very good job of running Congress; 33 percent rated their performance fair or poor.
In The New York Times/CBS News poll, conducted April 1-4, 57 percent of the 1,089 adults surveyed said they believed this Congress would get more done than have typical, previous Congresses.
A survey for USA Today and CNN by the Gallup Organization, conducted on April 5-6, drew a more divided response: Of the 802 people polled, 42 percent said the last three months of Congress had been a success; 40 percent rated them a failure.
Mr. Gingrich gets a healthy share of credit for whatever success the Republicans have enjoyed in the two polls that considered the issue. Fully 60 percent of those who replied in the Gallup poll said the party would have pushed fewer bills through Congress had Mr. Gingrich not been Speaker; 80 percent said he would be somewhat or very important to the party's legislative success in the next year.
Fifty-six percent in the poll rated Mr. Gingrich an effective leader, while 35 percent did not. Similarly, 51 percent of respondents to the Times poll said Mr. Gingrich had "strong qualities of leadership," compared with 30 percent who disagreed. The Time/CNN poll did not ask questions about Mr. Gingrich's leadership skills.
Still, with the exception of responses to one question, more people disapproved of Mr. Gingrich personally than approved of him. The exception was a Gallup poll question that asked citizens to evaluate their like or dislike of Mr. Gingrich on a 10-point scale. Exactly half of the respondents indicated they liked Mr. Gingrich at least a bit, with 6 percent giving him the highest rating. Among the other half, 18 percent gave Mr. Gingrich the lowest rating.
But in the same poll, respondents disapproved of what Mr. Gingrich "stands for politically" by 46 percent to 40 percent. The views of his "personal style" were similar: 49 percent disapproved while 40 percent approved.
And when asked to agree or disagree with specific descriptions of the Speaker's character, respondents in the Gallup poll showed clear preferences. Fifty-six percent agreed that he was too politically partisan, 48 percent thought him "thin-skinned about criticism," and 49 percent agreed that he was "reckless," as against 41 percent who said that description did not apply.
Fifty-one percent said Mr. Gingrich had a "clear vision for the future," and 49 percent said he keeps his promises.
In the Time/CNN poll, respondents disapproved of Mr. Gingrich's handling of his job by 47 percent to 41 percent. In the Times/CBS poll, respondents answered a nearly identical question by approving of Mr. Gingrich's performance, 39 percent to 34 percent. The remaining 27 percent either did not know or refused to answer.
The margins of sampling error in the Gallup and Time/CNN polls were four percentage points; the margin in the Time/CBS poll was three percentage points.

HEADLINE: Palestinians Seize 100 Militants Who Oppose Talks With Israel

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM 

DATELINE: GAZA, April 10

 BODY:
The Palestinian police announced today that they had arrested more than 100 members of Hamas and Islamic Holy War, the militant groups that took responsibility for two anti-Israeli bombings on Sunday in the Gaza Strip.
The death toll among victims of the bombings rose to eight, when an Israeli soldier and an American student died today. 
 This morning, a new military-style court set up by the Palestinian Authority to crack down on militants also issued its first sentence: a 34-year-old member of Islamic Holy War was sentenced to 15 years in jail on charges of training youths to attack Israelis.
The actions indicated a stiffening of Yasir Arafat's resolve to deal forcefully with the radical Palestinians who are challenging his authority. Senior Palestinian officials said that they would widen their crackdown, but that they remained persuaded that the only way to curb the violence would be to improve the economic situation in Gaza.
Despite the crackdown, there was defiance today from the militants.
Mahmoud Zahar, the most senior member of Hamas in Gaza, said in an interview at the Islamic University that the official moves were "empty gestures" and that similar tactics by the Israeli Army when it occupied Gaza had failed to end resistance.
Dr. Zahar, a physician and university professor, contended that Mr. Arafat would pay a heavy price in popularity for the arrests, but would not stop attacks against Jewish settlements in Gaza and targets in Israel.
The death toll among victims of Sunday's bombings rose to eight today with the death of the American student and an Israeli. The seven Israelis who died, five men and two women, were soldiers. More than 40 people were wounded. Two bombers also died.
The American student was Alisa M. Flatow, 20, a Brandeis University junior from West Orange, N.J., who had been spending a semester studying in Jerusalem. She had been traveling to a beach resort at a Jewish settlement in the Gaza Strip and was wounded in the head in the first of the bombings. Her father, Stephen, said some of her organs would be given to transplant patients.
Israel barred Palestinians from a six-mile stretch of Gaza's main north-south road between Kfar Darom and Netzarim, the Jewish settlements where the attacks occurred, Israeli security officials said today. Two roads linking the settlements with Israel were also closed.
In Khan Yunis, in the south of the Gaza Strip, the police exchanged fire with Hamas gunmen before arresting two of them, Palestinians said. There were no reports of injuries.
[The Palestinian police and Islamic militants exchanged fire in Gaza early on Tuesday, Reuters reported, quoting residents and officials. There were no reports of casualties.]
Nabil Abu Irdeina, Mr. Arafat's spokesman, said in an interview on Sunday that the Palestine Liberation Organization knows the "peace process is facing a real danger."
He contended that the "main danger to the whole process is Israel's constant search for excuses to delay its withdrawal from the West Bank and the rest of Gaza, and the economic strangulation of Gaza and the Palestinians."
A number of countries have committed funds to help the Palestinian Authority improve conditions, but most of the funds have yet to be delivered. In addition, from time to time Israel has barred Palestinian workers from entering Israel. Mr. Abu Irdeina said blocking the workers had aggravated the tensions among the million Palestinians living in the narrow Gaza Strip.
Still, today's sentencing by the special court and the roundup of suspects was meant to send a message both to Israel and to Islamic militants that the Palestinian Authority is serious about its efforts to stop attacks on Israeli targets.
The court sentenced the militant, Samir Ali el-Jedi, after an all-night trial that was closed to the public. Mr. Jedi had been charged with training Palestinians, including teen-agers, for suicide missions against Israelis, a copy of a judgment said. He is the first Palestinian sentenced to prison by the Palestinian Authority for anti-Israeli activities.
Today spokesmen for Hamas and Islamic Holy War, which oppose peace talks with Israel, said they would continue to attack Israelis.
"Arresting people will not solve the problem," said Dr. Zahar, of Hamas. "The Israelis have tried that before. The P.L.O. is doing the same thing now and getting the same reception. When they show up at homes to arrest our people, their cars are stoned and children spit at them."
Dr. Zahar said Hamas was determined to avoid a confrontation with the P.L.O. and with Mr. Arafat, the group's chairman. "Why should we have a confrontation with him?" he asked. "He is losing his popularity every time he uses the word 'terrorists' to describe Palestinians fighting against Israeli occupation."
There are indeed increasing signs that the P.L.O. is losing support.
On Friday, in what amounted to the first open election under the Palestinian Authority, Hamas adherents in the nurses' union won all 11 seats on the governing board. The Hamas supporters had run against a bloc of P.L.O. supporters and candidates from the leftist Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine.
Israel has argued that the suicide bombings and other attacks against its civilians and soldiers could lead it to reconsider whether self-rule will be expanded beyond Jericho to the rest of the West Bank. Sunday's killings brought to 64 the number of Israelis killed in attacks since October for which Hamas and Islamic Holy War have taken responsibility.
The P.L.O. contends that it is under siege both by Islamic militants and by Israeli hard-liners.
"We consider what happened yesterday to be a challenge against the people of Gaza and their interests," Mr. Abu Irdeina said, referring to the bombings. "We are being squeezed by extremists on both sides. But if we lose, the Israelis will lose too, and everyone will pay the price, which will be the death of the peace process itself."

HEADLINE: Latest Films for $ 2: Video Piracy Booms in Russia

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 10

 BODY:
Oscar fever does not usually run too high in Russia, but Aleksandr Boitsov is an enterprising man in a tough market. For the month or so before the Oscar ceremony last month, instead of just displaying the usual "Rocky" and Sharon Stone films, he pushed videocassettes of the year's major Academy Award nominees.
For a little more than $2 apiece, shoppers at the mammoth outdoor software and video market here can choose among "Pulp Fiction" (loosely translated as "Criminal Reading Material"), "Forrest Gump," "Nell" and many other video titles that are not even available yet in the United States. 
 But in Russia, where not long ago simply owning private property was a crime, there is still no genuine functioning legal system. Intellectual property is a vague, emerging concept that few understand and fewer care about. Copyright laws are flouted brazenly here, and there is almost no film, book, compact disc or computer software that cannot be found for a fraction of what it would cost in the United States.
"There is a law against this kind of theft," said Svetlana Abromovna, a senior researcher at the Institute of Civil Law in Moscow who has studied on intellectual property rights for 30 years. "But there are many laws in Russia that nobody takes seriously. There are no penalties."
Nobody who has spent as much as two hours strolling through Moscow could doubt that she speaks the truth. Nearly every kiosk, stall, store or market in the city sells videocassettes, compact discs and computer software at prices that would make any American customer reach for his or her wallet. But industry officials say almost all of these products have been copied illegally.
For every 100 copies of the hot computer game, Doom, which sells here for about $3, or Microsoft's immensely popular word processor, Word for Windows, which costs less than $10, perhaps only two have been sold through a licensed distributor, industry officials say. The rest are forged, and they vary in quality from perfect to unusable.
"I think it's worse there now than anywhere in the world," Steven Metalitz, vice president of the International Intellectual Property Alliance, a trade group based in Washington, said in a telephone interview. Last year alone, his organization says, American companies lost nearly $1 billion in revenues to Russians who illegally reproduce and sell copyrighted products.
"China and other Asian countries are now finally cleaning up their acts, but it seems like Russia is going in another direction," he said.
The rampant counterfeiting not only harms the people who have lost royalties but also makes it impossible for legal computer software designers and video distributors to make a living here.
Political leaders, who want Russia to be accepted as a member of the World Trade Organization and as a law-abiding nation, have vowed to crack down on violators. The Government has said it will adhere to international copyright standards and punish violators.
So far, however, the talk has not been matched by any enforcement effort.
"Private property -- whether it is land, a car or somebody else's idea -- is still the hardest thing for Russians today to understand," Ms. Abromovna said. "In principle, everyone is for it. But in fact, nothing is harder than convincing a Russian to leave other people's property alone."
A walk around the giant outdoor market at Mitino, on the northeast edge of the capital, is like a trip to a computer lover's ultimate cut-rate Disneyland, with acres of technical equipment, compact disks, videotapes and above all, computer software on display. Some stalls selling videocassettes of recent films proudly advertise that they sell "laser prints," the highest quality a bootleg outfit can offer. Most proprietors are glad to let a customer watch a bit of any movie that is for sale.
"The quality of these things is perfect," said Yevgeny Komarov, a 41-year-old television repairman, as he cruised the market recently for videos and other toys of technology. "How can you possibly do better than this? It doesn't even cost much money."
Mr. Komarov bought a copy of "Schindler's List" dubbed in Russian for $3. As with most of these dubbed bargains, though, one Russian actor records all parts. In the $2 version of "Pulp Fiction," for instance, John Travolta and Uma Thurman share not only some wild adventures, but also the same voice. Like most customers, Mr. Komarov said that did not bother him.
He also bought a compact disk of "Bob Dylan's Greatest Hits" for $4. And with great excitement, he spent $11 on a CD-ROM made by Microsoft called Professional Office Suite, which bundles a number of the company's most popular and expensive programs together. Egghead Software was selling the same program in Manhattan that week for $599.98.
"Why do people in the United States pay so much for software?" he asked earnestly when he was told American prices. "All you have to do is get one tape or disk and you can make a hundred copies. That's what's so great about computers."
His statements indicated that like many of his countrymen, Mr. Komarov has not had time to absorb the niceties of the royalty system or to think about the people he might deprive of income. When he was told that he was breaking the law, he burst into laughter and swept his arm in a slow circle across hundreds of costumers who were doing the same thing.
"Tell them," he said, "not me."
Trade groups like the intellectual property alliance and the Software Publishers Association -- which also says the software piracy rate in Russia is now the highest in the world -- have lobbied the United States Trade Representative's office about the problem.
A spokesman for the Trade Representative said that the United States took very seriously all violations of copyrights patented there, and that the office was aware that Russia was a serious abuser. He said the Commerce Department had made it clear to Russian leaders that trade between the countries could not improve unless compliance did.
Now that the United States has used the threat of trade sanctions to force China to agree to a much more vigorous effort against such piracy, these groups hope that the United States will turn its attention to the problem in Russia.
Late last year the Russian Government signed the two major international laws that protect copyrights, the Bern Convention and the Geneva Phonograms Convention. But copyright violations are still civil offenses, and until they are covered by criminal law, it is unlikely that they will have any teeth.
Even if stronger laws are passed and enforced, much of the damage will be hard to erase. The shops that copy software have become increasingly sophisticated. For instance, they can eliminate codes that force new users to register by requiring confirmation when they load the software. And a major educational effort would be needed to convince the average Russian who wants to play a few computer games with his children on the weekend that he ought to pay 10 times as much for them as he does now.
The biggest long-term loser, clearly, is the Russian economy itself. Few countries have produced more gifted and aggressive computer and electronics experts and engineers. Software is among the fastest growing industries in the world, and it is perfect for Russia: high-tech, low-capital and reliant on brain power.
But the industry here is moribund because good programmers have either left for the United States or have given up developing Russian software. After all, who can compete with $5 dollar versions of the world's best accounting software?
"This was really one of our great prides," said Viktor A. Pavelev, a senior computer programmer at the International Investment Bank in Moscow.
Mr. Pavelev said that during the more than two decades he spent working for the Soviet Government, "leaders from I.B.M. and other major American companies would travel here to see how we did things -- and they were impressed."
"Now we can't keep up," he said. "You can't even buy blank disks for much less than it costs to get good programs. There is no incentive to try anything new because you can't earn a living if you do. So everyone has just given up or gone away."

In the giant Mitino market in Moscow, a man offered a CD-ROM for $9. The prices of imported goods are often cited in dollars instead of rubles for easy conversion. (Gleb Kosorukov for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Penny-Pinching H.M.O.'s Showed Their Generosity In Executive Paychecks

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
The nation's big for-profit health maintenance organizations had a banner year in 1994 by doing what they are set up to do: squeezing every penny possible out of the fees charged by doctors and hospitals. But as they put pressure on health care providers to cut costs, the H.M.O.'s were rewarding their chief executives with sizable pay packages.
The cash and stock awards to the chiefs of the seven biggest for-profit H.M.O.'s averaged $7 million in 1994. "These are monstrously large grants, among the highest we have seen in any industry," said Graef Crystal, an executive compensation expert at the University of California at Berkeley. 
 On the one hand, publicly traded H.M.O.'s are accountable to their shareholders, and the payments to the top executives are meant to serve as a reward for increased earnings and higher stock prices. But on the other, critics say that the H.M.O.'s should be directing their spending at improving health care, not at large compensation packages.
The biggest pay package to the chief of a for-profit H.M.O., $15.5 million, went to Dr. Norman C. Payson, president and chief executive of Healthsource, a medium-sized H.M.O. in Hooksett, N.H. Dr. Payson's cash payment was $387,604, above the average payment of $255,000 that for-profit H.M.O. chiefs received, according to the Warren Surveys, which measures compensation at H.M.O.'s. But he also got stock options with a current value of $15.1 million.
At the Foundation Health Corporation, in Rancho Cordova, Calif., the chief executive, Daniel D. Crowley, received a $13.7 million package -- $3.3 million in cash and options valued at $10.4 million.
The stock options issued by the H.M.O.'s were valued by the companies or by outside compensation experts.
At Health Systems International, Dr. Malik M. Hasan, the co-chief executive, was given a "special bonus" of $1 million for helping the California H.M.O. win a huge Pentagon contract last month. The bonus -- $100,000 now and the rest deferred for tax reasons -- was folded into the $8.8 million in cash and stock that Health Systems paid Dr. Hasan for 1994.
There are, however, signs that such generosity by H.M.O.'s may be coming under challenge. Dr. Hasan's bonus is attracting scrutiny from health care economists and executive compensation experts. And the $2.5 billion Pentagon contract itself is being contested by the Aetna Life and Casualty Company, the current contractor. "The bonus might be premature," said Robert H. Kaplan, an Aetna health plans vice president.
Health Systems is not alone. Growing resentment among consumer groups, doctors and some employers suggests that 1995 may be the year in which the big H.M.O.'s begin to pay attention to some of their own expenses.
Other of 1994's highly paid H.M.O. chief executives include Roger F. Greaves, Dr. Hasan's co-chairman who recently resigned, $8.9 million; Dr. William W. McGuire, the United Healthcare Corporation, $6.8 million; George T. Jochum, Mid Atlantic Medical Services Inc., $3.7 million; Leonard Abramson, U.S. Healthcare, $3.9 million, and Stephen F. Wiggins, Oxford Health Plans, $2.8 million.
"H.M.O. executives' pay has exploded in the last five years," said Alan Johnson, an executive compensation consultant in New York. Still, he added, "Most of it is coming from long-term incentive awards, which is exactly where shareholders or policyholders would want to have it." And Mr. Crystal of Berkeley noted that a number of the executive stock option plans will pay off only if the H.M.O.'s stock price rises to specified levels above current prices.
Nevertheless, Mr. Johnson, also said: "These companies may want to portray themselves as kind of warm and cuddly, but they are big-time businesses, not quasi-charitable organizations. From a political standpoint, these numbers are obviously fodder for groups advocating national health care."
The stocks of the H.M.O. companies were strong last year. Douglas Sherlock, an investment banker specializing in H.M.O.'s, noted that H.M.O. stocks as a group rose 32.7 percent in 1994, while the Standard & Poor's index of 500 companies fell 1.5 percent.
The H.M.O. stocks rose 12 percent in the first quarter of 1995, outpacing the S.& P. 500 by 3 percentage points. Some analysts, however, are expecting a slowdown. Robert Mains of First Albany Securities said that "1995 will be a different year than any in the past because the monthly premiums that H.M.O.'s get will be more or less flat."
In any case, some customers will be looking hard at H.M.O. costs, including executive pay. "On its surface, it looks like a lot of money and it looks like a problem," said Helen Darling, health care strategy manager at the Xerox Corporation. "We would certainly want to understand better the relationship between the compensation they pay to executives and the premium we pay."
Jeanne Finberg, a senior lawyer in San Francisco with Consumer's Union, a nonprofit advocacy group, said, "It's no wonder that health care costs have skyrocketed when millions of dollars are being bled off to line the pockets of executives." And Mr. Crystal, the consultant at Berkeley, said it was "improper" for a chief executive like Dr. Hasan of Health Systems to be paid "a bonus based on anticipated future profits from a portion of a company's business."
Uwe E. Reinhardt, a health care economist at Princeton University, took a different view. He said the H.M.O. pay packages were financed by "the doctors and nurses and pharmaceutical companies on whom they put the squeeze." He added, "As long as the patients are happy, why should they care that Malik Hasan is going to be able to buy a new airplane every year?"
Professor Reinhardt said the H.M.O. executives were profiting by squeezing health costs, after the Government, for political reasons, had failed to do so. "We ran a sloppy show and didn't allow the Government to clean it up," he said. "It took certain people with guts to go after the doctors in this brutal fashion."
Spokesmen for physicians, not surprisingly, saw it differently. "We have considerable concern about the profit motive in health care," said Dr. James Todd, executive vice president of the American Medical Association. "Money that is paid out in profits to employees or investors is money that is leaving the system at a time when it is sorely needed."
Reflecting strong financial results from health care, the big insurance companies also paid their executives handsomely. Lawrence P. English, president of the Cigna Corporation's health care unit, got $2.1 million, including $1 million in stock options. James W. McLane, executive vice president for health and group life insurance at Aetna, got $888,286, of which 90 percent, or $799,447, was for health care duties.
Mutual insurance companies publish few financial details, but in a brief report to New York state regulators, the Prudential Insurance Company of America, which has the nation's second-largest H.M.O., said that William Link, its group insurance operations chairman, was paid $619,400.
As for nonprofit insurers, Kaiser Permanente, the nation's biggest H.M.O., said that Dr. David Lawrence, its chairman, received $803,000 in salary and bonuses "based on targets related to the quality of patient care."

HEADLINE: Goodyear Gets President as It Sets Succession

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: AKRON, Ohio, April 10

 BODY:
The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company named Samir Gibara president and chief operating officer today, putting him in line to succeed Stanley Gault as chief executive.
The choice of Mr. Gibara, which was expected, meshes with the company's strategy of maintaining growth by expanding in markets outside the United States. Mr. Gibara, 55, who was born in Cairo and is fluent in several languages, has worked at Goodyear for 30 years, including executive posts in Canada and Europe. 
 The transition, which was announced at today's annual meeting, "hasn't been finally put to bed yet," Mr. Gault said. But analysts said the rise of Mr. Gibara, now head of Goodyear's North American tire operations, to the No. 2 post made him the heir apparent. Mr. Gault's contract with the company ends this year. Hoyt Wells, who holds the titles of president, chief operating officer and vice chairman of the board, announced his plans earlier this year to retire.
"Gibara certainly is the front-runner at this point," said Marvin Behm, fixed-income analyst at Duff & Phelps Credit Rating in Chicago..
Goodyear, based in Akron, also announced today that it had increased its quarterly dividend 25 percent, to 25 cents a share from 20 cents. The company forecast first-quarter earnings would rise between 86 cents and 88 cents a share, compared with 77 cents in the quarter a year earlier, in line with analysts' expectations.
Shares of Goodyear were unchanged at $38.125 today on the New York Stock Exchange.
Mr. Gibara, who will be 56 on April 23, received his bachelor's degree in business administration from Cairo University and a master's degree in international business from Harvard Business School. He joined Goodyear in 1965 as a management trainee in France. He assumes his new responsibilities April 15.

HEADLINE: Climb in Technology Issues Lifts Market as Dow Gains 5.53

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Despite continued nervous trading of the dollar, the stock market rose yesterday, with technology stocks rising powerfully on expectations of a surge in earnings at Motorola, the cellular telephone and microchip maker that has often led the market in recent months.
The dollar stabilized in afternoon trading in New York, helping also to stabilize bond prices, which turn volatile when the dollar declines. 
 As a sign of the growing calm, the price of gold, a widely watched indicator of market nervousness, fell $3.10, to $392.60 an ounce for a contract set for June delivery.
Still, many stock traders stayed on the sidelines yesterday in advance of the Producer Price Index, scheduled to be released this morning, and the Consumer Price Index, scheduled for tomorrow. Moreover, the short week brought about by the Good Friday close of most financial markets in the United States could mean market action will be concentrated today and tomorrow.
In light trading yesterday, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 5.53 points, to 4,198.15, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 0.59 point, to 507.01. But the Nasdaq composite index, rich in technology stocks, rose 6.57 points, to 821.26.
Bond prices dipped slightly, and the yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond was unchanged at 7.39 percent.
After falling briefly to as low as 80.15 yen, the dollar settled late yesterday at 84.02 yen, up from 83.82 yen on Friday. The dollar also edged up to 1.4100 German marks from 1.3779 marks.
"The average equity guy pays attention to the dollar when it's in free fall," said Todd Clark, managing director of equity trading at Rodman & Renshaw. "When it stabilizes, nobody cares."
Currency traders were cautious, however, about the stabilization in the dollar's value, saying the dollar's rise was brought about by technical factors, such as traders taking yen profits on a 15-minute drop in the dollar in Tokyo and rumors in New York of intervention by the Federal Reserve.
The biggest factors behind the dollar weakness against the yen is the United States trade deficit with Japan and the Federal budget deficit at home. Currency traders bid down the value of the dollar when the Republicans' balanced budget amendment was defeated in the Senate earlier this year.
But when there is a signal, like the Japanese meeting on import restrictions, that the United States may be able to sell more goods in Japan, thus lessening the trade deficit, currency traders bid up the dollar.
The recent surprise decision by the German central bank, the Bundesbank, to cut interest rates modestly, thus making the mark less valuable, also prompted traders in recent weeks to sell marks for yen. One consequence was to make the value of the dollar rise against the mark.
"At some point, as well," said Charles A. Spence, director of Treasury sales at Standard Chartered Bank, "people concluded that the dollar is undervalued." But he cautioned that the dollar could turn volatile once again since nothing fundamental had yet changed with either the United States budget deficit or the trade deficit.
On the New York Stock Exchange, advancing stocks outnumbered declining stocks by 1,109 to 1,057. The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.25 point, to 273.98, and volume was below normal at 261 million shares.
The Nasdaq index lifted substantially as securities analysts in the morning predicted higher-than-expected first-quarter earnings for Motorola. When Motorola reported earnings after the market closed, however, they were 61 cents a share, a penny shy of the consensus estimate of 62 cents.
Motorola's share price may drop this morning and have an effect on other technology stocks. Yesterday, it rose 7/8, to 56 1/2.

HEADLINE: 70's Dreams, 90's Realities;
Renewable Energy: A Luxury Now. A Necessity Later?

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
It was a vision from the energy-short 1970's that seemed on the verge of coming true in the boundless 80's: harnessing the wind, the sun and hot water from the bowels of the earth to produce electricity without pollution and without end.
But that dream has foundered in the bottom-line 90's. Now, with costs still high and a new era of competition roiling the long-protected energy business, alternative sources of power are fighting for their lives. These so-called renewable sources may well survive only as window dressing for utility company annual reports, many industry experts say. 
 As the renewables lose ground, there is more on the line than the fortunes of producers like the Kenetech Corporation, the biggest supplier of wind-generated energy, and the California Energy Company, a major geothermal player. Their fate also has implications for the environment and the pace with which the country uses up nonrenewable fuels like coal and natural gas.
The decline of renewables carries long-term risk, for example, if global warming becomes something more than just a threat, said Daniel A. Kirshner, an analyst for the Environmental Defense Fund, a major environmental group. In that instance, there would be pressure to reduce pollution quickly. "It's going to be much more difficult to do that without a ready renewable industry," he said.
The renewables are turning into an endangered species because of the brutal economics of the utility industry, which is awash in surplus power and increasingly faced with big commercial customers demanding lower rates and finding them through independent energy wholesalers. Renewables are a luxury that belt-tightening utilities can no longer afford, executives complain, particularly now that natural gas is so plentiful and gas-fired generating plants so inexpensive to operate.
The price gap is big enough that one utility, Southern California Edison, a unit of SCEcorp, is even paying Kenetech not to produce electricity for future delivery, saying it will save millions by not fulfilling a long-term contract for wind-generated power.
What is more, state and Federal programs that fostered the growth of renewables by guaranteeing them a market despite high start-up costs have been effectively gutted by a recent decision by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. In its ruling, the commission greatly weakened a provision of a 1978 Federal law that enabled states to force utilities to use renewables for some of their electricity through long-term contracts at what turned out to be above-market rates.
Although the decision was limited to California, where renewables have their strongest base, it is already being used by utilities in Iowa, Minnesota, New York and Texas to avoid future contracts. Without such contracts, there is little chance that much new capacity for wind, solar and geothermal power will be built.
"It's been devastating," said Jan Smutny-Jones, executive director of the Independent Energy Producers, a group of nonutility companies that provide power, sometimes from renewable sources, to big industrial customers and utilities. "The decision raises serious questions whether renewables will be allowed to compete in future markets."
The supporters of renewables believe that any short-term savings for the utilities will come at the expense of long-term benefits.
"Society will have to pay somewhere through respiratory problems from pollution," said Ken Karas, president and chief executive of Zond Systems of Tehachapi, Calif., a major developer of wind power.
Peter Fox Penner, head of one of the renewable energy projects at the Department of Energy, said that if environmental costs were added in, the renewables could increasingly compete for the new capacity that would have to be added by the end of the decade.
"In some ways it's cheaper to meet environmental standards by using renewables," he said.
Paradoxically, the decline of renewables comes at a time when some forms, particularly wind power, are making technical breakthroughs to bring down costs and make production more reliable.
But utility executives say the price gap is still too wide. Plants fired by natural gas can produce electricity for 3 cents a kilowatt-hour or less. Even the most advanced wind turbines produce power at about 5 cents a kilowatt-hour. Geothermal plants cost from 5.5 cents and solar power is 14 cents and higher.
Because of the Federal ruling, producers of alternative power are facing "a different world," said David K. Owens, a senior vice president of the Edison Electric Institute, which represents private utilities. "They have to be able to compete in the market. Utilities will now say to the wind power producers: 'Why should I buy power at 5 cents when I can get it much lower?' "
But not all utility executives are ready to drive a stake through the heart of the renewable energy sources. Some states will continue to foster their use, they say, and foreign markets beckon. And if costs continue to fall, a market in the United States should eventually reemerge.
"Some states, such as California, will come up with a way for renewable resources to stay in the mix," said Robert Glynn, executive vice president of the Pacific Gas and Electric Company of San Francisco, the nation's largest utility and one that has had extensive dealings with renewable suppliers. "The big unresolved issue is how much are they willing to pay for it and who will pay."
Indeed, the California Public Utilities Commission has asked that the ruling of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission be stayed while it considers what course to take.
State regulators and legislators who support renewables are in a bind, however, since they also want to bring more low-cost power into their states to prepare their utilities for more competition.
Those who produce alternative power are not ready to throw in the towel, either.
"There is no question that a large amount of business has been placed at risk," said Clarence Grebey, a spokesman for Kenetech, the wind power producer. But, he added, "That doesn't mean that we are moping around thinking we don't have a future."
Still, that future is not nearly as bright as it was in the 70's, when alternative power was touted as the vehicle that would help free the country from the dirty grip of fossil fuels and the risks of nuclear energy. Even with the big push provided by the 1978 Federal law, the Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act, renewables now account for only 2 percent of energy use in the United States.
If renewables found a home anywhere, it was in California, which went beyond the Federal law with its own supportive legislation.
Because of that support, companies like Kenetech were able to thrive. Based in San Francisco, Kenetech got commitments in recent years from the state's three largest utilities to buy up to 945 megawatts of power -- enough to run a city the size of Phoenix and the biggest order for wind power ever. It meant supplying 2,800 turbines, worth about $1 billion.
But the three utilities -- Southern California Edison, Pacific Gas and Electric and San Diego Gas and Electric -- were strongly opposed to making such commitments because of the extra cost.
Last November, Southern California Edison agreed to pay Kenetech an undisclosed amount to keep it from producing 420 megawatts of power. The utility said the payment would produce a net savings of about $200 million.
Kenetech will still be able to build a much smaller plant and have the right to build more if the utility should need more power in the future. That, some industry executives concede, is the window dressing.
The Federal agency ruling has put other Kenetech contracts in jeopardy, including one for 100 megawatts with Pacific Gas and Electric. Kenetech's chances of adding any more capacity in the future in the United States now appear to be slim.
The blow comes at a time when Kenetech is finally surmounting start-up problems with a new variable-speed turbine that makes the conversion of wind to energy more efficient.
The combination of the start-up problems and the Federal ruling has sent Kenetech stock into a tailspin. The stock, which traded as high as $29.50 a share last year, closed yesterday at $11.75, up 50 cents.
"They basically made a regulatory bet, not a market bet, and they lost," said Lawrence D. Gilson, the president of Venture Associates, a consulting group that follows the utility industry for Arthur Andersen.
Kenetech is now looking overseas. It recently signed agreements to ship 92 turbines to India and is building plants in Spain and the Netherlands.
At this point in the United States, "no other fuel source can compete with spot market gas pricing," said David Sokol, chairman and chief executive of California Energy, the Omaha-based geothermal company.
But while gas prices are now low, there are no guarantees for the future, said Mr. Karas of Zond Systems, the wind power developer.
"Gas prices are at a historical low," Mr. Karas said. "Will they stay that way forever? I don't think so." And when they go up, he said, wind and geothermal plants built now to produce at 5 cents a kilowatt-hour will look pretty good, he said.
"To burn gas to save a few cents per kilowatt-hour and not do anything to support renewables is absurd," Mr. Karas said.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Mets Ready to Make an Offer to Butler

BYLINE: By JENNIFER FREY 

DATELINE: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., April 11

 BODY:
Fewer than 24 hours after saying Brett Butler was "not a guy we are targeting," the Mets stepped up their interest today in the free-agent outfielder. Fred Wilpon, a team owner, called Butler at home with a personal appeal and club executives were poised to make his agent, Richard Moss, an offer.
According to Gerry Hunsicker, the Mets' assistant vice president of baseball operations, the Mets have completed meetings to determine how much they can offer Butler and stay within their budget. They expected to make an offer as soon as they were able to contact Moss, who was traveling today. 
 "We should find out in the near future if we have any chance of getting a deal done," Hunsicker said. "I don't think this thing is going to last very long. If he's swept off his feet by someone else, so be it."
To become the Mets' leadoff batter and center fielder, Butler would have to be willing to take a substantial cut from the 1994 salary of $3.5 million he would have earned with the Los Angeles Dodgers without a strike.
The Mets' salary limits, determined after discussions that included Wilpon, apparently do not stretch substantially above $1.5 million. Because those figures do not represent a starting point for contract negotiations, but rather an outline of the Mets' limits, the club does not expect its discussions with Butler to last for more than a day or so.
Reached at his home in Atlanta tonight, Butler said he was well aware of the economic situation in baseball and its effect on salaries. But he would not discuss how low an offer he'd be willing to accept. While emphasizing his interest in the Mets, Butler also said his pride would prompt him to walk away from baseball before he played for a figure that he found an insult.
"When an offer comes in -- whether it's from the Mets or whomever -- I'll go from there and make a decision whether it's in my best interests to stay in this game or not," said Butler, who turns 38 years old on June 15. "I'm not antsy, I'm tired. I'm tired of all the stuff that's been going on this winter and all the stuff that's going on now."
Butler, a visible and vocal supporter of the union's position, said he believed his role in the labor dispute was "being used against me" in his pursuit of a free-agent contract. But he also said the call from Wilpon, a moderate among owners in the labor dispute who is popular with his players, certainly weighed in the Mets' favor.
With the season barely more than two weeks away, Butler said he has had some interest from other clubs. One apparantly is the Baltimore Orioles, who reportedly have offered him a one-year deal of $1.2-$1.3 million.
"To me, it doesn't look like anybody is in any hurry to sign Brett Butler," he said.
Despite an obvious hole at the top of their lineup, the Mets did not pursue Butler earlier this spring because they felt he was out of their financial reach. The Mets have consistently said that, in the aftermath of signing both John Franco and Pete Harnisch to substantial contracts, they cannot sign any big-ticket free agents.
If Butler is to sign with the Mets, he will have to do what two of his former Dodger teammates -- Orel Hershiser and Tim Wallach -- have done this spring. Both signed contracts that involved salary cuts of nearly $2 million from their 1994 levels.
"If I'm going to float my boat, last year I hit .314 and I had 8 home runs on Aug. 12, when my best is 9 home runs for a full season," said Butler, disputing comparisons to the Hershiser and Wallach situations. "I haven't shown any signs of slipping. I don't expect to be paid $3.5 million, but I expect it to be within reason."

HEADLINE: U.S.-Mexico Environment Needs Bailout

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Mexico, after having imposed tough austerity measures at home and set aside oil revenues to secure loans that make up the United States portion of the peso rescue package, must be discouraged by efforts in the United States Congress to back out of the commitment altogether (front page, April 2). 
 Rather than simply add to Mexico's economic woes, Congress might pursue opportunities for the two countries to move ahead together. There are many such opportunities, but the border region is a good place to start.
Here neighbors can take advantage of opportunities that arise from mutual self-interest, that depend on community-based initiatives, and that do not require increases in government spending from either country. However, the federal governments must act together to give border residents the management institutions they need.
For example, air pollution that moves back and forth across the border between the sister cities of El Paso, Tex., and Juarez, Chihuahua, causes illness, higher medical costs, lower productivity and reduced quality of life. This problem -- like the degradation of other common air basins, acquifers and watersheds along the border -- can be fixed.
The best way to clean up El Paso-Juarez's air is for the two federal governments to establish a binational air-quality management district and delegate responsibility to the people who live and work in the region. If local businesses are given flexibility to achieve targets, they will make the most cost-effective reductions first, and new or expanding polluters in El Paso might decide to offset their emissions by investing in low-cost pollution abatement activities in Juarez.
Political bashing doesn't make sense. It would be better to tackle tasks that will benefit both Mexico and the United States and link sustainable economic growth with environmental protection in the years ahead.
 
PETER M. EMERSON
Senior Economist
Environmental Defense Fund
Austin, Tex., April 4, 1995

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Stottlemyre Goes to A's Without Anger for Jays

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

DATELINE: HOMESTEAD, Fla., April 10

 BODY:
Some tiny part of Todd Stottlemyre would like to say something nasty about the Toronto Blue Jays, would like to express anger and frustration that he has been at a camp for jobless men in Homestead instead of the Blue Jays' camp across the state.
But no part of him, however tiny, can do that, however agonizing the pangs of separation are as he puts the Blue Jays in his past and heads for Oakland, where he will pitch for the Athletics with a $1.8 million salary, $520,000 less than his 1994 salary. 
 "It would be tough for me to sit here and say bad things about the Jays because there were nothing but good times for me there," the pitcher said at the Players Association's spring camp for unsigned free agents, before learning that he had a job with the A's. "That's a great organization over there."
So great that playing for the Blue Jays, Stottlemyre said, "was as good as going fishing with Thurman Munson. I get goose bumps when I think about it. They were great people to be with. The last couple days haven't been easy. I'm leaving where I lived."
Stottlemyre was a child when his father, Mel, pitched for the Yankees, and the fringe benefits included fishing trips with his father's catcher, Munson. The fringe benefits of playing for the Blue Jays included first-class treatment and first-place finishes.
Stottlemyre grew up in the Toronto organization, spending all nine years of his professional career in it. He could have remained with the team had he accepted a three-year, $7 million offer early last December, but personal negotiations ran into faltering labor negotiations and signing-freeze strike strategy.
When normalcy returned to baseball last week, the Blue Jays began looking elsewhere for a fifth starter to bolster their pitching rotation, and today they reached agreement with another free-agent right-hander, Danny Darwin. At 39, he is 10 years older than Stottlemyre, but at $300,000, much cheaper.
"To have signed Todd now would put us way beyond our payroll budget," Gord Ash, the Blue Jays' new general manager, said from Dunedin, explaining that his payroll limit was $44 million. "This has been one of the more difficult situations we've been involved in because Todd has been a Blue Jay since the beginning of his career."
Last December, the Blue Jays offered Stottlemyre arbitration to retain negotiating rights to him, but since then, the system changed and changed back, and clubs had until last Friday to offer arbitration to their free agents. The day before, though, the Blue Jays acquired David Cone in a trade.
That deal effectively ended Stottlemyre's chances of returning.
"It's a little different than I expected because of the circumstances surrounding the game," Stottlemyre said. "You get six years in, and you know you're going to be a free agent with the thought you'll find out what the people around the league think about you. Then we get to this circumstance and here I am in Homestead."
On one hand, Stottlemyre said, he was "a little disappointed" that the Blue Jays, in effect, said to him, "It's time to go." On the other, he quickly added: "I don't blame them. They got David Cone. Anyone who had a chance to get David Cone would do that. He's one of the best pitchers in the league. You have to give credit to the organization for going out and trying to get the best people to put the best product on the field. Toronto's always done that. I was a part of that and this time I fell on the short end."
Stottlemyre several times said he was "over" the disappointment of being banished from the family, but it was evident he still had some work to do.
"On the first day of camp each spring," he related, "I'd say jokingly -- but I meant it, too -- 'Welcome to the first day of camp. Get on your hands and knees and say thanks for putting this uniform on.' It was that good. There's always ups and downs, bad times and good times, but I see nothing but good. I guess that's what makes it hard knowing I'm not going back.
"It wasn't good for me; it was great for me. I had a manager who went to bat for me. I got two World Series rings. What else can a player ask for?"

HEADLINE: Computer Chip Ratio Was Up for March

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif., April 10

 BODY:
The book-to-bill ratio compiled by the Semiconductor Industry Association rose to 1.14 last month from a revised 1.11 for February, the group said today.
The ratio, which measures the demand for computer chips in North America, was the second highest for March during the last nine years. In March 1987 the ratio was 1.15. The number for February was revised down from 1.12. 
 A ratio of 1.14 means that for every $100 of goods shipped, semiconductor makers took in $114 in new orders. A ratio higher than 1 indicates that the market is expanding.
The ratio is computed using a three-month moving average and is seasonally adjusted using the same method used by the Government.

HEADLINE: Aid Cutoff Feared By Some In Arts

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES 

 BODY:
Many of New York's smaller arts organizations were scrambling yesterday to organize a response to what they believed was a new city proposal to eliminate their grants from the Department of Cultural Affairs.
The organizations, more than 400 that make up what is known as the program group, were allotted $12.5 million in grants in the 1995 fiscal year. 
 Administrators of some of the groups, which include such disparate organizations as Dance Theater of Harlem, Performance Space 122, the Alvin Ailey Dance Company and the Metropolitan Opera, said that all direct grants from the city would be eliminated in 1996 under a plan proposed by John S. Dyson, the deputy mayor for finance and economic development. The total budget for the cultural affairs department this year is $96.1 million.
A spokesman for Mr. Dyson would neither confirm nor deny the proposal. "Many scenarios have emanated from within the administration concerning all city agencies," said the spokesman, Forrest Taylor. "It is too early to comment on what direction the Mayor is headed."
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's final budget will not be submitted for approval by the City Council for another month.
In December 1993, just before he took office, Mr. Dyson touched off a furor by suggesting that the city channel its cultural grant money primarily, if not exclusively, to the city's premier cultural organizations, which he said pulled in most of the tourist dollars. He expressed deep skepticism about the program groups, describing them as recipients of "clubhouse type political handouts." His remarks provoked a barrage of criticism by arts administrators and local politicians.
The arts administrators expressed the fear that Mr. Dyson remained dubious about the program groups, and that the proposed cuts reflected his belief that the city should invest in proven winners, while smaller organizations should demonstrate their worth by showing an ability to raise money.
The main recipients of money from the Department of Cultural Affairs are the 31 organizations that make up the "cultural institutions group," most of them larger organizations, like the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Brooklyn Museum. Those groups received $74 million in 1995 and, arts administrators said yesterday, will face an additional cut of $9 million beyond the $11 million proposed in the Mayor's preliminary budget.
Although the $173,000 that the Metropolitan Opera receives from the city accounts for only a tiny fraction of its annual budget, city grants represent a much larger slice of the budget pie for most of the program groups. Their administrators say it is also the hardest kind of money to raise: general operating expenses.
Schuyler G. Chapin, the Cultural Affairs Commissioner, proposed in a March 23 memo to Mr. Dyson that the cuts should be administered equally to the cultural institutions group and the program group. Mr. Chapin was out of town and all questions about the department's budget were referred to Mr. Dyson's office.
The proposed cuts in direct grants would be partly offset by a dollar-for-dollar program of matching or challenge grants under which the city would provide $7.8 million to organizations able to raise money on their own. The matching grants program was first proposed in mid-February in the Mayor's preliminary budget. In essence, this would be a smaller version of the $10 million matching-grants program that was put into operation by the city and state last year. That plan provided grants to organizations that raised money to create new programs or expand existing programs with the goal of increasing and diversifying their audiences.
The program-group administrators say, however, that the matching grants will not offset the direct cuts. "A challenge program in a year when base funding is being cut is meaningless," said Steven Tennen, the executive director of Arts Connection, which brings visual and performing artists to schools in the five boroughs. "I have to replace the base funding from private sources. I couldn't conceivably think about expanding, which is what the challenge grant is for." Arts Connection receives $300,000 from the city and last year received an additional $30,000 in matching-grant money.
Mark Russell, the artistic director of Performance Space 122, said: "We've just gone through a cultural challenge. It's been a push all year to make that work. I don't think I could stand it another year."
Mr. Russell said his organization received $16,121 from the city in 1995 from its regular services contract. Under the city's portion of the city-state challenge grant, it received $20,000 to expand its audience by offering a late-night series and student passes.
