HEADLINE: Training Found a Big Factor in Child Care

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN 

 BODY:
The quality of care that preschool children receive both in day-care centers and in family day care can be significantly improved with training and tighter limits on the number of children each adult looks after, according to two new studies made public yesterday.
The studies, by the Families and Work Institute, a nonprofit research group in New York, examined 150 licensed care centers in Florida and 130 family care homes in three states. 
 "Parents have been concerned about several recent studies showing that the quality of early care that children receive is uneven at best and, for really young children, frightening," said Ellen Galinsky, co-president of the Families and Work Institute. "So we wanted to address the question of what can be done to quality. When you do this kind of research, you never know what, if anything, you'll find. We weren't sure that a modest effort, like 16 hours of training, would have noticeable effects on kids' development. We were pleasantly surprised that it did."
The study was based on visits to care centers before and after Florida passed legislation tightening staffing requirements. As of October 1992, the state required 1 adult for every 4 babies under a year old, as against 1 for every 6 previously. Moreover, the new standard required 1 adult for every 6 toddlers aged 1 to 2, as against 1 for every 8 toddlers previously.
The study found that with the new standards, children engaged in more complex play, both with objects and with one another, had better language skills, were more securely attached to their teachers and had fewer behavior problems.
The study also found that, with the smaller groups, teachers were less likely to respond to a child's misbehavior with such "negative management styles" as yelling, scolding, threatening, being sarcastic, smacking or hitting. In some programs, such responses were reduced by 75 percent.
Florida legislation that goes into effect in July also requires that day-care centers have 1 staff person with formal child development training for every 20 children. The Families and Work researchers plan to revisit the centers they studied after that requirement is in place.
The new child-care studies come at a time when Congress is considering legislation that would eliminate money for improving the quality of child care and insuring that all providers receiving public dollars meet minimum health and safety standards. Florida used some of that money to support its laws, offering scholarships for child care workers to receive training.
For some Democrats in the Senate, the studies' findings provided an opportunity to protest the legislation the House of Representatives passed last month to cut off such financing.
"The reports demonstrate that the funds made available through the Child Care and Development Block Grant for improving the quality of child care are making a positive difference in children's lives," said Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts. "Unfortunately, the welfare reform bill passed by the House of Representatives eliminates these quality improvement funds as well as the minimal health and safety requirements."
While day-care centers are becoming an increasingly popular form of care for preschool children, the most common arrangement for young children whose mothers are employed is being looked after in someone's home.
According to the Urban Institute's 1990 National Child Care Study, 33 percent of preschool children with employed mothers are in such family day care -- 13 percent with a relative and 20 percent with a non-relative. Usually, family day care costs less than a formal day-care center.
The study on family day care examined the effects of at least 16 hours of training on 130 family day-care workers in Dallas, Charlotte, N.C., and the San Fernando Valley in California. They were visited before and after the training, and compared with 112 workers in the same communities who did not take part in training.
The report found that after the workers were trained in skills like discipline and safety, the children in their care became more engaged in activities and spent less time wandering aimlessly. It also found that the children behaved in ways indicating that they felt more securely attached to those caring for them.
The study also found that after the training, 97 percent of the care workers said they reported the income they made from giving care on their tax returns, as against only 70 percent who said they did before the training.
The quality of care at two of the three sites increased after the training, the study found, but at the third site, which had the highest quality rating before training, there was no statistically significant change. The study did not identify which sites improved and which one did not.

HEADLINE: Chrysler and Ford Lower '92 Expectations

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 11

 BODY:
Disappointed by the slow pace of sales in the first quarter, the Chrysler Corporation and the Ford Motor Company said today that they had lowered their expectations and were forecasting only modest growth in industry sales in the United States this year.
Citing higher interest rates as a cause, both companies brought their estimates in line with that of the General Motors Corporation, which projected sales of 15.6 million cars and light and heavy trucks this year, up narrowly from 1994 sales of 15.4 million. 
 Robert J. Eaton, Chrysler's chairman and chief executive, told a group of auto stock analysts in New York today that the company had cut its forecast for 1995 by 300,000 vehicles, to 15.5 million. It reduced its 1996 estimate by 500,000 vehicles, to 15.8 million from 16.3 million vehicles.
It was the third time in three months that Chrysler had cut its estimates, which had been far higher than the other companies'.
Joel Pitcoff, Ford's market analysis manager, said Ford had also recently reduced its 1995 sales projection, estimating sales of 15.5 million to 15.6 million vehicles, from 15.8 million to 15.9 million vehicles. Ford expects sales of trucks to set a record this year, but sales of cars to slip below last year's level.
Mr. Pitcoff said that interest rates were deterring some buyers, and others appeared to be postponing purchases in hopes that auto makers would add rebates and other incentives. Incentives have risen steadily this quarter.
During the first quarter of 1994, cars and trucks sold at an annualized rate of 15.8 million, well ahead of sales for the year as a whole. During the first quarter of 1995, the sales rate was 15.2 million. Mr. Pitcoff predicted that the new incentives would raise the selling rate for each of the next three quarters.

HEADLINE: A String of Disasters Leaves Japanese on Edge

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 11

 BODY:
The most shocking drama to reach Japan in years has its audience riveted, in part because of the possibility of an even scarier sequel coming soon.
It began last month with the nerve gas attack on the Tokyo subway system, which killed 11 people and injured more than 5,000, and it is unfolding on streets and television screens around Japan. The case has become the national obsession. 
 A lawyer found out just how preoccupied the police were when she went to a police station the other day to report the date rape of a client. "They said they were too busy with the nerve gas incident," said the lawyer, Kazue Akita.
In American terms, it is as if the search of O. J. Simpson's estate had turned up not just a bloody glove but also biological warfare supplies, a suspected machine-gun factory, hundreds of tons of chemicals to make nerve gas and nitroglycerine, and a huge Russian military helicopter that would fit nicely in any air force.
The daily searches of Aum Shinrikyo, the religious sect suspected of involvement in the nerve gas attack, have turned up all of these things. And there is the titillation of what the authorities did not find: the sect's leaders, two small helicopters that the group also owns and quantities of sarin nerve gas that the police suspect may have already been prepared.
Mainichi Shimbun, a major Japanese newspaper, reported today that the police had examined the quantities of chemicals purchased by Aum and the quantities recovered in the raids of its warehouses. Unaccounted for are enough chemicals to make 5.6 tons of sarin, theoretically enough nerve gas to kill many millions of people.
Aum leaders vigorously deny that they did anything wrong, asserting that it is they who are the victims of nerve gas poisoning by the United States military. They deny that they were manufacturing guns and say they were stockpiling chemicals mainly to help agriculture recover from an apocalypse that they expect within the next few years.
The drama of the nerve gas attack, and the possibility of others, dominates the nation's newspapers and television shows, not to mention conversations in offices, bars and communal baths.
Kazuyoshi Nishikura, an editor at Kyodo News Service, said the public fascination with the news about Aum was even greater than the interest in the slow death of Emperor Hirohito six years ago. The nerve gas attack and its aftermath constitute one of the dominant news stories of the postwar era, he said.
"All the premises that we used to work on are now falling apart," Mr. Nishikura said.
The nerve gas attack, as Mr. Nishikura noted, was a particularly serious blow to the Japanese psyche because it came as part of a string of events that collectively created fundamental new uncertainties about the future.
In January an earthquake devastated the western city of Kobe, killing more than 5,000 people and reminding Japanese of their vulnerability to natural disaster. Then in the last few weeks the yen has been surging to new postwar highs, making Japanese products less competitive abroad and threatening companies and jobs in the export sector.
Now, with the nerve gas attack, people no longer feel safe in the streets that were once famed for their safety day or night.
A senior newspaper editor found that when he went out on the street with sunglasses and a baseball cap that obscured his face, taxis refused to stop for him. Subways are now halted for emergency examinations when someone finds a liquid spilled on the floor.
When two Japanese women met at a shop and found that they were both artists, they exchanged phone numbers and decided to get together. But one woman asked the other, "You're not a member of a religious cult, are you?"
Even among foreigners, there are special apprehensions these days. Americans are on edge because the guru of Aum, Shoko Asahara, has denounced the United States with special ferocity.
A few days ago, a 20-year-old American woman, the daughter of an American Embassy employee, was suddenly assaulted by three men in a nice neighborhood of Tokyo. There is no evidence that the attack was connected with the nerve gas incident or with any religious cult, but it prompted a round of nervous cable traffic and some jitters among diplomats.
"There's all kinds of speculation," a diplomat said. "We don't know who did it or what it means."
Hiroyoshi Ishikawa, a social psychologist at Seijo University in Tokyo, said, "In the depths of this, we can find some basic anxieties of the Japanese people."
Professor Ishikawa said the anxiety had originated with the collapse of the "bubble economy" several years ago and was particularly pronounced among young people, who often have no clear image of what the future holds for them.
The public fascination with Aum is partly a function of its professionalism and boldness in challenging the authorities. The cult was organized in Government ministries, and news reports suggest that it was trying to acquire not just nerve gas and biological weapons, but also precision equipment to manufacture AK-47 submachine guns.
Even the skill with which Aum's executives have evaded police raids is startling. Today the police found a bungalow that they say they believe was used by Takeshi Matsumoto, an Aum leader who is wanted in the kidnapping of a public notary this year.
In the bungalow, the police found medical equipment used to perform plastic surgery, along with a woman's wig and a pair of very large women's shoes. The police reportedly also found fingerprints of an Aum doctor who trained at one of the country's best medical schools and later worked at a hospital in Detroit.
So now there is widespread speculation that Mr. Matsumoto may have a new face and women's clothing, making him harder than ever to find.
There has also been amazement at the skill involved in the shooting of Japan's top law enforcement official on March 30. Aum has denied involvement in that shooting, and organized crime groups are also under suspicion, but in any case the gunman was apparently a first-rate marksman.
There is speculation that the gunman was a professional hit man, perhaps a Russian. Japanese news organizations reported tonight that the bullets were unusual American-made hollow-points with a special coating to increase the damage they cause.

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Hold the Line, Calming Jitters About Inflation

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 11

 BODY:
In an unexpectedly benign report, Government figures showed today that inflation vanished at the producer level in March, as both energy and food prices turned down.
Not only was the price of finished products unchanged for the month, constituting the best performance since October, but goods at earlier stages of production also settled back to a pace that calmed jitters that had been developing from sharp price increases since late last year. March marked the end of the fourth year of economic recovery and expansion following the 1990-91 recession. 
 "The United States still does not have any serious inflationary problem," said Lacy Hunt, chief economist at HSBC Holdings in New York. "There's an ample supply of goods and services and companies keep finding ways to make productivity gains."
With the erratic energy and food components removed, the Producer Price Index for finished goods edged up just one-tenth of 1 percent in March, also the skimpiest rise in five months.
Today's figures, if followed on Wednesday by similarly restrained consumer prices, which also reflect the price of services, would seem to further reduce the possibility that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates any time soon, analysts said. Indeed, a growing number of economists are coming to believe that in light of the significant slowing of the economy that has become evident in recent weeks, the Fed's next move might as likely be to cut rates as to raise them.
Yet the economy still shows signs of vigor, with store sales last week climbing 10 percent above those of the comparable 1994 week, which followed Easter, according to the Johnson Redbook tabulation. The gain was adjusted for one less shopping day last year.
The Labor Department's price figures showed finished goods unchanged in March despite flooding in California that curbed production of fruit and vegetables and despite the dollar's decline against the Japanese yen and the German mark, which might have allowed competing American producers to raise prices. Imported goods themselves are not included in the index.
In fact, the price of passenger cars fell four-tenths of 1 percent, the report showed, the second straight decline. Analysts noted that car sales had softened here and that Detroit had suffered also from the economic crisis in Mexico, where peso customers face huge price increases and where dealers are having great difficulty financing inventories.
In all, according to analysts at S. G. Warburg, 31 finished goods rose by more than one-tenth of 1 percent last month, while 20 fell that much and 23 were essentially unchanged. In February, 50 items rose significantly and only 12 declined.
In addition to cars, the March report showed prices fell 2.1 percent for gasoline, 4.8 percent for roasted coffee, 4.3 percent for pork and nine-tenths of 1 percent for computers. Capital equipment, which accounts for nearly one-quarter of the index, edged down one-tenth of 1 percent.
Moving higher were fresh and dry vegetables (5.7 percent), light trucks (three-tenths of 1 percent), cosmetics (2.5 percent), tires and tubes (2.1 percent) and home heating oil (seven-tenths of 1 percent, following a 6.5 percent February jump).
But at least as impressive as the tabluation of zero inflation for finished goods was a rise of just three- tenths of 1 percent for items at the intermediate stage of production, such as lumber and copper and brass mill shapes.
"The best news is that intermediate goods prices seemed to have given us a break," said L. Douglas Lee, an economist at NatWest Washington Analysis here. Intermediate items had risen an average of eight-tenths of 1 percent a month for November through February.
Without food and energy, the intermediate "core" rose four-tenths of 1 percent in March after 1 percent surges in both January and February, the department also said.
Similarly, crude materials sank 1.3 percent last month after increases of that size in the preceding two months as prices of raw foods and feeds fell 2.4 percent and crude energy fell 1.6 percent.
"There's a lot more moving through the pipeline than materials," said Stuart G. Hoffman, chief economist at the PNC Bank in Pittsburgh. "Goods get blended with labor costs," which have been restrained.
But basic industrial materials, though slowing, climbed five-tenths of 1 percent in March to bring the first quarter's rise to an annual pace of 21.1 percent, not much below the 26.7 percent pace from September through December.

HEADLINE: Police Squad Pursues North Bergen Graffiti Vandals

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY 

DATELINE: NORTH BERGEN, N.J., April 11

 BODY:
The undercover anti-graffiti police have already caught "SET2," age 11; "AMOS," age 17, and "MYSTAFO," age 12.
Now the police patrol is looking hard, day and night, for "FLEX," "EVE" and "PYRO," as well as the people behind scores of illegible and illegal scrawls that have popped up on businesses, homes and playground structures since last fall. 
 If they are caught and they are over age 18, they face 10 days in jail or 80 hours of community service and a fine of at least $250, no exceptions or excuses. Penalties for a second offense are at least 10 days in jail and a fine of at least $500. A third offense: up to 90 days in jail and a fine up to $1,000.
The penalties are part of what Mayor Nicholas J. Sacco calls the toughest anti-graffiti law in New Jersey.
Besides the stiff sentences, the crackdown here includes widely advertised rewards of $250, anti-graffiti lessons for schoolchildren from kindergarten through 12th grade, and some vigorous lobbying in Trenton for passage of a state law that would go after one of a teen-ager's most cherished possessions: the driver's license. Under the legislation, which awaits a vote in the Senate, a licensed driver convicted of writing graffiti would have the license suspended for one year. Those too young to drive would not be able to receive a license until age 18, instead of 17.
North Bergen is a tidy, no-nonsense working-class community on the banks of the Hudson River, just north of Jersey City, long a canvas of graffiti. Some here see the sudden spurt of graffiti as a sign of urban creep that, they say, tarnishes North Bergen's well-ordered image.
Mr. Sacco wants none of it and has taken a leading role in shaping the crackdown. He brings more influence to the campaign than most mayors. He has put up the $250 reward money from his political club, the North Bergen Democratic Municipal Committee, which is privately financed. He is the principal at Lincoln School and thus can help shape the anti-graffiti lessons in the classrooms. He is also a State Senator and a co-sponsor of the bill that goes after driving licenses.
He says the graffiti proliferated about six months ago and was starting to get out of hand.
"We were unable to keep up with it," he said. "We have our graffiti machines out constantly. There was no deterrent. So we decided to get a law that is extremely strict but fair. I hope surrounding towns do what we're doing or go further, so we have a united front and kids can't go across town lines and scrawl."
Newspaper ads announcing the $250 reward said the graffiti was beginning to tarnish North Bergen's image and destroy neighborhood pride. Promise of money for information leading to arrests and convictions has won the town some allies. One resident spotted a man spray-painting a telephone booth outside the Coach House restaurant just north of the Jersey City border and snapped some photographs as the painter applied his logo.
The anti-graffiti patrol is now trying to identify him.
"I've even had students call from their principal's office asking if they could get the money or if their parents could," he said.
Six boys have been arrested since the new law took effect March 30. All were caught in the act by the new anti-graffiti patrol: seven undercover officers who keep an eye out for scrawlers, in addition to their regular police duties.
Those arrested are 11 to 17 years old. Legally, all are classified as juveniles, making them too young to face the new law's jail time and stiff fines. Their cases go automatically to Hudson County juvenile court. Conviction will probably result in some form of community service, Mayor Sacco said.
The best deterrent, he said, would be passage of the bill requiring a year's delay in the granting of a license. Also, he said, the new town law makes their parents liable for damages from spray painting.
"I feel parents will be our best offense against this, because they'll be responsible economically," he said.
One member of the undercover patrol, Officer Debra Cummings, said some graffiti suggest groups of boys staking out turf. Many symbols and logos belong to individuals. But other markings, Officer Cummings said, contain three-letter logos: JAO for "Jersey All Out"; AFO, for "All for One," and AFK, for "Artists Forever Known." The logos suggest gang membership, she said.
One inviting target is the north wall of a car dealership, North Hudson Dodge, at 65th Street and Kennedy Boulevard. Each spring, the manager, David Sciorsci, had the brick wall, 120 feet long and 30 feet high, painted white. Just as soon as it was painted, it was filled with scrawls in red and black, he said.
"Every year, it's the same thing," he said. "They call it art and everything, but I think it's ugly. I don't want kids doing any hard jail time. I'd just have them paint my wall white."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Penalties being considered against youthful graffiti vandals in North Bergen include postponement of the right to receive a driver's license. Graffiti on a wall at 63d Street and Kennedy Boulevard. (Lenore Victoria Davis for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Whitman Administration and Judiciary Accused of Bias

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN 

DATELINE: TRENTON. April 11

 BODY:
A Hispanic organization today filed a complaint with the State Division on Civil Rights, charging that all departments of the Whitman Administration as well as the judiciary have been practicing "institutionalized discrimination" against Spanish-speaking job seekers.
The organization, the Hispanic Council of New Jersey, which calls itself Hispac, says it represents 1,500 people who have been systematically denied employment with the state. The council said that, based on its examination of state affirmative-action reports, not one department is meeting hiring goals set by the State Department of Personnel and the State Department of Labor. 
 Although the complaint seeks damages for economic loss, humiliation, mental pain and suffering, John Fuentes, first vice chairman of the council, said the group really just wanted someone to listen. "We want someone to examine our position and that of the administration and tell who is right," he said.
The council also forwarded a copy of the complaint to the United States Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. The state Department of Law and Public Safety, which is named in the complaint, includes a Civil Rights Division; the relationship between the two may create a conflict of interest, because the division is being asked to investigate its own department.
Mr. Fuentes said figures provided by the personnel department show that 4.7 percent of the state's 76,692 employees are Hispanic, compared with the 9 percent representation they should have, based on state labor pool figures.
Mr. Fuentes also repeated allegations made last December that Gov. Christine Todd Whitman is not paying enough attention to the problems of Hispanic residents. At that time the Governor made a speech announcing a new racial tolerance campaign and failed to mention Hispanic residents. Among those who criticized her oversight were Representative Robert Menendez and State Assemblyman Raul Garcia, both Union City Democrats.
And in October 1994, leaders of the Hispanic Bar Association of New Jersey accused Governor Whitman of falling short in her appointments of Hispanic residents to her Cabinet and to the bench.
More recently, Mr. Fuentes said, efforts to sit down with some Cabinet-level officials of the administration were unsuccessful. Instead, he said, his group was able to talk only with an aide in the Office of Policy and Planning. Mr. Fuentes said it is possible that someone in her administration is misleading Governor Whitman and "misrepresenting reality" concerning the treatment of Hispanic residents by the administration.
Carl Golden, Governor Whitman's spokesman, said the administration was prepared to defend itself against the civil rights complaint. "We believe our record in terms of reaching out to minority groups, including Hispanic residents, and our record on hiring ultimately will prevail."
Mr. Golden said it was difficult to make major changes in employment patterns "when there hasn't been much hiring in the last year and four months, and there has been a job freeze as of April 1."
He also said he was surprised at the allegation that Hispanic leaders have been unable to talk any top level administration officials.
"There recently was a roundtable meeting of the Governor and Gil Medina, the commissioner of commerce and economic development, with some people who represented Hispanic groups," Mr. Golden said. "There have been lines of communication opened."
Guillermo Beytagh-Maldonado, another Hispac leader who has joined seven others in signing the civil rights complaint, said the organization not only wants to see more people hired but also more promotions to administrative and professional positions. He said many Hispanic residents with college degrees have submitted resumes and applications for positions as they were advertised in civil service publications and never received the courtesy of a reply.
With the stack of affirmative action reports on the table in front of him, Mr. Fuentes quoted from a report of the Attorney General's Office for the current year that said that while black and white employees, both male and female, were represented in the category of those earning more than $75,000, there was not one Hispanic employee in that category. And Hispanic workers were the only group not represented in the category of those who received raises during the current fiscal year.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues Are Higher; Inflation Pressures Steady

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved higher yesterday, as a Government report showed inflation pressures holding steady at the wholesale level.
But comments by a Federal Reserve official and early rumors in the market that the retail sales reports by Johnson Redbook and Mitsubishi/Wertheim Schroder would be strong helped to touch off selling that pared early gains. A weak dollar provided a negative backdrop to trading. 
 The 30-year bond rose 8/32 , to a price of 1032/32to yield 7.37 percent, down from 7.39 percent on Monday.
Bonds initially opened morning trading on the upside after the Labor Department said its Producer Price Index, which measures the rate of inflation at the wholesale level, was unchanged in March. The report eased investor concern that inflation might accelerate and cause their fixed-income investments to lose value, and as a result brought more buyers into the market.
The report, which showed the overall index number unchanged at three-tenths of 1 percent for March, also showed the core, less food and energy, up one-tenth of 1 percent compared with three-tenths of 1 percent the previous month. Analysts said this was good for the market because it suggested that rising interest rates had slowed the economy and made it less likely that inflation would accelerate.
The early Mitsubishi/ Wertheim Schroeder index on weekly chain-store sales rose a hefty 3.3 percent for the week ending April 8, compared with the fall of 1.3 percent for the week ended April 1. It fueled speculation that the Redbook report would also come in strong and it did, coming in up 3.9 percent in the first week of April.
Rising price pressures were also noted in another report yesterday, this one by the Federal Reserve of Richmond. In its latest survey of regional manufacturing and service sector activity, the Richmond Fed said that price pressures were being led by sharp increases in wages and retail prices.
Elsewhere, Janet Yellen, a Federal Reserve governor, told Market News, a financial wire service, the financial markets should not assume monetary policy is definitely on hold. But she was careful not to give any hint about the likelihood of a rate increase or easing, saying only that the Fed has made no decision to leave policy unchanged and that it is continuing to examine incoming economic and financial data carefully.
Carl Palash, the chief economist at MCM Moneywatch, a market analysis firm, said the producer price numbers showed that moderation in manufacturing and consumer spending had taken the edge off inflation. "We should see something like that in the March Consumer Price Index," he said. "But I think, given that the economy is still operating at full capacity, the market still has to be weary of inflation risks in the outlook.
"That was the thrust of the Yellen comments this morning that took the wind out of the market."
Mr. Palash went on to say that the market's negative reaction to the Richmond Fed regional survey was a result of its focusing on the headline numbers, which reflected retail prices and raw materials. "But I have to be cautious about that report because it's a local survey and I'm not sure it's truly representative of the economy," he said.
Mr. Palash noted that while the Johnson Redbook survey was strong, "this week is difficult, because of the adjustments for the holiday effect." He added, "I would view today's Redbook with a lot of caution." He believes the market will have to wait until the end of the month to draw any conclusions.
And while the headline numbers were bearish for bonds, there were some soft spots in the report, which suggest that apparel was below retailers' expectations for sales because of cold weather. This was similar to the Mitsubishi report.
Mr. Palash attributed the afternoon pickup in bond prices to some short-covering that started when the Redbook report showed retail sales up 3.9 percent, below market rumors of a 5 percent gain.

HEADLINE: In America;
Jobless In Bay Ridge

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
The "Dear Employee" letters were signed by First Deputy Mayor Peter J. Powers. Many of them were sent out. The one that I saw was delivered to a man who lives with his family in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn, a stable middle- and working-class enclave about five miles from City Hall and several light years from the seat of Federal power in Washington.
Consisting of four short, devastating paragraphs, the letter is the kind that can leave the recipient disoriented, afraid, sometimes even ashamed. It begins, "Despite every effort to achieve savings through attrition . . ." 
 By the end of the third paragraph, the cold, gray bureaucratic language is set in darker type and underlined, as if some emphasis were needed. "I strongly encourage you," the letter says, "to avail yourself of this final severance opportunity."
On Monday the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, announced officially that he was running for President. Like most politicians, Mr. Dole feels compelled to portray himself as a champion of the middle class, a partisan of hard-working folks like those in Bay Ridge. The preferred way of doing this is to indulge in fantasy. And so Mr. Dole looked out at his audience in Topeka, Kan., and said, to tremendous cheers: "Let me make one fundamental belief crystal clear. We can cut taxes and balance the budget all at the same time."
This, of course, would be a shock to any schoolchild who has recently mastered arithmetic. Mr. Dole seemed serious -- as serious as a grown man can be while trying to assure us that down is up, up is down, and the sky is no longer blue. What Mr. Dole managed to prove is that he, like most politicians from both parties, is clueless about the one issue that would help the middle class (and everyone else) the most -- employment.
Bay Ridge is, for the most part, conservative in its politics. It voted for Rudolph Giuliani over David Dinkins, and George Pataki over Mario Cuomo. But the issue in Bay Ridge is no different from the issue in Bedford-Stuyvesant or the issue across most of America.
"My constituents are concerned about unemployment and underemployment," said Sal F. Albanese, a Democrat who represents Bay Ridge on the City Council. He noted that the official unemployment rate in New York City is 8.5 percent, and the real rate is much higher.
"I held a hearing on employment about a week and a half ago," Mr. Albanese said. "Two men from Bay Ridge were among those who testified. Both were white males and seemed very conservative. One had been laid off by Nynex, which was downsizing last year. He was 47 years old and he actually broke down and cried. The other had worked at Taystee Bread for 22 years, and he'd been out of work for more than a year. He cried, too."
Neither the Republicans nor the Democrats know what to do about this. In fact, the fundamental approach of both parties is to take the downsizing mindset of corporate America and apply it to government. When the current budget-cutting frenzy really takes hold, a staggering number of government employees across the country will be forced out of work.
"There are a tremendous number of civil servants who live in my district," said Mr. Albanese, "but that area of opportunity is basically being choked off."
It is estimated that in the New York area there are at least eight applicants for every available job. On March 16, nearly 1,000 men and women showed up at a Labor Department office in White Plains to apply for temporary jobs with no benefits at a General Motors plant in Tarrytown.
Bereft of ideas, yet faced with constituents increasingly anxious about their economic prospects, the politicians have turned to scapegoating and demagoguery. Instead of figuring out how to put America back to work, our so-called leaders are spinning deceptive and destructive yarns about the twin evils of affirmative action and immigration, the miraculous effects of the death penalty and the everlasting benefits of assault weapons.
Mr. Dole was in New York Monday evening. He picked up a couple of million at fund-raisers and hobnobbed with Boss D'Amato. Not much was said about Bay Ridge. Not much was said about ordinary New Yorkers walking the unemployment plank.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Retains Some of Its Gains Despite Data on Producer Prices

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar held onto some short-term gains yesterday after rebounding on Monday from a postwar low against the Japanese yen.
Callum Henderson, an analyst with the consulting firm MMS International, said: "The dollar is indeed consolidating after the recent yen turmoil. In the very near term, we may have found a floor. But further out, there is some potential for further dollar-yen decline." 
 The dollar had touched a low of 80.15 yen in Tokyo trading early Monday, rebounding to settle in New York trading at 84.02 yen late that afternoon. Yesterday, it slipped to 83.82 yen.
On Monday, the dollar made its biggest one-day gain against the German mark since August. Yesterday, it slipped here, too, to 1.4015 marks from 1.4100.
Currency dealers said the dollar had declined against the mark after the Labor Department reported that inflation at the producer level was flat in March.
Subdued inflation relieves pressure on the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates. Higher rates tend to make a currency more attractive, and dealers had hoped for a coordinated round of interest-rate changes to support the dollar.
The German central bank lowered its discount rate on March 30, and the Japanese are expected to soon cut their discount rate. But yesterday's producer-price report confirmed the expecations of some that the Fed would not raise rates soon.
Mr. Henderson of MMS International said the essential problem in foreign-exchange markets remained the strength of the yen, "which can only be halted by structural reforms in the Japanese economy."
"Further efforts are needed to stimulate domestic demand in Japan through fiscal or monetary policy," he added. "That's what Japan needs if it wants to see its economy pick up and import more U.S. products."
The low dollar has so far done little to correct the huge American trade deficit with Japan because of barriers to foreign goods in the Japanese market, analysts and Government officials reiterated.
"We have been told for a long time that changes in yen-dollar valuations would have a dramatic, positive impact on our trade deficit with Japan," Secretary of Commerce Ronald H. Brown said yesterday. "That has not been the case." Mr. Brown said negotiations with Japan were the only way to reduce the two nations' $60 billion trade imbalance.
In other currency trading in New York yesterday, the British pound fell to $1.5920 from $1.5930 on Monday. The dollar fell to 1.545 Swiss francs from 1.600 francs.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Those mortgage-backed derivative securities are about dead in the water.

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris 

 BODY:
TAKE big losses. Mix in a lot of bad publicity. What do you get? A market that is almost dead.
The creators of mortgage-backed derivative securities, who were churning out more than $1 billion a day of new merchandise early last year, managed to sell just $5.1 billion of such securities in the first quarter of this year. That was down an immodest 94 percent from the $82.5 billion sold in the first quarter of 1994. 
 "Nobody wants to buy them," said Guy Cecela, the editor and publisher of Inside Mortgage Securities, a newsletter in Bethesda, Md., that compiled the figures.
The figure was down even from the fourth quarter of 1994, which had looked like about the worst possible, when $6.1 billion in such securities were issued, and was the lowest since the last quarter of 1985, when $5 billion were issued. At the peak, in the third quarter of 1993, issuance came to $100.5 billion.
Mortgage-backed derivative securities take pools of mortgages and cut up the cash flows into several different securities. Those securities can have a wide variety of characteristics, including some fairly exotic ones, and since such securities were invented in 1983, the number of ways a pool could be cut up grew as investment bankers vied with each other in creativity.
Such derivative securities can range from amazingly safe and conservative to wildly speculative. Some parts can benefit if interest rates rise; others can suffer. Over all, however, mortgage-backed securities generally suffer if rates rise, as they did last year.
So far this year, mortgage rates have slipped. The failure of the mortgage-backed derivatives market to revive reflects the fact that investors in such securities suffered steep losses last year. The Securities Industry Association called what happened "a liquidity crisis in the secondary markets" as buyers vanished. Some owners of the securities turned out not to have understood the risks of the more exotic securities.
To create such securities, the underwriter must find buyers for all of the pieces. That has proved difficult this year. No doubt bad publicity about money managers who bought derivatives has scared some of them away from the market.
New mortgage derivatives can be created only from pools of mortgage-backed securities, and those are down sharply as well, in large part because fewer mortgages are being issued now that the refinancing boom has ended. But the issuance of derivatives is off far more.
In the first quarter of this year, only $41.6 billion in new mortgage-backed securities were issued, down 77 percent from the $178.6 billion issued in the same period of 1994 and off 28 percent from $57.8 billion in last year's fourth quarter.
One way of looking at the populariry of mortgage derivatives is to look at their total volume as a percentage of new mortgage securities. At the peak in 1993, more than half of new mortgage securities were cut up into derivatives; now the figure is 12 percent.

HEADLINE: Vietnam Investments

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: HANOI, April 11

 BODY:
The Vietnamese Government approved $1.9 billion in foreign investments during the first quarter of the year, almost triple the value of the ventures and projects licensed in the corresponding period of 1994. The increase, reported today by the State Committee for Cooperation and Investment, can be partly attributed to American investment after the United States ended its 19-year economic embargo against Vietnam in February 1994. The United States became Vietnam's eighth-largest investor last month, with 33 licensed ventures worth $525 million, the report said. Taiwan remained the largest source of foreign investment.

HEADLINE: Wine Talk

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial 

 BODY:
AS anyone who has climbed the Matterhorn or sped through the St. Gotthard Tunnel knows, the Swiss thrive on challenges. Even as we speak, they are here in New York for a go at a tough obstacle, the American wine market.
Swiss wine? Yes, the Swiss have made wine for probably as long as the French next door. Maybe longer; there are grapes in Switzerland, like the petite arvine, that supposedly trace their lineage back to the Roman legions. 
 Wine is not a major industry in Switzerland. All the Swiss vineyards together don't add up to the grape plantings in Sonoma County. Not much there, but as Spencer Tracy said of Katharine Hepburn in "Pat and Mike," "What's there is cherce."
The Swiss like to say that the rest of us don't know much about their wines because they, the wines, are so good that they, the Swiss, drink them all up. That's a good story, but it's not quite on the mark. The Swiss do drink lots of wine: per-person consumption is about 20 liters of their own each year plus 30 liters of imports. Beaujolais, made nearby, has been called the Swiss national drink.
Even so, the Swiss would be happy to export more of their wine than they do now -- virtually none -- which is the idea behind the current promotion in New York restaurants. The problem has long been price. Most of the vineyards are tiny, and most of them cling like mountain goats to south-facing Alpine slopes. Even under ideal economic conditions, production costs would be high. But added to this is the fact that Swiss vineyard workers are among the highest paid agricultural workers in the world.
More than half of all Swiss wine is white -- made from the chasselas grape. In skilled hands, chasselas produces a fresh, lively wine, often slightly petillant -- influenced by the soil from which it springs.
Chasselas predominates in three of the French-speaking cantons -- Geneva, Valais and Vaud. In the Valais, it is known as fendant, and so is the wine made from it. Pinot gris, chardonnay, marsanne, petite arvine and another singularly Swiss grape, the amigne, all find their way into white Swiss wines.
The Vaud is divided into five districts. The wines are generally known by the villages within the districts. Among the better known ones are Nyon, Morges, Dezaley, Epesses, St. Saphorin and Aigle. There are subtle, often intriguing differences among them, but they are all made from the chasselas grape.
The most popular red wine in French-speaking Switzerland is called Dole and is a blend of pinot noir and gamay. Dole is light and fruity and should be drunk young. Some pinot noir is produced as a very light red or rose called Oeil de Perdrix, or Eye of the Partridge.
In the German-speaking areas, the main white grape is a cross between sylvaner and riesling called Muller-Thurgau, a grape the Germans developed. The German-speaking cantons also make wine from pinot noir, which they, like the Germans, call blauburgunder or klevner.
Like the reds from the Vaud and Valais, the blauburgunder can be fruity and pleasant. And like them, it will never cause any French Burgundy or Beaujolais producers to lose a night's sleep.
In the Ticino region, around Locarno and Lugano, where Italian is the principal tongue, the main grape is merlot and, of course, the wine is red.
The best place to drink Swiss wines is in Switzerland, whether at an elegant restaurant like Girardet, near Lausanne; the Chat Botte at the Beau Rivage in Geneva or at any one of the rustic, lakeside inns along the shore of Lake Neuchatel. A cold, young Aigle les Murailles, with a freshly caught and simply prepared lake fish, in a setting of Swiss tranquillity, is one of life's true pleasures.
For the next few weeks, New Yorkers can enjoy the wines, and possibly the fish, at the following restaurants: Adrienne, the Four Seasons, Gramercy Park Cafe, Montrachet, Tse Yang, Lespinasse, Michael's, March, La Reserve, La Colombe d'Or, Daniel, Le Perigord, La Caravelle, Zut!, Colors, the Drake Bar, Picholine, Chanterelle, Aureole and Chiam. As part of the promotion, these restaurants will be offering a variety of Swiss wines by the glass during the month of April.
Retail prices for Swiss wines have never been more attractive. For example, a 1993 Aigle les Murailles from Henri Badoux is $24 at Morrell & Company in Manhattan. A 1993 Les Murettes, Fendant de Sion, is $16, and a rare Petite Arvine 1993, from Pierre Ollaire, is $20. For merlot devotees interested in seeing how the Swiss do it, a Ticinese version called Rubro can be found for around $28.
In addition to Morrell & Company, retailers participating in the Swiss wine promotion include Acker, Merrall & Condit and Beekman Liquors in New York City, and Wine and Spirit World in Fort Lee and Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J.
You may already have a Swatch and a Swiss Army knife. Are they not sufficient proof that the Swiss can do remarkable things when they put their minds to it?

TASTINGS
Fortant de France Kosher Chardonnay 1993. Vin de Pays d'Oc. About $8.
 
This varietal from the Languedoc-Roussillon region of France, whose introduction is timed to coincide with Passover, typifies the drier kosher wines replacing the traditionally heavy, sweet ones that dominated the market not long ago. Fortant de France is a leader in the effort to bring reasonably priced varietal wines from the South of France to the American market. A kosher merlot is scheduled for release here next autumn. While drier than old-style kosher wines, this chardonnay is hardly austere. On the contrary, it is a full-flavored, rounded wine that reflects the warm sun and generous soils of the Mediterranean vineyards that produced it. Obviously fashioned with a contemporary palate in mind, it is still soft enough and tasty enough to appeal even to old Concord hard-liners, although God forbid they should admit it.

HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW;
Warm but Unhappy Look at Farming

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN 

 BODY:
Paul Zehrer's moody family drama "Blessing" captures the rhythms and rituals of Midwestern farming life in such acute detail that you can almost feel the bite of the damp morning air at milking time and smell the pungency of the barn. Regularly throughout the film, the camera draws back to gauge the weather and survey the austere beauty of the countryside.
This atmosphere seeps under the skin of the film's four main characters, all members of dairy-farming family in Wisconsin. Jack (Guy Griffis), the flinty, autocratic head of the household, is an embittered eccentric barely able to make ends meet with his herd of dairy cattle. In fits of frustration, he beats his beloved cows. Lately he has acquired the habit of climbing to the top of his silo and taking snapshots. 
 His frightened wife, Arlene (Carlin Glynn), fends off despair by entering newspaper lotteries and tending her collection of small religious statues. Each time her husband climbs the silo, she is convinced he is spying on a woman from a neighboring farm. When she voices her suspicion of his roving eye, he flies into a rage, digs a gaping hole in the backyard and orders her to fill it up just to give her something to do.
Of the couple's three children, an older son has already fled the nest. Remaining are a younger son, 10-year-old Clovis (Clovis Siemon), and a 23-year-old daughter, Randi (Melora Griffis, Mr. Griffis's daughter), who is the movie's central character. Randi, who has vague dreams of becoming a marine biologist, plans to leave the farm, but her tugging sense of responsibility keeps delaying her departure.
"Blessing," which opens today at the Angelika 57, suggests a softened, contemporary echo of "Wisconsin Death Trip," Michael Lesy's celebrated collection of grim photographs, news stories and obituaries from the 1890's. Instead of telling a story, the film is a minutely drawn portrait of a troubled family that suggests the devastating impact of social and economic change on a 19th-century way of life. That life, the movie suggests, is painfully out of step with the beat of the modern world, which beckons by satellite dish and radio.
The family's state of frozen embattlement begins to thaw when Randi becomes involved with Lyle (Gareth Williams), a milk deliverer and freelance astrologer. They meet at the general store and form a friendship that quickly deepens into a romance. The fact that Lyle has a wife and child back East doesn't seem to faze them.
"Blessing," Mr. Zehrer's first feature film as a writer and director, presents a pointedly anti-romantic view of the heartland. All the characters except Clovis are gripped by boredom and a lurking claustrophobia.
If the screenplay has moments when the characters begin to sound like authorial mouthpieces, the director and his fine cast have pulled off the difficult task of portraying a family whose deep strains don't obscure their equally deep and helpless love.

BLESSING 1
 
Written and directed by Paul Zehrer; director of photography, Stephen Kazmierski; edited by Andrew Morreale and Mr. Zehrer; music by Joseph S. DeBeasi; production designer, Steve Rosenzweig; produced by Melissa Powell and Mr. Zehrer; released by Starr Valley Films. At the Angelika 57, 225 West 57th Street, Manhattan. HEADLINE: Dole Works on Expansion Of a Conservative Resume

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: DES MOINES, April 11

 BODY:
The day after signing a no-new-taxes pledge to reaffirm his credentials as a fiscal conservative, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas plunged into the Midwest today to present himself as a dedicated social conservative.
Making a weeklong tour to announce his candidacy for the Republican Presidential nomination, Mr. Dole unleashed scornful attacks on the entertainment industry, drug dealers and welfare mothers and put forth a forceful endorsement of voluntary prayer in schools. 
 "Our music and movies and advertising regularly push the limits of decency, bombarding our children with destructive messages of casual violence and even more casual sex," Mr. Dole, the Senate majority leader, told a crowd packed into a pavilion at the Iowa State Fairgrounds. "Nowhere is it more evident than in what we see on television. Prime-time programming once was for families. No more."
Mr. Dole's remarks here and at an earlier stop at the Capitol in Columbus, Ohio, were notable because in his 34-year career in the House and Senate, he has shied away from touchy social issues and been more closely identified with a pragmatic brand of conservatism geared toward economics.
But Mr. Dole is mounting his third bid for the Republican nomination against rivals who are generally to his right, and he must try to win over the party's primary voters, who tend to be more conservative than the rest of the party and the country as a whole. In particular, Mr. Dole must gain the support of the cultural and religious conservatives who more and more are making themselves heard in the Republican Party.
Thus, his sharp oratory today, as well as his call today and Monday for cutting Federal funding of the arts, was more reminiscent of former Vice President Dan Quayle's campaign against Hollywood and of Ralph Reed, the chairman of the Christian Coalition, than of the Bob Dole familiar to those who watch Congress.
Most surprising, perhaps, was Mr. Dole's outspokenness on prayer in schools. Although his aides noted that in 1984 Mr. Dole backed an amendment supporting school prayer, until today he had stayed largely silent on the issue.
"We must guarantee that every American has the right to enjoy religious liberty and freedom of conscience," he said. "If students can discuss sports, music or drama at school, they should also be allowed to voluntarily pray." Mr. Dole said he would favor legislating school prayer rather than a constitutional amendment, adding that the Senate probably would not have time to take up the matter this year.
"One of the most alarming aspects of Government intrusiveness has been the assault it has waged on our values," Mr. Dole said. "Today we find that voluntary prayer is forbidden in our classrooms, that the moral code we nurture in our churches and synagogues is under attack from our Government."
He dived into a litany of other red-eat issues for social conservatives:
* "We must hold Hollywood accountable for putting profit ahead of common decency."
* "We must stop cash payments to children having children and find another way to care for their babies."
*"Drugs are evil and the drug dealers must be punished and should be punished. They ought to throw the book at them."
*"No President should ever, ever appoint a Surgeon General who believes the best way to fight illegal drugs is to legalize them," referring to Dr. Joycelyn Elders, the former Surgeon General and a favorite target of social conservatives.
Mr. Dole's comments today were the latest example of his trying to avoid the mistakes that sunk his Presidential campaign in 1988.
In New Hampshire on Monday, his aides made public a pledge that Mr. Dole signed promising not to raise marginal tax rates. He refused to go along with a similar pledge in 1988, a move that helped cost him the primary, and he has in the past supported some tax increases to try to control the Federal deficit.
But signing the pledge this time may prove politically risky over time. The man who did make the no-new-tax promise in 1988, George Bush, learned in his failed re-election campaign in 1992 that voters do not take well to broken promises.
Mr. Dole explained to reporters traveling on a chartered plane with him here today that he did not think raising taxes was nearly as heated an issue as it was in 1988. But he said he went with the pledge after he was satisfied that this year's version would allow for the closing of loopholes. "That was my objection last time," he said.
Robert Teeter, Mr. Bush's pollster in the 1988 campaign, said in a telephone interview that it was only natural for Mr. Dole to sign the pledge. " '88 and '95 are different times," he said. "Public opinion has changed. It would surprise me if any candidate did not take a pretty strong anti-tax position."
Jack Abramoff, a partner in Americans for Tax Reform, the group that devised the pledge, said members would hold Mr. Dole to the pledge for years, whether he stays as majority leader or is elected President. If Mr. Dole were to break the pledge, Mr. Abramoff warned, "I'm sure he would probably enjoy some of the same public scrutiny that President Bush enjoyed."
"But I don't think it's on the horizon this time," he added.
In Mr. Dole's speeches today, the one important social issue conspicuously absent was abortion. While Mr. Dole and some of his rivals have studiously avoided raising the divisive issue, the Senator shrugged off the omission, telling reporters, "My views are consistently pro-life."
Mr. Dole also said he was not pandering to the right wing. He said that he had long held the views he enunciated this week but that most people were more aware of his record of forging compromises as the Republican leader.
Still, in a glimpse of the old Dole, at one point today he seemed eager to temper his uncharacteristically strong words by telling the audience in Columbus that he was no extremist. Asked later to explain, he said voters were "looking for someone with stability, with experience."
Mr. Dole's campaign manager, Scott Reed, was blunt when asked about the Senator's comments on social issues: "Any survey research you or I have seen shows that these are issues that primary voters care about or are motivated by." As for his reversal on the tax pledge, Mr. Reed said, "It's called getting off the defense."
The Senator's comments today seemed intended to protect him from being outflanked on the right by competitors like Senator Phil Gramm of Texas. Mr. Dole rejected the notion that his colleague was getting under his skin -- though he did note that he was headed for the Texan's turf for a fund-raising event. "I'm going to get under his skin -- and his wallet -- tomorrow," he said with a sly smile. "I'm going to Dallas."

HEADLINE: Trump Is Selling Plaza Hotel To Saudi and Asian Investors

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT with KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
The Plaza Hotel, long a symbol of luxury and grandeur in New York and more recently the crown jewel in Donald J. Trump's shaky business empire, is being sold to two of the world's richest men: a Saudi Arabian Prince and one of Singapore's leading entrepreneurs.
The buyers said yesterday that the deal put a total value of $325 million on the landmark hotel at 59th Street and Fifth Avenue near Central Park. 
 In essence, the buyers are taking over the Plaza by assuming most of its debts. None of the money from the deal will go to Mr. Trump, who acquired the hotel for about $400 million in 1988. Rather, it will go to banks in the United States that had lent money to Mr. Trump and to banks in Japan that hold a mortgage on the hotel property.
While Mr. Trump will retain a say in the hotel's operations as a minority partner, his surrender of control is a defeat for the real estate developer, who in the heady days of the late 1980's proclaimed the Plaza "the ultimate trophy in the world." But the world has drastically changed for Mr. Trump since then, as real estate prices collapsed.
The complexity of the sale announced yesterday, and the international scope of the transaction, illustrated how the arenas of real estate and finance have grown beyond national boundaries, and how the business world has shrunk, in ways even the most visionary people could have hardly imagined when the Plaza opened in 1907.
The sale, rumored for weeks, was announced in Singapore by CDL Hotels International Ltd. The company, which owns 35 hotels around the world including the Hotel Macklowe the Millenium in Manhattan, said it had formed a venture with an entity controlled by Prince Walid bin Talal, a 40-year-old nephew of King Fahd of Saudi Arabia who has been buying into the luxury hotel business.
The prince first came to prominence several years ago when he invested heavily in Citicorp as that banking company was struggling with big losses. He has since invested in the Four Seasons Hotels chain, Saks Fifth Avenue and Euro Disney.
CDL is part of the Singapore Hong Leong Group, a corporate empire controlled by the developer Kewk Hong Png, which also has interests in real estate, machine tools and energy. His son, Kwek Leng Beng, runs CDL.
The purchase of the hotel is a complex deal but in its simplest terms the new investors will take control of the property and manage the hotel, and Mr. Trump, who once had near total control of it, will have a substantially reduced role.
He will, however, develop plans with the new owners to build luxury condominiums on the Plaza's top floors and additional retail space. The new owners also plan to spend $28 million for renovations.
As part of the deal, CDL and the Prince will pay down the outstanding debt on the hotel owed to the banks, reducing it to about $25 million from more than $300 million. According to people familiar with the transaction, that remaining $25 million will be converted into equity held by a bank consortium led by Citibank.
Under terms of an agreement reached late in 1992, that consortium agreed to forgive overdue interest payments on some $300 million in loans in return for a 49 percent stake in the Plaza.
"There will be four partners," said Abraham Wallach, a spokesman for Mr. Trump. "The banks, primarily Citibank, who will get a preferred return on their equity; Prince Walid; CDL Hotels and Mr. Trump."
Mr. Wallach declined to specify what percentage of the Plaza each partner would own. But at a news conference in Singapore yesterday, a CDL spokesman told The Associated Press that the Prince and CDL "eventually" would hold up to 80 percent of the hotel.
In addition to paying down the debt, the new partners have agreed to pay $25 million in each of the next three years to reduce a $300 million first mortgage on the property held by a consortium of Japanese banks.
The mortgage, which is held by the Industrial Bank of Japan, comes due in December. If the Japanese group does not want to refinance the loan, CDL and the Prince have agreed to pay off the mortgage in its entirety.
Mr. Trump currently owns 51 percent of the Plaza. The rest is owned by the banks, which obtained their interest from Mr. Trump three years ago in exchange for a substantial reduction in his bank debt. Mr. Wallach said those involved hoped to complete the deal by summer.
Mr. Trump bought the Plaza during the real estate boom of the 1980's, using borrowed money. Additional debt was piled on the property over the next couple of years as he leveraged the landmark to buy the Eastern Airlines shuttle and to help pay the construction cost of his Taj Mahal casino in Atlantic City.
By 1992, the weight of the recession that hit New York City after the stock market crash in 1987 and the collapse in real estate prices had taken a heavy toll on Mr. Trump's finances. Negotiations began to rework some $560 million in debt.
After the Citibank consortium agreed to forgive the past interest payments on debt, Mr. Trump still retained the 51 percent interest on paper, but since he had no equity in the hotel -- having put up no cash when he bought it -- the banks effectively owned the property. The banks have been trying to find a buyer for the last three years.
Negotiations between CDL and Mr. Trump began last fall. In February, the Prince visited the hotel and expressed an interest.
Along with Mr. Kwek and the Prince, Mr. Trump will be a member of a management committee and "will have responsibility for setting policy at the hotel," the announcement in Singapore said. But day-to-day operations will be handled by Fairmont Hotel Management, the San Francisco-based concern in which the Prince is half-owner.
Designed by Henry Janeway Hardenbergh, the architect whose works include the Dakota apartment building on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, the Plaza has long been as much institution as hotel. Overlooking Grand Army Plaza and Central Park South, the 19-story French Renaissance structure has played host to billionaires, heads of state, artists and dreams.
When it opened for business on Oct. 1, 1907, Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt was the first to sign the guest register. Jay Gould and other turn-of-the-century high-rollers kept suites there. So did Frank Lloyd Wright, who according to legend grudgingly conceded that the Plaza was one of the few buildings he liked that he had not designed himself.
Films celebrating the Plaza include "Plaza Suite," "North by Northwest," "Network," "The Way We Were," and "Home Alone 2."
Mr. Trump may not have known every chapter in the hotel's history, but he no doubt knew some of it when he said, after he bought it: "This isn't just a building, it's the ultimate work of art. I was in love with it. I tore myself up to get the Plaza."
Rates at the Plaza vary by season and availability. A reservations assistant said yesterday that typical rates range from $225 to $495 for a room and $650 to $12,000 for a suite.
Ivana Trump, Mr. Trump's wife at the time he bought the hotel, managed the Plaza for a while but no longer has a role there.
Regardless of his financial troubles, Mr. Trump and his organization have run the Plaza quite well, said Thomas McConnell, a hotel expert with the accounting firm of Arthur Andersen & Company.
Before Mr. Trump acquired the Plaza, "it was more a three-star," Mr. McConnell said, "and he kicked it up to a four-star."
The Plaza has had a consistent occupancy percentage in the high 70's or low 80's, which exceeds the city average, Mr. McConnell said.

HEADLINE: Other Party to the Contract Isn't Impressed

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER 

DATELINE: YPSILANTI, Mich., April 8

 BODY:
"How many of you watched Newt?" asked Peter Fletcher, presiding at the Ypsilanti Republicans' regular Saturday breakfast at Max's Deli the morning after the House Speaker was on national television to celebrate his Contract With America.
There were 16 Republicans drinking coffee around a long table. One person, Bob Kilpatrick, raised his hand. Sheepish glances were exchanged among the others. No one else had caught the speech. They had had other things to do, they said. 
 JoAnn Geer, a retired funeral director, had gone to dinner with a friend. Joe Lawrence, a property manager, had worked on his taxes. Mr. Fletcher, a former Republican national committeeman, announced without apology that he had taken in a particularly fine performance of "H.M.S. Pinafore" at the University of Michigan, in Ann Arbor.
The lack of excitement at Max's Deli was hardly unusual. From more than 100 conversations around the country -- in small North Carolina towns, in the wealthy desert outskirts of Phoenix, in the auto plant town of Ypsilanti outside Detroit and in suburban Massachusetts -- what emerged in recent days was a sense that those who had framed the Contract were far more enthusiastic about it than the people with whom they had supposedly contracted.
"It's just a political strategy," said Lonnie Parcell, a 50-year-old contractor eating at Stacy's Diner in Pittsboro, N.C.
Michael Marshner, a 43-year-old disabled truck driver now working as a massage therapist in Dearborn, Mich., who voted Libertarian in the last election, said: "They ought to call it the Contract out on America. How can you believe them? Everything they say falls through or doesn't come through. What happened to the Brady bill? What happened to the Gramm-Rudman Act? That was supposed to fix everything. The biggest thing that's out of control is the politicians."
Even Mr. Fletcher said Republican leaders and journalists were focusing on a political fad. "It's Contract, Contract, Contract, just like it was health care, health care, health care," at the start of the Clinton Administration, he said.
Despite such sentiments, plenty of people interviewed praised the Republicans' legislative agenda and the House's passage of it under the promised 100-day deadline. "For the first time in 40 years there's been a change in direction," said Jim Bruner, a tax lawyer and Republican from Scottsdale, Ariz.
And Bob Kilpatrick, the lone Republican at Max's Deli who watched Mr. Gingrich's speech, raved about the new Congress and the Contract. "Oh, I think it's great," he said. "They got it all the way through the House. It brings new hope."
But in Durham, N.C., the members of St. Joseph's A.M.E. Episcopal Church did not feel hopeful. Ed Stewart, a church elder said, "That Contract With American has placed black folks under siege."
While Democrats and registered independents, not surprisingly, disparaged the Contract, and Republicans were more favorable, most of those interviewed expressed similar views on three subjects. They said the House Republican proposal to balance the budget while giving the middle class a tax cut was unworkable. And while they enthusiastically support the Republican call for an overhaul of the welfare system, many said they thought that the House measure went too far. And they were disappointed that the proposed term limits were voted down.
In Shrewsbury, Mass., a suburb of Worcester, Virginia Berberian, a Republican, said: "How are you going to cut the taxes and balance the budget? Where's the money going to come from? You can't do it."
But while the Contract may be the talk of Washington, as well as a media focal point, out in the country it seemed almost incidental to people's lives. Some had not heard about it, or were barely familiar with it. Cindi Johnson, a 31-year-old mother of two small children, and a Republican, was racing from a gas station in Dearborn, to her waitress job at Lim's Garden the other evening. "Contract With America?" she said, in a hurry, but trying to respond politely to a reporter's question. "I don't pay too much attention. I'm working class. I go day by day. It has nothing to do with me."
"Life goes on no matter what happens in Congress," said Mrs. Johnson, who, with her husband laid off from his job laying asphalt, has been putting in extra hours at the restaurant.
At Max's Deli, Mr. Fletcher brought up the Contract only toward the end of an informal discussion that had ranged from the town's recent election of an independent as Mayor to the irritating necessity of downtown parking meters.
"If we were having a special Congressional election today," he asked, "how important would the Contract be?" No one said a word. "Nobody thinks it would be important," Mr. Fletcher said. "Then why is it getting so much attention?" No one answered, but he said later that the media and the politicians were talking to themselves.
At Stacy's Diner in Pittsboro, N.C., Mr. Parcell, Bill Burgess and John Goldston, grabbing lunch after a morning spent laying the foundation for a septic tank, were griping to a reporter that the Contract was just another done deal cooked up by a bunch of crooked millionaires.
"They're all a bunch of damn liars," said Mr. Parcell, an independent who, like his buddies, voted for Ross Perot in the last Presidential election. "It's the same thing on TV every week."
Digging into a plate of barbecue at the next booth, Mike Grinstead, who owns a commercial seeding business, broke in: "You must be talking about the O. J. trial."
Mr. Burgess, a 27-year-old Democrat, laughed. "Might as well be."
 
Chapel Hill, N.C.
Beneficial Side To Government
 Chapel Hill, a bucolic college town, is part of a Congressional district that, like so many others across the country, replaced a longtime Democratic incumbent representative last fall with a Republican.
Among the pockets of liberal sentiment, however, are the Chapel Hill retirees who belong to Arvin Kramish and Joe Kahl's "Readings in American History" discussion group. At their last meeting, the retirees, who overwhelmingly supported the Democrat last fall, were considering Franklin Delano Roosevelt's first and second inaugural addresses, speeches they had heard on the radio as children during the Depression.
The group, which had studied the House Republicans' 10-point Contract, disparaged Mr. Gingrich's efforts to compare the legislative achievements of his 100 days to the first 100 days of F.D.R. President Roosevelt had, among other things, closed the banks, established Federal banking insurance to protect depositors and created the Securities and Exchange Commission to regulate the stock market.
"All that's happened in the last 100 days is that the House has passed 8 of the 10 points," said Mr. Kramish, a retired economist, who spent much of his career with the State Department and the Pentagon.
The discussion group members said they had been struck anew by Mr. Roosevelt's emphasis on what government could do for people. In the second speech, Mr. Roosevelt spoke of "the need to find through government the instrument of our united purpose to solve for the individual the ever-rising problems of a complex civilization."
Mr. Kramish said: "What would be the reaction to that speech among the Republicans in Congress today? Nobody would dare read it on the floor."
The group also worried about what would happen to poor people. "This breed of Republican is a very dangerous animal," said Bernard Rosen, a retired pyschologist. "They're in some danger of rending the social fabric of society."
 
Scottsdale, Ariz.
Crossed Fingers For a Tax Break
 Scottsdale, a prosperous desert town where the landscape is dotted with golf courses and manicured gardens, is staunchly Republican. And while the first topic of conversation has been the return of the San Francisco Giants for spring training, many people there readily expressed satisfaction with the speedy passage through the House of the Republican agenda.
"It's the first time there's been an accounting," said Diana Smith, the president of the Scottsdale Chamber of Commerce. "They said, 'Score us after 100 days.' We haven't seen that in a politician."
Ms. Smith and nine other local civic and business leaders were lauding Mr. Gingrich and his Contract in an informal meeting the other day at the Chamber of Commerce, across from City Hall, which is ringed by a sculptured moat that is home to a group of swans.
"We're still not convinced that it's all going to happen," said Tim Bray, the president of a land development consulting company. "But this is the best opportunity we've seen."
The consensus was that the easing of Federal mandates and the proposed capital gains tax were among the most important items in the Contract. "Historically, when they have cut the capital gains tax rate, they have raised more money," said Jim Bruner, the tax lawyer.
But he and most of the others said they did not think that it was possible to cut taxes for the middle class and balance the budget. And balancing the budget, they said, was more important. They were also disappointed, they said, that the term-limits proposal had failed.
They became most animated when they turned to welfare and the Republicans' insistence on getting welfare recipients to work.
"There's a personal reward in earning something," Ms. Smith said.
Mr. Bruner, who as a boy worked in his father's hardware store in Iowa, said welfare recipients needed to assume more responsibility. "Why work when you get a check?" he asked. "They get food stamps, free medical, they don't pay taxes. Pardon the expression, but when you keep popping out more kids, you get more money."
Still, the group said that people should be gradually phased off welfare and that the disabled should continue to receive help. "We're not a third world country," Mr. Bruner said. "We're not going to throw people on the street who cannot help themselves."
 
Ypsilanti, Mich.
Bigger Worries Close to Home
 Americans are buying cars again. Outside the Motor City, in Ypsilanti, the men and women at the General Motors Powertrain plant are working overtime making transmissions for Cadillacs.
That is what James Bell, a welder operator, has been doing in the past 100 days, working, 12 hours a day, six days a week. "Yeah, we're making it," said Mr. Bell, 39, who has three children. "Making it on 12 hours a day."
But the auto workers do not expect it to last. Down the road is a reminder of how tenuous is their hold on the American Dream: the Willow Run Assembly Plant, where once 4,500 men and women had jobs making Chevrolet Caprices. General Motors shut the plant three years ago.
Mr. Bell, like many other auto workers, believes in the union and Democratic ideals. Michigan's conservative, tax-cutting Republican Governor, John Engler, may be a role model for the new Congress, but he is no hero on the assembly line.
"All they've talked about is what they can take away from poor people and give to the rich," Mr. Bell said. "They want welfare reform, but they're not providing jobs."
Ken Crane, 56, a machine repairman at Powertrain, is an independent, who supported Ross Perot for President. Asked about the last 100 days, Mr. Crane did not talk about the Contract.
"My father died last Friday," he said. "He was 87. My mother is in a nursing home. I visit her several times a week. My wife's mother has breast cancer. She's being operated on today. My son, who is 27, lives with us. He has a maintenance job at Big Boy. He was born brain damaged and can't drive. So my wife takes him to work and I bring him home."
There is some talk that the transmissions made now at Powertrain may eventually be moved to another plant. With mortgages to pay and families to feed, Mr. Crane and many of his co-workers were more concerned with their own contract, with General Motors, than with the Contract with America.
