HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Airbus Has Its Eye on Half of the Global Market

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: TOULOUSE, France

 BODY:
Boeing may scoff, but Airbus Industrie is serious: It wants to command half of the world market for large civilian aircraft by the next century.
One way to do it, its executives believe, is to make planes that are cheaper to buy and cheaper to operate than Boeing's. 
 For some time, Airbus has been the only real challenger to the Boeing Company's supremacy in transport production. Started in 1969 and backed by the Governments of Germany, France, Britain and Spain, Airbus has clawed its way to about a 30 percent share of the global market to Boeing's 50 percent.
In January, it made something of a splash by contending it had taken more orders last year than its American rival -- 125 versus 120. Boeing scorned the numbers as a fluke. Moreover, analysts said the American aircraft maker could get a spate of huge orders this year.
Airbus acknowledged that the milestone was mostly symbolic. Its actual deliveries last year totaled 123 aircraft, compared with Boeing's 271. And its revenue of $8.5 billion paled next to the American company's $21.9 billion. Airbus conceded that Boeing would probably maintain its 50 percent market share over the long haul.
But, it said, it wants the other half. And its main pitch -- that its planes are more cost effective than Boeing's -- resonated with a North American airline industry that is only now recovering from several years of losses.
Leading its marketing charge is John J. Leahy, a compact 44-year-old native New Yorker who formerly was with Piper Aircraft in the United States. Before joining Airbus headquarters in this southern French city as senior vice president for marketing, Mr. Leahy worked at the European consortium's North American subsidiary for 10 years, helping to mount a successful sales drive. The way he sees it, Airbus has long enjoyed a built-in cost advantage. By designing an entire range of aircraft from scratch, it was able to incorporate features that made its planes economical to operate. Engines were generally similar in type, reducing maintenance costs, and cockpits were virtually identical, making it easier and cheaper to deploy crews. Moreover, Airbus pioneered computerized flight systems, enabling airlines to reduce crews from three or four to two or three on many flights.
Such considerations swayed Air Canada into placing a hotly contested $1 billion order for Airbuses last May. The transaction tells a lot about Airbus's aggressive selling techniques.
Air Canada, reeling from two years of heavy losses, was trying to decide whether to refurbish its aging fleet of McDonnell Douglas DC-9's or replace them with Airbus's new A319's. It was already flying A320's, so buying the new models would have made a nice fit. What clinched the deal, though, was Airbus's offer to provide full financing on the sale.
"The No. 1 thing is unrestricted interchange of air crews, so that pilot productivity is phenomenal," Kym Robertson, an Air Canada spokeswoman, said. "Plus, the A319 and A320 engines are identical, so you have cost reductions on things like simulators and spare parts."
With the Air Canada deal fresh in mind, Mr. Leahy last year pushed through the idea for a new Airbus Finance Company based in Dublin that will eventually become Airbus's principal financing vehicle. It will also enable the big aerospace concerns in Germany, France, Britain and Spain, which own Airbus, to shift the cost of financing aircraft purchases by their customers from their own balance sheets to the finance company. That would decrease their risk in case of default, and maintaining their own borrowing capacity. Paul Ruddle, an analyst at S. G. Warburg in London, said this might give Airbus a competitive advantage over Boeing, since it separates the group's borrowing needs for aircraft finance from those required to develop new products.
Boeing's finance arm, however, does essentially the same thing. But to increase its borrowing capacity, Boeing has taken the reverse route. To develop its new 777 long-haul jetliner, for instance, Boeing turned to three big Japanese manufacturers, led by Kawasaki Heavy Industries, whose own borrowing capacity supplemented that of Boeing, thus taking pressure off Boeing's own balance sheet.
Air Canada also ordered six A340's to replace 20-year-old Boeing 747's on the airline's Toronto-Vancouver-Osaka, Japan, routes. Part of the reason was that Airbus persuaded the airline that its model's smaller size was more cost effective.
Although matching the range of the Boeing jumbo, the Airbus 340 has a seating capacity that is about two-thirds that of the jumbo, yet boasts the same "seat-mile cost" -- the price it costs to transport one passenger. When passengers, or cargo, are short, the Airbus is more profitable.
And because Canada's air-traffic treaty with Japan limits the cargo that Air Canada's jumbos can haul on passenger flights, Ms. Robertson said, "Our 747's are now flying with their upper cargo decks empty."
Mr. Leahy said that "in terms of seat cost, the 340 is the most efficient plane out." "From Toulouse to London," he added, "it takes less fuel per seat than if you took your car."
Mr. Leahy is also trying to convince airlines that by flying Airbus's 340 in place of Boeing's 747 they can attract passengers by offering direct flights from city to city, rather than making them fly jumbos from hub to hub, and then transfer to feeder flights.
"Take Tokyo, which is a very congested airport," he said. "How many people really want to fly to Tokyo? They want to go from Chicago to Seoul, or Chicago to Hong Kong. After a 12-hour flight, they sit around Tokyo airport for four hours waiting for a connection, when as a business traveler they want to go point to point."
Mr. Leahy appears to have convinced Singapore officials in the other big transaction of 1994. Last June, Singapore said it was splitting a major order for $10.3 billion worth of aircraft between Boeing and Airbus. The order was a blow not only to Boeing, but also to McDonnell Douglas, which had bid an upgraded version of its three-engine MD-11 long-range airliner, but was cut out by Airbus.
Boeing, meantime, has been responding to the Airbus challenge with its new 777, the twin-engine long-range jetliner that will begin delivery this year. Boeing is also expecting several major orders this year, notably from China and Saudi Arabia. And the American company brushes aside many of Airbus's boasts as wishful thinking.
"Any airline interested in maximizing revenues and minimizing costs is going to be matching the plane to the requirements, so we all have to provide planes for market niches," T. Craig Martin, a Boeing spokesman in Seattle, said. "And Boeing has the most extended family."
Mr. Martin rejected Airbus's claim that the 340 is the most efficient plane. He said that as an example Boeing's new 777-200B was as cheap to fly as the A340-300X but, with 30 more seats, the 777 had much lower seat-mile costs.
"Profitability is always based on a set of assumptions, and we're all expert on creating sets of assumptions that look good," he added. Mr. Martin said that Boeing had already moved to a city-to-city system, from a hub-to-hub system, on North Atlantic routes and it planned to do so worldwide. For all of Airbus's 1994 successes, it has also had setbacks. In recent months, two major American carriers, Continental Airlines and Delta Air Lines, announced they were discontinuing the few Airbuses they now fly, to simplify their fleet structure and rely mainly on Boeing as a supplier. Whether or not it meets its 50 percent market-share goal, Airbus is clearly a European success story. While it does not disclose earnings, Jean Pierson, the Frenchman who is the Airbus chief executive, said the consortium has been operating profitably sine 1990, and industry insiders estimate last year's pretax earnings at about $350 million, compared with Boeing's earnings of $856 million.

HEADLINE: 'Can You Hurl, Lad?';
A Sport Deep in the Irish Blood Is Running Thin in New York

BYLINE: By PAM BELLUCK 

 BODY:
Two thousand years ago, or so the legend goes, an Irish hero conquered a kingdom by wrestling a giant guard dog and shoving a ball down its throat. This was not just any ball. It came from the lightning-fast, rough-and-tumble, lacrosselike sport called hurling.
That pretty much sealed hurling's place as Ireland's national pastime. Ancient armies played it to warm up for battle, sometimes killing hundreds before the real fighting began. Fourteenth-century British rulers banned it: too Irish. Irish Republican Army supporters used hurley sticks to break up British Army recruiting classes. 
 And for decades, an Irishman coming to New York knew he could get a good job through the construction, carpentry or concrete unions if he answered yes to the important question: "Can you hurl, lad?"
But now, after decades of bare-handed catches and overhead smacks, the sport that runs so deep in Irish blood is running thin in New York.
This year, there are only five senior (top-level) and six junior teams, about half the number that existed in the 1960's. The Galway team, which had not missed a season since 1914, was forced to drop out for lack of players, a tragedy memorialized in a two-page spread in The Irish Voice, an Irish-American weekly newspaper.
And for the first time, the 12 American hurling teams outside New York City forbade New York to borrow their players, fearing it would draw too many hurlers from Boston, Chicago or San Francisco. "It's harder to get it going here," said John Madden of the Tipperary team. "It's too bad, you know. Hurling is the Irish soul. It keeps people alive in Ireland."
Behind the decline is a tale of immigration and assimilation in a community that has shrunk from a quarter of New York City's population to 7 percent. The laborers who were, for so long, the backbone of Irish New York are no longer coming in great numbers -- and they were hurling's rank and file.
Hurling, a rugged sport requiring tremendous skill and speed, has been buffeted by everything from cautious Irish-American mothers to the soccer fever of the World Cup. It is even being hurt by its own high standards, set when Irish toddlers would pick up hurleys and smack stones around on great green meadows.
"It's too hard to play," said Fergus Hanna, a sportswriter for The Irish Voice. "You really have to be reared with the hurley."
In hurling, 15 players (13 in the American version) send a baseball-sized ball, called a sliothair (pronounced slither), racing nearly 100 miles an hour down a pitch, or field, longer and wider than a football field. Points are scored by getting the sliothair into a goal or over its crossbar. To do this, hurlers catch the sliothair bare-handed, whack it like a hockey puck or run while bouncing it on the curved end of the hurley, a three-foot stick carved only from ash trees in Ireland.
There are still Sunday hurling matches in Gaelic Park, a hardscrabble field on the edge of Riverdale, the Bronx, where for 70 years or so, the brogues in the bleachers have barked and cheered, growled about Irish politics and wagered a few bucks here and there on the teams named after their native counties.
"Hit it on the ground, you clown!" screamed Therese Crowe, at age 60 a passionate fan and president of the Tipperary team, at the first game of the season, on Sunday.
John Kennedy, on the Clare team, spurted blood over his face and yellow shirt when he was cocked over his right eye by a Limerick player's hurley. "Just patch it up there," Mr. Kennedy told Ms. Crowe, who is also the sideline nurse. A few minutes later, head swathed in bandages, Mr. Kennedy was back in the game.
Two other players got yanked for brawling. And in the last few seconds, Clare surged ahead to beat Limerick, last year's champions, 16 to 15.
Top Irish hurlers have, in recent years, been courted by New York teams, who paid their air fare out of dinner-dance fund-raisers and barroom collections, and fixed them up with apartments or jobs. And New York teams -- legally allowed three Irish players -- have been known to fly in ringers who pretended they were Americans; hurlers joke about redheads who dyed their hair brown and O'Connors who somehow became Fitzpatricks.
"There was a time when practically 100 percent of people coming out from Ireland, their first stop would be Gaelic Park," said Terry Connaughton, past president of the New York Gaelic Athletic Association. "Now, they're interested in other sports. They'll go skiing or something, and of course, you can't blame them for that."
Dessie Costello is feeling it firsthand. Mr. Costello came to New York in 1985 during a burst of Irish immigration, most of it illegal, as people fled high unemployment in Ireland. He got a carpentry job and hurled for Westmeath. It was a golden age for the sport.
Now 40, Mr. Costello said he is too old for the body-bruising game. But as his generation retires, there are too few to replace them.
"There's a different type of Irish coming over," said John McDonald, who came from Kilkenny in 1992. "They have way more education than the former immigrants, better degrees. They are computer analysts and such."
Mr. Costello would love his son Kieran, 7, to play the game. But the other day, at training for the all-star hurling team in Van Cortlandt Park, Kieran squatted restlessly. "I like basketball," he proclaimed.
"The first generation Irish-American, they haven't attuned to it at all," said Norbert Hennessy, a leader of the Tipperary team and owner of Hennessy Headquarters, a pub near Gaelic Park. Folks still come on Monday nights to watch videos of Ireland's hurling matches, but the pictures on the walls and the marquee over the door reflect the bar's real bread and butter: soccer, especially since Ireland made the final rounds of last year's World Cup.
Hurling has only a handful of American-born players -- some actually raised in Ireland.
"American mums don't want to put their kid out there and get him chewed up with the hurley," said Cecily Rohan, president of the dormant Galway team. Helmets have not caught on with most hurlers, although young players in Ireland now wear them.
"I've lost more skin than would make a man," said Mr. Madden, sidelined with a pulled groin, his face pocked with hurley scars. "But at least my teeth are intact."
Even in Ireland, the sport is not at its height. There are still more than 100,000 hurlers, all unpaid amateurs, but the quality has dropped some, said Danny Lynch, a spokesman for Ireland's Gaelic Athletic Association, which has been sending coaches into schools to train young hurlers.
In New York, die-hards are determined to keep the game alive. The defunct Galway team held a $55-a-head dance Saturday to pay for last year's plane fares and regroup for next year.
"It'll never fade for good," Ms. Crowe said. "Our culture and our heritage will never die, believe me."

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
Lessons for Bruno From His Own District and His Relatives' Good Fortune

BYLINE: By Joyce Purnick 

 BODY:
JOSEPH L. BRUNO is the new majority leader of the New York State Senate, which makes him one of the three most powerful elected officials in state government. It is therefore of more than passing interest that he has this theory about black and Hispanic New Yorkers:
"They are the people that got their hands out," he said last week to Newsday. "They are the ones fighting for welfare." 
 The Senator's remarks ignore readily available facts, facts about the poor of New York that are easy to get and that make Mr. Bruno's comments sound crass. There are also facts that bear directly on the Senator's view of the world, facts about his unpoor relatives who have turned up on the state payroll since the Senator became majority leader in December. Talk about handouts.
Begin with a demographic lesson for the majority leader, Republican from Brunswick, about his own constituents.
Mr. Bruno represents two upstate counties: all of Renssalaer County and part of Saratoga. Both support people with public assistance, meaning state or Federal Supplemental Security Income; Aid for Families with Dependent Children; Home Relief. Lo and behold, most of those Saratoga and Renssalaer beneficiaries are white, understandably enough, since most of the inhabitants of those counties are white.
According to 1990 Federal Census data, 97 percent of the households in Renssalaer are headed by non-Hispanic whites, and 88 percent of the households on public assistance are non-Hispanic whites, a close statistical match. The same in Saratoga, where 98 percent of the households and 96 percent of those receiving assistance are white. (There are disproportions elsewhere in New York. Statewide, Census figures show, 40 percent of the households on public assistance, but 74 percent of the total population, are white. Hispanic and black New Yorkers make up 24 percent of the population, but 58 percent of those on public assistance.)
The obvious question for Mr. Bruno is whether he really believes that all people on welfare have "their hands out," or just black and Hispanic residents. What does he think of those on assistance in Troy? It is the largest city in Renssalaer, and so economically depressed it has still not recovered from the loss of manufacturing jobs. Another question is whether Mr. Bruno includes Medicaid recipients in his "hands out" category, since Renssalaer County has a large proportion of elderly residents receiving Medicaid.
Matters are clearly more complicated than Mr. Bruno suggested. His spokesman, John E. McArdle, says that the majority leader "knows full well the extent of the problem in his district, who is on welfare in New York State, and what the breakdown is."
Mr. Bruno's remarks were taken out of context, he said, adding, "He feels welfare is wrong, it is a problem that needs to be addressed and is not a problem that needs to be defined in racial terms or should be."
MR. BRUNO'S comments came as he attacked Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, a Manhattan Democrat whom he accused of representing the interests of "the lowest income people" over those of the middle class. After his words hit print, Mr. Bruno said he stood by his statements, and made a highly conditional apology to "those people that feel offended." But, he added, "I in no way apologize for the message that I was delivering."
Mr. Bruno might consider what message he sends by putting members of his family on the state payroll. Since he became majority leader in December, state government has become an employment agency for his family, even as he and Gov. George E. Pataki are urgently trying to slash the state budget, notably services to the poor.
Despite the budget crisis, Mr. Bruno's son Joseph is now a $45,000-a-year construction inspector in the Office of General Services. The Senator's son-in-law, Richard Hynes, is also in the Office of General Services, as an assistant to the commissioner, at $41,865 a year. Mr. Bruno's brother Robert just happened to find a newly created position of special assistant in the Office of Alcoholism and Substance Abuse Services, at $73,600 a year. Mr. Bruno's daughter Susan has been working since 1990 as executive assistant to the Assembly minority leader, a job that pays $34,600.
Mr. Bruno maintains that his relatives are qualified for their jobs. Maybe they are. They were certainly lucky to find jobs in this economy, even as the Governor dismisses others, to reduce patronage, he has claimed. Well, some patronage.
The Senator might ponder the good fortune of his relatives. He also might consider why he gives his relatives the benefit of the doubt, and belittles black and Hispanic New Yorkers who lack the training or connections to compete for his largess. Can he really not know that most of those on public assistance actually need help?
Maybe Mr. Bruno should consider treating the poor as relatives. That would be a really novel public policy: sympathy -- and patronage -- for all New Yorkers with their hands out.

HEADLINE: Stocks Are Unruffled by Chrysler Bid, With Dow Up 10.73

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The stock market shrugged off a surprise bid for Chrysler and a mild inflation indicator yesterday, closing modestly higher.
Other markets were similarly unruffled. Bond prices rose slightly. The dollar rose modestly against the Japanese yen but fell against the German mark. 
 "Today was very confusing," said Bill Allyn, director of listed equity trading at Jefferies & Company, "It was a very mixed day."
But Paul Hennessey, senior vice president for equity trading at the Boston Company, said, "I think it was a good day over all, especially because you're going into a long weekend when people might not want to be long on stocks."
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 10.73 points, to 4,197.81, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 rose 1.64 points, to 507.17. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 3.70 points, to 828.53.
Normally, a big takeover bid, like that of Chrysler, excites trader speculation in similar stocks and sometimes sparks a wider rally.
But the $20 billion bid for Chrysler by a group including the financier Kirk Kerkorian and Lee A. Iaccoca sent only Chrysler's stock soaring 9 1/2, to 48 3/4. Chrysler was the most active stock on any exchange at 33.8 million shares. Ford, however, was up only 7/8, to 27 5/8, and General Motors up only 1/8, to 44 1/4.
The deal should be important to the stock market. If the deal goes through, then some of the largest mutual funds in the country will get a cash windfall, analysts say.
Except for Chrysler, there was little news to move the market, especially before a long Passover and Easter weekend that starts for some traders late this afternoon.
Yesterday, the March Consumer Price Index rose an unexpectedly small two-tenths of 1 percent, but was no substantial surprise after Tuesday's Producer Price Index, which showed no change.
The indicators reinforced the market consensus that the Federal Reserve will not raise interest rates soon and cheered some traders who believe the Fed will not raise rates for the rest of the year.
But Motorola on Monday cast a pall on the market, traders say. The semiconductor and cellular telephone maker, which had been expected to report first-quarter earnings higher than Wall Street projections, reported profits that were slightly lower. Motorola is considered by some traders as a "cyclical stock" sensitive to trends in the economy.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was normal, with 327.9 million shares changing hands, about equal to this year's daily average of 327 million shares.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.75 point, to 274.04, with advancing stocks outnumbering declining stocks by 1,182 to 995. The American Stock Exchange market value index rose 0.67 point, to 471.40.
Among the biggest gainers yesterday was Avid Technology, a computer software company, which rose 5 3/8, to 36 3/8, after several analysts issued buy recommendations after an Avid presentation at an industry convention.
H & R Block, the tax preparer, rose 4 1/4, to 46 1/4, after its chief executive, the son of the founder, announced his resignation, effective in August.
Among the big decliners was BGS Systems Inc., which fell 2, to 28 1/2, after an insider sold stock. According to Government filings, James S. McGuire, the computer software company's chief operating officer, sold 2,000 shares last Tuesday at $28.25 a share and on March 31 sold 2,000 shares at $28.50. The sales reduced his stake by nearly half from 8,435 shares to 4,435 shares
The Franklin Electric Company, which makes specialized motors, fell 1 3/4, to 31 1/4, after it reported on Tuesday a drop in first-quarter earnings to 25 cents a share from 48 cents a year ago.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of Treasuries Increase A 2d Day on Inflation Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rose for a second consecutive day yesterday, helped by a gain in the Consumer Price Index of only two-tenths of a percent.
Some market participants noted, however, that the market has now seen three good sets of figures -- last Friday's jobs data, Tuesday's Producer Price Index and yesterday's Consumer Price Index -- and has not really taken off. Part of the reason may be that small investors are staying away; another may be that expectations of a slowing economy with little inflation have already been priced into the market. 
 The 30-year bond rose 8/32 , to 10310/32 ; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, dropped to 7.35 percent yesterday from 7.37 percent on Tuesday.
Dealers and traders were generally cautious ahead of the short trading week going into the Easter weekend. Reports on industrial production and capacity utilization are scheduled tomorrow -- Good Friday -- when United States markets will be closed.
In another report issued yesterday, the Atlanta Fed said its monthly survey of business activity showed a slower pace of growth in March compared with the previous month. However, market reaction to the report was muted, traders said.
Today investors will get a look at March's retail sales, but trading will be shortened as the Public Securities Association, the main trade group for the public debt industry, has recommended that the Government securities market close at 2 P.M. in observance of Holy Thursday. The recommendation includes money-market and mortgage-backed securities trading.
Yesterday's report on the consumer prices for March showed a gain of two-tenths of a percent, lower than the average forecast of three-tenths of a percent; while the core rate, excluding the more volatile food and energy components, was up three-tenths of a percent, as expected. But some analysts feel that inflation is not as low as it should be.
Michelle Laughlin, chief economist at Sanwa Securities, said that through the first quarter of this year the inflation rate was running at 4.1 percent on an annualized basis, compared with a 2.6 percent inflation rate for all of 1994. "Last year in the first three months, the inflation rate was 2.9 percent annualized," she said. "This is a confirmation that higher input cost or raw materials gains are coming through to the consumer level."
Ms. Laughlin said the market might have been helped later in the morning when a CNW Research and Marketing report on car sales for the first 10 days of April showed considerable weakness. In fact, she said, the report noted that this was the slowest 10-day sales in autos in at least three years.
"I do think that the inflation news this week will keep the Fed in play for a tightening on May 23," she said. "The odds are low but not zero. The market has priced in a 30 percent chance of a rate increase, which I think is about appropriate."
In the municipal bond market, prices were little changed. Some investors were concerned that some housing bond issues could be hurt by proposed government revisions, including last month's plan to reorganize the Department of Housing and Urban Development to consolidate 60 major programs and result in three performance-based funds.
The fear is that many of the tax-exempt securities sold to fund subsidy programs could face potential ratings changes or early redemptions. The restructuring could even even raise the default rate on some housing bonds backed by rental aggreements if there are changes to the rent subsidy programs.
Housing bonds are popular with many investors because they offer higher yields than other tax-exempt securities. Other investors avoid them because they are often redeemed early and tend to lag when interest rates fall. Investors can get as much as 50 basis points more by buying housing bonds instead of similarly rated double-A revenue bonds.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Steadier Against Yen As Rate Cuts Are Seen in Japan

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar steadied against the Japanese yen and other leading currencies yesterday, helped by speculation that the Bank of Japan would cut interest rates when the Japanese Government announced an economic package tomorrow.
Lower Japanese rates could help the dollar by making yen-denominated deposits less attractive. But the Japanese discount rate, which acts as a floor for other money market rates, is already at a record low, at 1.75 percent, compared with the discount rate of 5.25 percent in the United States. 
 Still, any move by the Bank of Japan could have an exaggerated effect on the foreign exchange markets tomorrow and Monday because trading is expected to be thin. The financial markets will be closed tomorrow for the Good Friday holiday in the United States. And tomorrow and Monday are national holidays in London, the world's biggest center for currency trading.
In New York late yesterday the dollar edged up to 83.75 yen, from 83.55 yen on Tuesday. The dollar slipped to 1.4010 German marks from 1.4015 marks.
The Japanese Government is expected to announce measures tomorrow to combat the strength of the yen and its effects on the economic recovery in Japan.
"Actions in Japan will be very important for setting the tone for the yen," said Michael Perelstein, managing director of international investments at the MacKay Shields Financial Corporation in New York. "It's the one currency against which the dollar has not yet put in a strong bottom."
But many dealers said they doubted that the Government's package would help to weaken the surging yen. They argued that the only thing likely to reverse the gains of the yen against the dollar would be a significant reduction in Japan's trade surplus with the United States.
"The market is well aware that sometimes in the past these packages have been disappointing," said Dennis Pettit, foreign exchange manager at the Long Term Credit Bank of Japan.
In other currency trading, the Canadian dollar plunged, after Moody's Investors Service lowered its rating on Canada's debt. The changes were expected, however, and the Canadian currency recovered later.
"A lot of people had been waiting for this announcement to buy Canadian dollars," said Amy Smith, senior currency market strategist at IDEA, a consulting firm. "Some are probably disappointed there wasn't a bigger blowout."
The Canadian dollar settled at 72.68 cents (United States), up from 72.25 cents on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Battered but not broken, the honey lobby is back and winning.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
REMEMBER price supports for honey, the Federal largesse that was to agricultural subsidies what the $600 toilet seat was to military spending? In a gesture much noted at the time, Congress suspended the 44-year-old honey program in 1993. And last year President Clinton chose to honor the spirit of Congress's attack on the honey pot, denying the producers' plea for special protection against imports from Communist countries.
But the beekeepers, explains Greg Rushford, the publisher of The Rushford Report, a Washington-based newsletter on trade policy, have fought back, taking to heart one of the great maxims of modern lobbying: If at first you don't succeed, hire a better lawyer. 
 Prodded by Michael Coursey of the law firm of Collier, Shannon, Rill & Scott, the Commerce Department ruled last month that honey from China was being dumped on innocent American consumers and took steps to save them from the decadent pleasure of high-quality, low-cost imports. The story of how Mr. Coursey managed this feat says much about the ways in which United States trade law is rigged in favor of domestic producers -- and against common sense.
Washington put a floor under the price of honey in 1949, only abandoning it in the deficit reduction fervor of 1993. Battered but not broken, the honey makers then asked the Clinton Administration to limit imports from China, a major supplier of honey for breakfast cereals and other packaged foods. The tariff would have had the effect of a subsidy, but would have raised consumer prices rather than Federal spending.
The ploy almost worked. The International Trade Commission, a Federal agency, ruled that honey from a "Communist country" had indeed "disrupted" the market and recommended that the President block imports from the wily henchmen of Marx and Mao. But Mr. Clinton, who had seemingly invited the initiative with a conciliatory letter to the honey lobby's friends in Congress, denied the recommendation in April 1994.
Enter Mr. Coursey, the lawyer. He filed a suit charging that China was selling honey in the United States for less than "fair market value."
And what is fair market value? Under American law it is usually the foreigners' cost of production. But costs are difficult to reconstruct for "nonmarket economies." And although China's 28 honey exporters are in the vanguard of change in an economy rapidly evolving toward free markets, the Commerce Department decided that it would use prices from a third country to assay the value of Chinese honey.
The department chose India as the "surrogate." It used Indian prices -- wages, packaging material prices and, most important, the price of raw honey -- to figure what it cost the Chinese to prepare honey for export. And lo, the bean counters discovered it cost independent Chinese producers two and a half times as much to manufacture honey as they were charging their American customers. The department thus set tentative "dumping margins" -- that is, punitive tariffs -- of roughly 150 percent.
The figure is subject to review until August. Even then, the International Trade Commission would have to agree that American honey makers had been injured by Chinese exports to make the tariff binding. But since importers would be retroactively liable for a 150 percent duty if it passes muster, imports of Chinese honey have come to a screeching halt.
What's wrong with that? In Mr. Coursey's view, nothing. "Why should America be a dumping ground?" he asks. But the theory behind the statute, as well as its implementation in the case of honey, has to make one wonder.
The only plausible explanation for systematically selling below cost -- that the seller plans to drive rivals from the market and then raise prices -- makes no sense here because a half- dozen other countries would happily export more honey to America if the price rose substantially.
Then there is the question of finding a comparable third country. "Going to India and consulting a few old yearbooks" isn't much help in reconstructing China's costs, Mr. Rushford of the trade policy newsletter argues. What's more, after the calculations are made, they must be translated from Indian rupees to dollars -- a process fraught with conceptual problems.
Perhaps most offensive is the way the Commerce Department treats foreigners as lowly petitioners. European steelmakers may be able to comply with demands for data in English and on a timely basis. But it seems bizarre to expect the same from Chinese companies exporting a few million dollars' worth of honey.
The antidumping law is not about to be changed. But the bureaucrats were curbed in the 1970's and 80's and could be curbed again. "You can blame the White House for letting the bureaucrats run amok," Mr. Rushford says.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
McNamara Concedes: 'We Were Wrong'

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT 

 BODY:

IN RETROSPECT
The Tragedy and Lessons of Vietnam
By Robert S. McNamara with Brian VanDeMark
Illustrated. 414 pages. Times Books. $27.50. 
 As Robert S. McNamara concedes at the end of his new book, "In Retrospect: The Tragedy and Lessons of Vietnam," some people still believe that the heavy costs of American involvement in Vietnam were worthwhile. Such people, Mr. McNamara writes, "conclude that without U.S. intervention in Vietnam, Communist hegemony -- both Soviet and Chinese -- would have spread farther through South and East Asia to include control of Indonesia, Thailand and possibly India."
But Mr. McNamara, who served Presidents Kennedy and Johnson as Secretary of Defense from 1961 until early in 1968, does not agree. He says the country could and should have withdrawn from Vietnam "in late 1963 amid the turmoil following" the assassination of South Vietnam's President, Ngo Dinh Diem, "or in late 1964 or early 1965 in the face of increasing political and military weakness," or on several later occasions. Not only would our allies have understood, he adds, but we might even have "improved our credibility by withdrawing from Vietnam and saving our strength for more defensible stands elsewhere."
That the United States did not get out cost a terrible price in lives, in damage to the American economy and, most significantly to Mr. McNamara, in the shattering of our "political unity." In short, he says that "we were wrong, terribly wrong." He therefore decided to write a book that would face his own and his colleagues' mistakes. He would be hard on everyone. But his purpose would not be so much to point fingers as to dispel the cynicism that he believes Vietnam helped engender. For he still is convinced that the war was fought with good and honorable motives. And by identifying both the motives and the errors, he might help to restore faith in our leaders.
As it turns out, he is only partly successful in his attempt to clear the air. He makes good sense when defining the basic causes of the failure. These he sums up in familiar enough terms: a view of Communism as monolithic, an anxious outlook aggravated by Cuba and Berlin, an absence of experts on the Far East caused by the purge of the China specialists in the McCarthy era, and perhaps most fundamentally, the contradiction, never resolved, of looking upon South Vietnam as both the bulwark of Southeast Asia and a country that needed to be trained to defend itself.
Yet in detailing how these flaws manifested themselves he is not so consistently lucid. On some matters he is outspoken. For instance, he blames the law of unintended consequences for the way the decision to bomb led to a need for ground troops to defend the airfields, and then more and more ground troops as the war on the ground expanded. He defends Gen. William S. Westmoreland against the accusation brought by a CBS Reports documentary, "The Uncounted Enemy: A Vietnam Deception," alleging, as he puts it, "that Westy ordered his intelligence officers knowingly to underestimate enemy strength in order to bolster his claims of military progress." And he faults President Johnson for failing to be more forthright with the American public about the growing expense of the war. He attributes this failure to Johnson's worthy desire to keep his Great Society programs on track.
Elsewhere, however, Mr. McNamara seems less lucid on why and how things went wrong. On the one hand, he wrings his hands over the deaths of President Diem and his brother Ngo Dinh Nhu, as if he were somehow at fault; on the other hand he is critical of Roger Hilsman Jr., Assistant Secretary of State for Far Eastern Affairs, and Ambassador Henry Cabot Lodge for their roles in promoting the coup against the Diems. On the one hand, he blames himself for not forcing the debate on bombing out into the open; on the other hand he keeps pointing an accusing finger at the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
And concerning his eventual departure from the Johnson Administration over his loss of belief in the war, he both professes his love for Johnson and his loyalty to him and faults the President for not following his advice.
Part of the trouble lies in Mr. McNamara's unevenness of tone. Sometimes he is official in his prose style, as when he resorts to the passive voice in discussing the coup against the Diems, "Neither question received an adequate answer, and Lodge was not given instructions to meet Diem." Putting the matter this way leaves no one in particular at fault. At other times he is disconcertingly personal, as when he blames himself for not talking things out with his family: "at moments like this I often turn inward instead -- it is a grave weakness."
At still other times he seems caught bizarrely in between the official and the personal, as, for instance, when he reports in his official voice how he tried to demonstrate for Eunice Shriver the function of "the fountain pen-like tear-gas dispenser" that was stored in the rear compartment of his limousine: "I rolled the window down a bit, held the dispenser up to it, and pressed. Because we were moving so fast, there was a vacuum, which drew the fumes into the car. Eunice -- who planned to make a speech" at the Wardman Park Hotel -- "began choking and screaming. I had incapacitated her by the time we arrived."
One begins to suspect the presence of a highly complex code in these pages, the deciphering of which would require the collaboration of scholars, cryptographers and psychoanalysts. Certain points in the book come across like thunderclaps, like the author's clear preference for President Kennedy, who, he believes, would have pulled out of Vietnam had he lived, over President Johnson, whom he faults for not allowing open discussion of Vietnam policy among his senior advisers.
Other points pop like firecrackers, like the author's criticism of Walt Rostow, McGeorge Bundy's successor as national security adviser, for tending "to be skeptical of any report that failed to indicate we were making progress." But because Mr. McNamara's contradictions leave one in the dark about so much of what he really thinks, one ends up feeling, if not precisely cynicism, then a residue of confusion about what went wrong in Vietnam.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Robert S. McNamara (Diana Walker/Times Books)

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
Shifting Course On the Arts, Aiming For the Mainstream

BYLINE: By PAUL GOLDBERGER 

 BODY:
Who deserves a slice of the shrinking pie? So far as New York City arts financing goes, it may turn out to be the institutions with the biggest appetites. According to representatives of several of the city's arts organizations, the Giuliani administration decided last week to eliminate city support entirely for 400 smaller museums, theater companies, arts education organizations and other groups, and to concentrate the city's increasingly limited cultural-affairs budget on larger, more established institutions.
The proposal -- which is not yet final, and has not been announced -- represents a further step in a preference expressed in December 1993 by John S. Dyson, the Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, that city arts subsidies be funneled toward large institutions, like the Metropolitan Museum of Art, that directly enhance the city's economy by attracting tourist dollars. 
 With virtually every portion of the city's budget facing cuts, arts groups hardly expected to be exempt from the ax. But last week's proposal, which would become effective in the 1996 fiscal year, is not a reduction but an elimination. It would result in the complete end to city support for organizations like Dance Theater of Harlem, the Children's Museum of Manhattan, the South Street Seaport Museum, the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater and the Alvin Ailey Dance Company and educational groups like the Harlem School of the Arts, the Henry Street Settlement, Arts Connection and Studio in a School.
The plan would represent a monumental shift in the nature and type of support that the city has given its arts community, sending a clear signal that the culture the city wishes to support is the mainstream culture that lures tourists to Manhattan and spins off additional dollars for hotels and restaurants. The other side of the arts -- the incubation side, not the consumption side -- would be left to fend for itself.
The plan is a kind of cultural Darwinism in that it favors what is already strongest. But it is Darwinism under a false premise, for it holds out the promise of cultural survival not to the culturally strongest but to the economically strongest. By focusing on economic development as a prime criterion for cultural subsidy, the city's proposed new policy ignores those sides of the arts that often provide the most social benefit in the long run: teaching, community service and development of young artists. These things may not provide the quick economic pay-back of a blockbuster show at the Met, but they are the tools by which audiences are built and social fabrics woven. And they are the ways in which the arts most directly reach minorities and residents of the city's more disadvantaged communities, groups that are likely to suffer the most under the new plan.
It is true, of course, that the galleries of the Met are open to everyone. But it is often the small museum in the Bronx or the educational program run by an organization like Studio in a School that inspires a young person to go to the Met in the first place. At a time when the New York City Board of Education has all but abandoned arts education in the schools, private groups have taken up the mission of building an arts audience for the future. Many of these groups are among those designated to lose their city support, and they fear that this new policy will shake them to the core, because they have already squeezed what they can out of private sources and there is no more private money available to take up the slack. The ripples of the proposed new policy would be little felt in the galleries of the Brooklyn Museum, but the complete loss of city funds could threaten several smaller institutions with closure.
"The city talks about encouraging public-private partnerships, but that's what we've been doing all along," said Linda LeRoy Janklow, chairwoman of Arts Connection, an arts-education organization for public school students that has been threatened with the loss of its entire $311,000 city subsidy. "We leverage four or five dollars in private funds for every dollar the city gives us, but we can't do that if the city doesn't give us our base money."
Smaller cultural groups also serve as incubators for mainstream culture. "Three Tall Women," the Pulitzer Prize-winning play by Edward Albee that is still running off Broadway, got its start at the small Vineyard Theater, which is supported in part by city subsidies that would disappear under the new plan.
And while the smaller organizations may not bring tourists to New York, they buttress the city's economy by creating substantial employment. Arts Connection, for example, employs 24 full-time staff members and 700 artists as teachers each year. For many of these artists, the part-time Arts Connection work is the one thing that allows them to pursue their own careers in the arts.
The director of one of the city's most respected smaller museums, which is threatened with the loss of more than $200,000 in city assistance, roughly 14 percent of its budget, points out another risk in the new policy: that corporations, already reluctant in today's economic climate to support arts programs unless they can see a clear marketing benefit from doing so, will become the supporters of last resort, and could feel emboldened to set difficult conditions. Imagine the Alvin Ailey company having to name a new dance after the Amalgamated Computer Company, or the Children's Museum of Manhattan having no choice but to make its ecology exhibit a paean to the glories of a chemical company.
"When I had city money, I felt I could turn down a corporation that wanted to use an exhibition mainly as advertising for itself," said the director, who spoke on the condition that his name not be used. "The city was wonderful in giving us a moral platform for refusing commercial demands. But now we will have to play ball with them; I see us placed in a position where the corporations will call the shots completely."
While the city's proposed new policy emerges largely out of Mr. Dyson's stated preferences for cultural financing, it also connects to a historical anomaly in the way in which the city's cultural organizations operate. The bulk of the $96.1 million cultural affairs budget goes to pay housekeeping costs for 31 cultural organizations -- including the Brooklyn Museum, the Brooklyn Children's Museum, the Metropolitan Museum and the American Museum of Natural History -- that are in city-owned buildings or on city-owned land. It is something of a historical accident which institutions are in this group and which are not: the Brooklyn Children's Museum is part of the group while the Children's Museum of Manhattan is not, for example, just as the Metropolitan Museum of Art is city-owned and the Museum of Modern Art is not.
But this accident of history now threatens to determine the future of many organizations, because the city appears to have decided that it will favor those institutions, collectively known as the cultural institutions group, at the expense of the others. The cultural institutions group will continue to receive major city support under Mr. Dyson's proposal, even though its members are expected to face some budget cuts as well.
Schuyler G. Chapin, the city's Cultural Affairs Commissioner, is reported to have proposed a plan under which the cultural institutions group and the program group would have shared equally in an across-the-board cut of roughly 18 percent in response to the budget crisis. Mr. Chapin's plan is said to have been rejected by Mr. Dyson in favor of a more modest cut for the cultural institutions group and a total cut for the others.

SECTION: Section A; Page 24; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 365 words

HEADLINE: Ms. Bhutto's Wish List

 BODY:
The United States and Pakistan, once locked in an expedient cold-war embrace that served mutual defense interests, are warily exploring how to establish a subtler, more productive relationship. It will not be easy, as Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's visit to Washington this week demonstrated.
Pakistan wants improved relations, renewed American aid and delivery of 38 F-16 jet fighters it bought in 1988. It advertises itself as a secular, democratic Islamic state in a sea of fundamentalism. But it is not willing to give up nuclear arming, the reason relations are strained and the warplanes are sitting in Arizona instead of Pakistan. 
 The challenge for President Clinton is to support secular, democratic forces in Pakistan without yielding on the nuclear issue or pretending that Pakistan is a model of political and economic stability. Mr. Clinton seldom strayed from that course during the Bhutto visit, but left unclear how he intends to shape relations in the months ahead.
Pakistan, once an ally against Communism and now a hothouse for terrorists, is shaken by domestic unrest fed by religious and ethnic conflict, economic crisis and an expanding drug trade. The instability will only be exacerbated by a nuclear arms race between Pakistan and India. If Mr. Clinton wants to prevent that, he has to restore some economic and military ties to Pakistan without jeopardizing new ties with India.
Delivery of the F-16's, along with other military and economic aid to Pakistan, has been barred under the Pressler Amendment since 1990 after Pakistan, violating promises made to Washington, began stockpiling nuclear material for bombs. Mr. Clinton suggested he might refund the $658 million Pakistan paid for the F-16's if he can find another buyer. He was right to avoid a pledge to deliver the planes.
What Ms. Bhutto needs is a boost for her economy. It should involve aid for cooperative projects between India and Pakistan. That would require Congress to relax the Pressler Amendment, permitting limited economic assistance while still barring other aid or arms sales. Ms. Bhutto deserves some help, but she must restrain Pakistan's nuclear ambitions.

HEADLINE: Market Opening on Internet For Pollution-Credit Trades

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON 

 BODY:
An electronic market for trading pollution credits from Southern California is to begin operating today on the Internet, offering a system that its developers believe will help businesses reduce pollution at the lowest possible cost.
Its developers, scientists from the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena, hope their automated environmental credit exchange, as it is known, will supplant a rival auction market begun last year by Cantor Fitzgerald L.P., a Wall Street brokerage firm. 
 Developers of the automated credit exchange said that the new system was already drawing interest from the Environmental Protection Agency and environmental regulators for several states. The supporters hope the credit exchange becomes the standard trading mechanism used in other regions that are planning to let free-market forces clean urban air through the trading of smog credits.
Credits in the chemical that causes acid rain have been traded since 1993 among utilities through the Chicago Board of Trade, but other global markets for trading credits in water and greenhouse gases are also emerging.
"The fundamental purpose of moving to a market-based approach to environmental regulation is to reduce emissions faster and more efficiently than traditional regulations," said Dale Carlson, vice president of corporate affairs for the Pacific Stock Exchange in San Francisco. The exchange will act to clear and settle trades on the credit exchange along with the Bank of America, a unit of the BankAmerica Corporation.
"This concept of using market systems is the coming trend," said Robert D. Brenner, the E.P.A.'s director of air policy. It is too early to determine whether a single system will emerge as a standard, he said, "but there's an opportunity for anyone to break into the market."
The environmental credit exchange is expected to operate one week a quarter, but trades will not be executed until the final day of the trading week. That lets participants refine their bids and find the price the rest of the market is setting by relying on analysis provided by the system's software.
The exchange was developed by Caltech professors, whose two companies, Sholtz & Associates and Econdesigns, will make money three ways: by charging companies a fee to participate, by selling their software, and by a commission based on the value of the trades that are made.
Ann Sholtz, a Caltech economics professor and a co-developer of the credit exchange, said Cantor's auction system left small business without access to sophisticated financial analysis at a disadvantage when buying or selling pollution credits.
Carlton W. Bartels, director of environmental brokerage services for Cantor, countered that the Caltech system was too complex and lacked customer service.
Southern California's 390 largest polluters, those that produce four or more tons a year of smog-making chemicals, must determine whether buying new technology or buying the right to pollute from someone else is the cheapest way for them to reduce emissions. The South Coast Air Quality Management District will force progress by cutting the ceiling of credits each year.
Prices for credits went for as low as one-tenth of 1 cent a pound of chemicals during the most recent auction, held in January by Cantor Fitzgerald. Such prices, conceded James M. Lents, executive officer of the air quality district, "were dirt cheap. By the second year of the program, the rubber starts to meet to road."
It is to the agency's advantage to see rival trading systems for credits emerge, he said, adding: "We want a market with lots of trades. It gives people confidence. If you don't have good trading, people will hoard credits."

Japan Cuts Interest Rates In Effort to Curb Yen's Rise
 The Japanese central bank has cut the discount rate by three-quarters of a percentage point, to a record low of 1 percent, as part of a plan to halt the ascent of the yen against the dollar. The strong yen has been hindering efforts to revive Japan's sluggish economy because it reduces the demand for the nation's exports. A1. 
 President Clinton said he saw little basis for the dollar's weakness and said the markets would eventually respond to Administration efforts to cut the deficit. D3.
 The dollar fell against most leading currencies, settling in New York at 1.3864 marks and 83.50 yen. D16.
 
Retail Sales Rose in March
 Retail sales edged up two-tenths of 1 percent in March, with consumers spending about $2 billion less than anticipated. D2.
 
Calpers Protest on Philip Morris
 The California Public Employees' Retirement System, or Calpers, said it would vote against a management slate of candidates for the board of Philip Morris, accusing the company of being unresponsive to institutional shareholders. D2.
 
Deal for Six Flags Parks Advances
 Time Warner is closer to selling 51 percent of the Six Flags theme parks to an investment group for $200 million in cash. Robert W. Pittman would continue to run Six Flags and get a small stake in the new company. D5.
 
Microsoft Net Exceeds Estimates
 Microsoft said earnings rose 55 percent in the third quarter. Some analysts had expected a slowdown. But continued strong demand for personal computer translated into stronger-than-expected results. D4.
 
Pioneer Takes Hollywood Write-Off
 Pioneer Electronic is writing off $90 million from its stake in film maker Carolco Pictures and distributor Live Entertainment. D3.

Failed Firm's Accounts Transferred
 Customer accounts at the failed penny stock brokerage firm Hanover Sterling were transferred to Lew Lieberbaum & Co. D2.
 
Bellcore Put Up for Sale
 The regional Bell telephone companies formally put their research consortium, Bellcore, up for sale. D2.
 
Pilot Error Blamed for Crash
 The National Transportation Safety Board said pilot error led to the fatal crash of an American Eagle plane in December. A1.
 
Agency Creates a Cooler Cow
 With its eye-grabbing magenta milk carton sporting a Holstein wearing sunglasses, and quirky commercials pumped up by jazzy music, the brand, Cool Cow, aims to be hip. And now the low-fat milk from North Dakota is coming to the Northeast, supported by a campaign created by the tiny Soho Advertising agency. Advertising. D5.
 
First 100 Days Golden to Lobbyists
 For Washington's corporate and business lobbyists, the first 100 days could hardly have gone better. Key committees invited the lobbyists to help reshape environmental laws, and Administration regulators are backing off from several controversial proposals. A12.

HEADLINE: Clinton Says Tax Cut Hinges On Incentives for Education

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 13

 BODY:
Further refining his differences with the Republicans on the drive to cut taxes, President Clinton said today that "any tax relief must be geared to helping middle-class people and to helping people educate themselves."
The President's comments, in an interview with CNN, marked the second time in as many days that Mr. Clinton sought to distinguish his own tax proposals, which include new deductions for college and vocational training, from Republican alternatives. On Wednesday, he vowed to oppose any bill that did not include tax relief for the cost of education. 
 In the interview today, the President also refused to match Senator Bob Dole's campaign pledge that he would not raise taxes. Mr. Clinton said he had no intention of raising taxes, but he added, "On principle, I think a President runs the risk of breeding cynicism to sign that kind of pledge when you have no idea what will come forward."
Just as the White House used the popular school lunch program as a wedge in its attacks on the House Republicans' budget-cutting plans, Mr. Clinton is now accusing the Republicans of slighting education with proposed tax cuts that he has already denounced as unrealistically large and too favorable to the rich.
"Education is the fault line in America today," the President said on Wednesday in Warm Springs, Ga., where he commemorated the 50th anniversary of the death of Franklin Delano Roosevelt. "Those who have it are doing well in the global economy; those who don't are not doing well. We cannot walk away from this fundamental fact: the American dream will succeed or fail in the 21st century in direct proportion to our commitment to educate every person in the United States."
A tax cut for education, he added, "is the most important tax cut we can have, and I will insist upon it and will not support a legislative bill that does not have it."
In December, Mr. Clinton proposed up to $10,000 in annual income tax deductions for post-high-school education for families earning less than $120,000 a year, as part of a tax relief plan that also includes a credit of up to $500 per child for families earning up to $75,000. For weeks, the President portrayed the education incentives as the central difference between his tax cut plan and far larger Republican alternatives.
His remarks this week not only honed that critique, but also hinted at the sort of compromise that he might find acceptable, though it is far from clear that one will be forthcoming on Capitol Hill.
Last week the House passed a bill providing a variety of cuts in personal and business taxes that would total nearly $200 billion over five years, more than three times the size of the package Mr. Clinton favors. Its centerpiece is a $500-per-child tax cut for families earning up to $200,000 a year.
The bill's fate in the Senate is uncertain, with some leading Republicans like Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon, the chairman of the Finance Committee, sounding skeptical notes about the size of the tax cut.
But the prospects for passage of the education incentives in the President's plan appear even more complicated. The Clinton education proposal never even came up in the House debate. An amendment by the House minority leader, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, seeking educational deductions similar to the Clinton plan, failed by a vote of 313 to 119. And a significant number of Democrats joined the Republicans to defeat it.
In the CNN interview, Mr. Clinton repeated that he wanted to work with the Republicans when possible. But he rejected the suggestion that because he has not yet vetoed any bill, he lacked the will.
"Now, vetoes make a big splash," the President said. "If they'll just simply send me some bad bills, I'll be more than happy to veto them."

HEADLINE: Dornan, House Firebrand, Joins the '96 Race

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 13

 BODY:
Representative Robert K. Dornan of California, a firebrand conservative Republican who is perhaps the most garrulous and acerbic legislator on Capitol Hill, entered the 1996 Presidential race today, garrulously and acerbicly.
And also joyously. 
 "Come with me," the 62-year-old nine-term Congressman from Orange County said in an announcement speech in Washington. "I'm going to enjoy myself."
Mr. Dornan's speech, delivered at a memorial to slain police officers, promised to restore the American dream, wandered to an assertion that he had never yelled at his office staff, compared injuries he suffered in ejecting from a jet fighter in peacetime with wounds that the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, suffered in World War II combat, and finally concluded with a passionately voiced wish to "go down swinging."
"I love the dust," said the man who once called President Clinton "a disgraced draft dodger," who recently accused homosexuals of turning AIDS into "a political problem instead of a health problem" and who maintains that abortion is "a national sin" and that service in the military is not just patriotic but a sacred rite of passage.
Most political experts predict that few voters will respond to Mr. Dornan's message, saying he is too vociferously to the right even for the Republican Party's powerful right wing. But given his 16 years of combat on Capitol Hill -- he once grabbed a fellow legislator by the necktie and called him "a draft-dodging wimp" -- there is every expectation that he will go down swinging energetically.
The eight other announced or almost-announced Republican candidates, among them Mr. Dole, either have more money than Mr. Dornan or already have latched on to some of his favorite ideas, or both.
But Arnie Steinberg, a California political consultant who worked with Mr. Dornan in one of his House campaigns, said: "Don't underestimate Bob's one-on-one skills and his proven ability to stir debate and raise some money among the faithful. He's got a real message. But his real impact, if he has any, might be to steal away some support from Phil Gramm, which is a problem Phil already faces with Pat Buchanan and Alan Keyes."
As for a Democratic assessment of Mr. Dornan's chances, Bill Press, the California Democratic chairman, offered, in good Dornan style, "He has as much chance of being elected President as Madonna."
Mr. Dornan's Congressional record is mostly one of staunch opposition to abortion, sex education, homosexuality and gun control, combined with uncompromising support for anti-crime measures and a strengthening of the armed forces, not least the military installations and contractors in his Orange County district. But he is probably best known, when he is known at all nationally, for the way he advocates rather than for what he advocates.
A few weeks ago, for example, he made national headlines when he asserted in a speech on the floor of the House that Mr. Clinton "gave aid and comfort to the enemy" by participating in student protests against the Vietnam War.
House members, including Republican colleagues, had the remarks stricken from the record and imposed a 24-hour suspension on Mr. Dornan's floor privileges. It was the first such suspension in 21 years.
Today, alluding to that episode in his announcement speech and a follow-up news conference, Mr. Dornan held his ground with vintage tenacity.
"On the floor of the House, in the well, yes, I've been tough," he said, "tough as Patrick Henry yelling, 'Give me liberty or give me death.' I apologize for nothing where I was indignant over my years in the House.
"But I will tell you that if someone is not publicly indignant about the bankrupt policies of this, the richest country ever, destroying the American dream economically, and if somebody is not publicly indignant and saying, 'Stop this,' with our cultural meltdown and moral decline, then I'll show you somebody who doesn't understand the facts. I'll show you somebody who's a bystander watching the destruction of their country."
Mr. Dornan has lately spread his gospel by serving as a substitute host on some national talk shows, including Rush Limbaugh's. He honed his broadcast skills as a television talk show host in Southern California in the 1970's and also worked as an actor back then, having gained access to show business through Jack Haley, his uncle, who played the Tin Man in "The Wizard of Oz."
Before that, he was a pilot in the Air Force, an experience that appears to have deeply influenced his views on patriotism, duty and national purpose. On Capitol Hill, he is known as B-1 Bob because of his relentless advocacy of military power, in particular the B-1 bomber, manufactured in good part in Southern California.
Within his own district, he is a formidable fund-raiser, one of the best in Congress. Again and again over the years he has gone to his constituents in search of money for re-election, and again and again they have given, obviously pleased with his message and the way he delivers it.
Will that message and style of delivery now play well beyond Orange County, drawing both money and votes nationally?
Near the end of his appearance today, Mr. Dornan replied that if his campaign could contribute to the strength of his country, he would be satisfied. "Money does not buy you everything," he said. "Winning is not everything."
