HEADLINE: Rethinking Welfare: Collecting From Fathers -- A special report.;
Georgia, Pursuing Child Support, Discovers Its Potential and Limits

BYLINE: By RICK BRAGG 

DATELINE: ATLANTA

 BODY:
With a self-sufficiency born of pride and desperation, Sheila Anderson seems to be just the sort of single mother politicians are searching for in the rush to change the welfare system. Abandoned by the father of her 5-year-old son, she took welfare only long enough to find work.
"I make our living," said Ms. Anderson, a 27-year-old telephone operator. 
 Georgia, with its aggressive program of tracking down absent fathers and making them pay child support, collects $122 a month from the father on behalf of Ms. Anderson and her son, Avery. She is grateful for the extra money, which helps her stay afloat. But she gets angry when politicians harp on child support as a central weapon against the welfare problem, as if fathers were lining up to empty their pockets.
Ms. Anderson said that if she had depended on a man to lift her out of welfare, she would still be on it. "Any idiot ought to know $122 a month is not enough to raise a child," she said. Avery's father, erratically employed, makes little money.
Collecting more from the absent fathers of children on welfare has been a rallying cry for politicians in both political parties, something they hope can move more families out of poverty as well as cut public expenses.
On March 23, the United States House of Representatives voted to deny driver's licenses and other privileges to fathers who fail to pay court-ordered child support. In a more-disputed proposal, the wide-ranging Republican-sponsored welfare bill that passed the House the next day would also reduce cash welfare payments, for a period of months, to a mother who cannot or will not name the father of her child.
Nearly everyone seems to agree with the principle of making fathers help support their children. But poverty experts warn that child support has often been oversold as an answer to welfare or the plight of poor, single mothers.
The experience of Georgia, a national leader in the pursuit of child support, suggests both the potential for and the limits of such measures.
The state's child-support enforcement division has consistently ranked among the nation's top five in establishing paternity and collecting money from absent fathers.
In Georgia, roughly 1 in 4 of the state's welfare recipients receives at least some child support, which is better than the record in most other states. The average payment was about $100 a month, not nearly enough to remove most recipients from the welfare rolls. But in 18,000 cases, officials estimate, those payments, alone or combined with income from a job, were enough to lift the family off welfare.
In part because of a weak economy, the total number of welfare cases in Georgia, which has a population of more than 7 million, has climbed in recent years -- to 149,000 in 1994 from 99,000 in 1990. If the state had not aggressively gone after delinquent parents, the number would probably have increased well beyond 150,000, said Robert Swain, deputy director of Georgia's child-support enforcement division.
So far, Georgia has been harder on fathers who fail to pay than on mothers who fail to identify the fathers. Like many other states, it has jailed some fathers who could pay but do not, but it has not penalized uncooperative mothers by taking away benefits.
 
The Mothers
Getting 'Blood From a Turnip'
 On the steps of housing projects in Atlanta, where welfare and food stamps are often a means of survival, single-parent mothers say that lawmakers who see child support as a cure for welfare are out of touch with reality.
In this world, most of the fathers are unemployed or rarely work -- and then at the minimum wage -- or they have no traceable income or are in jail, said several mothers on welfare and social workers who handle their cases. Even here, officials succeed in the first step of finding fathers and establishing paternity for fewer than half of the children on welfare.
Fatherhood in this world seldom manifests itself with a wedding ring or a slow dance at the country club. At Techwood Homes, one of the nation's oldest public-housing units, mothers are fond of the phrase "blood from a turnip" when talking about collecting from absentee fathers.
"He caught the bus," said Sabrina Jones, when asked what happened to the father of her 4-year-old daughter, Bashira. "At least I got to name her pretty," she said of her daughter. They live on welfare.
Freya Sonenstein, an authority on child support at the Urban Institute in Washington, said, "For women who live on welfare, their partners are more likely to have low skills, low levels of education and low incomes, and may not be able to lift them out of poverty."
Some mothers think it is smarter to take occasional under-the-table presents from the fathers -- like groceries or a tricycle -- than to chase them through the courts for a child-support check that might never come. A few refuse to name the baby's father for a more ominous reason: They fear retaliation, to themselves or the child.
To Ms. Anderson, whose welfare experience is still fresh in her mind, the Republican plan to reduce monthly welfare checks as much as $50 for mothers who do not name a father is cruel.
"Do they have any idea how long a gallon of milk will last?" she asked. "Have they ever looked at a loaf of bread and tried to figure if it would last the week? I don't think so."
In welfare cases, experts say, only a few absent fathers are deadbeats who make good money and do not support their children because they do not care.
"People overstate the gains" that are feasible from child support, said Prof. Irwin Garfinkel, an authority on child support at Columbia University. "I don't think there's any question that it's a good thing. But if you think it's going to get rid of welfare, that's ignorant. If we had a perfect system and collected 100 percent of the child support, we would would still only cut welfare by 25 percent."
States should increase programs that support working mothers, like day care, Professor Garfinkel said, as they whittle away at the number of absentee fathers who could pay something, anything. But that is an old quest, with the same tired reality: Such programs require an up-front investment, in a time of spending cuts.
Dr. Sonenstein said that many states, following Georgia's example, could do more to collect what little they can from fathers in poor neighborhoods. "Usually, when they're threatened with jail they come up with something," she said of the fathers.
But if there is a safety net, Dr. Sonenstein added, it is welfare, not child support.
 
The System
Tracking Down Absent Parents
 It is a Wednesday afternoon at Techwood Homes and an ambulance, siren screeching, blocks the appointed round of an ice cream truck that tinkles a merry tune amid the din. In this place of uncertainties, there are two things people can count on: regular visits by paramedics, and Popsicles.
Three single mothers sit on the stoop, talking and waiting for the school bus to drop off their children. It is one of the nicer rituals. They discuss a father who has abandoned a mother and two children.
"That's O.K.," said Jeanette Jackson, between bouts of coughing caused by asthma. "He's going to get his in the long run. God don't like people who do ugly."
But first, the absent father has the State of Georgia to deal with.
Jerry Townsend, the director of Georgia's Child Support Enforcement Division, does not talk of remaking the welfare system, only about tracking down every parent who does not live up to his or her legal and moral obligations. They may be able to afford just $10 a month, he said, but any amount is a savings to taxpayers.
"We chase them all over creation," Mr. Townsend said.
In Georgia, as in Michigan, Virginia, Washington and other states with aggressive child-support enforcement, payments have steadily risen in the last five years. Georgia, whose aggressive approach began under the current Governor, Zell Miller, a Democrat, collected about $85 million in such payments for welfare families in 1993, compared with $36 million in 1989.
Last year, more than 236,000 fathers in Georgia were under court orders to pay child support. But only 40 percent actually paid. For fathers of welfare children, the rate was even lower, said state officials who could not give exact numbers.
Georgia is one of several states that begin searching for the father before he fades into the community. They stalk him in the maternity ward.
In Georgia, hospital employees, working with the State Department of Human Resources, carry affidavits of paternity along with birth certificates. The fathers, officials have found, tend to visit mothers and newborns in the hospital even if they have no plans to marry the mother or live with her. But in any case, officials press the mothers for the names and Social Security numbers even of fathers they do not see.
"If we have the Social Security number, we have a 50 percent chance of finding the parent," Mr. Swain said. "If we have a name and date of birth, it drops down to 25."
Since fatherhood is not a crime, officials cannot force a father to sign an affidavit of paternity. But in the brief time when the proud father is looking at a new baby, it is more difficult to deny paternity.
For those fathers who never go near the hospital, caseworkers must rely on the mother's information. That goes into a computer network that reaches throughout Georgia and beyond.
If he gives his Social Security number to an employer, they will find him. Once found, the father sometimes admits to paternity. Sometimes a DNA test is needed.
In Atlanta, the state has contracted with a private company to find the absentee fathers. Once paternity is established, the Child Support Enforcement Division draws up a support order and sets the amount the father must pay. If he is unemployed, he is still required to pay a nominal fee.
It is a myth that welfare mothers cannot name the baby's father, Mr. Townsend said. Most welfare babies are not products of one-night stands, but of longer relationships.
Ms. Jackson agreed. "I've got four children from four different daddies, and I know all my children's fathers," she said. Each time, she added, she had hoped that this would be the man who would stand with her.
Mr. Garfinkel, the Columbia professor, said mothers usually had a good reason when they did not name the fathers. A few are afraid they will be beaten by the child's father. Most refuse because they have made an arrangement to get help privately with money or groceries -- promises the fathers may or may not keep. Sometimes the mothers keep silent because they are afraid of losing their companionship.
 
The Fathers
'I Got Nothing' For the Children
 It is not hard to find some of the fathers who are wanted by child-support enforcement officials: They are on the street corners of inner cities, killing time.
Even in Atlanta, where there is a boom because of construction for the 1996 Olympic Games, decent work is scarce, said E. L. Jackson, 23, who said he was the father of two children by two different mothers.
"I got nothing," Mr. Jackson said, when asked if he paid anything to his children, a boy and girl. If he had to choose between child support or a jail sentence, he said, "I'd do time." He also said he loves his children.
Other young men say the same thing. One man, 26, said he worked about half the time, and gave money to the mother when he could. The last time was Christmas. Another man said he paid official child support to two women, but no more than $50 each.
Georgia has an uncommon twist in its payment system. Most states take money from the fathers and use it to repay the state and Federal welfare accounts, passing -- as required by Federal law -- an extra $50 a month to the mothers beyond their normal welfare payment.
But Georgia collects child support and pays it straight to the mothers, reducing their welfare check accordingly, still allowing the mother to keep an extra $50.
The two checks may add up to the same amount for the mothers, but this approach may encourage some fathers to pay more consistently since they see their money passed directly to their children, rather than disappearing into the state treasury.
"Psychologically, that's very good," for both mother and father, Professor Garfinkel said.
The recently passed House bill eliminates the requirement that states pass on an extra $50 of collected child support to mothers on welfare, but the Senate is expected to be asked to reinstate the requirement.
Some of the women in Techwood Homes say that, despite Georgia's good reputation in enforcing child support, there are still too many fathers walking around with money in their pockets, while their children do without.
Although mothers in the project are afraid to talk about drug trafficking there, some absent fathers have fat wads of money in their pockets that officials know nothing about. They make it by selling crack or by other illegal means, money that never makes its way onto a tax return.
One mother of three small children said, "It is the most frustrating aspect of life for many single mothers, when a young man drives a good car and wears nice clothes and the mothers cannot afford Pampers."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Georgia, a leader in child-support enforcement, collects $122 a month from the absent father of 5-year-old Avery Anderson, above. But his mother, Sheila, who watched him do homework last month in their apartment in Atlanta, gets angry with those who see child support as a way to curb welfare; "We chase them all over creation," says Jerry Townsend, director of Georgia's Child Support Enforcement Division. In his office last month he displayed a poster intended to help track down delinquent parents. (Photographs by Alan S. Weiner for The New York Times) (pg. D18)
 
Chart: "RETHINKING WELFARE: Collecting from Fathers"
 The Goal -- To increase collection of child support from absent fathers of welfare families, helping the families become less dependent on welfare and reducing public expenses.
 The proposal -- Mothers who do not name the father would have benefits temporarily reduced; numerous measures aim to strengthen the identification of fathers and collection of support payments, including a recommendation that states deny drivers' licenses to non-paying parents.
 Current law -- Many state and Federal laws already aim to establish paternity and collect support payments, though enforcement varies among the states. Mothers who do not name a father are not penalized.
 State experience -- Even in a state like Georgia that is among the most aggressive in tracking down fathers and collecting money, only about one in four welfare families receives support payments, averaging $100 a month. Most of these families still need welfare payments, though the state and Federal governments save some funds.
 Savings -- The Congressional Budget Office estimates that steped up enforcement of child support would increase collections for welfare families by about 10 percent in the year 2000, to $3.5 billion from $3.3 billion. The savings would be largely offset by increased spending on technical assistance and computer systems to improve enforcement and by other policy changes. (pg. D18)

HEADLINE: Street Newsstands and Bus Stops Are Giuliani's Latest Concern

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
Adding a new plank to his quality-of-life campaign, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced an ambitious effort yesterday to reduce clutter on some of New York City's busiest corners by regulating and in many cases relocating everything from newsstands to bus stop shelters and ultimately, public telephones.
If enacted by the City Council, the plan would bring radical changes to the city's streetscape and provide some organization to New York's chaotic and congested sidewalks. 
 It would alter the way newsstands are owned and operated and limit the number of newspaper vending machines on a single block. And, the Mayor promised, the plan would finally bring public toilets to many sidewalks, after many years of legislative hearings and false starts.
Mr. Giuliani said that the plan was based in part on a desire to make the city's sidewalks more accessible to the disabled. But he also made it clear that he viewed the initiative as a way of ridding the sidewalks of graffiti-covered newsstands and packs of unsightly news boxes chained to street light poles.
"For too long, New York City streets have offered few amenities and much clutter," Mr. Giuliani said, speaking at a news conference in City Hall. "Today, we begin to reverse that trend. New Yorkers deserve more amenities and less clutter."
But newspaper executives and representatives of the newsstand operators were wary of the plan, fearing it could ultimately reduce the number of newsstands and vending boxes and cut into the profits of news dealers.
As the first part of the effort, Mr. Giuliani issued an executive order yesterday instructing various agencies to draw up rules and procedures to clear street corners of news boxes and newsstands and to shift them to clusters in the middle of city blocks.
But the plan also attempts to impose a uniform appearance on sidewalk structures by placing the design, construction and maintenance of all bus shelters, public toilets and newsstands under a single contract.
Mr. Giuliani said that the effect would be to replace the current structures with a new generation of "street furniture," explaining that bidders would be asked to submit new designs for bus shelters and newsstands. The structures would be built at no cost to the city, the Mayor said, with the contractor generating income from advertising.
Although the new rules will apply to all five boroughs, their greatest impact will be in Manhattan, where the vast majority of newsstands and vending boxes are placed.
Currently, newsstand operators pay $1,000 to the city for a two-year license and can operate anywhere they choose. The plan Mr. Giuliani unveiled yesterday would call for newsstand operators to bid for the stands on a competitive basis, thereby increasing revenues to the city.
Deputy Mayor Fran Reiter said a similar arrangement is in use for about 15 newsstands in city parks. On these sites, she said, the city receives fees ranging from $3,000 to more than $100,000 each year.
Despite the likely increase in what newsstand operators pay to the city, Ms. Reiter said the initiative would probably result in an increase in the 330 newsstands on city streets.
But Robert S. Bookman, an attorney for the New York City Newsstand Operators Association, was skeptical of her assessment. With higher fees, he said, "the business would become less profitable." He added: "New York City has lost more than 1,000 newsstands since 1950. And this would cause the decline to continue."
Fred Drasner, co-publisher and chief executive of The Daily News, said his company had "not completed our analysis of what the impact of shifting the boxes would be." The Daily News, Mr. Drasner said, is "favorably disposed to any program that would increase the number of newsstands. But we would obviously be concerned about anything that results in fewer."
Russell T. Lewis, president and general manager of The New York Times, said said he saw no need for further regulation of newspaper vending boxes, citing a 1984 agreement between the city and five daily newspapers that outlined where vending machines could and couldn't be placed.
Under the accord, the newspapers were barred from placing vending boxes in public parks or where they would obstruct fire hydrants, driveways, railway and subway station entrances, bus stops and crosswalks. Although there was no limit placed on the number of machines that could be used, the accord said that no more than three could be placed next to each other.
"The Times doesn't see any need to reinvent the wheel," Mr. Lewis said. "I don't think vending machines represent an imminent danger or threat to public safety."
City officials said last night that they saw no conflict between the Mayor's initiative and the 1984 agreement.
Much of the Mayor's initiative must be approved by the City Council. Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone joined with several committee chairman yesterday in issuing a statement calling the Mayor's plan "a good start toward organizing and cleaning up the haphazard arrangement of structures on city sidewalks."
The shape and design of the new structures remain unclear, mayoral aides said. They said that it was possible that a newsstand and a public toilet could be combined as a single structure. The administration envisions adding public telephones to the structures. They also said that as many as 30 public toilets would be placed on city streets within the next three years on a test basis.
Officials said that under the plan, newspaper boxes and vending machines could no longer be chained to street lamp posts on corners. Instead, they will be required to be bolted to the sidewalk in the middle of the block, with no more than six boxes on any one side of the street. The permits would be issued on a first come, first served basis, the administration said.
Companies in the outdoor advertising market said the Mayor's plan had attractive features.They said that maintaining several different structures provided an economy of scale that would not be realized in servicing either bus shelters or public toilets alone.
"We're very supportive of the concept," said Joan Davidson, a spokeswoman for Gannett Outdoor New York, which has the city contract to maintain and place advertisements on New York's 2,700 bus shelters. "We believe the city's moving in the right direction."
Academics and preservation groups reacted enthusiastically to the Mayor's plan. "Newsstands and street vending have always been a positive force and an attraction in New York City," said Emanuel Tobier, professor of economics and planning and chairman of the urban planning department at New York University. "But it needs to be contained and it would be usefully reined in."
Kent L. Barwick, president of the Municipal Art Society, said that the plan would "put a little order into what has been chaos. It sent a message to the world that this great city was incapable of governing its public spaces. This make good street sense."

HEADLINE: OUR TOWNS;
A Tradition, and a Resort, at Twilight

BYLINE: By Evelyn Nieves 

DATELINE: SOUTH FALLSBURG, N.Y.

 BODY:
THE Pines Resort Hotel is busy, busy, busy. Chef On Ma is up to his elbows in matzoh balls. The bakers are whining for assistants. Busboys are stacking 4,000 new plates, knives, forks and spoons, which sound something like a symphony for cymbals.
Reservations for Passover have come in at a steady pace, with 700 guests expected tonight, the first of the eight-day holiday. True, this is 100 people short of a sell-out. And there was a time not too long ago when packing the place for Passover was a given. But it is nothing to fret over, all things considered. 
 "I'm not complaining," said Cliff Ehrlich, who knows a good booking when he sees one. He grew up at the Pines when his grandparents and parents ran it and is now a vice president, along with his brother Steve. If tradition still brings some families here when the old days are just about dead, "Great," he says.
But he quickly added that holidays and conferences can't prop up the hotel forever. In fact, he says it all the time. For the last several weeks, he's been running around New York trying to drum up support for the idea of an Oneida Indian casino at the Monticello Raceway.
It was his idea, as vice president of the Catskill Resort Association, to approach the Oneidas, who have gone from bingo games on their reservation in 1985 to opening the modest Turning Point Casino in Verona in 1993 to aiming for the grandeur of a Foxwoods, the richest casino in the country.
Mr. Ehrlich and Ray Halbritter, the Oneida Nation leader, have been joined at the hip since they announced the proposal last month. They've brought business leaders and officials from Sullivan County on bus tours to Turning Point, brought Oneidas to Sullivan County, met with every group with questions every time they've been asked. "Two meetings today," he said Thursday, checking his schedule. Since they unveiled their idea, Mr. Ehrlich said, he has had close to 100 meetings with politicians and community and business people.
 NOT that he has to do much convincing in these parts. Just about everyone in Sullivan County seems to think casino gambling would be salvation. (Remember when it was actually considered bad for a community?) Shopkeepers from Roscoe to South Fallsburg display petitions on their counters for people to show their support. A huge billboard on Route 17 announces "Sullivan County Business Association Welcomes The Oneida Nation." Politicians keep talking about new jobs.
"In all my life -- I'm 35 -- I have never seen anything that has united the community for one effort," Mr. Ehrlich said.
It doesn't seem to matter that Gov. George E. Pataki said no immediately to the idea of another Indian (tax-free) casino in New York, and is wavering on the idea of legalized state-run casinos. "He told us he wanted details," Mr. Ehrlich said, adding that the plan is to present a package of information to the Governor's office on May 15.
"It's an economic project," he said. "We want it so badly because there is only so much we can do here now."
The Pines, like the few other remaining year-round Catskill resorts, is holding on for dear life. It recognizes two seasons: on and on. But the situation has been off season for years, and it is trying hard to shake the "faded Borscht Belt" image.
Bruce Siegal, the Pines manager, sounds dismayed that it isn't more popular. "We have everything!" he said. (He isn't part of the Ehrlich family, but he might as well be. At 34, he has worked at the hotel for 17 years. When he gives a tour, it's as if he owned the place.)
"Think of it as a cruise ship on land," he said. "Look at that indoor pool. It has its own complex. Look at that: miniature golf. Look, here's the ice-skating rink." And the outdoor pool, he said, with a wave of his hand, has barbecues on deck in season.
"My parents in Brooklyn go to Atlantic City for a weekend every month," he said. "They could be coming here instead."
 LIKE the Concord, which bills itself as the golf and skiing resort, The Pines has tried different ways to lure new guests.
"Theme weekends," Mr. Ehrlich said. "We do a bluegrass festival. We do two Irish weekends a year. Four polka weekends. We do a country dance weekend twice a year. A ballroom dance weekend twice a year."
But none of that could compete with the ching-ching-ching of one-armed bandits. The Pines even promised tour groups free trips to Atlantic City or Las Vegas. "We'd give senior groups two free tickets to one of the casinos for every full bus," Mr. Ehrlich said. "We did that for two years!"
The Pines doesn't do it anymore, but Mr. Ehrlich is fatalistic. Passover will be lovely. The hotel is opening -- it has been closed for a few days to prepare -- looking spiffy. The guests will be greeted like long-lost relatives. It will be the way it's always been.
"I don't want it to end," he said. "But if we don't get casinos, I think this will be the last generation of the hotel. I just don't see how we can keep it up."

HEADLINE: Now on Moscow TV, Heeere's Aleksandr!

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 13

 BODY:
Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, the great anti-Soviet dissident who while living in exile in Vermont turned his wrath on the empty materialism and lowbrow culture of the West, has found a new calling since he returned to a free Russia.
He is a talk show host. 
 Mr. Solzhenitsyn, winner of the 1970 Nobel Prize in Literature, has not resorted to interviewing women-who-love-men-too-much or celebrity chefs. But the austere, bearded 76-year-old writer, a man revered and feared as a 20th-century prophet, has adapted quite nimbly to the mass media revolution that swept his country in his absence.
On his talk show, "A Meeting With Solzhenitsyn," he has chatted with well-known personalities like Svyatoslav N. Federov, a leading eye surgeon; Vladimir P. Lukin, a former Ambassador to Washington, and some of the country's most notable journalists.
Given to treating his guests to long, lofty monologues, Mr. Solzhenitsyn comes across as a combination of Charlie Rose and Moses.
"It is horrible that our officialdom is invulnerable," he said recently during a screed on the unaccountability of the Russian bureaucracy. "One cannot find the truth, and the horrible thing is that shamelessness is spilling over our society. The absence of conscience and honesty is the air of our society. It was like this in Soviet society, and it is going on now -- shamelessness is reigning."
The show is taped in Mr. Solzhenitsyn's apartment in Moscow, in his study. He and his guests sit side by side at his desk, against the backdrop of a giant bookcase crammed with books. Mr. Solzhenitsyn keeps a few handwritten notes on the desk, but mostly he speaks, apocalyptically, off the top of his head.
The Russian press has written almost nothing about the show. On the air since September, it has not been reviewed by television critics. But other Russian talk show hosts speak condescendingly about Mr. Solzhenitsyn's television venture.
"For the post-perestroika generation, he really means nothing," said Artyom Troitsky, a writer and rock critic who has a post-midnight talk show, "Cafe Oblomov."
"Why should anyone now care about the Gulag Archipelago?" he added. "I'm afraid that Solzhenitsyn is totally, totally passe."
But there are fans. Mr. Solzhenitsyn said on one show that he gets 30 to 40 letters a day, mostly from desperate older people imploring him to intercede on their behalf. He said his mail illustrated the corrosion of the Russian political system.
"In most cases, people ask for protection -- protection from courts, from state bodies of power, from officials," he said.
And some of the political leaders that Mr. Solzhenitsyn criticizes with such verve also pay heed to his show. President Boris N. Yeltsin's office often asks the television studio for transcripts of the program. So do some members of Parliament.
Mr. Solzhenitsyn recently staged a blistering attack on the Government's decision to reorganize state television and create a public station that will be partly owned by a consortium of banks and businesses that favor the current administration.
Sergei Blagovolin, the head of the public station, boasted that by not interfering with Mr. Solzhenitsyn's denunciation, he had illustrated the new station's commitment to fairness.
Mr. Solzhenitsyn's ratings are respectable, but not high. An April 3 survey of 650 random Moscow viewers showed that while 12 percent watched his show, 19.3 percent preferred to watch the talk show of Vladimir Pozner, who learned how to whip up a studio audience American-style while working alongside Phil Donahue in the 1980's.
Some of Mr. Solzhenitsyn's worst fears about the Westernization of the Russian soul appear to be true: The show with the highest ratings, 26.6 percent, was "Wild Rose," a Mexican soap opera.
When Mr. Solzhenitsyn returned to Russia last May after 20 years in exile -- 18 in virtual isolation in Vermont -- his comeback caused a sensation that flared brightly but petered out.
Most Russians, preoccupied with their daily lives and economic survival, have tuned out the fierce rectitude and scolding of the man who spent eight years in Stalin's labor camps and exposed the full horror of Soviet oppression in works like "The Gulag Archipelago," "One Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich" and "Cancer Ward."
After a two-month train ride across Siberia, which he took to reacquaint himself with ordinary Russians, he received little attention from the new Russian elite.
Democrats were alienated by his nationalistic views. Even former dissidents like Gleb Yakunin, a defrocked Russian Orthodox priest, worried openly that the inflexible Slavophile would become another "Ayatollah Khomeini," stirring up fundamentalism and xenophobia.
But Mr. Solzhenitsyn was equally withering about the ultra-nationalist leader Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky, calling him a "caricature of a Russian patriot."
Younger intellectuals, more attuned to irony than moral certitude, take delight in knocking the towering figure of Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn.
"It's better to have him speak than write," said Viktor Yerofeyev, a novelist and literary critic. "He writes such ugly Russian." He said that with the talk show, Mr. Solzhenitsyn had returned to his roots: "He is once again what he always was at heart -- a provincial schoolteacher."
Mr. Solzhenitsyn's most recent opus, "The Red Wheel," a 5,000-page history of the Russian Revolution, was coolly received by critics and largely unread by the public.
So when he arrived in Moscow, Mr. Solzhenitsyn turned to a more accessible medium, television.
"We completely do everything that Mr. Solzhenitsyn wants," said Alvar V. Kakuchaya, director of the Russian state television channel, No. 1, that produces his talk show. "He knows how much we respect him. I think that is why he chose us to broadcast his program."
Mr. Solzhenitsyn alone selects his guests. When the station offered him 15 minutes, he demanded 20. He also insisted on being broadcast on prime time, 9:40 P.M., the slot after the news, even though he is up against highly popular movie channels.
However dour and uncompromising his message, Mr. Solzhenitsyn is an energetic and compelling speaker, surprisingly at ease before the camera. But there is little small talk on his show.
When he introduced one recent guest, Mr. Lukin, the head of the Foreign Affairs Committee of the lower house of Parliament, as a former Ambassador to the United States, he brushed off Mr. Lukin's ingratiating reply -- "Oh, but you too were an ambassador ..." -- and raced ahead to one of his favorite topics, the perfidy of the West. The International Monetary Fund and Radio Liberty are among his pet peeves.
"This is a very ambiguous organization today; it seems to consist of our people, our contemporaries, living among us but receiving their salaries from Washington and their instructions from Washington," Mr. Solzhenitzyn said of Radio Liberty, which is financed by the United States Government. "This is direct interference in our affairs."
Mr. Lukin, like most other guests, did not get much of a chance to respond. Most shows are less a conversation than dueling monologues.
Which may explain why there will be a slight change in the format of "A Meeting With Solzhenitsyn" beginning next week. His wife, Natalya, explained that after an seven-month trial run, Mr. Solzhenitsyn has decided that the show would work better without guests.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Clinton Sees Little Basis for Dollar's Fall

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 13

 BODY:
In his most extensive comments on the dollar since it began its recent fall, President Clinton said today that he saw little basis in reality for its recent weakness. He expressed confidence that financial markets would ultimately take into account the effects of his Administration's fiscal policy.
"The United States will continue to reduce the deficit, we will reduce it more, we will have a responsible policy, and the dollar will respond accordingly," Mr. Clinton declared. 
 In an interview on CNN, Mr. Clinton said nothing to indicate whether the Treasury was prepared to intervene again in defense of the American currency, but he suggested strongly that the dollar was being wrongly undervalued.
"The economic condition of the American people is a whole lot better than the economy of Japan and Germany right now," the President said. "We have lower unemployment, we produce more jobs, we have low inflation."
Mr. Clinton spoke before Japan's Government and ruling coalition parties agreed to a package of fiscal stimulus measures as part of a new effort to rein in the surging yen. A senior Treasury official later declined to comment upon that Japanese package because he had not yet seen the details. All that another Administration official would say was that the package appeared to be tentative.
But for his part, the President was clearly determined to signal that the United States remained solidly on a course of deficit reduction, which should make the dollar more attractive to investors.
"The world markets may not know it yet, but that's going to be the policy of the United States," Mr. Clinton said. He said that he would favor nothing more than "appropriate, targeted, modest tax cuts," and said he believed such a plan would be approved despite the already approved quest by House Republicans for more sweeping tax reductions.
In this Administration as in previous ones, the President has generally avoided commenting about the dollar, in large part out of recognition that even comments intended as benign can have an enormous effect on the currency markets. Even today, Mr. Clinton was careful to say that he had "no idea" what had happened to drive the dollar so low.
But with Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin en route to Indonesia and the first stop on a weeklong economic mission, Mr. Clinton assumed an unusually prominent role today in talking about the currency during the 30-minute television interview, which was shown tonight on CNN.
The President did not single out the Republicans by name. But he seemed to be suggesting that their efforts to push deep tax cuts through Congress might have been responsible for the markets' trepidation about the dollar.
"When I was in charge of economic policy and the Congress was supporting it," Mr. Clinton said pointedly, "we had lower deficits, low inflation, high growth and a dollar that was stronger."
"I'm still in charge of economic policy," he said, interrupting himself at one point. "The question is, what's the Congress going to do?"
Mr. Clinton added a final swipe at his rivals' reluctance to detail exactly how they would finance the tax reductions they have proposed. "It's unwise to be out here talking about tax cuts until you explain how you're going to reduce the deficit," he said.

HEADLINE: Dr. David Thompson, 72, Dies; Ex-Head of New York Hospital

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
Dr. David D. Thompson, who led New York Hospital during 20 years of sweeping medical advances and turbulent upheaval until his retirement as director in 1987, died yesterday at the hospital where he had spent all but two years of an almost 50-year career. He was 72 and lived in Tenafly, N.J.
The hospital said he died of leukemia. 
 The two decades that Dr. Thompson served as director of one of the nation's premier teaching hospitals were a period of vast changes in medicine, among them the introduction of such advanced diagnostic techniques as CAT scans, M.R.I.'s and endoscopic examinations, and the development of a profusion of new therapeutic drugs.
As the 1,000-bed hospital's budget soared from $39 million when he became director in 1967 to $395 million when he retired in 1987, Dr. Thompson also supervised considerable capital expansion, including the development of the city's first advanced burn unit, new centers for the care of premature infants and for dialysis, and a pronounced shift from inpatient treatment to ambulatory care.
Dr. Thompson, who made it a point to take time to chat with employees even as his staff grew to more than 5,000, sought a similar rapport with the hospital's patients. He may not have been able to visit them all, but he was responsible for developing one of the nation's first patient-advocate programs.
For all the accomplishments, Dr. Thompson's tenure was also a period of unusual strain, including a series of well-publicized allegations of medical lapses by the hospital. But whether he was dealing with a siege by demonstrators and the news media during the controversial treatment of the deposed Shah of Iran in 1979, or responding to the charges, recriminations and litigation that followed the deaths of Libby Zion in 1984 and Andy Warhol in 1987, Dr. Thompson faced each succeeding crisis with equanimity.
"He was so even tempered," his longtime friend and colleague, Dr. John Ellis, said yesterday. "I never heard him say an unkind word about anybody."
That may have been because wherever he went at New York Hospital and its sister institution, Cornell Medical College, Dr. Thompson was always at home.
He was born and bred a Cornell man, and except for two years he spent with the National Institutes of Health in lieu of military service in the Korean War, he never strayed from the Big Red fold.
A native of Ithaca, where his father was a professor of agriculture at Cornell, he graduated from Cornell in 1943, received his medical degree from Cornell in 1946, served both as an intern and resident at New York Hospital and held a succession of positions at both the hospital and the college.
Although he had a promising career as a researcher into kidney diseases, he was lured into administration by his mentor, Dr. Hugh Luckey, the last man to serve as overall director of both the college and the hospital.
Dr. Thompson, known as a man who was not afraid of change, earned his reputation as a medical innovator early on. At a time when it was a cliche for a doctor to marry a nurse, Dr. Thompson married a doctor.
"I was the only girl in the class," she said yesterday, "and I married the cream of the crop."
In addition to his wife, Lynn, he is survived by three sons, David Jr., of Niantic, Conn., Richard of Meriden, N.H., and Peter of Yarmouth, Me.; a daughter, Catherine McKee of St. Mary's, Ga.; a brother, John, of Ithaca, and eight granchildren.

HEADLINE: The P.L.O. Crackdown in Gaza

 BODY:
Under heavy pressure from Israel and the United States, Yasir Arafat's Palestinian Authority has launched its toughest crackdown yet against Islamic groups who would wreck the Israel-Palestinian peace agreement by terror. Mr. Arafat's police in Gaza have arrested hundreds of people from the two main militant groups, Hamas and Islamic Holy War. The Palestinian administration has also announced a new drive to register weapons and has begun sentencing fiery orators to harsh terms for "inciting civil strife."
The Islamic groups have responded with rhetorical defiance but tactical caution. They are as anxious as Mr. Arafat to avoid an intra-Palestinian civil war in Gaza. So far Mr. Arafat has moved mainly against preachers, journalists and low-level militants, not armed fighters or commanders. It is far from clear whether his resolve, or the militants' restraint, will last. 
 Mr. Arafat is in an unenviable position. His political standing among Palestinians has tumbled in the face of delays and disappointments in the peace process. Autonomy seems to have made little practical difference to ordinary lives.
Meanwhile repeated suicide attacks on Israeli targets make Mr. Arafat look weak to Palestinians and Israelis alike. Some of his troubles are his own fault. He has never been skilled at administration and he has been extremely reluctant to be seen as Israel's ally in the war against terrorism.
Even a fully committed Mr. Arafat is unlikely to eliminate Gaza-based terrorism. The Israelis did not succeed when they controlled the area. Close to a million Palestinians, many unemployed, live in 140 square miles of desert squalor.
Under the best of conditions Mr. Arafat cannot hope to make Gaza a model of smoothly functioning Palestinian autonomy. Autonomy's future, if it has one, is in the more economically and demographically promising terrain of the West Bank. Last month Israel and the P.L.O. set a July 1 target for agreement on Palestinian elections and Israeli troop withdrawals in much of the West Bank.
The peace process has often been a cruel disappointment, for Israelis who expected an end to terrorism and for Palestinians who expected an end to misery and humiliation. But abandoning it would be crueler still.

HEADLINE: Endangered Integrity

 BODY:
Republicans bent on weakening the nation's environmental laws are trashing the principles of decent government in the process.
This double insult was underscored this week when Senator Slade Gorton of Washington unveiled a bill that would scrap major provisions of the Endangered Species Act. Making light work for himself, Mr. Gorton farmed out the chore of drafting his revision to a group of Washington lawyers representing timber, mining, ranching and utility interests that have a huge economic stake in disabling the current law. Those industries have also contributed sizably to Mr. Gorton's re-election campaign. Mr. Gorton says he did not bother to consult with environmentalists because he already knew what their views were. 
 This is the same one-sided methodology employed by Representative Bud Shuster of Pennsylvania, chairman of the House Transportation and Infrastructure Committee, who essentially let lawyers and lobbyists for special interests draft his bill to gut the Clean Water Act of 1972.
The issue of how best to protect the environment while avoiding possible cases of overzealous regulation is a matter that needs mature national debate. Legislators are supposed to foster that process, not just give campaign contributors what they paid for.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Prices Higher in Shortened Session

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved higher yesterday, in a shortened trading session, on weak retail sales data that suggested economic growth was continuing slowly enough to keep inflation under control.
Yesterday's half-day session in advance of Good Friday and the start of Passover was choppy but uneventful as the Commerce Department reported weaker-than-expected March retail sales, or about half the gain most market participants expected. 
 Today the financial markets will be closed.
The previous two sales reports released by the Commerce Department both showed a moderation in retail sales, and each time bonds rallied.
Yesterday, the 30-year bond rose 7/32 , to a price of 10317/32 for a yield of 7.33 percent, down from 7.35 percent on Wednesday. The yields of bonds move in the opposite direction of their prices.
Market expectations of slower economic growth have taken the yield on a Government 30-year bond from a peak of 8.16 percent in November to 7.33 percent yesterday, with the average yield in the last few weeks about 7.38 percent, as traders wait for more signs of a slowdown.
Trader said that despite another weak report, investors remained skeptical, and as long as they did, yields were not likely to rise or fall drastically.
Traders also said that the strong direction of the retail sales report was still not enough to force yields either way, leaving some investors unconvinced that the pace of economic expansion is slowing from last year's growth rate of 4.1 percent, a 10-year high.
Separately, the Labor Department reported yesterday that the number of Americans filing initial claims for jobless benefits fell an unexpected 4,000 last week to 338,000, compared with expectations of an increase of 1,000.
And in another economic report yesterday, the University of Michigan said its preliminary consumer confidence index for April rose to 93.8 points from 90.3, higher than the 91 that economists expected.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities, said several elements had moved the bond market: Along with the continued softness in the retail sales data, there are expectations that data to be released today will show declines in both industrial production and capacity utilization and another large and to some extent undesired increase in business inventories. Mr. Fine also attributed some of the movement yesterday to short-covering before the long weekend.
He said while the University of Michigan's sentiment index moved up quite noticeably, it had still not reached the levels seen in January and February, giving support to the view that "any improvement in consumer spending over the near term is likely to be moderate and will not alter the concept of a slowing economy."
Mr. Fine said that all the recent economic statistics, taken together, "strongly suggest no change in Fed policy" concerning short-term interest rates during the May 23 meeting of the central bank's policy making committee.
He said that traders' growing belief in a neutral Fed "is the primary reason for the sharp decline in yields at the short end of the curve since the beginning of April." He added that the long bond has stayed around its current level over the last month following a sharp rally begun last November, and will need further evidence that the economy's pace during the second quarter is continuing to move toward the Fed's desired goal of 2.5 percent before the rally can continue.
In the municipal market, bond prices also moved higher as large investors grabbed large blocks of bonds being offered for sale. Traders and dealers said the large blocks of bonds were getting a bit expensive as investors were willing to pay more money for size.
The Bond Buyer's index comprised of 40 municipal issues was down two basis points, to an average yield of 6.25 percent to first call. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Declines on Expectations That Fed Won't Increase Rates

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against most leading currencies yesterday. Some currency dealers said the decline was prompted by an economic report that supported expectations that the Federal Reserve would not raise interest rates soon.
The Commerce Department reported yesterday that retail sales rose two-tenths of 1 percent in March, much weaker than economists' estimates. The data provided further evidence that the United States economy was in a slowdown, which means the Fed has little need to raise rates to curb inflationary growth. Higher rates usually tend to bolster the value of a currency by making deposits denominated in it more attractive. 
 The retail sales report "got the ball rolling for the dollar to fall," said Vicki Schmelzer Alicea, currency saleswoman for Westdeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale in New York.
In New York late yesterday, the dollar fell to 1.3864 German marks from 1.4010 marks on Wednesday. The dollar slipped to 83.50 yen from 83.75 yen.
The dollar did not fall as far against the yen as it did against the mark because of expectations that the Japanese Government would present a package of economic measures today aimed at curbing the yen's strength by stimulating import demand and helping companies cope with the dollar's 16 percent drop against the yen this year.
The strong yen hurts Japan's economy by hobbling its exporters.
Currency trading is expected to be thin today and Monday. United States financial markets are closed for the Good Friday holiday, while today and Monday are national holidays in London, the world's biggest center for currency trading.
"Anticipation of a thin market and uncertainty about the Japanese package is giving people pause before establishing short-dollar positions," said David De Rosa, director of currency trading at the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York.
Traders take short-dollar positions by selling the dollar, hoping to buy it back later at lower levels.
In other currency trading, the British pound rose to $1.6095, from $1.5925 on Wednesday. The Canadian dollar rose to 72.78 United States cents from 72.75 cents

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Sticking Point Emerges on U.S.-China Trade

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, April 13

 BODY:
Wrapping up a contentious week of trade talks in China, a senior United States official said today that the reluctance of China to open its markets remained a serious impediment to its plans to join the global trading community.
Remarks by the official, Under Secretary of Commerce Jeffrey E. Garten, pointed to a stubborn gap between Beijing and Washington on trade issues. Despite the signing of a landmark intellectual property rights agreement in February that both sides hailed as a model of cooperation, China and the United States do not even agree about the size of their trade imbalance, much less what to do about it. 
 Mr. Garten and the Foreign Trade Minister, Wu Yi, argued publicly at a conference in Beijing earlier this week. Ms. Wu angrily accused Mr. Garten of violating a promise to support China's membership in the World Trade Organization after he told reporters on the eve of trade talks that such support depended on further steps to open China's market.
Mr. Garten said today that his comments, in The International Herald Tribune, had not been intended as a warning and had been taken out of context. But he did not deny that American support for China to join the trade organization would hinge on its willingness to improve market access.
China's rules restricting foreign access to its service industries -- like banking, law and accounting -- have been the target of American pressure for years, Mr. Garten said. But apart from pressing for the rules to be made less restrictive, he said, the Clinton Administration is also taking an advocate's position by urging China to approve specific projects that are pending.
"Now we're saying, we can't wait for those rules to change," Mr. Garten said. "We're coming at it from both ends."
Mr. Garten said he had urged Chinese officials to approve $15 billion worth of American projects in power, environmental technology, transportation and communications. He said his talks with Ms. Wu and other officials had been constructive, but he did not report any breakthrough.
Market access is a touchy issue between the United States and China now because of the palpable desire by China's leaders to join the World Trade Organization. China has argued that it should be allowed entry on political terms, the same way that other, if smaller, developing nations are treated.
However, American and European trade officials hold that the pre-eminent status of China as a major world trader means that it should join on the same rules that apply to other large members, or on commercial terms, in the trade organization's terminology.
"China wants entry to the W.T.O., and we would like to see it enter," Mr. Garten said while in Beijing. "But unless they come in on terms that promote a more open economy, we will be unable to support the Chinese entry."
American officials say they have a $29.5 billion trade deficit with China -- China says it is substantially less, but does not count exports through Hong Kong -- and Mr. Garten said it was uncomfortably large and growing at a surprisingly fast rate.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Umpires See First Pitch, From the Owners

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
As replacement umpires worked the first 1995 exhibition games not played by replacement players, major league umpires yesterday received management's first proposal since the National and American leagues locked them out on Jan. 1.
Robert Kheel, the lawyer who negotiates for the leagues, and Richie Phillips, the umpires' lawyer, both declined to disclose details of the proposal. 
 "I continue to urge them to moderate their position," Kheel said. "I offered them some inducements to do that."
Phillips, after the two-hour meeting in New York, said: "The proposal was not enough of a move on their part to give me optimism that there's going to be a quick resolution to this dispute. But it was certainly meaningful to the extent that it stimulates negotiations."
Phillips said he was evaluating the umpires' positions on the major economic issues and would have a counterproposal "in the next two days."
The leagues previously offered the umpires only a cost-of-living increase in salary for each of the four years of the proposed agreement. In the expired agreement, the salary scale for all four years ranged from $60,000 for rookies to $175,000 for umpires with 25 years of major league service.
The new proposal, Phillips said, "increases and modifies" the previous offer. The only specific example he provided was that the offer removes the cap on the maximum salary for 25-year umpires, who would not have received even a cost-of-living increase.
Phillips said the leagues also had increased their offers in the other major economic areas of per-diem payments, retirement pay and pay for special events.
The umpires have asked for a raise that would amount to a 53 percent increase over the past four years and the next four.
"The ball's in their court," Kheel said. "The main point, from my perspective, is it's entirely up to them. If they want to make an agreement, they know the parameters that we believe are reasonable in a year coming off a strike."
Asked if he was encouraged, Jerry Crawford, the president of the umpires association, said, "The thing that's encouraging is they made an offer, the first offer they've made since Jan. 1."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
JAPANESE SETTLE ON PLAN TO CURB THE SURGING YEN

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Friday, April 14

 BODY:
Japan's Government announced an emergency plan this morning aimed at halting the precipitous fall of the dollar against the yen and at rescuing the nation's fragile economy from the brink of another recession.
As part of the effort, the Japanese central bank later cut the discount rate three-quarters of a percentage point, to a record low of 1 percent. 
 In putting together the plan, officials here hope to convince a skeptical world that they are serious about reducing their huge trade surplus, which is considered a major factor behind the relentless rise of the yen and fall of the dollar.
The package is also an acknowledgment that Japan must act on its own because the United States does not appear fully intent on propping up the dollar against the yen. This is the view in Tokyo despite an angry call this week by Japan's Finance Minister that Washington do something to halt the dollar's slide and despite pronouncements from Clinton Administration officials that they favor a stronger dollar.
Some analysts think the United States prefers to see the dollar weak against the yen, though not necessarily against all currencies, because it makes American products more competitive against Japanese products and increases pressure on Japan to make trade concessions.
The United States and Japan are entering what could be a final round of negotiations aimed at increasing sales in Japan of American automobiles and auto parts.
So what was seen as a problem of a weak dollar a couple of weeks ago has now been transformed into a problem of a strong yen. Increasingly, the yen's strength has had the effect of a vise squeezing Japan's economy, reducing the demand for its exports as they become more expensive abroad.
Today, the Japanese took a big step toward restraining the yen's rise and bolstering the dollar -- cutting the benchmark discount rate, the interest rate charged when the central bank makes short-term loans to banks. Other short-term Japanese rates fell earlier in the day in anticipation of the rate cut.
The discount rate cut is expected to lower returns on Japanese deposits, making investments in yen less attractive to foreigners and those in dollars more appealing.
The rate cut was not a formal part of the Government's economic package because the central bank has autonomy in setting rates. But it was widely expected.
The American Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin, reacted favorably to the Japanese central bank's rate reduction. "We welcome today's action by the Bank of Japan as a constructive step in light of economic conditions and financial market developments," he said at a stop in Honolulu on his way to a finance ministers' meeting in on the Indonesian island of Bali.
The Japanese markets reacted modestly to the economic plan and the rate cut. This afternoon, the dollar was quoted here at 83.78 yen, up from 83.50 yen in New York late Thursday. Japanese stock prices slipped, with the Nikkei index of 225 issues trading down 152.98 points, or nearly 1 percent, to stand at 16,285.81
The recent strength of the yen has made Japanese officials so desperate to halt their currency's rise that some politicians argued into the early hours today for the nation to demonstrate its commitment by setting a numerical target -- cutting the trade surplus in half in five years.
That would have been an extraordinary reversal, given that Japan has spent the last two years resisting attempts by American trade negotiators to establish just such targets.
But Government bureaucrats, considered more powerful in this country in making policy than elected officials, managed to get such targets deleted from the package, leaving only a statement of "strong determination" to cut the surplus.
Finance Minister Masayoshi Takemura contended that it would have been difficult to turn such targets into national policy.
Japanese officials say their plan will help reduce the trade surplus by stimulating the economy, thus increasing the demand for imported products. Import-promotion measures are also included in the proposal, as is the elimination of some regulations, making the Japanese market easier to penetrate.
The emergency plan was ordered on Monday after the dollar dropped to a new low of 80.15 yen in Tokyo trading, falling a frightening 4 percent in the space of a few hours, before bouncing back.
Yet some economists here said the plan -- which also includes steps to increase public works spending and accelerate deregulation -- was too weak and unspecific and could be rejected by the markets, sending the dollar plunging again.
"It's very big and broad and comprehensive in the skeleton with very little meat attached to it," said Mineko Sasaki-Smith of Morgan Stanley & Company. "I think this is going to disappoint the market."
The fall of the dollar from a level of about 100 yen in January to about 83 yen now makes Japan's exports of automobiles, electronics and other products more costly and less competitive in world markets. It has also sent the Japanese stock market plunging, deepening a sense of insecurity that had also been fed by the earthquake in Kobe in January and last month's poison-gas attack in the Tokyo subways.
Some economists predict that Japan, which had only recently begun to recover from its longest economic slump in four decades, will now experience a "double dip" recession. Other economists, however, think the economy has enough resiliency to continue its recovery, although at a slower rate.
Tokyo has repeatedly called for coordinated action among major nations to control exchange rates, but has largely been disappointed. The dollar has weakened mainly against the yen and the German mark and not against most currencies, so recent currency fluctuations are not considered big problems for the United States, some analysts say.
Other measures can influence the psychology of the currency markets, by trying to convince traders that Japan's trade surplus will be reduced. The surplus is considered an important long-term factor behind the rise of the yen because Japanese exporters earn huge amounts of dollars they then convert back into yen, and are therefore always selling the dollar and buying yen.
Japan has announced numerous plans to spur imports and abolish trade barriers, most of which have been considered inadequate by the nation's trading partners.
Today's package calls for carrying out a recently announced five-year deregulation plan in three years. But the original plan, put forth on March 31, was widely derided as insufficient, so accelerating it is not expected to make a big difference.
In addition to trying to influence currency rates, the package is aimed at helping the economy cushion the effects of the strong yen. Among other things, it calls for increased public works spending as a fiscal stimulus.
There are steps to lend financial support to small and medium-size businesses, which are among those most hurt by the yen's rise. Unlike the larger companies like Toyota and Sony, the smaller companies often lack the wherewithal to be able to move their factories abroad to escape the yen's rise.
The plan also calls on the Government to urge industries to pass along the benefits of the strong yen by reducing prices of imported products. They would, for instance, hope for cuts in gas and electricity rates, which depend on imported fuel.
Jesper Koll of J. P. Morgan here said the plan might be more successful in helping the economy than in directly influencing exchange rates. "Apart from cutting the discount rate, there is very little that a change in fiscal policy will do to impact exchange rates," he said.
The plan is also aimed at satisfying Japan's angry business leaders, who say the weak three-party coalition Government has been too slow to act. The failure of the central bank to cut the discount rate on March 31, after Germany had cut its rate, contributed to a renewed rise of the yen.
Mr. Rubin and Finance Minister Takemura will be attend a meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum this weekend. The Group of Seven industrial nations are expected to discuss currency issues the following weekend in Washington.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

U.N. Offers to Ease Sanctions Against Iraq
 The Security Council voted unanimously to offer Iraq easier terms under which it could sell oil to meet its need for medicine, food and other essential items. If Iraq accepts the plan, it would be the first break in the sanctions that have constricted the Iraqi economy since Iraq invaded Kuwait in 1990. 
 Iraq's reaction to the vote was negative but not dismissive. It was couched in an attack on the United States, a sponsor of the resolution along with Argentina, Britain, Oman and Rwanda. The Iraqis accused Washington of making the proposal too harsh. Under the plan, Iraq could sell as much as $2 billion in oil within 180 days, but 30 percent of the proceeds would go to victims of the invasion. Page 1.

Industrial Output Down in March
 The Fed said industrial output fell 0.3 percent last month, the first time in six months that the nation's mines, factories and utilities cut production. The drop is one of several recent signs that the economy is rapidly losing steam. In addition, the Government reported that capacity use rates fell and business inventories rose. 33.
 
Japan Gains in U.S. Trade
 Japan said its trade surplus with the United States continued to widen, rising to $5.08 billion in March and $55.7 billion in the fiscal year. Over all, its surplus shrank to $13.8 billion in March and $118 billion for the year. 32.
 
Court Upholds Ban of Alcatel Chief
 A Paris court rejected an appeal by Pierre Suard, the chairman and chief executive of Alcatel Alsthom, of a temporary injunction that prevents him from working at the company while he is being investigated for misuse of corporate funds. 32.
 
Couple Convicted in Tax Protest
 A Federal jury in New Hampshire convicted a couple in the tax protest movement of evading Federal income taxes for four years. Stuart Tulchinsky and his wife, Cathie Schneider, the prosperous owners of what prosecutors called drug paraphernalia shops, said they believed that the Federal income tax system was voluntary. 34.
 
Clinton and Gore Release Returns
 President Clinton and his wife released their Federal tax return, which showed they claimed $30,125 in charitable contributions, or 11 percent of their adjusted gross income of $263,900. The Clintons paid $55,313 in Federal taxes, or 21 percent of their adjusted income in 1994. Vice President Al Gore and his wife paid $142,688 in Federal taxes, or 35 percent of their $411,713 adjusted income. They claimed no itemized deductions. 8.

U.S.-European Free Trade Is Pushed
 An idea for a trans-Atlantic free-trade agreement has caught the attention of politicians, trade experts and business executives in Europe and the United States. Its proponents said an agreement could include the elimination of tariffs and quotas on services, on new telecommunications products and on government procurement policies. 32.
 
Baseball's New Labor Woe: Umpires
 When the baseball season opens on April 25, the players will likely take the field with replacement umpires and may even have to cross picket lines set up by the umpires union. The National and American Leagues locked out their 64 umpires Jan. 1 and don't intend to ask them back to work until the two sides negotiate a collective bargaining agreement. 1.
 
Brazil Hopes to Woo U.S. Business
 Brazil's new president, Fernando Henrique Cardoso, is beginning a five-day visit to the United States on Monday with plans to shift Americans' attention from Mexico to his country. In speeches to business executives in New York, he is expected to outline expanding investment opportunities in Brazil. 5.
 
Italy Cannot Halt Fuel Flow to Serbia
 A senior official in the Italian Foreign Ministry said Rome could do little to stop Italian oil companies from selling fuel to Albania, even though most of the fuel is apparently being smuggled to Serbia in violation of a United Nations embargo. Italy allows tankers to sail only after Albania has verified that the shipments are for domestic consumption, but American officials said the verification system has broken down. 3.
