HEADLINE: Belated Regrets About Vietnam Create a Consensus of Antipathy

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. 

 BODY:
Robert S. McNamara's recently expressed regrets about United States involvement in the Vietnam War seem to be reopening old wounds and reviving a raw debate that was beginning to slip into history.
Reaction to the former Defense Secretary's revised views, published in his new book, "In Retrospect: The Tragedy and Lessons of Vietnam," has mostly been relentlessly negative, with little credence or charity accorded Mr. McNamara's comment that "we were wrong, terribly wrong." 
 The criticism has come from just about every quarter -- combat veterans, former colleagues in Government, hawks, doves, editorialists and, of course, the children of the 60's who took to the streets and to the grassy grounds outside Mr. McNamara's Pentagon window to noisily, sometimes violently, protest "McNamara's war."
Here and there a few kind words have been voiced for the Defense Secretary in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations. But not many words and not very often.
In particular, many veterans bitterly fault Mr. McNamara, publicly a hawks' hawk throughout his Pentagon days, for his most striking admission: that he knew as early as 1967 that involvement in the conflict was a catastrophic mistake but that he could not bring himself to say so until almost three decades later.
"It sure would have been helpful in May of 1967, when I volunteered for Vietnam, if he had said then that the war was unwinnable," Max Cleland, who lost both legs in Vietnam and afterward served as head of the Veterans Administration, said in an interview.
"The title of his book should be 'Sorry About That,' " added Mr. Cleland, a Democrat who is now Georgia's Secretary of State, dredging up an old "grunt" phrase of cynical resignation and frustration.
"McNamara went to the World Bank," Mr. Cleland concluded, "while a lot of other people went to their graves."
Similar criticism came from Senator John McCain of Arizona, a former Navy pilot who was tortured by the North Vietnamese while spending seven years in a Hanoi cell.
"I think it's about 25 years too late to save those Americans who would be alive if he hadn't pursued a policy that was doomed to failure," Mr. McCain said.
The Senator, a Republican and critic of United States policy in the war, spoke in a telephone interview from Hanoi. He was in Vietnam on a special mission to recover remains of dead Americans and to urge restoration of diplomatic relations between Washington and Hanoi.
"I can only assume," Mr. McCain said, "that McNamara's doing it now because he's trying to assume some place in history. What that place would be, I don't know, unless it would be as one of the architects of a policy that doomed more than 40,000 American young people and caused a division in our country. That's McNamara's legacy."
Martin Kaplan of Seattle, who was sent to Vietnam in 1969, is still angry about the war, and the McNamara book has only exacerbated that anger.
"I don't see McNamara's revelations doing any good for anyone," Mr. Kaplan said as he and several other veterans sat together on Wednesday night, watching the former Defense Secretary discuss his book on the television show "Prime Time Live." "There's a sense of betrayal. To him it was just all an intellectual exercise. And he was called one of the best and brightest?"
Most of the other veterans sitting with Mr. Kaplan also expressed anger about Mr. McNamara's revelation. But then, with some wiping away tears as the former Secretary spoke, himself in tears, they offered an unusual perspective, one that while it was not forgiving was nevertheless understanding.
 
 
A Veteran Dealing With Grief and Guilt
 "We're seeing another Vietnam veteran dealing with his grief and guilt," said Lee Raaen, a former Army draftee who was shipped to Vietnam in 1970 and now is a Seattle lawyer. "But I suppose I could say, from a historical standpoint, 'It's about time.' "
One of the few Government leaders from the Vietnam era to speak up in Mr. McNamara's defense was McGeorge Bundy, a national security adviser at the White House in both the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations.
"An excellent book, a very valuable one, a great contribution," Mr. Bundy
But should it have been written sooner?
"That's a funny ex post facto judgment," Mr. Bundy replied. "We are lucky to have the book now. It is understandable that it took this time to write the book. He was a very busy man 20 years ago."
Mr. McNamara, now 78 and retired from a lengthy stint as president of the World Bank, contends as he makes the rounds of talk shows and book signings that his book is not a work of redemption. Already in its second printing after an initial run of 80,000 copies, it is meant, he says, to make people think and debate so that history does not repeat itself.
That has done little to silence his critics. In fact, even some former close colleagues and policy makers in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations are speaking out about him.
 
 
Criticism Tinged With Disappointment
 Theirs is a more gentle criticism, much of it tinged with disappointment that Mr. McNamara somehow has abandoned the cause that was in good part his creation. But it is criticism nonetheless, scoring Mr. McNamara not only for his switch but also for saying now that American policy makers in the 1960's, himself included, overestimated the Communist threat in Asia and underestimated and misunderstood the Vietnamese people.
"He obviously has something to get off his chest," said Gen. William C. Westmoreland, the top United States commander in Saigon for much of the war, "but this is not the McNamara I did business with. None of this ever came up, never was indicated to me.
"Recall that we went into Vietnam promising we would bear any price, any burden to bolster the Vietnamese to self-sufficiency, and we almost did, until Congress cut us off.
"You can't turn your back on a promise like that. I think McNamara should be reminded of that."
Actually, American involvement in the war was ended during the Nixon Administration. By then Mr. McNamara was at the World Bank and General Westmoreland had left Saigon.
Former Nixon Administration officials have mostly remained silent on Mr. McNamara's comments.
 
 
Losing the Battle, Winning the War
 One of his war-era colleagues, Walt W. Rostow, President Lyndon B. Johnson's hawkish national security adviser, said in a telephone interview from Texas that he did not want to get into an argument with Mr. McNamara about the contents of the book but he then quoted a recent newspaper commentary he had written.
"We certainly lost the battle, the test of will, in Vietnam, but we won the war in Southeast Asia," Mr. Rostow argued in the commentary, taking direct issue with Mr. McNamara's conclusion about how the war ended.
Then, taking still further issue, the commentary concluded, "This was surely not simply a pointless, lost war. I am sure the families and the veterans have suffered from this narrow view of the war in Southeast Asia."
Some criticism of Mr. McNamara has come from editorialists, along with reporters and columnists who during the war were frequently at odds with American officials over how much progress was being made.
In the Los Angeles Times a few days ago, the cartoonist Paul Conrad portrayed the former Defense Secretary standing before the 58,000 names etched in the black marble of the Vietnam Veterans Memorial in Washington and saying, "Sorry About That."
And in their syndicated "Politics Today" column, published today, Jack Germond and Jules Witcover recall the "polarized and venomous" debate over the war that raged in the mid-1960's, then add:
"Officialdom equated pursuit of the war with loyalty and patriotism and criticism of it as disloyalty and even treason. The voice then of a key figure in the conduct of the war, questioning its core, would have been explosive and have given the protest a credibility it lacked with many Americans. Instead, McNamara's voice now sounds more like a whimper from a man who needed to get his mea culpa out of his system. It will offer little solace to the Americans who served and died in Vietnam and to the thousands more at home who were vilified for saying then what he has finally said now."
 
 
A Disciple of Peace Welcomes the Converted
 One who spoke up back then and immediately ran afoul of officialdom was David Harris, a freelance writer from San Francisco. In one of the more notable anti-war protests of the era, he pointedly returned his draft card to his local Selective Service Board, refused induction into the Army and was sentenced to three years in prison, serving 20 months before being released.
"I welcome the converted," Mr. Harris said of the McNamara book. "It's a little late and lot of people are dead or have been in prison or took off for Canada, but I say, 'welcome aboard' to the man, better late than never."
Still, Mr. McNamara's mea culpa is far from totally satisfactory to Mr. Harris.
"Despite it all, his understanding of what happened still seems shallow," he said. "You just don't drop the equivalent of 250 pounds of high explosives on every man, woman and child in Southeast Asia and kill close to 60,000 Americans and something like three million Vietnamese and then turn around, even 30 years too late, and be done with it all by saying, 'Oh, I'm sorry. We were terribly wrong.'
"It's too enormous and unforgivable for that. This is a start for him and America that I welcome. But it's only a start."
Stanley Karnow, who reported from Vietnam as a journalist and then went on to write one of the most definitive histories to date of the war, "Vietnam: A History," finds Mr. McNamara's treatment of war protesters in print, as opposed to his treatment of protesters as Pentagon chief, "a very, very interesting exercise."
"He writes movingly of them, almost sympathetically at times," Mr. Karnow said. "He's obviously a very tormented guy. An old protester like Bill Clinton will probably take some solace from his kind words.
"All that said, and giving McNamara full credit for finally getting out his story and his mea culpa, the cold fact is that admission is not an excuse. That won't bring back somebody's lost son."
 
 
And What of Those He Tried to Save
 And what of the Vietnamese, especially those from the South whom Mr. McNamara tried to save? What do they think of his book?
One refugee from Saigon, Tony Lam, who fled the South Vietnamese capital just before it fell in 1975 and eventually made it to Southern California, believes that Mr. McNamara is terribly wrong on one important change of mind.
Mr. Lam takes unyielding issue with the former Secretary's conclusion that the North Vietnamese leaders were primarily nationalists, not Communists. He said Mr. McNamara had it right back in the 1960's when he was arguing, passionately, that those leader were hard-line Communists.
Still, Mr. Lam, now a City Councilman in Westminster, Calif., has sympathy for Mr. McNamara and the torment that drove him, finally, to write his book, however it is being received.
"I praise his courage for admitting his mistakes," Mr. Lam said.

HEADLINE: U.N. COUNCIL VOTES TO EASE SANCTIONS AGAINST BAGHDAD

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, April 14

 BODY:
The Security Council voted unanimously today to offer Iraq easier terms under which to sell oil to meet its urgent need for medicine, food and other essentials.
If Iraq accepts the plan, it would be the first break in the wall of sanctions that has surrounded the country and constricted its economy since Iraq invaded Kuwait in 1990. 
 In 1991, the United Nations established a more restrictive plan to allow Iraq to resume limited oil exports to pay for emergency needs. But the Government of President Saddam Hussein rejected the deal as an infringement of Iraq's sovereignty, while maintaining that the Iraqis are suffering crippling hardships because of international sanctions.
Iraq's initial reaction to today's vote was negative but not dismissive. It was largely couched in an attack on the United States, a sponsor of the resolution along with Argentina, Britain, Oman and Rwanda.
"It is quite clear to the members of the Council that the United States did not intend in pushing this resolution to help alleviate the humanitarian hardships of Iraq," Deputy Prime Minister Tariq Aziz said in a written statement.
Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali met with Mr. Aziz after the vote and held out the prospect that the new offer would lead to a general lifting of sanctions.
"It is a first step toward the total lifting of the sanctions against Iraq," Mr. Boutros-Ghali said after the meeting. "It is a first step toward overcoming the crisis which exists between the international community and Iraq."
But Madeleine K. Albright, the chief United States delegate, avoided such a characterization.
"We believe we have found exactly the right compromise here," she said, "not a lifting of the sanctions on the Iraqi regime, but a humanitarian exception to the sanctions for the benefit of the Iraqi people."
If Baghdad refuses to accept this plan, Ms. Albright said, "it will only be because the Government of Iraq does not know how to take yes for an answer."
Under the plan, which is renewable, Iraq would be permitted to sell up to $2 billion in oil within 180 days, subject to certification every 90 days by the Secretary General, who must report to the Council on how the income is distributed.
Of that money, limited to $1 billion every 90 days, Iraq would have to earmark 30 percent to compensate the victims of its invasion of Kuwait. It would also have to pay the costs of United Nations monitors overseeing both the oil sales and Iraq's compliance with a resolution that demands the destruction or surveillance of major weapons systems.
In the first 90 days, Iraq would receive about $650 million because of the cost of readying the oil pipeline from Kirkuk to Yumurtalik, on Turkey's Mediterranean coast, through which most of the oil is to be exported. Iraq would then receive about $680 million in a 90-day period. The money would be placed in an escrow account and disbursed by the United Nations.
Iraq is also required by the resolution to set aside $150 million for Kurdish areas in northern Iraq, so its net proceeds would fall to $600 million or so every 90 days.
The new plan's provisions are less stringent than the 1991 version, in which the Security Council offered a one-time sale of $1.6 billion with more stringent monitoring.
The 15-to-0 vote today was a surprise to even the sponsors of the resolution, who thought there was a possibility of an abstention from Russia. Moscow wanted more time for the Iraqis to consider the proposal before it was enacted.
Weeks of effort to win some positive sign from the Iraqis apparently convinced all parties that the framers of the resolution had done what they could to give Baghdad a chance to approve the plan before it was put forth. United States officials and others felt that they were coming under increasing pressure from many nations to find a way to relieve the hardships of Iraqis.
The resolution now puts a plan on the table for Iraq to accept formally in negotiations with Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Criticism From Baghdad
 BAGHDAD, Iraq, Saturday, April 15 (Reuters) -- Iraq severely criticized the resolution on oil sales today, saying the terms violated its sovereignty.
A statement issued after a joint meeting of the Revolutionary Command Council and the ruling Baath party's regional command said the latest resolution was harsher than the one passed in 1991.
But it was not clear from the strongly worded statement whether Iraq had totally rejected the offer because, it said, Parliament and other institutions had to be consulted.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japan's Trade Surplus Shrinks (Except With U.S.)

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 14

 BODY:
With pressure mounting from Washington that Japan do more to narrow its trade surplus, the Japanese Government reported today that the overall surplus shrank in March and the latest fiscal year but that the imbalance with the United States widened in both periods.
As long as the yen remains strong, economists said, the overall surplus is not likely to decline significantly in coming months. 
 The Finance Ministry said Japan's customs-cleared trade surplus narrowed to $13.84 billion in March from $13.90 billion in March 1994 and to $117.98 billion in the fiscal year that ended on March 31 from a revised $121.88 billion in the prior fiscal year. The prior fiscal year's surplus was Japan's highest ever.
At the same time, the ministry said Japan's surplus with the United States widened to $5.08 billion in March from $4.94 billion in the month a year earlier and to $55.66 billion in the fiscal year from $51.12 billion in the previous fiscal year.
Japanese exports to the rest of the world rose 16.4 percent in March from a year earlier, to $42.53 billion, while imports to Japan increased 26.7 percent, to $28.69 billion. In the full fiscal year, exports rose 11.5 percent, to $408.47 billion, and imports increased 18.9 percent, to $290.49 billion.
In trade with the United States, Japanese exports rose 9.9 percent in March, to $11.75 billion, while imports grew 16 percent, to $6.66 billion. In the full year, Japanese exports to the United States increased 11.3 percent, to $120.10 billion, while imports from the United States grew 13.5 percent, to $64.44 billion.
Officials in Washington have pressed Japan for years to reduce its trade surplus. Earlier this week, Cabinet officers and other American officials who deal with trade matters approved a strategy under which the United States would warn Japan that it would move to impose several billion dollars in punitive tariffs unless major progress was made in opening Japanese markets to American autos and auto parts in the next three weeks.
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin will meet with his Japanese counterpart, Masayoshi Takemura, in Indonesia over the weekend.
Economists said they did not expect any significant decline in Japan's surplus unless the yen began to weaken. They said the high yen would spur Japanese companies to move more production abroad, which would necessitate exports of costly manufacturing equipment. That will help cause Japan's overall exports to increase.
In theory, imports should be increased by the strong yen because it makes foreign goods less expensive in terms of the Japanese currency. But the economic slowdown will trim the potential rise, the economists said.
 And even though the strong Japanese currency means that Japanese companies receive fewer yen for every dollar of sales in the United States, shipments to the United States are likely to continue unabated because the exporters would rather absorb the cost from the strong currency than raise prices in that important market, said Iwaki Hidehiro, senior economist at the Nomura Research Institute.

HEADLINE: Brazil's Chief Due in U.S. Riding Boom

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 14

 BODY:
With exports and investment surging into Brazil from the United States, this nation's new President plans to open a campaign next week to shift Americans' attention from Mexico to his country.
"We have sustained a 5 percent economic growth rate for the last three years," said President Fernando Henrique Cardoso, who arrives in New York on Monday on a five-day visit to the United States. "Mexico never had this." 
 The country's first English-speaking President in memory, Mr. Cardoso, 63, is fashioning a role as national salesman with the goal of attracting more investment and expanding Brazil's political influence.
In a speech on Tuesday at the United Nations, he is expected to argue that Brazil, with a population of 155 million, should win a permanent seat on an expanded Security Council.
In speeches to American business executives in New York, he is expected to outline expanding investment opportunities in Brazil, which has a market economy that is larger than Russia's. To encourage more Americans to come here, he plans to sign new legislation lengthening the visas issued to Americans from 90 days to five years.
United States exports to Brazil jumped by 35 percent last year, and Brazil has recently been the only major country to post monthly trade deficits with the United States. On the investor side, corporate interest in Latin America's largest economy has risen steadily, as reflected in rising membership in the American Chamber of Commerce in Sao Paulo.
"We have a flourishing economy," the President, a former sociology professor and politician from Sao Paulo, said in an interview last week in Brasilia, the capital. "Inflation has fallen to 1.5 percent a month."
This year Brazilian diplomats expect to wrap up negotiations for a South American free-trade zone intended largely to provide new markets for Sao Paulo's booming industries.
Brazil is also quietly expanding its role in regional politics, brokering cease-fires in the border fighting between Peru and Ecuador earlier this year, for example.
Next month it sends 1,100 peacekeeping troops to Angola, in its largest overseas military mission since Brazilians fought alongside Americans in Italy in World War II.
Although Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown visits the country regularly, the Clinton Administration's envoys to Brazil are generally low-level. By contrast, 10 British ministers have come here over the last year.
But several longstanding irritants in relations with the United States have eased in recent years. Brazil dismantled its secret nuclear bomb program in the early 1990's, and it renegotiated its huge debt to private foreign banks last year.
After 10 years of civilian government, tensions with the United States over military rule in Brazil have become a distant memory. On the first state visit accorded a Brazilian leader in decades, Mr. Cardoso will visit Washington as the leader of one of the world's largest democracies.
But the President, who has served as a Foreign Minister and Finance Minister, will need strong support at home to make good on some of his business pledges. While he is hoping to amend Brazil's Constitution to open the economy to foreign oil, telephone and mining companies, for instance, resistance in Congress is high.
Mr. Cardoso's five-party coalition technically constitutes a congressional majority, but he routinely loses vote after vote in Congress. Since he took office, lawmakers have voted a 12 percent cap on interest rates, approved a $3 billion bailout for large farmers and buried a bill intended to restructure Brazil's largely bankrupt social security system.
Mindful of Mexico's recent economic collapse, some economists fear that lack of congressional support could endanger Mr. Cardoso's anti-inflation plan.
Still, Mr. Cardoso takes comfort in recent public opinion polls, which give him approval ratings ranging from 40 percent to 64 percent.
"Brazil is going to change, and the minority that I defeated at the polling booths is not going to block the change," he told a crowd of peasants in a speech last month.
Known as a patient man who values the art of negotiation, Brazil's President seems unfazed by complaints of a slow start to his four-year term, which began on Jan. 1.
"You have to set a goal, and then build your road to get there," he said. "You lose today. You win tomorrow. You have to have perseverance."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Fernando Henrique Cardoso in his office in the capital. (John Maier Jr. for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Embargo Against Belgrade Has a Major Leak

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER 

DATELINE: ROME, April 13

 BODY:
In spite of appeals from the United States, a senior official in the Italian Foreign Ministry says Rome can do little to stop Italian oil companies from selling fuel to Albania, though most of the fuel is apparently being smuggled to Serbia in violation of a United Nations embargo.
The official said it was up to Albania to control the diversion. 
 Italy allows tankers to sail only after Albania has verified that the shipments are for domestic consumption, said the official, who spoke on the condition that he not be identified. But American officials say that verification system, put in place a few months ago to deal with the sanctions violations, has already broken down.
They add that at the current rate, the amount of fuel reaching Albania this year will be twice as much as last year, with at least half being smuggled to Serbia.
The matter has caused considerable diplomatic consternation.
Washington is especially alarmed by violations of the sanctions because the fuel eventually reaches the Serbian military. The sanctions were first imposed by the Security Council in 1992 to force Serbia to cooperate in finding an end to the war between Muslims and Serbs in Bosnia.
Italy and Greece are major suppliers of gasoline and diesel fuel to Albania. One Italian company, Anonima Petroli Italiana, accounts for 90 percent of fuel exports from Italy to Albania, the Foreign Ministry official said.
Marcello Senepa, who is president of API's Albanian subsidiary, said, "We have no comment," when asked about the issue. API is one of the larger oil companies in Italy that is not owned by the Government.
"I am very, very angry about these questions -- the problem is not serious," he said before abruptly hanging up.
In the first nine months last year, about 40 percent of Albania's diesel and gasoline imports came from Italian companies, including some five million gallons of diesel, according to the European Union's sanctions office in Brussels. Greek oil companies supplied most of the rest.
Albania has seen a rapid increase in its domestic fuel consumption since emerging from decades of economic backwardness under Communism. But the climb in fuel imports has been much greater than the Albanian economy requires to meet its own needs, Western officials say.
While it is legal to sell fuel to Albania, Western diplomats and sanctions monitors there say that the oil companies most likely know where the fuel is ending up, given the small size of the Albanian market and the openness of the smuggling.
To help stop the diversion, the United States has asked Italy to limit fuel sales to Albania. But the Foreign Ministry official said Italy could do little because the trade was legal.
American officials are sympathetic; they agree that the primary responsibility for cracking down on the smuggling belongs with Albania, and that if Italy stopped selling to Albania, other countries, notably Greece, would seize the market.
Nevertheless, Washington wishes Italy would do more, like calling in API officials for a stern lecture, as President Clinton recently did with officials of the American oil company Conoco to try to persuade them not to go ahead with an energy-development deal with Iran.
"It's part of the American way of thinking -- 'Where there's a will, there's a way,' " one American official said. "We'll never see eye to eye on this."
The Italian ministry official said limiting the flow of fuel to Albania was the responsibility of the sanctions committee of the United Nations, and some American diplomats in Europe agreed. "We cannot act unilaterally," the Italian said.

HEADLINE: Conflicting Orders on Mine Cleanup Sow Anger

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER 

DATELINE: BURNHAM, N.M.

 BODY:
A small coal mine set in a treeless expanse of grass and sand on the Navajo reservation in northwestern New Mexico has become the subject of a bureaucratic skirmish that could affect the very survival of the Federal agency charged with overseeing strip mines.
The dispute began, all the parties agree, with a simple act of Government inconsistency: Two regional branches of the Interior Department's Office of Surface Mining gave a big coal company conflicting directions for cleaning up its 135-acre mine here. The case, which has become widely known in the West, has been used by the agency's critics in the House of Representatives to help justify legislation that would cut the agency's work force in half and eliminate its inspection and enforcement program. 
 The Consolidation Coal Company, which permanently closed its Burnham mine in 1990, applied that year to the Office of Surface Mining for a permit to clean up the site as required by Federal law. Its request, filed with the agency's Denver office, languished for four years.
Then last summer, the company's officials say, the agency's office in Albuquerque, N.M., unexpectedly sent them a notice saying Consolidation Coal had violated Federal law by failing to clean up the site and ordering work to begin immediately.
The Albuquerque office prodded the Denver office to propose a fine of nearly $200,000 for each of Consolidation Coal's 18 corporate directors. These would have been the largest penalties ever levied against corporate mining officers in the West.
The Interior Department eventually suspended the fines, on the condition that the company clean up the mine, but by that time the incident had outraged the agency's critics and created sympathy for one of the nation's largest coal companies.
"No matter what we did, we were caught in the middle," said Thomas F. Hoffman, the chief spokesman for Consolidation Coal. "We ended up in a situation where one Government group wanted us to move, and another said stand still."
The director of the Office of Surface Mining, Robert Uram, was sympathetic once the misunderstanding became clear.
"What happened there was a perfect justification for reorganization" of his agency, said Mr. Uram, who described the office as "in chaos" when he took it over a year ago.
Soon after taking command as the Clinton Administration's Interior Secretary, Bruce Babbitt vowed to support tough enforcement of the Federal strip-mining law and make the agency "the best regulatory organization" in Washington.
But the new Republican House, emboldened by accounts of the Burnham mine mix-up and other stories, has its own plans. Under a proposal being considered by the House Budget Committee, the $46.7 million budget of the Office of Surface Mining's regulatory and inspection program would be cut by $30 million, a reduction that would mean that at least 500 of the agency's 986 employees would lose their jobs.
The agency's total budget is $293 million, but most of that money flows though the agency to the states for their own regulatory programs and to private contractors for restoring abandoned mines. The House's proposed cut in those programs is less than $6 million.
Mr. Uram said that if Congress approved the new budget, "it would be a signal to wildcatters and outlaws in the coal fields to open illegal mines."
The Office of Surface Mining was established as part of the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act in 1977. From the start, it was battered by the coal industry and its powerful Congressional supporters from Appalachia and the West.
The act requires mining companies to treat water and soil contamination by reclaiming the millions of acres torn up at the roughly 4,000 working strip mines, the largest of which are in the West. It also established a fund, paid for by the coal industry, to clean up some 20,000 abandoned strip mines.
Attacks on the agency are coming from state governments as well as Congress.
Gov. Michael O. Leavitt of Utah, a Republican, and Gov. Roy Romer of Colorado, a Democrat, have complained in recent months about interference by Federal coal-mine inspectors.
In one case involving a strip mine in Colorado, Federal inspectors found fault with a decision last year by the state to approve the Kerr Coal Company's cleanup of a 1,000-acre mine. The Federal team accused Kerr of violating the law by not filling in the huge gap it had cut out of a ridge.
"Whether or not a particular case satisfies the Federal Government, the issue the states are raising is that they have the authority to be the primary enforcer of the strip-mining law," said Douglas Larson, executive director of the Western Interstate Energy Board, a group based in Denver that represents state agencies overseeing mine cleanups in Colorado, Montana, New Mexico, Utah and Wyoming.
"Generally, it's agreed among states that a downsizing of the agency is appropriate." Mr. Larson said.
Indian leaders are no more satisfied, though many worry about too lax Federal oversight, rather than too vigorous.
The Navajo nation, which spans much of northern Arizona and some of northwestern New Mexico, is at the center of an immense coal-based energy colony. Roughly 30 million tons of coal, three-quarters of it mined on Navajo land, are stripped from the earth and used to power seven Southwestern electrical plants that generate 2 percent of the nation's electricity.
The Navajo nation says it gains nearly $50 million in royalty income a year from four working mines on its reservation. Some 3,100 people, many of them Navajos, work in the mines as well as two of the power plants that are on Navajo land.
Despite this economic clout, Navajo leaders, including the tribe's president, Albert Hale, worry about the environmental damage and say the Federal Government is not an effective steward.
"The operation of the Office of Surface Mining as an agency of the Interior Department presents a classic example of conflict of interest," said Mr. Hale, a lawyer who was elected in November.
"On the one hand," he said, "the Interior Department has a trust responsibility to obtain maximum returns from the extraction of coal to meet its obligations. On the other hand, it is regulating the land from which the coal is extracted."
"We are a sovereign nation, and we are capable of regulating," Mr. Hale continued. "There is great damage being done, and we are in a better position to oversee the industry."
But Federal mine inspectors, who refused to speak for attribution, said that they doubted that the tribe had the fortitude to enforce the law and that the Government was doing an adequate job.
The mine at Burnham was opened in the late 1970's to turn coal into natural gas and was closed in 1984. Though the Federal law requires "contemporaneous" reclamation, meaning that as coal is stripped, earth should be placed back in the mining pit, the site sat untouched for 10 years.
Only after the Citizens Coal Council, an environmental group, filed a complaint last May with the Albuquerque office did the Federal agency act.
But the settlement that the company and the Government finally negotiated, giving Consolidation Coal 18 months to complete the work and providing waivers for exceeding the deadline, was challenged as too generous by the Coal Council, which filed a court action last month to stop it.
"This mine should never have been allowed to be opened where it was," said Ernest Diswood, a Navajo environmental specialist, pointing to nearby Navajo homes and grave sites. "And it's been 11 years of struggle to get it cleaned up. Was this what the law was supposed to do?"

HEADLINE: Canada's Borrowing, With Its Fat Fees, Lures Wall Street

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH 

DATELINE: TORONTO, April 14

 BODY:
This city's compact financial district, overlooking Lake Ontario, bisected by lower Bay Street and occupying less than a square mile of real estate, so resembles its counterpart in lower Manhattan that movie companies looking for a Wall Street location often shoot here.
While film makers are attracted by the striking resemblance and a cheaper Canadian dollar, Wall Street's investment powerhouses in recent months have been lured to Bay Street by the fat underwriting commissions from one of the world's largest borrowing countries. 
 In the biggest American drive for Canadian financial business since the market was deregulated in the mid-1980's, Salomon Brothers; Goldman, Sachs & Company; Smith Barney, a unit of Travelers; Morgan Stanley Group, and Lehman Brothers are expanding their operations on Bay Street.
The American incursion has come even as the huge Canadian debt -- about $550 billion (Canadian), or nearly $400 billion (United States) -- has raised concerns over the country's credit rating. Moody's Investors Service on Wednesday downgraded Canada's triple-A status for Canadian dollar-denominated debt to double-A-1. But the move had been widely anticipated and had little market impact. The Canadian dollar actually rose both Wednesday and Thursday. As one trader put it, "The news cleared away the uncertainties." Markets have long known, he added, that Canada's risk was higher than the country's credit rating. Perceived weakness in the Quebec separatist movement has been a major force behind the strengthening Canadian dollar.
Besides helping sell government debt, the American houses work in an advisory capacity for many American and Canadian companies, helping with mergers and acquisitions, corporate finance and other matters. The American firms are benefiting from the increased North American business spurred by freer trade, especially after last year's North American Free Trade Agreement. And they share the general belief that despite some recent Government budget tightening future capital needs will continue to be enormous.
The outstanding federal and provincial debt is roughly the same as Canada's gross domestic product, or the value of all goods and services produced last year. As a percentage of G.D.P., only Italy's is higher among the leading industrial countries.
According to a tabulation by Euromoney magazine of London, eight Canadian provinces, topped by Ontario, led the pack of worldwide provincial, state and municipal borrowers for the year ended June 30, 1994. In fact, Ontario, with $7.5 billion of loans, ranked fourth after the European Investment Bank, Sweden and Italy.
The debt volumes exceed the capacity of the Canadian capital market. Nearly half of all Canadian debt is held by foreigners, chiefly pension funds in the United States.
"What makes this market compelling are its tremendous requirements for debt and equity capital, its growth at a relatively more rapid rate than other capital markets and the global market integration that's now under way," said Jamie Kiernan, president of Goldman, Sachs Canada Ltd.
Goldman, Sachs and the other houses are driven by strong competitive forces. David Driscoll, editor of The Investment Reporter, a weekly Toronto investment newsletter, says it is the case of no one wanting to be left behind. He speaks of a "lemming effect -- if there's money to be made, everyone follows."
An added incentive now is indications that Canadian authorities look more favorably upon investment houses with Canadian-based operations.
"It's no doubt much more difficult to distribute Canadian dollar bonds if there's no presence in the Canadian market," said John Madden, chief executive officer of the Ontario Financing Authority and the province's assistant deputy minister of finance.
The Canadian financial institutions are watching with keen interest. Many decline to comment for the record. An executive at one of the big Canadian national banks, who asked not to be identified, observed, "This is bound to get pretty cutthroat."
Yet some Canadians say they are looking forward to the competition. "The more players, the better," said Greg Clarke, vice president of the Investment Dealers Association of Canada. "We like to see knowledgeable, well-capitalized players in our marketplace because it breeds innovation and makes better markets."
John Ing, president of Maison Placements Canada Inc., an investment boutique dealing exclusively with institutions, said, "We welcome them, but so far we haven't seen much of them, since they're mainly going after the fixed-income side," or bond business.
A number of the American investment houses are simply building on a presence here dating from the so-called Big Bang of 1987, when the regulatory walls came down, eliminating the kind of restrictions that had forced Canadian financial institutions to provide circumscribed services and that had prohibited most foreign dealers from competing in Canada.
Goldman, Sachs came up then to set up full-scale bond trading and investment banking operations. Now Goldman, with 60 employees -- the second-biggest contingent after Merrill Lynch -- is building an equity trading and underwriting operation for Canadian institutional clients.
Merrill Lynch Canada, which set up shop here in 1952 and which employs 180 for its bond trading and investment banking operation, used to be much larger. In earlier years it had gone into the retail stock brokerage business and had as many as 1,600 employees. But profits were disappointing, especially after the 1987 market crash, and in 1990 it sold its brokerage business to CIBC Wood Gundy Inc., a subsidiary of the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce.
Despite the stepped-up activities of Merrill Lynch's competitors, Paul Thomas -- president of Merrill Lynch Canada and an alumnus of Goldman, Sachs -- said: "We're fairly comfortable. There's always room to improve, but we feel we cover the country fairly well." Expansion, he added, is "always under review."
Both Salomon and Morgan Stanley established corporate finance advisory services here in 1987. They intended to follow Goldman, Sachs with more ambitious bond trading and investment banking operations but got cold feet after the market crash that year. Now both are moving ahead full speed.
Salomon opened a bond trading floor in December; it has 4 salesmen and 4 traders and expects to have 15 on the payroll within a year. Morgan Stanley is tripling the size of its Toronto office staff, from 15 to 50.
Smith Barney has just moved into the corporate services business in Toronto. Andre Hidi, now chief executive of Smith Barney Canada, had run these activities for Morgan Stanley.
Last month, Lehman announced it was opening a broker-dealer office here that would have 15 professionals. It will focus on corporate finance, trading a broad range of bonds.
European and Asian financial houses are also raising the ante. The Hongkong Bank of Canada, part of the Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Group of HSBC Holdings, has expanded its stake -- from 50 to 75 percent -- in the Bay Street securities firm of BBN James Capel. Another international giant, the Deutsche Bank of Frankfurt, is increasing investment banking and bond trading activity at McLean McCarthy Inc., a financial boutique it acquired in 1987.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Wall Street firms have flocked to Bay Street, Toronto's financial district, which resembles its Manhattan counterpart. (Robert Skeoch for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Japan's Plan To Help Dollar Doesn't Impress Tokyo Markets

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 14

 BODY:
Japan's emergency plan to stem the fall of the dollar against the yen and to stimulate the nation's economy failed to impress the financial markets today, raising fears here that the dollar's fall could resume next week.
Critics said the measures, announced today, were vague and lacked teeth. "I'm a little bit shocked at seeing today's package," said Masaru Takagi, chief economist of the Fuji Research Institute, associated with the Fuji Bank. "There are no concrete figures yet, no concrete features at all." 
 Currency markets seemed to shrug off the announcement, with exchange rates barely budging. In late trading in Tokyo, the dollar was quoted at 83.58 yen, up only slightly from 83.50 yen in late New York trading Thursday. Trading was kept thin by the Good Friday holiday, which closed other major financial centers.
Stock investors gave an even harsher reception. After having climbed for four consecutive days, partly in anticipation of today's package, the Tokyo stock market fell sharply today. The Nikkei average of 225 stocks dropped 390.90 points, or 2.4 percent, to 16,047.89.
The emergency plan was announced today in response to Monday's sharp drop of the dollar to a postwar record low of 80.15 yen here. The weak dollar and strong yen are threatening to derail an economic recovery that has just begun in Japan by choking off Japan's exports.
In perhaps the most significant of today's measures, the Bank of Japan cut the official discount rate by three-quarters of a percentage point, to a record low for Japan of 1 percent. While businessmen called this a welcome move, if somewhat late, the currency markets had already been expecting such a cut.
Other parts of the plan called for increasing public works spending, spurring imports and accelerating the deregulation of the economy. The Government, in effect, was trying to convince the currency markets that it was serious about lowering Japan's trade surplus, which is considered a major factor behind the long-term rise of the yen.
It failed to convince. Today's measures, as in many past trade plans, consisted largely of statements of intent rather than concrete actions.
The Government did say it would be willing to use deficit financing to stimulate the economy, something that the Finance Ministry has long resisted. But there were no figures yet on how much public spending would be increased.
In the auto area, currently the focus of tense negotiations between the United States and Japan, the plan calls only for Japan to build some "permanent exhibition places" to display foreign cars and automobile parts.
Much of the plan was directed not at influencing the currency rates but at helping Japan cope with the stronger yen.
The discount rate cut, for instance, could help spur economic activity. But today's was the eighth cut in the rate since 1991, when Japan's economy started to go into a downturn. In that span the rate has been cut by 5 percent, yet the economy still remains weak.
Bureaucrats deleted from the plan some stronger proposals, such as one to set a numerical target for cutting the trade surplus in half in five years. A proposal to cut the tax on securities transactions in an effort to help revive the stock market will be studied.

Dollar Little Changed
 By Bloomberg Business News
 The dollar was little changed against the yen yesterday as currency dealers were skeptical that Japan's new economic package would be effective in curbing the strength of the yen.
Trading was very light yesterday. United States markets were closed for Good Friday, and many dealers stayed home for the Easter and Passover weekend. In London and Frankfurt, two large centers for currency trading, markets and banks were closed yesterday and will not reopen until Tuesday.
In New York late yesterday, the dollar was quoted at 83.30 yen, down from 83.50 yen on Thursday, and at 1.3915 German marks, up from 1.3864 marks.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Is a Trans-Atlantic Pact Coming Down the Pike?

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, April 14

 BODY:
An idea that seems self-evident economically, but almost impossible politically, has recently caught the attention of politicians, trade experts and business executives in Europe and North America -- a trans-Atlantic free-trade agreement.
Yes, it has been considered before and put aside. Yes, it would take years to negotiate. Yes, it might have to exclude agricultural subsidies. 
 And while no government has so far adopted such a free-trade zone as a goal, the decibel level of conversation is rising dramatically.
"There's hardly a high-level meeting on trade where the issue does not come up," said Stuart E. Eizenstat, the American Ambassador to the European Union in Brussels. "This is just in the earliest stages of getting on the Administration's radar screen."
Currently, the roster of politicians, trade officials or executives embracing the idea of an Atlantic free-trade zone, or something like it, includes Jean Chretien, Prime Minister of Canada; Jacques Santer, president of the European Commission; Edzard Reuter, chief executive of Daimler-Benz A. G.; Lane Kirkland, head of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., and Alain Juppe, Foreign Minister of France.
American officials said President Clinton had discussed the idea with Prime Minister John Major of Britain earlier this month, but the officials would not elaborate.
In the eyes of its proponents, a United States-Europe free-trade agreement would go far beyond the reduced tariff barriers negotiated under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to include elimination of tariffs and quotas on all services, on new telecommunications products and on government procurement policies. It might also harmonize taxation of corporations.
On the European side, support for such a trade agreement grows out of two areas of concern.
One is that without the binding force of a common Communist enemy, the European-American partnership has been weakened and is more and more vexed by a series of small trade disputes that almost inevitably turn into bitter squabbles.
Officials here point to the recent dispute over who would head the World Trade Organization, pitting an American candidate against a European one. Or a growing friction over subsidies of European and American airline manufacturers. Or recent charges by France that Washington engaged in economic espionage. Or European import restrictions on Latin American bananas.
"With every passing day I feel reconfirmed in my view that differing economic interests could quite conceivably undermine the old solidarity existing between us," said Mr. Reuter of Daimler-Benz.
Europe is also afraid that it will be isolated by free-trade pacts that Washington is trying to form with Latin American and Asian countries. While Europe had announced its own free-trade deals with East European and Mediterranean countries, its overall market would be dwarfed by that of the Americas and the Pacific Basin.
"It is rather odd for the E.U. to have concluded free-trade arrangements with a host of countries but not have something of the kind with the United States," said Andreas van Agt, the European Union's former ambassador to the United States.
Jeffrey E. Garten, Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade, and one of the Clinton Administration officials who is quietly pushing the idea of a union, argues that economics and social factors argue strongly in favor of such an agreement.
"Europe is and will continue to be for years the most important and biggest market for Americans," he said.
For example, United States trade and sales of American corporations based in Europe totaled $1.7 trillion in 1992, Mr. Garten said. That is 55 percent larger than the total commerce with Asia in the same year -- $1.1 trillion.
Moreover, in Asia the United States has accumulated a deficit of more than $1 trillion over the last 25 years; American trade with Europe in that time "has been almost perfectly in balance," Mr. Garten said.
And because the European Union is such a huge trade market -- $7 trillion a year in economic output -- modest growth of, say, 3 percent, generates a stunning $210 billion in economic activity that is a potential market for American goods.
"This is like finding a new market the size of Taiwan's every year," Mr. Garten said.
Spurring on Washington is the fact that Mexico is quietly trying to negotiate its own free-trade accord with Europe, and that Europe is seeking to establish free-trade ties with the countries of the Mercosur trade pact -- Argentina, Brazil, Uruguay and Paraguay -- as well as with Chile and Bolivia.
But whatever the arguments in favor of a broad agreement, officials say it may be long in coming.
One big obstacle is the issue of agricultural subsidies and barriers, which almost scuttled a GATT accord last year and could doom any free-trade accord.
Another is that officials want to get the World Trade Organization off the ground and see how it operates before taking up complex new negotiations. Mats Hellstrom, Sweden's Minister of Foreign Trade, said such negotiations should be expanded beyond a European-North American free-trade agreement, to include all GATT members.
Third, next year the European Union faces what is called its Intergovernmental Conference, a kind of constitutional convention, where the principles of the union will be examined and possibly changed.
Finally, American and European trade negotiators are suffering from a kind of diplomatic exhaustion from the negotiations over the GATT, and more recently the bitter dispute over who would head the W.T.O.
But those discussing the issue of a new trade pact say it is not about to go away.
"There is no question in my mind that 10 years from now our trade relationship with the E.U. will be more liberalized than it is today," Mr. Eizenstat said. "But doing a full-blown free-trade agreement sooner will be difficult."

HEADLINE: Industrial Production Drops For First Time in Six Months

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 14

 BODY:
The Government today reported the first drop in industrial production in six months, providing further evidence of an economic slowdown.
The Federal Reserve said that industrial output fell in March by three-tenths of 1 percent, only the second decline in nearly two years and the first drop since September, when the figure reflected an auto industry strike. 
 The central bank also revised figures for January and February to reflect that the cumulative gain in output for the two months was three-tenths of 1 percent less than previously estimated.
And another closely watched Federal Reserve index showed that the nation's factories, mines and utilities were operating with more slack in March for the second consecutive month. It was the first back-to-back decline for the operating rate in nearly two years.
Even though the production decline was led by a sharp drop for utilities because of unusually mild weather, analysts said the signs of a broad-based slowdown were unmistakable.
"All of the pieces are falling into place to strengthen the case for a soft landing," said Sung Won Sohn, an economist at the Norwest Corporation, a Minneapolis banking company. "We have really a nice situation where an economic slowdown is occurring with limited inflation."
There is practically no chance the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates again anytime soon, he said, adding the next move could be a rate cut to stimulate growth.
"Fed watching is going to be pretty boring for awhile," Mr. Sohn said.
Traders and analysts will have a long weekend to absorb the data; financial markets in the United States were closed today for Good Friday.
The Federal Reserve said the industrial operating rate fell five-tenths of 1 percent, following a dip of two-tenths of 1 percent in February that had earlier been estimated to be an increase of two-tenths of a point.
Still, the central bank said the consecutive declines left the operating rate at 84.9 percent of capacity -- equaling a peak achieved during a recovery in 1988 and 1989.
In another report that could lead to slower economic activity, the Commerce Department said business inventories rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in February, the 11th consecutive gain, and jumped a revised 1.3 percent the previous month. The January gain matched the biggest buildup of stocks on store shelves and factory back lots in more than a decade.
Analysts said the big increases might foretell a cut in production if consumer spending continued to ease.
The economy expanded at a robust 5.1 percent annual rate in the final quarter of last year. Economists expected it slowed to around 3 percent in the first three months of 1995 and predict an even smaller gain in the current quarter.
The slowdown was by design, as the Fed raised interest rates seven times in a 12-month period that ended Feb. 1 to keep inflation under control.
The Fed had worried that rising industrial output and dwindling unused capacity would lead to bottlenecks and rising prices.
Much of the drop-off in production last month occurred at utilities, where output plunged 2.6 percent and reversed a similar-sized jump in February.
Manufacturing output in March slipped one-tenth of 1 percent, matching the drop the previous month.
Production of big-ticket durable goods for consumers fell 1.9 percent last month, led by a drop in light trucks and further weakness in production of household furniture and appliances.
Production at mines fell half a percent in March after rising the same amount in February.

HEADLINE: Young Doctors Find Specialist Jobs Hard to Get

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
Five years ago, Dr. Jonathan Boniuk would have been guaranteed overnight success. An eye surgeon trained at top medical schools, he would have walked into a busy practice and earned over $150,000 a year.
But in the last month he has talked to friends, colleagues, friends of friends, recruiters, health maintenance organizations and drug company representatives who make the rounds of doctors' offices, all with the dwindling hope of finding a permanent job. He has had little success. 
 "I'll get by," he said recently, in words that have become newly familiar to doctors. "Maybe I won't work for a few months. Or I could work in an optical shop doing refractions a few days a week. I could live off that and I'd still be helping people."
A small but rapidly growing group of young doctors find themselves un- or underemployed, stranded in their profession's equivalent of flipping burgers or pumping gas.
Managed care has strikingly decreased the demand for specialists like Dr. Boniuk, particularly in places like New York, where specialists are already in abundant supply. So when Dr. Boniuk finishes his residency at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine-Montefiore Medical Center in June, after eight years of training, he is resigned to a temporary job or even a period of unemployment.
H.M.O.'s, which tightly restrict the use of specialists' skills, have become newly powerful in many parts of the country, leading to a sharp decrease in demand for the highly trained doctors. At the same time, training programs have for the most part kept churning them out, despite widespread agreement that there are too many specialists in the United States.
"In some specialties we could probably turn off the spigot for 10 years and still have plenty," said Dr. David R. Dantzker, president of Long Island Jewish Medical Center. "The pity is there are a number of people involved in years of specialty training who are not going to use it, who aren't going to have a job or at least aren't going to practice their subspecialty." H.M.O.'s decrease specialist business by prohibiting patients from visiting specialists without a referral from a general doctor, as well as scrutinizing the need for each specialty procedure that occurs. They also severely limit the number of specialists they use.
Health experts say the problems of highly trained doctors in the New York area are likely to get worse, as more New Yorkers enroll in H.M.O.'s or other forms of managed care. About 25 percent of people in New York State are in H.M.O.'s, and 20 percent in New York City. In Northern California, where over 40 percent belong to H.M.O.'s, some medical groups have begun dismissing specialists en masse.
In response, several academic hospitals in New York are considering scaling back specialty training programs, but these efforts, many undertaken reluctantly, may be outstripped by the medical students who are turning away in droves from once popular specialties.
In 1995, there was a remarkable upswing in the number of medical students seeking training in primary care fields like family practice, internal medicine and pediatrics, and a decline in previously popular specialties like radiology and anesthesiology, according to the American Association of Medical Colleges.
"A number of factors have contributed to the change, but I think what we're seeing is the market at work," said William Jacott, a member of the American Medical Association Board of Trustees and a family physician.
It has been a devastating experience for many young specialists who have spent a decade in training and ended up tens of thousands of dollars in debt to enter a chosen field.
"It's frustrating to come this far and go through all this training to find the jobs are not there," said Dr. Jill Kavaler, an anesthesiology resident at Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York. "One of the reasons people go into medicine is job security. We always thought there'd be a job. Now we're not sure."
Dr. Kavaler mailed 60 letters to hospitals in the New York area and received rejection after rejection, until she was finally offered a job at Mount Sinai at a salary 20 percent below what it would have been a few years ago.
The job crisis is most troublesome among doctors who usually work directly for hospitals, like anesthesiologists and radiologists, and surgical subspecialists like ophthalmologists and neurosurgeons. Large urban and suburban areas are particularly tight, where specialists traditionally have concentrated. Doctors in fields like cardiology and pulmonary medicine have been somewhat spared because they complete general internal medicine training before specializing, and so can practice general medicine if there is no demand for their specialty.
Most H.M.O.'s estimate that they need half of their doctors to be specialists and half to be involved in primary care. But in many urban areas, 70 percent of doctors specialize.
Newly minted specialists have coped in a variety of ways, depending on their specialty and goals.
Those entering the market are taking jobs their peers might have disdained a few years ago, in a distant city, with lower salaries or without long-term commitments from employers. Traditionally, a doctor joining a practice is salaried for a couple of years and then becomes a partner, with guaranteed employment and a share of profits.
"Now nobody's promising anything," Dr. Kavaler said. "In fact, they're saying: 'There's no possibility of partnership here.' "
Specialists in some fields have the option of practicing primary care. Dr. Seymour I. Huberfeld, who trained for three years in pulmonary medicine at Long Island Jewish Medical Center, is taking a job in which he expects to do more general medicine than specialty care, although he said he hoped the balance would shift over time. "If I were starting out now I would not have become a specialist," Dr. Huberfeld said.
Some young doctors, facing a glutted market, are choosing paradoxically to sign on for more training to become even more specialized. They are gambling that their added skills will make them more marketable when looking for work. Added training also postpones the painful job search.
"Ironically, when the idea is to have more people go into general practice, the pressure we feel around here is to become more specialized," said Paul M. Tesser, an ophthalmology resident at Albert Einstein who is doing a fellowship in glaucoma surgery.
He said that some young ophthalmologists were taking courses to learn a controversial type of elective surgery intended as an alternative to the wearing of glasses. Like cosmetic surgery, it is not paid for by medical insurance, and so it will not be affected by the growth of H.M.O.'s.
Health policy analysts have suggested that, with reduced demand for their services, specialists might have to consider retraining in primary care. Most young specialists bristle at the suggestion.
"Retraining is not a real option for most young specialists who are coming out in heavy debt," said Rob T. Stallings, director of corporate services at Jackson & Coker, a physician placement service based in Atlanta. "You can't tell them just retrain, even though that's what you are thinking would be best for them."
Mr. Stallings said that he frequently recommends that young doctors in particularly tight specialties like anesthesiology take on temporary work, filling in for vacationing doctors, or short-term work at a hospital, as at a resort area in the summer. "If they're looking for a permanent job, we try to steer them to temporary work so they can keep up their skills and make some money," he said.
Many young specialists who would have slipped into a full-time job with tremendous security just a few years ago are now instead piecing together a salary by working a few days here and a few days there.
Dr. Boniuk said that if he didn't find a good full-time position he might consider working part time for a nursing home, or a stopgap job at a surgicenter that advertises in subways, in addition to prescribing glasses in optical shops. Then again, he said, he was still holding a place for advanced training in corneal surgery in St. Louis, his hometown. But that would be difficult, since his wife's career is in New York.
In some fields, even temporary work is harder to find. Dr. Phyllis Woodring, an anesthesiologist in Winston-Salem, N.C., who gets temporary assignments through medical staffing agencies, said that although she was willing to travel anywhere in the country, she was unable to find any work for four months last year.
"This is pathetic," she said. "You spend 12 years of your life preparing to do this and then you can't find work."
A few training programs have plans to reduce the number of specialists they graduate. For example, Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan has plans to decrease the number of anesthesiology residents from 75 now to about 53 by 1997. "I am not in the business of training doctors for jobs that don't exist," said Dr. Joel Kaplan, head of the department there. This year, almost none of the training programs for anesthesiology in New York City had enough medical students to fill their training positions.
But few departments are likely to welcome the idea of downsizing, since New York's hospitals all rely on their virtual armies of residents to provide low cost care in their clinics and on their wards.
Educators at New York's top hospitals, who have often helped build these palaces of specialty care, now find themselves in the odd position of nudging young doctors to think about alternative career paths. Dr. Myron L. Weisfeldt, head of the medical service at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, said he was encouraging residents to look into careers in developing fields, such as linking medicine with computers and health policy research.
"I tell students that unless they have an undying love for a subspecialty they should go into general medicine," Dr. Dantzker said. " Because if they go into something like cardiology they are going to find themselves in a very compromised position."

HEADLINE: $1.9 Billion Is Poured Into Stock Funds

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Investors poured $1.9 billion into stock funds in the week ended Wednesday, the largest amount in more than a month, as major stock indexes rose to record highs, according to AMG Data Services.
The prospect of higher corporate earnings and forecasts of a gradual slowdown in the economy made last week the best for stock funds since the week ended March 1, when investors put $2.2 billion into stock funds. The Dow Jones industrial average is up 9.75 percent this year and closed at a record 4,208.18 on Thursday. 
 Investors put $380 million into growth and income funds in the latest week and $143 million into international funds. Taxable bond funds also grew in the latest week, the second consecutive week of gains, amid expectations that the Federal Reserve would not raise interest rates any time soon, AMG said.
A net $142 million flowed into taxable bond funds in the week ended Wednesday as investors shoveled money into United States corporate bonds, AMG said. Investors withdrew money from taxable bond funds last month.
While $114 million was redeemed from United States Government bond funds and another $110 million was withdrawn from international debt funds, investors put $182 million into bond funds that invest in debt with investment-grade ratings. They put another $53 million into junk bond funds.
About $152 million was withdrawn from municipal bond funds in the latest week, AMG said. Municipal bonds were among the top-performing assets through the first three months of 1995.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Players Take Field, But Umpires Walk The Picket Lines

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Just when you thought it was safe to go to the ball park again, the labor-lashed game of baseball still threatens to put replacements on the field. With the delayed opening of the season 10 days away, the real players are playing for the first time since last August, but the real umpires are picketing instead of calling balls and strikes.
The National and American leagues locked out their 64 umpires Jan. 1 and do not intend to ask them back to work until the two sides negotiate a new collective bargaining agreement. No one knows when that might be because bargaining is progressing as slowly and fruitlessly as the languorous talks between the owners and the players, who also have no agreement. 
 In other words, come opening night on April 25, the players, who ended their strike after 234 days, will very likely take the field with replacement umpires. The players may even have to cross the locked-out umpires' picket lines to reach the fields.
"It's not going to work," Jack McDowell, the Yankees' new pitcher, said, discussing the use of replacement umpires, most of whom would be former minor league umpires or amateur umpires. "It'll work on the level that the replacement players would have worked for us. When you put someone in the situation who is not at the level of major league umpires, you're going to have big problems."
Although this dispute over wages and other economic benefits is between leagues and umpires -- the umpires have not received a raise in pay since 1991 -- it also raises intriguing questions about the relationship between umpires and players.
For many years, the two groups' unions have not been enamored of each other. "There's been no love lost," acknowledged Jerry Crawford, president of the Major League Umpires Association. But this year they feel greater kinship because they are at economic war with a common employer, and the players have offered noticeably greater vocal support for their locked-out brethren.
That does not mean that the players will honor picket lines and forgo more of their salaries than the 28 percent they lost last year and the 11 percent they are already losing this season. But Richie Phillips, the umpires' lawyer, said yesterday that the umpires would ask the players to make that very sacrifice if the season begins with replacement umpires.
"We'd like to see baseball get back together and get everybody in America and Canada happy again," Phillips said in a telephone interview. "So we're not asking players to honor our picket lines during spring training because this is the time players need to prepare for the season. That will change if this thing gets to the regular season and we throw up legitimate picket lines. We're going to ask the players not to cross those picket lines, not because we want to put them on the spot but because we feel compelled to do that."
Eugene Orza, the No. 2 official of the players' union, was noncommittal in his reaction to Phillips's comments.
"Right now, we're obviously concerned about the use of scab umpires only slightly less than we were concerned about the use of scab players," Orza said by telephone from Scottsdale, Ariz. "The players believe whatever the occasional differences they have with umpires, those issues are dwarfed by having scab umpires. The players are concerned about playing games with scab umpires and want this thing resolved, but we have not resolved nor addressed the question of what to do in the event that there is picketing."
Robert Kheel, the leagues' negotiator, said the clubs' understanding is that the players are not very likely to honor picket lines. "We certainly hope that isn't the case," he said.
Indeed, besides losing more pay, if the players refused to cross they would play into the strategy of the hard-line owners who wanted to lock them out when they offered to end their strike.
This is the first lockout of umpires after 6 strikes in the previous 25 years. It is a labor history that rivals that of the players and the owners, who have engaged in 8 work stoppages in 23 years.
Gene Budig, the American League president, said the leagues hoped to have the regular umpires back in time for the start of the season, but he added, "We are doing the best we can with the existing situation."
Orza derided the quality of the replacements, saying: "They're not even minor league umpires. They have been released for incompetence and they are being used as scab players were used, as pawns in the leagues' fight with umpires."
By not asking minor league umpires to work major league games, baseball officials have opted to take a different approach than the one taken during the umpires' 73-day strike in 1979. That time they not only used minor league umpires during the strike but also hired four for each league to continue working once the striking umpires returned.
"We learned a lesson in 1979," said Marty Springstead, the American League's executive director of umpiring. "We don't want to jeopardize a guy's career for a short-term use."
The salary scale under the expired four-year contract ranged from $60,000 for rookies to $175,000 for umpires with 25 years in the majors. The leagues proposed only cost-of-living increases while the union asked for what it said would work out to a raise of approximately 6 percent a year for the last four years and the next four, or a total of 47 percent. The union is also seeking increases in per diems, post-season bonuses and retirement pay.
The leagues have rejected that kind of raise, saying the losses suffered in the players' nearly eight-month strike make it impossible. "This is not the time for extraordinary increases," Kheel said. "We have to educate the umpires that they're going to get a Chevy and not a Cadillac."
The umpires say they are used to that sort of treatment and they do not like it. The fans do not view them much differently. Whereas replacement players evoked outrage from at least some fans, replacement umpires have not prompted a whimper.
"We're the last ones anybody cares about," said Don Denkinger, an American League umpire for 26 years. "When do they look for us? They look for us at game time. At 7 o'clock for a 7:05 game they say, 'Where are the umpires?' Until then, there's no major concern for us."
But the players, whether or not they put their money where their mouths are, have more vocally expressed their views this week.
"I think everybody knows that all the players would rather have the regular umpires out there," the Yankees' Don Mattingly said. "They do an excellent job."
Terry Tata, a National League umpire for 22 years, appreciates the verbal support, and for him, that may be sufficient.
"Personally," he said, "I'd rather see the players work so they can expose the people being out on the field acting as umpires. That way we can show them up for what they are."

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW MEDICAL SPECIALTY: UNEMPLOYMENT
A growing number of young doctors are finding themselves un- or underemployed, stranded in their profession's equivalent of flipping burgers or pumping gas. Managed care has decreased the demand for specialists, particularly in places like New York. Page 1.
 
NEW YORK CITY
 

2 BOMBING LEADERS: CAN U.S. PROVE IT?
Ever since Ramzi Ahmed Yousef was arrested in Pakistan two months ago on charges that he engineered the World Trade Center explosion, Federal prosecutors have found themselves in a predicament. On the one hand, they are trying to prove that Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman was the spiritual leader of a band of terrorists who plotted to blow up not only the World Trade Center but also the United Nations and the Hudson River tunnels. On the other hand, prosecutors will soon try to prove in a separate trial that it was Mr. Yousef who masterminded the Trade Center attack. Page 1.
 
'TAKE PART IN SPIRITUAL WARFARE'
 Abortion foes from across the country are planning a rally in New York City next month, seeking to amend or repeal a Federal law that bars protesters from blocking entrances to abortion clinics. The group organizing the rally, Operation Rescue California, is urging followers to come to New York and "take part in spiritual warfare." Page 22.

The state-appointed school superintendent in Jersey City wields something granted no one else in the municipal government: veto power. It is this absolute control that has engendered widespread hostility to state takeover in Jersey City and Paterson, a process now looming in Newark. Page 24.
