HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL;
N.B.A. Union Leader Quits Amid Discord

BYLINE: By MIKE WISE 

 BODY:
Charles Grantham, the executive director of the National Basketball Association players union since 1988, announced yesterday that he was resigning, a sudden departure that heightened the uncertainty surrounding the league's unsettled labor situation.
Citing "irreconcilable differences" over matters of governing the players organization, Grantham and the union's president, Buck Williams, released a terse, joint statement announcing the resignation. 
 Simon Gourdine, the union's general counsel, was immediately named as Grantham's successor.
Williams, the veteran forward for the Portland Trail Blazers, said in the statement that Grantham was "departing the association on amicable terms."
Two people close to the union, however, said they believed the executive board either ousted Grantham or allowed him to step down under pressure, mainly because he had failed to move along negotiations for a new collective bargaining agreement between the association and the league.
Grantham did not respond to messages left at his New York City home seeking comment.
His departure comes at a critical time for the N.B.A., which last fall barely avoided becoming the third professional sport to shut down because of a labor dispute. In late October, with the baseball players on strike and the hockey owners locking out their players, Grantham joined Commissioner David Stern in agreeing to play a full season under the previous contract, with some stipulations.
But with the end of the regular season and the playoffs approaching, the two sides are facing a summer of negotiations that, according to one person with knowledge of the bargaining, have produced very little progress so far.
Issues such as the salary cap, a proposed cap on rookie salaries and the abolition of restricted free agency have been some of the sticking points in the negotiations.
Charles Smith, a Knicks forward and executive vice president of the players association, said before his game in Indiana last night: "It was a difference of opinion and philosophies. Over a period of time, we just saw things differently regarding the governing of the office. We wanted to have more control of the situation regarding everything from A to Z. We wanted to know more about everything that was going on. After months and months of talking about the future, and what needs to be done, it just got to the point where we saw a difference of opinion and it wasn't going to change."
When asked how he would assess Grantham's handling of the negotiations, Smith replied: "We thought he was doing a decent job. It just came to a head, talking about the past, present and future. We just had a difference of opinion. We wanted things to be done one way, and he thinks things should be done another."
Smith said Grantham was not dismissed.
As early as three weeks ago, Grantham intimated the union was close to submitting a new proposal that he believed would lead to the signing of a new agreement.
"People don't realize how close we are to having the same problems baseball had," he said in late March before a Knicks-Nets game. "I feel confident we can avoid what happened there, but you just can't tell until the other side has a chance to respond."
Grantham, who played basketball at Cheyney State and earned a graduate degree from the Wharton School, began working for the union full time in 1978 under his predecessor, Larry Fleisher. He believed part of the success the league and the union had in avoiding a work stoppage had much to do with both sides refusing to negotiate through the news media, as in baseball.
"Once you say something in the papers, you can't take it back," he said. "But when you say it at the bargaining table, and it's kept there, you can always come back the next day and change your mind. I feel confident we'll have something done very soon."
But in less than a month, Grantham's plans apparently backfired severely.
"At some point over the last several weeks, the executive committee effectively lost confidence in Charlie and his leadership," said one person close to the union. "In essence, they gave him the opportunity to resign."
In the prepared statement, he said, "I valued greatly my experience representing N.B.A. players over the past 15 years, but now I'm looking forward to pursuing other career opportunities."
Russell T. Granik, the league's deputy commissioner, released a statement regarding Grantham's resignation. "Charles Grantham guided a Players Association through a period of tremendous economic growth for the N.B.A. and its players," it said. "We have always maintained a productive business relationship with the union's leadership and are confident that this relationship will continue with the union under the direction of Buck and Simon."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japan's Trade Surplus Shrinks (Except With U.S.)

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 14

 BODY:
With pressure mounting from Washington that Japan do more to narrow its trade surplus, the Japanese Government reported today that the overall surplus shrank in March and the latest fiscal year but that the imbalance with the United States widened in both periods.
As long as the yen remains strong, economists said, the overall surplus is not likely to decline significantly in coming months. 
 The Finance Ministry said Japan's customs-cleared trade surplus narrowed to $13.84 billion in March from $13.90 billion in March 1994 and to $117.98 billion in the fiscal year that ended on March 31 from a revised $121.88 billion in the prior fiscal year. The prior fiscal year's surplus was Japan's highest ever.
At the same time, the ministry said Japan's surplus with the United States widened to $5.08 billion in March from $4.94 billion in the month a year earlier and to $55.66 billion in the fiscal year from $51.12 billion in the previous fiscal year.
Japanese exports to the rest of the world rose 16.4 percent in March from a year earlier, to $42.53 billion, while imports to Japan increased 26.7 percent, to $28.69 billion. In the full fiscal year, exports rose 11.5 percent, to $408.47 billion, and imports increased 18.9 percent, to $290.49 billion.
In trade with the United States, Japanese exports rose 9.9 percent in March, to $11.75 billion, while imports grew 16 percent, to $6.66 billion. In the full year, Japanese exports to the United States increased 11.3 percent, to $120.10 billion, while imports from the United States grew 13.5 percent, to $64.44 billion.
Officials in Washington have pressed Japan for years to reduce its trade surplus. Earlier this week, Cabinet officers and other American officials who deal with trade matters approved a strategy under which the United States would warn Japan that it would move to impose several billion dollars in punitive tariffs unless major progress was made in opening Japanese markets to American autos and auto parts in the next three weeks.
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin will meet with his Japanese counterpart, Masayoshi Takemura, in Indonesia over the weekend.
Economists said they did not expect any significant decline in Japan's surplus unless the yen began to weaken. They said the high yen would spur Japanese companies to move more production abroad, which would necessitate exports of costly manufacturing equipment. That will help cause Japan's overall exports to increase.
In theory, imports should be increased by the strong yen because it makes foreign goods less expensive in terms of the Japanese currency. But the economic slowdown will trim the potential rise, the economists said.
 And even though the strong Japanese currency means that Japanese companies receive fewer yen for every dollar of sales in the United States, shipments to the United States are likely to continue unabated because the exporters would rather absorb the cost from the strong currency than raise prices in that important market, said Iwaki Hidehiro, senior economist at the Nomura Research Institute.

HEADLINE: Canada's Borrowing, With Its Fat Fees, Lures Wall Street

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH

DATELINE: TORONTO, April 14

 BODY:
This city's compact financial district, overlooking Lake Ontario, bisected by lower Bay Street and occupying less than a square mile of real estate, so resembles its counterpart in lower Manhattan that movie companies looking for a Wall Street location often shoot here.
While film makers are attracted by the striking resemblance and a cheaper Canadian dollar, Wall Street's investment powerhouses in recent months have been lured to Bay Street by the fat underwriting commissions from one of the world's largest borrowing countries. 
 In the biggest American drive for Canadian financial business since the market was deregulated in the mid-1980's, Salomon Brothers; Goldman, Sachs & Company; Smith Barney, a unit of Travelers; Morgan Stanley Group, and Lehman Brothers are expanding their operations on Bay Street.
The American incursion has come even as the huge Canadian debt -- about $550 billion (Canadian), or nearly $400 billion (United States) -- has raised concerns over the country's credit rating. Moody's Investors Service on Wednesday downgraded Canada's triple-A status for Canadian dollar-denominated debt to double-A-1. But the move had been widely anticipated and had little market impact. The Canadian dollar actually rose both Wednesday and Thursday. As one trader put it, "The news cleared away the uncertainties." Markets have long known, he added, that Canada's risk was higher than the country's credit rating. Perceived weakness in the Quebec separatist movement has been a major force behind the strengthening Canadian dollar.
Besides helping sell government debt, the American houses work in an advisory capacity for many American and Canadian companies, helping with mergers and acquisitions, corporate finance and other matters. The American firms are benefiting from the increased North American business spurred by freer trade, especially after last year's North American Free Trade Agreement. And they share the general belief that despite some recent Government budget tightening future capital needs will continue to be enormous.
The outstanding federal and provincial debt is roughly the same as Canada's gross domestic product, or the value of all goods and services produced last year. As a percentage of G.D.P., only Italy's is higher among the leading industrial countries.
According to a tabulation by Euromoney magazine of London, eight Canadian provinces, topped by Ontario, led the pack of worldwide provincial, state and municipal borrowers for the year ended June 30, 1994. In fact, Ontario, with $7.5 billion of loans, ranked fourth after the European Investment Bank, Sweden and Italy.
The debt volumes exceed the capacity of the Canadian capital market. Nearly half of all Canadian debt is held by foreigners, chiefly pension funds in the United States.
"What makes this market compelling are its tremendous requirements for debt and equity capital, its growth at a relatively more rapid rate than other capital markets and the global market integration that's now under way," said Jamie Kiernan, president of Goldman, Sachs Canada Ltd.
Goldman, Sachs and the other houses are driven by strong competitive forces. David Driscoll, editor of The Investment Reporter, a weekly Toronto investment newsletter, says it is the case of no one wanting to be left behind. He speaks of a "lemming effect -- if there's money to be made, everyone follows."
An added incentive now is indications that Canadian authorities look more favorably upon investment houses with Canadian-based operations.
"It's no doubt much more difficult to distribute Canadian dollar bonds if there's no presence in the Canadian market," said John Madden, chief executive officer of the Ontario Financing Authority and the province's assistant deputy minister of finance.
The Canadian financial institutions are watching with keen interest. Many decline to comment for the record. An executive at one of the big Canadian national banks, who asked not to be identified, observed, "This is bound to get pretty cutthroat."
Yet some Canadians say they are looking forward to the competition. "The more players, the better," said Greg Clarke, vice president of the Investment Dealers Association of Canada. "We like to see knowledgeable, well-capitalized players in our marketplace because it breeds innovation and makes better markets."
John Ing, president of Maison Placements Canada Inc., an investment boutique dealing exclusively with institutions, said, "We welcome them, but so far we haven't seen much of them, since they're mainly going after the fixed-income side," or bond business.
A number of the American investment houses are simply building on a presence here dating from the so-called Big Bang of 1987, when the regulatory walls came down, eliminating the kind of restrictions that had forced Canadian financial institutions to provide circumscribed services and that had prohibited most foreign dealers from competing in Canada.
Goldman, Sachs came up then to set up full-scale bond trading and investment banking operations. Now Goldman, with 60 employees -- the second-biggest contingent after Merrill Lynch -- is building an equity trading and underwriting operation for Canadian institutional clients.
Merrill Lynch Canada, which set up shop here in 1952 and which employs 180 for its bond trading and investment banking operation, used to be much larger. In earlier years it had gone into the retail stock brokerage business and had as many as 1,600 employees. But profits were disappointing, especially after the 1987 market crash, and in 1990 it sold its brokerage business to CIBC Wood Gundy Inc., a subsidiary of the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce.
Despite the stepped-up activities of Merrill Lynch's competitors, Paul Thomas -- president of Merrill Lynch Canada and an alumnus of Goldman, Sachs -- said: "We're fairly comfortable. There's always room to improve, but we feel we cover the country fairly well." Expansion, he added, is "always under review."
Both Salomon and Morgan Stanley established corporate finance advisory services here in 1987. They intended to follow Goldman, Sachs with more ambitious bond trading and investment banking operations but got cold feet after the market crash that year. Now both are moving ahead full speed.
Salomon opened a bond trading floor in December; it has 4 salesmen and 4 traders and expects to have 15 on the payroll within a year. Morgan Stanley is tripling the size of its Toronto office staff, from 15 to 50.
Smith Barney has just moved into the corporate services business in Toronto. Andre Hidi, now chief executive of Smith Barney Canada, had run these activities for Morgan Stanley.
Last month, Lehman announced it was opening a broker-dealer office here that would have 15 professionals. It will focus on corporate finance, trading a broad range of bonds.
European and Asian financial houses are also raising the ante. The Hongkong Bank of Canada, part of the Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Group of HSBC Holdings, has expanded its stake -- from 50 to 75 percent -- in the Bay Street securities firm of BBN James Capel. Another international giant, the Deutsche Bank of Frankfurt, is increasing investment banking and bond trading activity at McLean McCarthy Inc., a financial boutique it acquired in 1987.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Wall Street firms have flocked to Bay Street, Toronto's financial district, which resembles its Manhattan counterpart. (Robert Skeoch for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Japan's Plan To Help Dollar Doesn't Impress Tokyo Markets

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 14

 BODY:
Japan's emergency plan to stem the fall of the dollar against the yen and to stimulate the nation's economy failed to impress the financial markets today, raising fears here that the dollar's fall could resume next week.
Critics said the measures, announced today, were vague and lacked teeth. "I'm a little bit shocked at seeing today's package," said Masaru Takagi, chief economist of the Fuji Research Institute, associated with the Fuji Bank. "There are no concrete figures yet, no concrete features at all." 
 Currency markets seemed to shrug off the announcement, with exchange rates barely budging. In late trading in Tokyo, the dollar was quoted at 83.58 yen, up only slightly from 83.50 yen in late New York trading Thursday. Trading was kept thin by the Good Friday holiday, which closed other major financial centers.
Stock investors gave an even harsher reception. After having climbed for four consecutive days, partly in anticipation of today's package, the Tokyo stock market fell sharply today. The Nikkei average of 225 stocks dropped 390.90 points, or 2.4 percent, to 16,047.89.
The emergency plan was announced today in response to Monday's sharp drop of the dollar to a postwar record low of 80.15 yen here. The weak dollar and strong yen are threatening to derail an economic recovery that has just begun in Japan by choking off Japan's exports.
In perhaps the most significant of today's measures, the Bank of Japan cut the official discount rate by three-quarters of a percentage point, to a record low for Japan of 1 percent. While businessmen called this a welcome move, if somewhat late, the currency markets had already been expecting such a cut.
Other parts of the plan called for increasing public works spending, spurring imports and accelerating the deregulation of the economy. The Government, in effect, was trying to convince the currency markets that it was serious about lowering Japan's trade surplus, which is considered a major factor behind the long-term rise of the yen.
It failed to convince. Today's measures, as in many past trade plans, consisted largely of statements of intent rather than concrete actions.
The Government did say it would be willing to use deficit financing to stimulate the economy, something that the Finance Ministry has long resisted. But there were no figures yet on how much public spending would be increased.
In the auto area, currently the focus of tense negotiations between the United States and Japan, the plan calls only for Japan to build some "permanent exhibition places" to display foreign cars and automobile parts.
Much of the plan was directed not at influencing the currency rates but at helping Japan cope with the stronger yen.
The discount rate cut, for instance, could help spur economic activity. But today's was the eighth cut in the rate since 1991, when Japan's economy started to go into a downturn. In that span the rate has been cut by 5 percent, yet the economy still remains weak.
Bureaucrats deleted from the plan some stronger proposals, such as one to set a numerical target for cutting the trade surplus in half in five years. A proposal to cut the tax on securities transactions in an effort to help revive the stock market will be studied.

Dollar Little Changed
 By Bloomberg Business News
 The dollar was little changed against the yen yesterday as currency dealers were skeptical that Japan's new economic package would be effective in curbing the strength of the yen.
Trading was very light yesterday. United States markets were closed for Good Friday, and many dealers stayed home for the Easter and Passover weekend. In London and Frankfurt, two large centers for currency trading, markets and banks were closed yesterday and will not reopen until Tuesday.
In New York late yesterday, the dollar was quoted at 83.30 yen, down from 83.50 yen on Thursday, and at 1.3915 German marks, up from 1.3864 marks.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Is a Trans-Atlantic Pact Coming Down the Pike?

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, April 14

 BODY:
An idea that seems self-evident economically, but almost impossible politically, has recently caught the attention of politicians, trade experts and business executives in Europe and North America -- a trans-Atlantic free-trade agreement.
Yes, it has been considered before and put aside. Yes, it would take years to negotiate. Yes, it might have to exclude agricultural subsidies. 
 And while no government has so far adopted such a free-trade zone as a goal, the decibel level of conversation is rising dramatically.
"There's hardly a high-level meeting on trade where the issue does not come up," said Stuart E. Eizenstat, the American Ambassador to the European Union in Brussels. "This is just in the earliest stages of getting on the Administration's radar screen."
Currently, the roster of politicians, trade officials or executives embracing the idea of an Atlantic free-trade zone, or something like it, includes Jean Chretien, Prime Minister of Canada; Jacques Santer, president of the European Commission; Edzard Reuter, chief executive of Daimler-Benz A. G.; Lane Kirkland, head of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., and Alain Juppe, Foreign Minister of France.
American officials said President Clinton had discussed the idea with Prime Minister John Major of Britain earlier this month, but the officials would not elaborate.
In the eyes of its proponents, a United States-Europe free-trade agreement would go far beyond the reduced tariff barriers negotiated under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to include elimination of tariffs and quotas on all services, on new telecommunications products and on government procurement policies. It might also harmonize taxation of corporations.
On the European side, support for such a trade agreement grows out of two areas of concern.
One is that without the binding force of a common Communist enemy, the European-American partnership has been weakened and is more and more vexed by a series of small trade disputes that almost inevitably turn into bitter squabbles.
Officials here point to the recent dispute over who would head the World Trade Organization, pitting an American candidate against a European one. Or a growing friction over subsidies of European and American airline manufacturers. Or recent charges by France that Washington engaged in economic espionage. Or European import restrictions on Latin American bananas.
"With every passing day I feel reconfirmed in my view that differing economic interests could quite conceivably undermine the old solidarity existing between us," said Mr. Reuter of Daimler-Benz.
Europe is also afraid that it will be isolated by free-trade pacts that Washington is trying to form with Latin American and Asian countries. While Europe had announced its own free-trade deals with East European and Mediterranean countries, its overall market would be dwarfed by that of the Americas and the Pacific Basin.
"It is rather odd for the E.U. to have concluded free-trade arrangements with a host of countries but not have something of the kind with the United States," said Andreas van Agt, the European Union's former ambassador to the United States.
Jeffrey E. Garten, Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade, and one of the Clinton Administration officials who is quietly pushing the idea of a union, argues that economics and social factors argue strongly in favor of such an agreement.
"Europe is and will continue to be for years the most important and biggest market for Americans," he said.
For example, United States trade and sales of American corporations based in Europe totaled $1.7 trillion in 1992, Mr. Garten said. That is 55 percent larger than the total commerce with Asia in the same year -- $1.1 trillion.
Moreover, in Asia the United States has accumulated a deficit of more than $1 trillion over the last 25 years; American trade with Europe in that time "has been almost perfectly in balance," Mr. Garten said.
And because the European Union is such a huge trade market -- $7 trillion a year in economic output -- modest growth of, say, 3 percent, generates a stunning $210 billion in economic activity that is a potential market for American goods.
"This is like finding a new market the size of Taiwan's every year," Mr. Garten said.
Spurring on Washington is the fact that Mexico is quietly trying to negotiate its own free-trade accord with Europe, and that Europe is seeking to establish free-trade ties with the countries of the Mercosur trade pact -- Argentina, Brazil, Uruguay and Paraguay -- as well as with Chile and Bolivia.
But whatever the arguments in favor of a broad agreement, officials say it may be long in coming.
One big obstacle is the issue of agricultural subsidies and barriers, which almost scuttled a GATT accord last year and could doom any free-trade accord.
Another is that officials want to get the World Trade Organization off the ground and see how it operates before taking up complex new negotiations. Mats Hellstrom, Sweden's Minister of Foreign Trade, said such negotiations should be expanded beyond a European-North American free-trade agreement, to include all GATT members.
Third, next year the European Union faces what is called its Intergovernmental Conference, a kind of constitutional convention, where the principles of the union will be examined and possibly changed.
Finally, American and European trade negotiators are suffering from a kind of diplomatic exhaustion from the negotiations over the GATT, and more recently the bitter dispute over who would head the W.T.O.
But those discussing the issue of a new trade pact say it is not about to go away.
"There is no question in my mind that 10 years from now our trade relationship with the E.U. will be more liberalized than it is today," Mr. Eizenstat said. "But doing a full-blown free-trade agreement sooner will be difficult."

HEADLINE: Industrial Production Drops For First Time in Six Months

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 14

 BODY:
The Government today reported the first drop in industrial production in six months, providing further evidence of an economic slowdown.
The Federal Reserve said that industrial output fell in March by three-tenths of 1 percent, only the second decline in nearly two years and the first drop since September, when the figure reflected an auto industry strike. 
 The central bank also revised figures for January and February to reflect that the cumulative gain in output for the two months was three-tenths of 1 percent less than previously estimated.
And another closely watched Federal Reserve index showed that the nation's factories, mines and utilities were operating with more slack in March for the second consecutive month. It was the first back-to-back decline for the operating rate in nearly two years.
Even though the production decline was led by a sharp drop for utilities because of unusually mild weather, analysts said the signs of a broad-based slowdown were unmistakable.
"All of the pieces are falling into place to strengthen the case for a soft landing," said Sung Won Sohn, an economist at the Norwest Corporation, a Minneapolis banking company. "We have really a nice situation where an economic slowdown is occurring with limited inflation."
There is practically no chance the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates again anytime soon, he said, adding the next move could be a rate cut to stimulate growth.
"Fed watching is going to be pretty boring for awhile," Mr. Sohn said.
Traders and analysts will have a long weekend to absorb the data; financial markets in the United States were closed today for Good Friday.
The Federal Reserve said the industrial operating rate fell five-tenths of 1 percent, following a dip of two-tenths of 1 percent in February that had earlier been estimated to be an increase of two-tenths of a point.
Still, the central bank said the consecutive declines left the operating rate at 84.9 percent of capacity -- equaling a peak achieved during a recovery in 1988 and 1989.
In another report that could lead to slower economic activity, the Commerce Department said business inventories rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in February, the 11th consecutive gain, and jumped a revised 1.3 percent the previous month. The January gain matched the biggest buildup of stocks on store shelves and factory back lots in more than a decade.
Analysts said the big increases might foretell a cut in production if consumer spending continued to ease.
The economy expanded at a robust 5.1 percent annual rate in the final quarter of last year. Economists expected it slowed to around 3 percent in the first three months of 1995 and predict an even smaller gain in the current quarter.
The slowdown was by design, as the Fed raised interest rates seven times in a 12-month period that ended Feb. 1 to keep inflation under control.
The Fed had worried that rising industrial output and dwindling unused capacity would lead to bottlenecks and rising prices.
Much of the drop-off in production last month occurred at utilities, where output plunged 2.6 percent and reversed a similar-sized jump in February.
Manufacturing output in March slipped one-tenth of 1 percent, matching the drop the previous month.
Production of big-ticket durable goods for consumers fell 1.9 percent last month, led by a drop in light trucks and further weakness in production of household furniture and appliances.
Production at mines fell half a percent in March after rising the same amount in February.

HEADLINE: $1.9 Billion Is Poured Into Stock Funds

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
Investors poured $1.9 billion into stock funds in the week ended Wednesday, the largest amount in more than a month, as major stock indexes rose to record highs, according to AMG Data Services.
The prospect of higher corporate earnings and forecasts of a gradual slowdown in the economy made last week the best for stock funds since the week ended March 1, when investors put $2.2 billion into stock funds. The Dow Jones industrial average is up 9.75 percent this year and closed at a record 4,208.18 on Thursday. 
 Investors put $380 million into growth and income funds in the latest week and $143 million into international funds. Taxable bond funds also grew in the latest week, the second consecutive week of gains, amid expectations that the Federal Reserve would not raise interest rates any time soon, AMG said.
A net $142 million flowed into taxable bond funds in the week ended Wednesday as investors shoveled money into United States corporate bonds, AMG said. Investors withdrew money from taxable bond funds last month.
While $114 million was redeemed from United States Government bond funds and another $110 million was withdrawn from international debt funds, investors put $182 million into bond funds that invest in debt with investment-grade ratings. They put another $53 million into junk bond funds.
About $152 million was withdrawn from municipal bond funds in the latest week, AMG said. Municipal bonds were among the top-performing assets through the first three months of 1995.

HEADLINE: McNamara's Retreat

BYLINE: By Max Frankel; Max Frankel, a columnist for The New York Times Magazine and a former executive editor of The Times, was a Washington correspondent covering diplomacy and the White House in the 1960's.

 BODY:

IN RETROSPECT
The Tragedy and Lessons of Vietnam.
By Robert S. McNamara with Brian VanDeMark.
Illustrated. 414 pp. New York:
Times Books/Random House. $27.50. 
 IN his 79th year, Robert S. McNamara at long last offers the public a glimpse of his aching conscience. The most willful Vietnam warrior in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations, he was also the first at the top to admit defeat, in private. He then stood silent on the war for a quarter-century and drowned his sorrow in good works at the World Bank. Mr. McNamara personified the slow maturing of America's foreign policy from cocky interventionism to cost-conscious realism, yet for a generation he refused to explain his conversion, explore his mistakes, judge his colleagues or instruct posterity. The pain, or the guilt, was simply too great. As he states in the preface to "In Retrospect": "This is the book I planned never to write."
Until now, he contends, the story of how "the best and the brightest" got it wrong in Vietnam has not been told. But David Halberstam, who applied that ironic phrase to his rendering of the tale 23 years ago, told it better in many ways than Mr. McNamara does now. So, too, did the Pentagon Papers, that huge trove of documents assembled at Mr. McNamara's behest when he first recognized a debt to history. The contemporary analyses in the papers, which were leaked to The Times in 1971, stand up so well that they now serve their patron as a major source.
What Mr. McNamara adds to the public record are some White House documents and tape transcripts revealing, most notably, his own agonized attempts in 1967 to persuade President Lyndon B. Johnson to stop sending more men to the slaughter: the Secretary of Defense who had come to tame the Pentagon with managerial wizardry ended up desperately begging for a fig leaf for withdrawal, in the form of a coalition that would inevitably give the Vietcong dominance in Saigon. Mr. McNamara says he does not know to this day whether he thus quit or was fired. "Maybe it was both."
But he left with a whimper, not a bang. So why speak out now? The main reason, he says, is that he has "grown sick at heart witnessing the cynicism and even contempt" with which so many Americans view their institutions and leaders. He knows how much Vietnam contributed to that disaffection; he would never deny the war's terrible damage. But he hopes to prove that the mistakes were "mostly honest," even if traceable to a ghastly ignorance of the Vietnamese people, culture and terrain, and the historical forces of that time.
Why should the rest of us relive his agony? Mr. McNamara, characteristically statistical, points to "11 major causes for our disaster in Vietnam" in a chapter called "The Lessons of Vietnam." But implicitly his book screams another lesson: Though cynicism and contempt for power are destructive of government, a respectful skepticism is essential, and rarely wrong.
BY delaying his war memoir so long, Mr. McNamara has greatly compounded the difficulty of his mission. Now that the Soviet Union lies in ruins and American corporations beg for business in China and Vietnam, no one under the age of 50 can be expected to fathom the fears and phobias of the 1960's to which he rightly ascribes the Indochina disaster. President Dwight D. Eisenhower, the most venerated American of the time, had taught -- and the Kennedy and Johnson teams never dared to doubt in time -- that if South Vietnam was "lost" to Communism, Laos, Cambodia, Thailand and Malaysia would fall like dominoes, imperiling India, Burma, Indonesia and the Philippines, if not also Japan, and emboldening the Russians and Chinese to extend Communist conquests by military force or subversion in ways that would sooner or later provoke a nuclear World War III, the very destruction of civilization.
Yes, that is how America's leaders spoke to each other and, all too persuasively, to the public. Mr. McNamara's book reminds us that they even repeated the litany in memos to their Presidents, to inoculate them against any temptation to retreat from Vietnam. And if all those dominoes were not cause enough, there were promises to be kept in order to preserve the value of America's other diplomatic threats and commitments.
Mr. McNamara and his generation came to power convinced that the "appeasement" of Nazi Germany -- the failure to block its early grasp for Europe's dominoes -- had led inevitably to a catastrophic World War II. Averting another such disaster, they were sure, required punishing anything resembling Communist aggression in its earliest stages, when the cost would be tolerable. That was their creed as they rebuilt Western Europe and stood toe to toe with the Soviet armies across Germany, fought to a bloody stalemate against China in Korea, threatened war over Berlin and risked war to force Soviet missiles out of Cuba. Thus "contained," the Soviets and Chinese took to endorsing "wars of liberation," thereby qualifying even distant uprisings as threats to American security. Mr. McNamara's first assignment from President John F. Kennedy was to augment America's nuclear power, whose use was unimaginable, with the forces and weapons they were sure would be needed to fight "conventional" wars.
From this bed of doctrine grew what Mr. McNamara considers his team's most fateful error: mistaking Ho Chi Minh's nationalist drive to unite Vietnam as the challenge of a monolithic Communist world. That misjudgment foreclosed any discussion of how an American withdrawal from Indochina could be made strategically tolerable. It even prevented analysis, before the plunge, of how high a price the commitment was worth. Mr. McNamara's dry rendering of those fateful tenets of containment fails to convey the passion with which they were embraced. And he mostly ignores their powerful resonance in domestic politics.
Kennedy, no less than Johnson, subscribed to these simplistic doctrines and the misjudgments they inspired, even though Mr. McNamara, without persuasive evidence, deems it "highly probable" that Kennedy would have pulled back from massive intervention in a second term. This presumes that had Kennedy lived, the same cast of senior officials would have avoided what Mr. McNamara describes as a second tier of error: the failure to live by the mantra that the battle in Vietnam was political, a fight for the "hearts and minds" of an abused peasantry, and that Americans could assist but never supplant the South Vietnamese.
In this pew, Mr. McNamara himself was a prominent sinner. His can-do spirit found no mission impossible, even as Saigon's governments and armies crumbled. His domineering intellect and predilection for systems analysis made him a pathetic victim of erroneous and deceptive military audits of bodies counted, weapons captured, sorties flown, supply lines ruptured. Soon enough, as the press decided, it became "McNamara's war," and certainly America's.
Mr. McNamara deplores the absence of political advice from old Asia hands who had been driven from Government service in the McCarthy purges. But as he proves again in this memoir, he did not easily integrate political wisdom and intuition into his analyses. Even in retrospect, he does not associate the drift into war in Vietnam with the Republican taunts that Democrats had "lost" China to Communism. (Kennedy was afraid to recognize not only China but even Outer Mongolia!) Mr. McNamara cannot bring himself to believe that the election calendar affected Johnson's willingness to escalate the war in 1965 but not in 1964 or, as Johnson eventually confessed to Doris Kearns, that he stayed the course in Asia because he feared losing effectiveness at home -- like Truman after the "loss" of China -- as much as he feared the repercussions of defeat abroad.
Finally, Mr. McNamara recounts a third tier of error -- an escalating pattern of military misjudgment. He is hard on the Joint Chiefs of Staff for their misplaced optimism in the early years, their always excessive faith in high-tech weapons and their later expectations that massive bombing and frontal battles could wear down the Vietnamese enemy. He is remiss in not fully rebutting the postwar claims that timid civilians had tied the military's hands with unreasonable limits on troop commitments and bombing targets. Mr. McNamara emphasizes how little was accomplished by bombings heavier even than those in World War II. And he explains Johnson's caution in target selection by recalling the fear that a more rapid escalation could provoke Chinese intervention. But Americans who cannot accept David's triumph over Goliath draw more belligerent "lessons" from this history, which Mr. McNamara should have engaged more directly.
Even more disappointing is Mr. McNamara's unwillingness to explore the human tragedies and political legacies of this longest American war. What was it like to send tens of thousands to their deaths in an increasingly dubious cause? How did the strain affect the men in charge? We get a glimpse of Jacqueline Kennedy beating him on the chest in protest against the war, and of angry insults hurled on the ski slopes, but no real introspection. Mr. McNamara says the war tore deeply at his own family, but quickly adds: "I am not comfortable speaking in such terms."
What then of the political legacy? How, without growing cynical, can citizens protect themselves against the stubborn ignorance and misplaced zeal of their leaders? In the darkest days, Mr. McNamara remembers, he watched the demonstrators from his Pentagon window and insisted that his subordinates show respect for the freedoms of speech and assembly. But he took refuge -- and takes it even now -- in opinion polls that recorded support from the majority of Americans who, as he well knew, had been misinformed and denied vital information at every major turn.
"Looking back," he writes, "I clearly erred by not forcing . . . a knock-down, drag-out debate over the loose assumptions, unasked questions and thin analyses underlying our military strategy in Vietnam. I had spent 20 years as a manager identifying problems and forcing organizations -- often against their will -- to think deeply and realistically about alternative courses of action and their consequences. I doubt I will ever fully understand why I did not do so here."
YET even now Mr. McNamara means he should have stirred debate only inside the small circle of Presidential counselors led by himself, Secretary of State Dean Rusk and McGeorge Bundy, the national security adviser (later succeeded by Walt Rostow). Mr. McNamara blames Johnson for going to war furtively, with no regard for the rights of Congress and the public, but he rejects any obligation to resign in protest or, once out of office, to share his policy disagreements with the country. Cabinet officers, he contends, should have a constituency of one: the President -- from whom they derive all authority and through whom alone they can be held accountable.
That is surely the right ethic for normal times. Unelected officials should not steal their President's mandate to pursue an independent course. But a thousand dead Americans a month create their own constituency. Even military discipline admits a higher duty than hierarchical loyalty when power is badly used and puts lives at risk.
Mr. McNamara relieved his private turmoil by reading poetry, and shared his misgivings with Robert F. Kennedy and a few other intimates. But he refused to abandon or attack the President whom he had helped to guide into quicksand. He and Johnson "loved and respected" each other, in a bond that even now, in retrospect, keeps the public at a distance looking on, with skepticism, I hope.
