SECTION: Section 6; Page 29; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 7643 words

HEADLINE: THE FIRST PRIMARY

BYLINE: By Jason DeParle; Jason Deparle is the staff writer for The Times Magazine

 BODY:
Twenty-nine floors above Nashville, a slight man in a dark suit is exploding into the telephone. "What's goin' owwnnn?!" he shouts, in a voice that has closed a thousand deals. Ted Welch, mid-south mogul and Republican money man, is searching for $20 million, which he thinks can turn Lamar Alexander, the former Governor of Tennessee, into the President of the United States. It is 3 P.M., and Welch is on his 19th phone call of the afternoon - this one to a Washington lobbyist he os urging to co-sponsor a $1,000-a-plate dinner. The lobbyist, as confident and as loud, responds with a name that Welch does not want to hear -- Gov. William Weld of Massachusetts, another potential candidate. Welch, a former Bible salesman, answers with pity. "Bill Weld, bless his heart, he has no idea what it takes to do fund- raising." The conversation moves on to Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, a more obvious rival and no one's idea of a financial naif. "Here's what I think," Welch says. "I think north of Kentucky he'll have a hard time."
The men parry for a minute or two and then Welch moves in for the kill, with an expenditure of tense, coiled energy. "We really want you, Peter," he says, falling forward in his turquoise chair. His knee meets the ground and his shoulder hits his desk, flagpole at Iwo Jima style. 
 "You want to help with the New York dinner?" he asks. "We're about to go to press with the invitations."
But the lobbyist will not be lobbied. "I don't need to be a part of that," he barks, without a trace of softening apology.
Rejection is flooding through Welch's phone, but it does not register on his face. Honeysuckle sweet, he asks about the man's wife by name and then offers a cheerful goodbye. Momentarily reflective, Welch wonders whether his quarry has secretly committed elsewhere; then two blinks later, he is back on the phone. "How're you, sir?" he shouts toward Texas.
This is the sound of the 1996 election -- earnest, coy, beggarly or bold, it is the sound of men (they are almost always men) asking for money.
Though the first vote is still 10 months away, fund-raising now constitutes a virtual First Primary. To be sure, early money has always helped: for the past four Presidential cycles, each party has nominated the candidate who raised the most money in the year before the election. But next year's compressed primary schedule raises the fund-raising pressure to a new level.
In the past, a candidate could hope that early success in Iowa or New Hampshire would open the financial faucets for months of subsequent campaigning. The survivors of the 1992 Iowa caucuses had 113 days to prepare for the California primary, which with nearly 20 percent of the delegates needed for the nomination twinkled at the end of the road like a pot of June gold. (Bill Clinton raised only $3 million in all of 1991.)
But next year's calendar apportions almost three-quarters of the delegates by the end of March; only 43 days separate the Iowa caucuses on Feb. 12 and the California primary on March 26. Once the flurry of contests begins, candidates will have little time either to raise new money or to spend it.
Prime television spots sell out 30 to 60 days in advance; it can take four or five months to assemble field staffs. Perhaps someone can still win on a shoestring, but it's no wonder that Welch says, "You better already have the money in the bank."
A lot of money. To reach his 1995 goal of $20 million, the amount most analysts think is needed, Alexander has to raise $77,000 each business day, or about $10,000 an hour. Such sums favor established figures like Gramm, Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, or perhaps Gov. Pete Wilson of California. But a surprising number of other prominent figures have looked at the financial demands and quit. They include Weld, Dan Quayle, Dick Cheney and Jack Kemp, who in stepping aside denounced the "grotesqueries" of Presidential fund-raising.
Grotesque or not, it certainly is a specialized sport, a subculture of little-known players with big egos, mixed motives and -- despite the public suspicion they arouse -- unmistakable pride in what they do. Personal wealth helps, but with individual contributions limited to $1,000, the size of their Rolodexes matters more. There are just a few hundred people in the Republican Party who can put together the gala high-dollar dinners that the candidates need, and among those, a handful like Welch stand out.
Unknown to the public, out of elective office for nearly a decade, Alexander has made it his business to meet them. He entered the money primary as something worse than a long shot, hoping to pull off a dozen dinners this March that might get people to take him seriously. The results say something about him, something about Welch and even more about the new rules of running for President.
It is a late afternoon in January, and a few dozen business executives gather in a private room at the Jefferson Hotel, a redoubt of old-world elegance a few blocks north of the White House. They are men, mainly, most in their 50's and 60's and most aligned with Dick Cheney, the former Defense Secretary, whose withdrawal has just left them politically orphaned. They snack on shrimp and then file into an anteroom to meet the slender man in a sober suit who seeks their support.
In another setting, Andrew Lamar Alexander Jr. would be boasting an impressive resume: a two-term Governor; former president of the University of Tennessee; George Bush's second Education Secretary; a millionaire lawyer-businessman. Here, however, he is conscious of his own obscurity and he quotes an Australian proverb about former officeholders like himself: "Rooster today, feather duster tomorrow." He predicts that the speech he's scheduled to give will sink to "page 435 of some newspaper" and adds, "I may be the first candidate to peak before anybody's heard of me."
The demands of self-deprecation thus satisfied, Alexander rails against the "arrogant empire of Washington, D.C.," and pledges to devolve power back to the states. Stressing that no one since John F. Kennedy has moved straight from the Senate to the White House, he trumpets his status as a former Governor. The uniqueness of this claim will disappears later in the spring, as Pete Wilson all but formally declares his candidacy. But for now, Alexander can argue that he alone has what the White House most needs: a beyond-the-Beltway soul. "We're going to have Alexander's band," he says, "and the best thing I can say is, 'Come on along.' "
On that folksy note, the meeting moves on to the real agenda: money. Alexander steps aside and now it is Welch who does the talking. He's after $5 million with the March dinners, including a Washington event that he hopes will bring in $500,000. Seeking salesmen, he offers titles. "Sign up to be a co-chair by selling 20 tickets," he says, "or a vice-chair by selling 10." Welch posts an attractive woman at each of the room's exits. "Nobody gets out without filling out one of those forms." It's a joke, sort of.
If Alexander's White House dreams prove more than a passing conceit, he will owe an incalculable debt to Welch, who is both the grand architect of the financial strategy and its master craftsman, presiding over everything from million-dollar dinners to 10-cent lapel pins. Working from an ever-present white three-ring binder, Welch tracks the progress of every ticket salesman, coast to coast.
After more than two decades of Republican fund-raising, Welch carries a mental map of political debts, business relationships, philanthropic connections, school ties, vanities, hopes and fears that can be converted into campaign contributions. "Ted is the No. 1 political fund-raiser in all history," says Howard Baker, the former Senate majority leader, whose own campaigns benefited from many millions of dollars generated by Welch's handwork.
His pastime is, in its way, a strangely apolitical pursuit. Though Welch claims to be "very conservative on fiscal issues and more progressive on social issues," issues seldom arise during his countless hours on the telephone. Taxes, spending, Government regulation -- the usual Republican complaints do not cross his lips. In response to a question, he even offers a kind word for the President he is trying to unseat. "I wouldn't characterize him as a disaster," he says of Clinton. "He's done some good."
So what does Ted Welch want? He has sunk years of his life into political fund-raising without a penny of pay. And while lesser figures have sailed the Caribbean wearing the title "Ambassador," Welch has never claimed a Federal appointment. Asked about his motivation, he resorts to existential terms; he is taking his own measure. "Instead of playing golf, I raise money," he says.
But if issues don't move Welch, his candidate does. He stares into the distance as he recounts the moment, a decade ago, that he encouraged Alexander to run. "I'd seen his focus," he says. "I'd seen his vision. I'd seen his ability to attract and manage people." This talk of epiphany sounds strange -- not even Alexander calls himself a charismatic figure. But Welch rolls on, remembering the breakfast they had at the Governor's mansion as Alexander began his second term.
"I said I'd like to assist him in any way I could, to get him elected President of this country," he says. "While that hasn't been on the front burner of my mind every day since then, I always knew it was only a matter of time before he'd run for President."
What was Alexander's response?
"After you get to know Lamar, you can tell when he's pleased with a notion," Welch says with a coy, satisfied smile. "And he was pleased with that one."
In time, they made some unusual plans.
Lamar Alexander had been dreaming of Bill Clinton. "Sometimes even I feel his pain," he says. "There he was, sitting all alone in the Oval Office, wearing his funny Indonesian shirt and singing this sad song." Long-faced, Alexander moves to the piano and croons the Eddy Arnold standard, "Make the World Go Away," with fanciful Clinton lyrics: "Ma-ake Newt Gingrich go a-way/Out of my li-ife forever. . . . " Two hundred couples in evening clothes applaud the joke.
It is early January and a hammy Alexander is thanking the people whose checks (of $10,000 and up) financed the unusual organization that prepared his Presidential bid -- a nonprofit corporation called the Republican Exchange Satellite Network. Other gestating candidates have typically used political action committees to build staff and meet donors. Alexander created his own monthly television show, beaming himself by satellite into the homes of party workers.
As television, "The Republican Neighborhood Meetings" were certainly no threat to "Nightline." The first broadcast was knocked from the air by a thunderstorm and another ended 15 minutes early. Even the 19th and final show, taped in January, found Alexander unsure when to smile or where to find the camera. "One-eight-hundred, seven-seven-two, seven-three, seven-six," he sang, in the cadence of a toaster salesman. "Our phone lines are all lit up!"
But as politics, the satellite network was a shrewd move. It bolstered his name recognition among the party faithful. It allowed him to build a staff that included a full-time organizer in Iowa. And it gave him two years to test and refine his anti-Washington message, with slogans like the anti-Congressional rant, "Cut their pay and send them home."
Alexander says he was trying to help the party rethink "what we're for," and the network even produced a slick brochure by that name. To the untrained eye, "What We're For" reads a lot like "What We're Against." It attacks unfinanced mandates, the Clinton health bill, high taxes and big Government.
No matter. For Alexander, the network was the latest move in a creative career that, depending on one's point of view, has shown a long streak of either resourcefulness or opportunism. In his first Governor's race, in 1974, he donned a business suit and lost to an opponent who cast him as a drab Nashville lawyer. Four years later, he draped himself in a red plaid shirt, walked across the state and won.
In an earlier incarnation, Alexander showed all the signs of conventional Washington ambition. As a 20-something lawyer, he served as a junior Nixon White House aide. As Governor, he told The Nashville Banner that joining the United States Senate was his "lifetime ambition." Now he plays to the anti-Washington 90's by depicting his Senate rivals as compromised insiders and demanding the abolition of the Education Department, which only three years ago he happily ran.
Alexander grew up in the small town of Maryville, Tenn., where, he writes in his autobiography, the family "never had money to waste." His father left his job as a school principal to work as a safety officer in a nearby Alcoa plant because it paid better. His strong-willed mother, Floreine, ran a kindergarten from the family's backyard.
A talented student and pianist, Alexander went to Vanderbilt as an undergraduate and New York University for law school, then clerked in New Orleans for the Federal Court of Appeals judge John Minor Wisdom, noted as a champion of civil rights. Though Alexander is now reinventing himself as a right-leaning conservative, in his eight years as Governor he was known for his middle-of-the road instincts.
Watching Alexander at work invites the suspicion that, somewhere between the dark suit and the plaid shirt, there's a chip on his shoulder. In his standard stump speech, he complains that The New York Times once called him "lower-middle class." (In fact, the paper described him as "solidly middle-class," noting that he had spun a myth of hillbilly roots.) His favorite anti-Washington peroration, launched on behalf of local control, is "We're not too stupid to know what to do!"
Working a breakfast in Orlando, Fla., a few days before the Super Bowl, Alexander tells a crowd that he and Paul Tagliabue, the N.F.L. commissioner, were "Rhodes Scholar rejects together." But the attempted self-deprecation begins to clank. "In their wisdom," he continues, "they thought neither of us would amount to anything."
In Presidential terms, many of the party's top fund-raisers thought the same. But the satellite network helped modify that. Its biggest benefit was its least obvious: it gave Alexander two years to romance the party's top donors, under optimal circumstances. As a formal candidate, he would have been just another politician with his hand stuck out; as a party builder, he stepped through the door in statesmanlike guise. He came away with $5.5 million, essentially to promote himself, and while that money cannot be transferred to a Presidential campaign, the loyalties of the donors can.
Alexander describes the mechanics with surprising candor. "I realized that making repeated visits to New York and California and Texas and all around the country, meeting with people who traditionally supported the Republican Party financially, would make a great deal of difference to me," he says. "That formed relationships and gave people who didn't know me a chance to get to know me.
"Of all the things it did for me, I'd say it was probably the financial network that was most important. It turned out to be a lot better than a PAC."
Political action committees, after all, must abide by laws that limit donations to $5,000 and demand public disclosure. As a nonprofit corporation, the network could accept unlimited sums and withhold its donors' identities. About 200 people gave $10,000 or more and 13 of them gave $100,000, according to Agnes Warfield, a fund-raiser who followed Alexander from the Education Department to the satellite network to the campaign. Large donations, secret donors: the network perpetuated in perfectly legal fashion the very practices that the post-Watergate campaign reform laws were designed to extinguish. (See "Illusory Limits" at left.)
Still, the question arises: Why would anyone want to give an unemployed politician a $10,000 check? Welch and Alexander kicked things off with their own donations, then organized a 1993 meeting with about a dozen other old Alexander hands, including his former law partner and members of his state cabinet. With about half the money coming from corporations and three-quarters from Tennesee, Welch says he raised nearly $1.5 million in 1993.
Then the effort went national. Alexander invited scores of the party elite to weekends at Blackberry Farms, a resort in the foothills of the Smoky Mountains. He met dozens of others through five getting-to-know-you dinners sponsored by his old boss, Howard Baker. With Alexander claiming no pay from the network, Baker also brought him into his law firm at a salary of more than $300,000 a year, in exchange for duties that could charitably be described as light. Then again, Alexander has long shown a penchant for mixing politics and personal profit, benefiting even as Governor from lucrative, low-risk investments with the help of Baker and other friends. When the Senate scrutinized his suitability as Education Secretary, the hearings focused not just on educational philosophy but also on a history of stock deals and low-interest loans.
Freed from financial worry, Alexander made good use of the time. He met Sam Bamieh at a White House reception in the last weeks of the Bush Administration. A California investor, Bamieh was one of Pete Wilson's most important fund-raisers, pulling together more than $1 million with a single dinner in his home. "I said, 'Lamar, what are you going to be doing, ' " Bamieh recalls. "He answered, 'I'm going to be President.' "
Nine months later, Alexander was sitting in Bamieh's office, pitching the network. Bamieh says he wrote a $10,000 check -- because "I have a deep passion for education" -- but warned Alexander that when the campaign arrived, his loyalties might rest elsewhere. Alexander kept up with calls and visits and even arranged a broadcast from the developer's home, featuring Milton Friedman, the Nobel-winning economist. Bamieh paid for the show with a $50,000 check; his contributions eventually totaled $100,000. When Bamieh had eye surgery last fall in London, Alexander offered to come visit on his way to the Middle East. Bamieh says that sealed it: though Wilson is now preparing his own race, Bamieh is raising money for Alexander.
A former neighbor from Maryville, John Thornton, proved a less complicated sell. Though their parents were friends, Thornton, at 41, is 13 years younger than Alexander and the two were scarcely acquainted. They ran into each other at a fund-raising dinner for the state party in 1993. As it happened, Thornton had just sold the rug company he founded 10 years earlier with a life savings of $20,000. He pocketed $27 million.
Thornton used part of the windfall to buy a "a 33-foot-long, super-duper, stretch Lincoln limousine," painting it "big orange" to honor the University of Tennessee Volunteers. Then he drove 11 days cross-country to the football season opener at U.C.L.A. "Rented Elvis costumes and walked down the strip in Las Vegas," he says. "Had a helluva time."
Alexander invited him to a weekend at Blackberry Farms, where he recited his accomplishments as a business-friendly Governor. Thornton liked what he heard: "I just got out the checkbook and wrote him a check for $100,000. Happy to do it, too."
Perhaps no network find has been as valuable as Carl Bouckaert, a carpet magnate from Dalton, Ga., According to Warfield, Bouckaert gave $100,000 of his own money and helped raise $800,000 more. And when Alexander unveiled the 17 members of his Presidential finance team in February, Bouckaert was among them. So were six of the party's last eight finance chairmen. (Four of them, including Welch, live in Nashville.)
So was Dick Cheney's main fund-raiser.
And Jack Kemp's.
And, in Bamieh, one of Pete Wilson's.
What brings this kind of lineup to a long shot? Using his own obscurity to his advantage, Alexander offers the kind of personalized attention that unattached money men could not expect in the more crowded camps of Gramm and Dole. "Lamar is the only guy who tells you what he's doing," Bamieh says. "He doesn't just say, 'Give me the money.' "
Ted Welch is atop his Nashville tower, setting the goal for a dinner in Tennessee's rural First Congressional District, a sum so high the gasps come through the other end of the receiver: $250,000!
"That'll mean blitzing it," Welch agrees. But he makes it known that the district's most powerful politician, Representative Jimmy Quillen, is counting on it. "I don't know how it all happened, I just know that Jimmy Quillen would like very much for you two to be the wagon masters up there," he says. "Quillen is behind us 100 percent."
Welch offers sympathy: "I know that means turning over an awful lotta rocks." He offers tips: try for $2,000 a couple, but admit spouses free if necessary. He concludes with a warning: "There can't be no factions."
And he's onto his next phone call, about four minutes later. This one is to Warfield, the campaign's senior paid fund-raiser. "The 250 scares the life out of them," he laughs. But this call, as always, has a purpose: to schedule a time for Alexander to meet with the First District's sales team.
Welch then turns his attention to the dinner planned in Denver. The chairman is confident but Welch is not. "It's taken care of," assures a voice on the other end of the line. That means invitations are in the mail. But Welch wants a traditional dinner organization; that means salesmen whose progress he can track. Ten seconds after hanging up, he is on the phone with a West Coast consultant, explaining that the Denver man is "of the mistaken notion that he can send out 250 invitations and get 175 checks." The consultant vows to straighten things out.
So it goes, throughout the day. He strokes. ("I didn't want anything in the world but to thank you," he tells Atlanta.) He gripes. ("The damn dinner'll be over before he gets his committee together," he says to another southern city.) He prospects. ("The Korean community -- do you have an entree?" he asks New York.) He cajoles. (Selling one table "doesn't mean you're married to us!" he tells a Mississippi man.)
In an aside to Warfield, he explains the nature of the game. "What you do is push people," he says, "without their knowing they're being pushed."
Like a striking number of the people he is pushing, Welch is a self-made man, whose up-from-nothing story stands in contrast to his party's born-on-third-base image. He was born 61 years ago in tiny Parsons, Tenn., where his father was a teacher, part-time farmer and failed shopkeeper. "We grew up poor, but not without spirit," he says.
Biographical inquiries yield other, similarly spare comments. Though Ted Welch loves to talk about Lamar Alexander, he does not like to talk about Ted Welch. His long, wary silences make the air feel like it is about to shatter.
Still, the basics emerge. A 5-foot-7-inch, 150-pound wingback, Welch escaped to the University of Tennessee at Martin on a football scholarship. He spent his first summer vacation working the wheat harvest through Kansas. He spent the next one in Tarentum, Pa., with the Southwestern Publishing Company. As a door-to-door salesman of dictionaries and Bibles, Welch outperformed the hundreds of other young men who fan out each year across the South. He had found his vocation.
Joining Southwestern upon graduation, Welch eventually borrowed enough money to buy part of the company, which was sold to the Times-Mirror corporation in 1968. Among his subsequent investments are magazines (Business Nashville and Nashville Life), restaurants (L & N Seafood and Ruby Tuesday's, both of which he has now sold) and, most important, real estate. His holdings include half of the Tower, the 31-story office building adjacent to the Nashville Convention Center.
Welch entered politics in 1970 when his fund-raising helped a Memphis dentist named Winfield Dunn become the state's first Republican Governor in a half-century. He followed Dunn into office as Finance Commissioner, but fund-raising, not administration, proved his passion. When a former Tennessee Senator, Bill Brock, moved to Washington in 1977 to lead the Republican National Committee, he brought in Welch as the party's finance chairman. Welch even met his wife through fund-raising. As the new dean of the Vanderbilt University School of Nursing, Colleen Conway made Welch her first development call. He wrote her a $10,000 check, called her for dinner two weeks later and married her 19 weeks after that.
At the committee, Welch's first move was to give the party $10,000, making himself a Republican "Eagle." Then he persuaded 200 others to do the same. Welch went on to raise Presidential money for Howard Baker, Ronald Reagan and George Bush and he developed a specialty in "soft money" donations, made nominally to the party, not the candidate, and thus exempt from the $1,000 cap on direct contributions.
What makes him good? "One is believing in what you do," he says. "The other is having the courage to ask for the money.
"People don't like the rejection. It's hard -- and you get a lot of it."
This day, rejection is not the problem. The campaign has just landed Larry Bathgate, the New Jersey real-estate lawyer who had been lining up support for Kemp. A former party finance chairman, Bathgate is a proven producer. The problem is what to call him.
Campaign workers are drafting a news release, but Welch is supplying the worry. "He'll be joining our team at the highest level," Welch says, but doubt creeps in. Make that "at a very high level," he says. No, "a high level." The conversation continues on and off for an hour or so, and when the release goes out, Bathgate is upgraded once again to "the highest level."
Are titles important? "Hell, yes!" Welch responds, suddenly animated. "You notice I don't call myself chairman. A lot of people, if they can't be No. 1, they don't want to work with anybody else."
Welch is so sensitive to the potential for conflict that he even distributes a printed parable to deal with it, an elaborate story of honking geese. He tells the other fund-raisers that geese get "at least 71 percent more flying range" by staying in formation. When one is sick or shot, others fall back to help, and while honking can spur the lead goose on, "we need to be careful what we say when we honk from behind." At least one of the co-chairmen was so impressed that he took the page home to show his teen-age daughters.
Welch returns to the phone, on the day of the Bathgate coup, to plot the recruitment of a former Bush supporter. "He's the one that wanted an ambassadorship," he tells Warfield in a listen-to-this-one tone. "They were sending him to a little country I'd never heard of.
"They showed him a picture of the residence and it was just beautiful. Then he got over there and it was the wrong one! He stayed about a year, then came back home."
Warfield, on the other end of the phone, is joking about how the news release will read. "Yes," Welch laughs. "At the highest level!"
WHEN ALEXANDER TALKS about the importance of money, he is talking the language of his rival, Senator Gramm. No one has done more to conflate cash with credibility, and he has done so for a simple reason -- cash is what he has got. Gramm transferred $5 million from a Senate campaign fund and says he raised $8.5 million more in the first quarter. It remains to be seen whether the money will bring the votes Gramm says it will; in 1980, another Texan, John Connally, raised almost $10 million but won just a single delegate. Still, for years Gramm has been banking on the bank.
He started in 1991 with the conquest of a fund-raising fiefdom called the National Republican Senatorial Committee, which helps finance the party's senate campaigns. Winning an unprecedented second term as chairman, Gramm raised more than $120 million over the four years. Packing himself off to hundreds of fund-raising events, Gramm cultivated countless new networks for himself. He says he held 40 functions just for Mike DeWine of Ohio. Now DeWine is in the Senate and Gramm is on a first-name basis with dozens of major donors in a strategically pivotal state.
Gramm has caused a quiet stir by leaving the post with another precious possession: the committee's list of direct-mail donors. Or most of it, anyway. Past chairmen typically kept the names of a few thousand major contributors; Gramm kept the name of anyone who responded to a letter he signed.
"We were able to take people who contributed over the Senator's signature," says Carla Eudy, his finance director. Since the committee mails 20 million letters a year and the chairman signs more than 90 percent of them, that's a lot of names -- as many as 400,000 by some estimates. Critics say Gramm broke past practice by departing with a list that others consider party property. It would easily cost $4 million to build such a list from scratch.
Gramm is quick to acknowledge that he sought the committee post with a Presidential race in mind. "Nobody can say I didn't do a good job for the committee," Gramm says, "but obviously I got more out of it than saddle sores."
Gramm has condensed his financial pitch into a slide show that has become notorious in fund-raising circles. He professes to have met precisely 164,454 potential donors since 1991 and to have kept notes on every one. The faces of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Barnette of Marietta, Ga., light up the room, offering a detailed example. Gramm has their home phone, work phone, car phone and fax numbers; their address; their secretary's name and their history of support. ("PG flew in his plane to Portsmouth, N.H., 9-15-93.") Gramm presented the show to Phil Handy, an Orlando, Fla., businessman, then called him a few days later to thank him for signing up. But Handy had done no such thing. Now raising money for Alexander, he calls the Gramm machine "Orwellian."
It's hard to know what adjective describes the February dinner Gramm throws at the Dallas Convention Center -- one he dubs the most lucrative in the history of Presidential politics. Everything seems larger than life: limousines the size of Greyhound buses, 20-foot screens to project his face. Even the name-dropping comes in outsize, Texas proportions.
"I'm Candace Tyson. I handle billion-dollar lawsuits," volunteers an excited woman, who introduces herself as the county's first female Republican judge. Standing in a sea of $10,000 tables, she offers a quick tour. There's Norman Brinker ("he's Steak and Ale"), there's Harold Simmons ("a big entrepreneur") and there, too, is Caroline Rose Hunt ("one of the Hunt family").
Then here, heading for the coffee bar, is Don White, the senator's half-brother and the full-time fund-raiser on Gramm's Senate staff. Tyson plants a kiss on his cheek and moves the man to rhyme. "I've said many times: 'Candy's dandy, but liquor's quicker,' " White says. The judge responds jokingly, in a stage whisper: "He's the money man, the bag man." The money man asks her to lunch, but she leaves him with a lipstick tattoo and a promise to call.
On stage, Gramm proclaims financial triumph. While Alexander treats money like sex -- something to take care of behind closed doors and refer to with discretion -- Gramm savors the details. "I know that people do not call you up and ask if they can give money," he says. "People do not come and write checks and stick them in the drawer of your desk."
He thanks the crowd "for making all those calls."
For "knocking on all those doors."
For "using up all those i.o.u.'s."
"Thanks to you, I have the most reliable friend that you can have in American politics," he says, "and that is ready money."
Bob Dole doesn't talk that way, but then again, he doesn't have to. As the party's Senate leader and a man mounting his third national campaign, Dole is dealing from a position of strength. In the last election cycle, his PAC, Campaign America, raised $6 million through a network that remains at his fingertips. With a donor list of more than 500,000 names, he plans to raise as much as 30 percent of his money through direct mail. That frees up time from the dinner circuit, a luxury that could prove especially advantageous early next year, when every hour of candidate time grows precious.
Alexander got a taste of Dole's strength in trying to sell tickets to his Washington dinner, which fell more than $100,000 short of its goal. "We just ran into a brick wall," says an Alexander aide. "Anybody who has legislation on the Hill doesn't want to do anything that will hurt their chances."
Plus Dole already has much of what Alexander and Gramm hope to buy: name recognition. "We don't have to spend money to get out and acquaint people with who Bob Dole is," says John Moran, his finance chairman. "There's no real pressure being felt over here."
The pressure is felt out there -- out on the money trail, among people reluctant to bet against the front-runner. It is being felt on this February night by John Price, a Salt Lake City developer, who repairs to the bar after a gathering in Miami of hundreds of Republican fund-raisers. A substantial donor to Alexander's satellite network, he has agreed to help sponsor a Utah dinner with a goal of $150,000. But now he's having second thoughts.
"It's a tough decision," he says, his head turning in search of eavesdroppers. On the one hand, "Lamar personally calls and stays in touch with me," he says. But "there are other people saying: 'Do these events, help out Lamar, but stay somewhat neutral.' " Price pauses, looks around and whispers. "I don't know how to say it: 'Don't turn your back on Bob Dole, that's what they're saying.' "
All this anxiety for a mere $150,000! "I would write him a check for that if I could -- it's not much," says Price, who arrived in the United States as a child refugee from Nazi Germany and built an empire of shopping centers throughout the West.
On a car phone a month later, Price offers an update: the Alexander dinner underperforms, raising just $70,000, and he agrees to lend Dole a hand.
Alexander suffered another setback in late March, when Pete Wilson robbed him of his outside-Washington franchise by setting up an exploratory committee. After raising $28 million for his 1994 Governor's race, Wilson seems to have the requisite fund-raising credentials. The Alexander people are quick to note, dismissively, that California law allowed unlimited gifts from individuals and corporations; Bamieh alone gave $259,000. But Wilson also raised impressive sums in his '82 and '88 Senate campaigns ($7 and $12 million respectively) while operating under the $1,000 per-person limit and the mammoth state gives him a coveted base.
Jack Kemp calls it all revolting. It is late January and he is sitting in a conference room at his Washington office, announcing that he will not announce. "There are a lot of grotesqueries, not least of which is the fund-raising side of it," he says. He objects to "traveling the country in this circuit, in that element.
"The fund-raising overwhelms the ideas."
It is a classic Kemp performance -- engrossing, eccentric, self-serving and, in a way, endearing. Referring to himself in the third person, he complains that on the fund-raising circuit he couldn't just "be Kemp being Kemp." In renouncing the race, he vows to spend his time instead "worrying about how to save the Mexican peso."
Possibly not even Kemp himself knows whether fund-raising really drove him from the race. Perhaps he is simply making too much money (aides say his speeches will bring in about $1 million this year). Perhaps he does not want reporters combing through his personal and professional life.
Sometimes Kemp says he couldn't have raised the money had he tried. Businessmen bristled at his refusal to back the balanced-budget amendment. Californians "shut off my fund-raising" for criticizing the anti-immigration measure, Proposition 187. "I don't want to be in a party that's all white," he says.
At other times, Kemp says he simply didn't want to make the effort, especially after Bathgate, his would-be finance chairman, penciled in 241 fund-raising events for 1995. "I didn't want to spend the time to go where you have to go, do what you have to do, say what you have to say," he says.
But whether the money forced him out or he voluntarily withdrew, Kemp is instructive as a kind of anti-Alexander. Alexander, having no natural base to launch a $20 million drive, willed one into being, making himself plausible by dint of determination.
Kemp had fame, but campaign fortune would not follow.
"I don't like asking for money," he says.
"I do not like asking for money."
"I don't even like myself when I'm asking for money."
Like too much time in the desert, a few months on the money trail produces a mirage. Where there once was America with its K Marts and trailer parks and squalid ghettos, there are now just shimmering images of wealth -- fabulous, ubiquitous wealth. Money, money -- it seems to be everywhere. It's at the Nashville dinner that the horse breeder must leave because his pilot has spotted a front moving in. It's in long orange limousines. It's in as unlikely a spot as the Mountain City Club in Chattanooga, a tired place with plain walls and heavily sauced food. But even here, there is a fortune at every table: offspring of the families that produce Little Debbie snack cakes and Magic Chef appliances, Brock Candy and Krystal hamburgers.
And this is mere Chattanooga. Out on the fund-raising circuit, the Apostle John seems to have it all wrong -- it is the rich who will be here always, dining out at $1,000 a plate. No wonder what thought comes to Alexander's mind when, on a swing through Florida, he spots a man on crutches. "You don't play polo do you?" he says. "I've run into two people lately who've hurt themselves badly playing polo."
A few weeks later, he is in Aspen. It is President's Day weekend and Alexander is plying his outsider message from a suite at the Ritz-Carlton, with peach-colored walls and a glorious mountain view.
The occasion is a retreat for Team 100, the exclusive Republican club whose members must pass only one admissions test: write the party a check for $100,000. They are clomping about in ski boots, talking politics and snow, and Alexander is on their trail.
He works a reception, speaks at a dinner and holds two days of private meetings. Alexander's patron for the weekend is Mel Sembler, a shopping center developer from St. Petersburg, Fla., who would have been Cheney's main money man. An effusive, charming man, silver-haired and jowly, he invites me to watch him at work but the authorities at Team 100 are quick to say no. "They know how it's going to look," an Alexander aide explains. "A bunch of rich people romping in the snow, deciding who should be President."
There is something irresistibly likable about Mel Sembler. He could star in a comic novel about Republican fund-raising; call it "Men Who Give and the Politicians Who Love Them." The stereotype is of hard men in back rooms, but Sembler is an ingenuous, almost innocent figure. Recognized from the podium at a fund-raising dinner, he cocks his fist into a pistol, pulls the trigger and winks. When I visit his Florida office, he makes no pretense of modesty but whisks me straight to the framed photo where he stands between Presidents Reagan and Bush. "This is what I call my power picture," he says. "Standing between two of my friends there. Exhilarating!"
Sembler has cuff links from George Bush and ceramic knickknacks, High Holiday wishes and pens -- "five books of this stuff!" He raised millions in the 1988 campaign, working, he says, "at the highest level." Bush responded by sending him to Australia and Sembler still answers to "Mr. Ambassador." His wife, Betty, has a better title. Greeting me in Aspen with a hug, she rehearses a favorite joke. "Call me Ambassador-able," she says.
Sembler knows that fund-raisers are a suspect class and he resents it. The son of a Russian immigrant (who eked out a living as a prize fighter), Sembler made his millions on his own. He gives to politicians but also to colleges, hospitals and drug-treatment programs. When Bush named him Ambassador, Garry Trudeau responded with a biting caricature in his "Doonesbury" cartoon strip. "I paid for this ambassadorship fair and square," the Sembler-like figure says at an auction. Mocking the mockers, Sembler had the panels framed and hung above his toilet. But the wound still seems fresh. "We always get painted in ugly pictures because we touch the money," he says.
Alexander courted him for years. When Sembler was sent to Australia, Alexander forwarded an inscribed copy of a memoir of Australia he had written after a six-month family vacation there. As Education Secretary, he found occasion to visit Sembler in Canberra and he kept up the romance with frequent calls upon Sembler's return. When Cheney dropped from the race, Sembler's phone rang within the hour. It was Alexander, asking for his support. "Lamar's got a lot of humanistics about him," Sembler says.
The Aspen reception proceeds smoothly, but dinner proves problematic. The Team 100 crowd, weary from the day's skiing, straggles off even as Alexander hits the piano for a reprise of "Make Newt Gingrich Go Away." Sembler says the setup was all wrong. "It should have been, 'Hi folks,' one song, boom-boom, out of there," he says. "The guy next to me fell asleep."
Sembler is cheerier the following evening as he emerges from the day of small sessions in his suite. Encountering the Team 100 members one at a time, he says Alexander won three more professions of support and one firm commitment: an Orlando man who pledges to host a $100,000 event in his home. "Lamar was smart enough to be here and make himself available," Sembler says. "He's not a sprinter. He's a distance runner." Then he dons a cowboy hat and escorts Ambassador-able to the evening's event, a Team 100 hoedown.
In the bar down the block, an unlikely conversation unfolds: a money man mocks the money men. Why would anyone give $100,000 to consort with politicians? "It's like smelling jockstraps, being around Michael Jordan," he says. "It's to be affiliated with power."
Harsh words, but they're coming from Phil Handy -- Alexander's state chairman in Florida. He's not yet Team 100 rich but, at age 50, he's on his way. "I think there's a certain point in a business career where business itself is no longer enough," he says. "The question is: What is it after that that matters? Making another $1 million, or another $10 million, building another shopping center isn't enough."
Sipping a microbrewed ale and quoting Nietzsche and Dan Quayle, Handy is on a roll. "Fundamentally," he says, "I don't think anybody gives for another's benefit; you do it to solve some problem that's inside. You can call it selfish, but I think it results in an extraordinary amount of generosity. I don't think it attributes bad motives to people."
It all starts to pay off in March. Dinner is served and the cash begins to flow: $363,000 out of tiny Dalton, Ga., and $235,000 a night later in Jackson, Miss. At $400,000, Chattanooga falls far short of its $750,000 goal. But Memphis weighs in at $750,000 and a quick hop through Los Angeles and San Francisco adds $160,000 more. An end-of-the-month swing up the Eastern Seaboard, Atlanta-Baltimore-Washington-New York, adds in excess of a million more.
Alexander may never reach his 1995 goal of $20 million -- the last dollars are the hardest. But he does manage a $5 million March. And it all begins in Nashville, with the largest fund-raising dinner in Tennessee history, a $2.2 million extravaganza at the Opryland Hotel.
In a few hours, there will be balloons, senators and country music stars. Two thousand beef fillets will swim forth in crab-meat bearnaise sauce and a white-chocolate piano will decorate every dessert plate. Ted Welch will shout "Attention!" from the stage and insist that everyone sell four tickets to a subsequent event.
So it's an understandably proud candidate who steps before the cameras at a midafternoon news conference to flex his financial muscles. "Right now, there are only three candidates who can raise the $20 million that's needed," Alexander says, and he is claiming to be one of them. (Wilson's entry, by most accounts, would add a fourth.)
The problem is the timing. His day of glory comes as Congressional Republicans vote to cut food stamps and to end Federal support of school lunches. Poor Lamar. He throws a $2 million dinner and all the local press wants to talk about is nutrition for the needy!
He tries to cast aside the questions. "They're not talking about cuts," he says, to skeptical stares.
He tries again. "We're not too stupid to know what to do in Tennessee about school lunches!"
A few months earlier, Alexander had complained that he would be "spending all my time with people who can afford to give $500 or $1,000," which, he added, "isn't a good way to prepare yourself for President." Now he goes as far as to call the arriving army of surgeons, lawyers and business barons "a fairly representative group of people."
But this assertion is so absurd that even he doesn't stick by it. He finally just throws in the towel.
"The system is not a good system, but I'm not complaining about it," he says. Away from the microphones, he adds: "The irony of it is, it's run off most of the people that it would have been most difficult for me to beat."

HEADLINE: WORD & IMAGE;
The Story of Dow

BYLINE: By MAX FRANKEL 

 BODY:
I HAVE BECOME ADDICTED TO THE serialized fiction that serious newspapers tuck away back among the stock tables. The plot of the daily "Market Story" beats any TV soap. It's a Freudian drama that tracks the moment-by-moment anxieties of a highly neurotic character named Dow. His feverish ups and downs are not only recounted with medical precision but also interpreted with obvious poetic license by faceless Traders, Investors and Analysts. They are more skilled than any Euripidean chorus at finding heavenly explanations for every twist of fortune.
Synopses don't do justice to the excitement of every day's plot turns. But I think I've caught the essence of the drama by tracking the tale from New Year's Day to the Ides of March. 
 Take the month of January. When Dow (which is short for the Dow Jones average of industrial stocks but also a metaphor for the entire market) begins the year by improving from a value of 3,834 to 3,857, the Analysts sing the praises of a "stronger dollar" and think long-term interest rates bring "reasons to be less concerned about inflation." O.K. But two days later, when December is revealed to have produced the lowest unemployment rate in four years, the Analysts fear new "inflationary pressures" and yet the Dow index climbs anyway, to 3,867. That happens, Analysts decide, because of the "flattening" of the interest-rate "yield curve." Analysts also call the news about Mexico's falling peso upsetting, but then again, they think that "Latin America's troubles may spell good news for American stocks." Got it.
Mercifully, that's the last we ever hear of yield curves. By mid-January, with the Dow rising up to 3,908, the Analysts again credit some news about December, but this time it's the bad news of an "unanticipated slump" of one-tenth of 1 percent in retail sales. That makes them optimistic about inflation again and propels the Dow index even higher, to 3,932. Traders "hope that the Federal Reserve would moderate or even forgo an expected increase in interest rates."
Just then, "inflationary pressures" reappear, yet the market holds steady anyway. Why, dear Analysts? Because of "the prospect of favorable corporate earnings this month." But when the index then drops 46 points the next day, to 3,882, the Analysts forget about profits and shift to watching the dollar -- it's falling in value against the mark. A further decline, to 3,869, is pinned on inflation again, but come to think of it, maybe the blame belongs to "Double Witching," the dreaded expirations of options that automatically foster computer-guided trades.
We come now to an interesting week in which the Dow index leaps high and low throughout each day but beds down each night in just about the same place as the night before. That condition, alternately called volatility and stability, evokes a delicious range of explanations. Analysts invoke "evidence of an economy that is not cooling as fast as had been thought." They point to Congress's dithering about the Mexico aid package. And there's the Kobe earthquake: it has "undermined the Japanese market." Although there exists a consensus that the Fed will again raise interest rates at month's end, Analysts deplore the "ambiguity" of Fed statements about whether that will be the year's last increase.
In short, nothing that the Analysts said could prepare me for Jan. 31, when the market awoke with what they decide is a "shudder" at the headlong plunge by Mexico's peso. Dow plummets to 3,832 -- the very point from which it started at New Year's.
So it goes also through February, each tick evoking a new analytical tack. Dow recovers and Analysts attribute the resurgence to the economy's slowdown; it goes higher still and they attribute it to the economy's healthy growth and high corporate profits. They spend another month worrying about Dow's decline if the Fed again raises interest rates, but when the Fed does indeed raise them, the Dow nonetheless leaps past 4,000 and on to 4,049 at the Ides of March.
WHAT PROMPTS THESE FICTIONS? WHY ON earth do otherwise sober publications and broadcast media indulge these tall tales by Analysts presuming to explain more than 300 million trades a day? Why belabor the artificial drama of the Dow, which could be rendered in a simple number, like yesterday's humidity? And why ascribe human form to the market, as if it could have a single emotion, like "confidence" in the dollar or a "lack of faith" in Congress?
Some market influences are indeed discernible. If on any one day investors shift more money into stock purchases than they are taking out from sales, they are probably bidding up the value of an index that fairly summarizes stock prices. And if some other day interest rates in Germany are more attractive than in America, more money may indeed be shifted across the Atlantic and cause the stock index to fall. But millions of subjective judgments are also at work at every moment. Some traders are buying and selling in quick bursts for minute gain while others buy and sell from long-term considerations that may reflect their private needs even more than the conditions of the public companies whose stock they trade. Like the butterfly that flaps its wings in China and ultimately causes a ripple of wind in Chicago, any one of a zillion transactions anywhere can combine with others to move the market index up or down or not at all.
The Analysts who presume to explain the moods and moves of these zillions (many of whom are in any case looking to outguess each other's moods and moves) are spinning fairy tales. The media embrace them because they've learned that dramatic narratives, not raw numbers, are their stock in trade. What fun is the game's final score if we can't read about villains and heroes? What's so interesting about yesterday's temperature if we can't read about stalled cars on icy roads and brutal landlords who failed to turn on the heat?
The daily market drama is particularly appealing because, like the soaps or the newspaper yarns that finally added up to Charles Dickens's novels, it provides a running story with familiar characters. Inflation, I.B.M., the Fed and the peso -- they need no daily introductions. Moreover, the adventures of the market stir the blood of stockholders; it's a story that plays on their hopes and fears and keeps them engaged, maybe longer in the paper even than in the market. And like any good myth, it's a story that purports to demystify the causes and motives of outrageous fortune. It makes fortune bearable.
So weep not for the missing astrology column in your favorite newspaper. You can divine the heavenly signs each day, in the Story of Dow.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

HEADLINE: DANCE;
The Great Ballet Partnerships Are All but Gone

BYLINE: By JENNIFER DUNNING

 BODY:
"Frightened?"
"Not with you, mate."
A spot of color burned on his cheeks. I nuzzled against him. He held me silently, for some seconds. Then I broke away. The overture was beginning."
From "Lynn: An Autobiography," by Lynn Seymour 
 TWO DANCERS STAND CLOSE IN THE DARK wings of a stage, waiting for the moment they will rush together out into the light as ballet lovers. In those few seconds before their entrance, they are bonded in a way known to few other mortals. They know each other's bodies and minds as intimately and instinctually as real-life lovers. But theirs is an intimacy born of dancing. They are that rare and fragile thing, a great ballet partnership.
Margot Fonteyn and Rudolf Nureyev once waited together in the wings at the Metropolitan Opera House, their presence, when visible at last, drawing wild cheers even before a foot was pointed. Across the plaza at the New York State Theater, the cool heat of Suzanne Farrell and Peter Martins made the stage George Balanchine's temple of the dance. But only their ghosts linger on in the theaters where American Ballet Theater and the New York City Ballet continue to perform.
The age of star pairings, which lent such glitter to 20th-century ballet, seems for the most part to be over. Today, ballet is a form of entertainment and a careerrather than the esoteric, perfumed art that once fostered the dance equivalents of Hepburn and Tracy or Lunt and Fontanne. Battalions of dancers have taken over for the chosen few of other eras. Choreography itself has become a star. And the pas de deux, once an exegesis on love and lovers' manners, is now performed as much for the sake of complexity or purely physical excitement. Yet the old idea of partnership is not entirely lost.
Alessandra Ferri and Julio Bocca come close to the ideal in our own time. Principal dancers with American Ballet Theater, they will open the company's season at the Metropolitan Opera House on April 24 in one of the supreme tests of a pairing, "Giselle" -- she as the innocent, doomed young peasant girl; he as the nobleman who betrays her love.
At City Ballet, the 14-year partnership of Heather Watts and Jock Soto ended last season, when Miss Watts left the company. But Mr. Soto, who will perform with City Ballet when its spring season opens on April 25 at the State Theater, remains an exemplar of effortless, selfless male partnering, squiring just about every ballerina in the troupe.
There has, however, never been a partnership quite like that of Dame Margot Fonteyn and Rudolf Nureyev. In many ways they defined the phenomenon. Chosen by Fonteyn to dance with her soon after his arrival in the West in 1961, Nureyev revived her career and together they galvanized -- and nearly swamped -- the Royal Ballet. He was a fiery Soviet defector in his 20's. She was a radiantly ladylike English ballerina 19 years his senior. Huge stars in their own right before their pairing, Fonteyn and Nureyev were a box-office bonanza through the 1970's until just before Fonteyn's retirement from performing.
Their power lay not in the perfection of their technique but in the tension that existed between the sometimes steely, sometimes delicate restraint of a mature ballerina and the abandonment of a wild youth. They were the embodiment of the young girl and the pirate in the "Corsaire" pas de deux, one of their most popular showpieces.
To the death-defying acrobatics of some Soviet partnerships before them, when tiny, muscular ballerinas tore across the stage to leap into the arms of a distant, rock-steady partner, Fonteyn and Nureyev brought a suggestion of love. To the ethereal otherworldliness of Alicia Markova and Anton Dolin, English stars who had danced together almost as a single body from the 1930's on, Fonteyn and Nureyev added the spice of threatened ravishment.
The Royal Ballet and its other dancers paled in the hot reflected light of Fonteyn-Nureyev, as they were known. The mid-1960's were, in one of the mysteries of ballet history, a singular time for partnerships in the company. Lynn Seymour, dark and headstrong, performed with Christopher Gable, blond and charmingly boyish, an unruffled yang to her turbulent yin. Kenneth MacMillan had created "Romeo and Juliet" for them, though the premiere was given to Fonteyn and Nureyev, and Seymour and Gable epitomized MacMillan's ideal of dramatic ballet.
Antoinette Sibley and Anthony Dowell were "heavenly twins," as some English fans called them, dancers whose body lines seemed to merge, particularly in the exalted lyrical ballets of Frederick Ashton. But Fonteyn and Nureyev triumphed over all. They had no bounds, it seemed, giving all that they danced together the imprint of their personalities and their partnership.
The pairing of Fonteyn and Nureyev occurred at a peculiar juncture in ballet. Nureyev had almost singlehandedly reintroduced the idea of the exotic on a level almost comparable to that of the astonishing experiments of Serge Diaghilev and his Ballets Russes some half a century earlier. The exoticism personified by Nureyev was in part due to his allure as a foreigner and to his tantalizing sexual ambiguity, as well as to the way he wedded sexuality with dazzling pyrotechnics. Ballet was suddenly popular, made so in part by two performers who became household names.
 
 
Two Hearts Beating in Time
 What makes a great partnership? Two dancers' bodies may match in height, weight and heft. Their schooling and experience may be similar. They may both be passionate or chill. In the end, however, there must be that indefinable thing called chemistry. In motion together, two dancers may become a kind of third thing. They may have very little to do with each other once they leave the theater each night. But when they dance, it is, as Gerald Arpino, artistic director of the Joffrey Ballet, puts it, as if two human hearts beat in a single time.
After nine years of dancing together at Ballet Theater and throughout the world, Miss Ferri and Mr. Bocca have become friends offstage and soul mates when they dance. "It is a matter of being totally naked in front of another person, of letting everything show," Miss Ferri says. "The strengths, the weaknesses. You let yourself be taken into someone else's arms."
They have had their battles. They are frequently apart, dancing with companies on separate continents. But when they are together again, it is as if they are resuming an old friendship.
"It's always lovely," Miss Ferri says. "When we finish a performance we always look at each other and say, 'Thank you, Julio,' 'Thank you, Alex.' I have danced with other partners as strong and good as he. It is a matter of not being alone. I really dance for Julio, and he for me. You open up your heart. Dancing for him, I dance for everybody. I'm not just showing off."
Good partners also tend to have a shared sensitivity to music; each dancer then hears the music in the same way. Kevin McKenzie, an exceptional partner who now directs Ballet Theater, says another ingredient is a willingness to settle into a relationship somewhere between complementing and competing with each other. And dancers must trust each other.
"Otherwise," says Damian Woetzel, a principal with the City Ballet, "it's a complicated game of chicken."
Many of ballet's famed pairings have consisted of an older woman and a younger man, with the woman guiding the man to anticipate what she needs from him.
"Partners are sometimes nervous when they're new," says Kyra Nichols, a principal who has danced with many men over her 21-year career with City Ballet. Sometimes, Miss Nichols adds, she is assigned to dance with a new man in order to guide him through one of the company's ultimate tests of sang-froid, George Balanchine's "Theme and Variations."
"When a partner gets nervous," she says, "his arms don't function. You're kind of fighting with him. But usually I can calm them down. I kind of take their hand and try to get a little eye contact going."
Adam Luders, one of the outstanding partners in recent City Ballet history and now a teacher at the company school, treated his ballerinas like "porcelain dolls," Miss Nichols says. Such self-effacement was foreign to Nureyev.
 
 
Definitely Not A Man's World
 Men have tended to be invisible in classical ballet. In works of the Romantic era, the man existed mainly to support and carry the woman, to give the illusion captured in many lithographs of the period, Mr. Arpino notes, of a gossamer creature so light she could balance on a leaf.
Mr. Dowell and Mr. Gable knew how to present their ballerinas to the audience. That was one secret of partnerships like that of Erik Bruhn and Carla Fracci, of Mr. Martins and Miss Farrell, of Igor Yousekevitch and Alicia Alonso, and of the husband-and-wife pairing of Vladimir Vasiliev and Ekaterina Maximova.
The art of squiring a ballerina is taught today in most ballet academies, though Miss Nichols believes that the best partners are born, not made. At the School of American Ballet, which is affiliated with City Ballet, dancers even take ballroom dancing classes to learn to loosen up in their partnering, a program begun by Mr. Martins, director of the school and company. But Mr. Soto says he learned most by watching performances and studying the partnering techniques of Mr. Martins particularly.
"Peter had such a presence," he says. "Then, when he came out with Suzanne or someone else, she was floating. It was almost as if you didn't see him."
That combination of invisibility and presence is achieved by a total attentiveness to the ballerina's needs. The look of both dancers is thus enhanced, so that they appear as attuned to each other as a man and a woman in a long-term relationship.
The effect can be heightened by good partnering technique. "You have to allow her to do what she can do," Mr. McKenzie adds. "You have to stay out of her way but take her a little further than she could go on her own." He offers the example of lifting a ballerina from a pirouette into an arabesque. "You can't just plop her up and down. It is almost as if you are going into an arabesque yourself.
"You must use your hands economically, and use them not just to make her secure but to help shape her body rather than just holding on to her. It is as if you are sculpting her body, though no one sees it happening. It's like shaping a clay pot when it's spinning, which you can do because you're aware of the center. It's almost subliminal."
The instinctual sense of connection with another body can be a danger, though. Sean Lavery learned it on the job as a teen-age performer and eventually became one of the most sensitive partners at City Ballet, where he is now Mr. Martins's assistant. Years after his apprenticeship, dancing with Merrill Ashley in a tumultuous moment in Jerome Robbins's "Evening's Waltzes," Mr. Lavery grabbed and swung the ballerina around his head as the choreography required.
"I got carried away," Mr. Lavery recalls. "It was summer, in Saratoga. My hands were sweaty. And she went sailing off onto the floor and into splits. I caught her, but we must have looked like deer in headlights."
The sensitivity that marked the partnering of Mr. McKenzie and Mr. Lavery will guide the dancer through many styles. And it must, even among the classic narrative ballets. In the pas de deux in "Don Quixote," for example, Mr. McKenzie says, "you put out your hand for her to balance."
"The ballet is all about a woman on her own," he says. "In the balcony scene in 'Romeo and Juliet,' you're cross-eyed and out of breath, and the first thing Juliet does is throw herself at you."
Balanchine's classicism must be learned just as much as the 19th-century classicism of Marius Petipa, or the frequently off-center, skewed body line and lack of eye contact in ballets by choreographers who come from 20th-century modern dance. Balanchine insisted that his male dancers curve two fingers around the hand or wrist of their ballerinas to support them. He tended to present his dancers frontally to the audience. Manipulation of the woman's body is a big part of Balanchine's ballets, Mr. Soto says, and City Ballet choreographers like Mr. Martins and Richard Tanner carry that further.
 
 
Where Have the Great Partnerships Gone?
 The hothouse atmosphere of 20th-century ballet lent itself to the development of stars like Nijinsky, Eglevsky and Danilova. Then there was Balanchine, for whom the dance itself was the star and the dancers were the vivid instruments of that creation. An emphasis on technical expertise for its own sake from the 1970's on helped develop proficient technicians who were almost as unlikely to meld into partnerships as the stars who preceded them early in this century.
Companies today are large and perform in a huge variety of styles, including modern dance, which is historically an art of the individual rather than of the social mores from which classical ballet grew. And ways of working have also changed.
Choreography helped create the star duos of history, but choreographers now work under the gun. Gone are the open-ended rehearsal periods in which some of the classics of ballet were created, in quiet, uncluttered studios. Working consistently with a few sympathetic dancers has become a luxury. A good partnership has been likened to a good marriage or romance, but it is hard to move through the rituals of love with strangers looking on. Today, Mr. Arpino says, choreographers create pas de deux not only with two chosen dancers but with their understudies.
Could a contemporary choreographer create a pas de deux for Miss Ferri and Mr. Bocca that would plumb the depths of passion in that partnership as well as of the classics they will dance this season at the Metropolitan? It might be difficult.
Miss Ferri and Mr. Bocca seldom rehearse those classics, choosing instead to dance spontaneously and even to improvise to make the performance as fresh as possible. "I almost know where he will finish, and so I know where to catch up with him, and he with me," Miss Ferri says of the sudden, improvised moments.
"I remember once in 'Romeo and Juliet,' after the scene in the ballroom, I was supposed to run offstage to the left with everyone following me. I was looking so much at Julio, I ran off on the wrong side. The dancers were all giggling. I didn't even know. And that has happened to him.
"You get to the point where it doesn't matter any more. Steps don't matter so much. You go beyond doing well."
 
 
 
The Topic of Much Talk
 Over the years, critics and dancers have weighed in on the art of partnering. Here is a sampling.
"Shattered eardrums must have been a dime a dozen last evening at the Metropolitan Opera House as the audience beat its palms and cheered wildly for an elegant ballet duo who might also be classified as the hottest little team in show biz. . . . Combine the smolder, the mystery, the dynamic presence, the great streaks of vivid movement which Nureyev gives us with the beauty, the radiance, the womanliness, the queenliness and the shining movements of Dame Margot and the cheers that have shaken the old Met to its foundations are explained."
Walter Terry, dance critic, The New York Herald Tribune, describing the Fonteyn-Nureyev phenomenon in 1963.
"The partner surrenders his intelligence, his balletic skill, his showmanship, to the creation and perfection of a dance."
Anton Dolin, an outstanding English classical partner, in his 1949 book, "Pas de Deux, the Art of Partnering."
"As a partner, Massine was terrible. He wasn't interested in anybody else. He considered lifting a ballerina or supporting her in pirouettes not part of his job and acted as if he were doing her a favor. Like Nijinsky, like Eglevsky . . . he preferred to dance by himself."
Alexandra Danilova, in her 1986 autobiography, "Choura: The Memoirs of Alexandra Danilova"
"She gave me the freedom to partner her."
Julio Bocca on the ballerina Alessandra Ferri in a recent interview.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
Dollar Is Weak, but Not Everywhere

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
Economists can provide all sorts of complicated and sometimes contradictory reasons for why currencies gyrate in value. Some of those reasons may even be correct. But for Americans traveling in most of the world, one thing is clear: The dollar is not worth as much as it used to be.
Since the beginning of last year, the dollar has lost more than 20 percent of its value versus the world's two other major currencies, the Japanese yen and the German mark, and is trading at or near all-time lows against them. And because of the way the world's economies are interconnected these days, the relationships among those three major currencies filter down to affect almost all exchange rates, causing a form of sticker shock for Americans approaching a currency-exchange bureau. 
 In Europe, many other currencies set their values based on the German mark. So while the dollar lost 20.65 percent against the mark between Jan. 3, 1994, when the American currency was at one of its highest levels in years, and April 4, 1995, it also lost 20.62 percent against the Dutch guilder and 21.79 percent against the Belgian franc.
 Other currencies have not gained quite so much against the dollar in the last 15 months. The dollar is down about 18 percent versus the French franc. Britain remains a relative bargain: The dollar is off less than 8 percent against the pound.
There are some glaring exceptions to the trend. Mexico, plagued by economic problems, has seen the peso plummet in value, meaning that the dollar goes much farther there (although the gain could be at least partly offset by price increases). And Canada has seen its dollar fall 5.88 percent in value versus its American counterpart, making a trip north of the border that much less expensive.
Against the Italian lira, the dollar has hardly changed in value at all in the last 15 months. And the dollar still buys more lire and more Spanish pesetas than it did in mid-1992, when many Americans were complaining about Europe's being overpriced.
But Americans should hold on to their wallets if they head to Finland. The dollar has lost more than 26 percent of its value against the Finnish mark in the last 15 months.
For national economies, a devalued currency has its pluses and minuses. For travelers, it means only that everything effectively costs more.
The hotel room in Germany that cost $200 a night at the beginning of last year will now cost about $240 -- assuming the hotel has not raised rates. Dinner at that cozy little place on the Left Bank that previously cost $150 is now about $177.
What's the outlook for the dollar for the rest of the year? As with any economic question, there's no simple or reliable answer. The American currency's value has seemed to level off or even begin strengthening several times, only to dive again. Against the Japanese yen, the dollar often seems not to have any floor.
In Europe, much of the dollar's strength, or lack of it, has to do with the unpredictable financial interplay among the major Western European currencies, which by the end of the decade are supposed to be melded into one. No one has yet figured out how that is going to work.
So what is a traveler to do? The best practical advice might be to shop around among currency-exchange bureaus, comparing rates and commission fees. Check the rates that credit-card issuers use in converting purchases abroad into dollars. And remember that in many cases, local currency can be withdrawn from automated teller machines at foreign banks using an A.T.M. card issued by an American bank at rates more favorable than those at change bureaus.

HEADLINE: ARTS/ARTIFACTS;
Tiffany Lamps Recapture Their Glow

BYLINE: By RITA REIF 

 BODY:
WILL TIFFANY LAMPS retain their glow for aficionados in the 21st century? Four years ago, this seemed an unlikely prospect as sales of Louis Comfort Tiffany's works faltered in the recession. But their popularity was soon restored, auction records were broken, and now a miniboom appears to be developing, set off by the spirited buying of several new collectors.
The real test of the market will come on Saturday, when Sotheby's in New York auctions 75 Tiffany lamps, the largest collection ever to go on the block. The lamps, which are expected to bring a total of $6 million to $9 million, are owned by John W. Mecom Jr., a Houston oil heir and real estate investor who is the former owner of the New Orleans Saints football team. 
 Mr. Mecom became a collector in 1974, when he saw some Tiffany lamps that looked like the "great chandeliers I saw as a child in my mother's parents home; they were so beautiful." That year he paid $7,500 for a six-light candelabrum at the Manhattan shop of Lillian Nassau, then the most important dealer in the field. It may double in price at the sale.
He stopped buying around 1990, and last year, when he was divorced, people in the trade say, he offered the collection to the Sultan of Brunei and two Japanese collectors for about $50 million. "I bought these lamps to create a collection," he explained. "And I wanted to keep them together. That's why I tried to sell them to one collector." He says the sale has nothing to do with his divorce. "My taste changed," he said. "I was trying to simplify my life."
Critics contend that even Sotheby's valuations are too high. Nonetheless, the auction house expects that four lamps may exceed the record at auction for any Tiffany object: $770,000. That price was paid in 1992 at Sotheby's for a lamp with a spider-web shade and a glass-mosaic base of daffodils.
Mr. Mecom's more delicate version of the spider-web lamp has an iridescent base of blue-green glass tiles overlaid with bronze blades of grass. Its price could reach $900,000. A lamp with a shocking pink and orange shade patterned with maplelike leaves from the Virginia creeper vine could equal that figure. Two others with unusual shades -- one showing carp in a fishbowl, the second a landscape at dawn, midday and dusk -- are expected to fetch up to $800,000 each.
Compared with these rarities, a wisteria lamp with its magical mix of blues and mauves in leaded glass on a bronze tree base will probably seem a bargain if it brings the $300,000 Sotheby's says it will. The relatively low figure for what many experts consider Tiffany's most beautiful lamp is explained by the fact that so many of this one-time best seller survive.
Tiffany's vibrantly colored lamps, windows and vases have been admired and collected since they were first produced about 1900. They fell out of favor around 1930, during the Depression, when Art Deco and machine-age modern came into fashion. Twenty-five years later, they were rediscovered by collectors, curators and dealers like Mrs. Nassau, and since then, enthusiasm for them has rarely abated. In 1990, the Metropolitan Museum of Art presented "Masterworks of Louis Comfort Tiffany," the largest such exhibition ever; the show attracted 500,000 people, making it the best-attended show of decorative arts in the museum's history.
Several other Tiffany records have also been rewritten in recent years. A wisteria window was auctioned in 1991 at Christie's for $440,000. And, last November, a flower-shaped vase was bought at Sotheby's for $250,000 by Takeo Horiuchi, a Japanese real estate developer and owner of the Louis C. Tiffany Museum in Nagoya.
MR. HORIUCHI IS ONE OF the newcomers who will probably take part in the Mecom sale (either through agents or by telephone). Another is Brad Pitt, the actor, who buys Tiffany lamps to go with his collection of early-20th-century furniture and houses in the Arts and Crafts style. He favors the turtleback- and Moorish-style lamps from Tiffany's earlier period.
"Mr. Tiffany will never be totally ignored or scorned," said Alastair Duncan, an adviser to the Nagoya museum who has written six books on the subject. "His lamps are unsophisticated, pleasurable and so easy to love. Besides, there's been too much interest and too much money paid for his creations. Each generation has found different reasons to collect Tiffany. These lamps are busy and colorful, and they fit well in late-20th-century homes."
Mr. Pitt's passion for the Tiffany windows is no less intense. "I can't justify spending 20 grand on a truck," Mr. Pitt told Premiere magazine last fall. "But on a Tiffany stained glass window? If I could get one for 20 grand, I could completely justify that."
A window at that price would be no problem, said Barbara E. Deisroth, who heads Sotheby's sales of 19th- and 20th-century decorative arts. "But he's not going to get much in a Tiffany lamp for $20,000."

Going to Greenland
Q. We are planning a trip to Greenland and we're wondering if there are any inexpensive hotels in Godthaab. -- Ellen Leopold, Reseda, Calif. 
 A. The choices are pretty slim in Godthaab, which is the Danish name for a town now known officially in Greenland by its Inuit name of Nuuk. And whether because of the dollar's poor showing in financial markets or because of the natural difficulties of running a business in a place as remote as Greenland, accommodation prices are hardly bargain basement.
According to Greenland Tourism, a company formed in 1992 by Greenland Home Rule, which is what the government was called after the island achieved self-rule from Denmark on May 1, 1979, there are two hotels in Nuuk, the capital of Southwest Greenland. The town has a population of 13,000.
Hotel Hans Egede, Box 289, 3900 Nuuk, Greenland, (299) 24222, fax (299) 24487, charges $193 for a regular single room, $129 for an economy single and $240 for a double, calculated at 5.4 Danish kroner to the dollar. The 105-room hotel was named for a Danish churchman who landed in Greenland in 1721 and began the island's modern colonization. The settlement was founded in 1727.
The alternative is the 27-room Seamens Home, Postbox 1021, 3900 Nuuk, Greenland, (299) 21029, fax (299) 22104, which despite its name is open to non-mariners, including women, and is like a hotel in all respects except that it does not serve liquor. A single room is $110 ($73 for an economy) and a double $160.
For more information contact Greenland Tourism, Postbox 1552, DK-3900 Nuuk, Greenland; (299) 22888, fax (299) 22877, or one of the following agents in North America, both of which sell package tours to Greenland:
Pedersen World Tours, Park Place Corporate Center, 15 Wertheim Court, Richmond Hill, Ontario, Canada; (905) 882-5470, fax (905) 882-5472.
Scanam, 933 Highway 23, Pompton Plains, N.J. 07444; (201) 835-7070, fax (201) 835-3030.
