Day Trip to Venice
 Q. My husband and I will be spending some time in May in Florence and understand it is possible to take a day trip from there to Venice. Which is more convenient, to go by bus or train? -- Tina Bruder, Alexandria, Va.
A. There is no bus service between the two cities, but there are rather convenient trains.
The times are good through May 27; in Florence (area code 055) call 288785 for any changes in schedule.
The Intercity 712 leaves Florence at 7:15 A.M. and arrives at Venezia Santa Lucia at 10:15 A.M.
The Eurocity 30 leaves Florence at 9:47 A.M. and arrives in Venezia Mestre at 12:27 P.M. Trains for Venezia Santa Lucia leave Venezia Mestre every 10 minutes and the trip takes about 10 minutes.
On the return trip, the Intercity 723 leaves Venezia Santa Lucia at 7:42 P.M., arriving in Florence at 10:48 P.M.
There are also local trains to and from Venice from Florence but they involve making a change in Bologna, which wastes precious time on such a short visit.
A one-way ticket costs $21, including the Intercity supplement.

HEADLINE: Using Zoning to Spur Lower-Priced Housing

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN 

 BODY:
LYNN ZAMBRANA'S condominium looks out to the tall oak trees and the occasional deer on historic Princeton Ridge, the overlook where the British first spied the Continental Army, a sighting that ignited the Battle of Princeton in 1777.
"It's so pretty I don't even want curtains," Mrs. Zambrana said of the view from the three-bedroom unit she and her husband, Hector, bought 14 months ago. Given his $32,000 annual salary as a mail carrier in nearby Lawrenceville and her decision to quit her job as a mail carrier to raise the couple's two children, the Zambranas feel lucky to have found a unit that cost only $70,000. 
 Their condominium is one of 60 low- and moderate-income units mixed in with 240 market-rate single-family detached houses and town houses in the Washington Oaks complex completed last year along the Stony Brook in Princeton Township. It is a mile and a half from Drumthwacket, the New Jersey Governor's mansion in Princeton.
The family is one of a small but growing number of homeowners with modest incomes in the metropolitan area who are benefiting from density bonuses -- incentives given to builders who provide some units of moderate- or low-income housing in developments of market-rate homes. By building such units, which are termed affordable housing, the developers are able to construct a larger number of market-rate units than zoning would otherwise allow.
A density bonus is a way to override often restrictive land-use policies that limit densities and keep land costs high. The concept has been widely used over the last decade in New Jersey, where developers have either built the affordable units on their sites, provided money to the township to build them, or "exported" the money with which to build them to nearby urban centers. More recently Connecticut has made it easier for home builders to produce affordable housing in communities that have less than 10 percent of it. A 1989 law gives those communities the burden of proof in showing why they should deny developers the right to build such housing.
A few municipalities in the metropolitan area have voluntarily used the density bonus concept to promote affordable housing. But suburban fears that property values will decline if densities are increased have made most municipalities reluctant to promote any technique or seek any subsidy for building moderately priced homes.
George M. Raymond, whose Tarrytown, N.Y., planning-consultant firm bears his name, directs the Westchester County Housing Opportunity Commission, which is trying to persuade communities to comply with voluntary affordable-housing guidelines.
"Anyone advocating affordable housing is about as welcome as Typhoid Mary," he said, noting that county legislators and officials associated with what he called "the dreaded A word" tended to lose elections.
Density bonuses have proved popular with builders in New Jersey and more recently in Connecticut, but with continued community resistance the process of winning approval is often time-consuming and expensive, and builders are often reluctant to pick a fight.
In New York State, which has not enacted comprehensive affordable-housing legislation, density-bonus initiatives have been particularly slow in coming. "Firm community support is rare," said George A. Frank, executive vice president of the Builders' Institute of Westchester and the Mid-Hudson Region. "Density bonuses can increase the number of units and lower prices, and builders have used these opportunities whenever and wherever they can. But relatively few units have been built."
Samuel B. Fuller, vice president of Development for Avalon Properties of New Canaan, Conn., a large developer of multifamily affordable rental housing, said that if towns were sincere about affordable housing, they might consider more bonus densities.
"If you want more affordable housing, you have to provide economic incentives," said Mr. Fuller, whose company is building its first bonus-density project in New Canaan -- a 102-unit project with 20 percent of the units restricted to moderate-income families. "Bonus densities are a good way to do it because they don't cost municipalities anything."
But affordable housing does cost municipalities, said Robert Yaro, executive director of the Regional Plan Association. Municipal finances are almost totally dependent on the property-tax system, he said. "Communities don't readily zone for uses that demand a lot of services," he said. "A three-bedroom house on a small lot is a drain."
In the typical bonus agreement, the developer who agrees to make 20 percent of his units affordable will receive double the density allowed under the zoning code. The developer absorbs the cost of the affordable units with increased market-rate profits while the municipality gains affordable housing. Often, it gives public employees and young families priority in owning or renting this housing. In New Jersey, however, the Supreme Court has banned such limitations, saying that affordable housing should be offered on a regional basis.
TYPICALLY, units in the "moderate income" category must be affordable to families earning up to 80 percent of the region's median income; "low-income" units are intended for families earning no more than 50 percent of the median. Under Federal guidelines, the carrying cost of an affordable unit -- including utilities and rent or mortgage payments with taxes -- should not exceed 30 percent of household income.
Communities are becoming more accepting of affordable housing as they discover that their own employees, senior citizens and teachers have no local or nearby place to live, said P. Lynn Oliva, Commissioner of Planning for Westchester County. Since 1990, 16 Westchester communities have built 1,200 of the 4,800 units the county estimates it will need by the decade's end. The median income in Westchester is $66,900; the median house price is $319,000, and business leaders fear that the growing gap will threaten the broader economy.
Planners continue to sound the alarm. In June, the Regional Plan Association will release a study assessing the impact of the lack of affordable housing in the metropolitan area, where housing prices are 50 to 60 percent above the national average.
Growing awareness of the need for affordable housing has produced sweeping legislation in New Jersey and led communities throughout the state to free land for modestly priced, primarily multifamily, housing. Similar legislation was enacted six years ago in Connecticut, and there have been significant court cases in New York.
Mixed-income communities like Washington Oaks are appearing more frequently throughout the region as builders realize they have a friend in court. By agreeing to include a percentage of affordable housing in their market-rate projects, builders are using these laws to circumvent cumbersome zoning ordinances, increase density and build for a more mixed-income market.
The beneficiaries in most areas of Westchester and eastern Connecticut are middle-management office personnel, said H. Claude Shostal, president of the Regional Plan Association. Eighty percent of median income for a family of four in Westchester is $53,520 a year. It is $58,880 in Fairfield County.
"The lack of affordable housing in the metropolitan region is a major reason companies are relocating," Mr. Shostal said.
The legislative push for density bonuses for affordable housing began a decade ago in New Jersey, following a series of State Supreme Court rulings, collectively known as the Mount Laurel decisions, led the Legislature to adopt a sweeping affordable housing statute, known as the Fair Housing Act.
Local governments had an obligation to provide a "fair share" of the region's housing needs, the courts declared, and ordered them to remove regulations preventing the building of affordable housing and to take steps to provide it. Since land costs were a major impediment, the courts said, the key step was to offer developers density bonuses in exchange for providing lower-income housing units.
In 1985 the New Jersey Legislature created the Council on Affordable Housing, which has established allocations of affordable housing for each town. Today, each community in the state must develop an acceptable plan or be subject to developer suits.
CONTINUED local opposition and a general building slowdown have kept the courts busy and the process moving slowly, but 161 of 567 communities in New Jersey have now developed acceptable plans, said Shirley Bishop, the Council's executive director. By the end of 1993, 13,000 units of affordable housing had been constructed in 93 New Jersey communities, Ms. Bishop said, adding that these were the latest available figures. "The density bonus is critical," Ms. Bishop said. "The entire process is market-driven without income supplements. The density bonus gives the developer a realistic opportunity to build these units."
Mr. Raymond of the Westchester County Housing Opportunity Commission, one of several people with housing backgrounds appointed by the New Jersey courts to monitor compliance by certain towns, agrees. "The major proportion of affordable housing built in New Jersey following the Mount Laurel rulings has come from density bonuses," he said. An estimated 13,000 affordable-housing units have been built in the state under the Mount Laurel process. The most recent target set by the state's Council on Affordable Housing was for 86,308 more units of such housing by 1999.
The K. Hovnanian Companies, based in Red Bank, have built 30 "inclusionary communities" in the state, including 2,500 Mount Laurel units, all in projects with density bonuses. Without Mount Laurel, said James Corbett, the president of Hovnanian's northern New Jersey division, "there would be substantially fewer multifamily homes."
Building such homes is a difficult process. In Princeton, the Washington Oaks project was completed in February 1994, following a 10-year fight finally settled out of court. In what some came to know as the "second battle of Princeton," the developer sued the township for the right to build 1,280 units of a mixed-income project on 124 acres of a former farm.
The out-of-court settlement preserved over half the site for historic preservation and open space and provided a court-imposed density bonus, which allowed a total of 300 units on 73 acres of the original 124-acre site. The affordable units are contained in three of six two-story buildings, indistinguishable from their market-rate neighbors and abutted by open space, toddler playgrounds and tennis courts.
"The bonus density is what made it work," said Robert Fourniadis, senior vice president and general counsel of Calton Homes, the project developer. "Under existing density, we would have built 40 homes in the $500,000 to $600,000 range, out of reach of 90 percent of the population. This way, we opened home ownership to people who had only dreamed of it."
Three- and four-bedroom single-family homes sold for an average $350,000 while three- and four-bedroom town houses sold for $160,000 to $170,000 and market-rate condominiums ranged from $120,000 to $140,000. Market-rate home buyers showed "some resistance" to buying homes in a project that included low- and moderate-income units, said Mr. Fourniadis. But now, he said, the project is sold out.
Neighbors were concerned about increased traffic, said Thomas Poole, who heads Princeton's Affordable Housing Board. But, he added, there was an underlying issue. "The not-in-my-backyard syndrome is prevalent in Princeton," he said. "Suggest affordable housing and residents immediately picture people running around with guns in their hands."
Pressure for affordable housing has encouraged a few municipalities to use both bonus densities and subsidies to create affordable housing with little community opposition. North Amityville, L.I., in the Town of Babylon, recently completed a 72-unit project clustered on 11 acres leaving an additional 59 acres for open space. The single-family houses, each with a $25,000 subsidy from the New York State Affordable Housing Corporation, are now owned by families picked in a lottery that included 560 village residents.
Because the project was built by the Long Island Housing Partnership, a nonprofit corporation, there are no market-rate units, and the density bonus was used simply to increase the number of affordable units. Each of the two-bedroom town houses sold last year for $58,584.
IN FARMINGTON, CONN., Ron Janeczko, a developer who is a native of the community, is putting the finishing touches on The Cornerstone at Farmington, a mixed-income development of 68 single-family market-rate homes and 46 affordable duplex units on 30 acres. Prices for three-bedroom affordable units will start at $109,000 in a town where the median price for a new house is about $210,000. Market-rate homes will start at $169,000 for the smallest house -- 1,620 square feet with three bedrooms.
Mr. Janeczko, a partner of Inland/Hixon Associates of Simsbury, was the first developer to take advantage of the town's four-year-old bonus-density provision, which ties the allowable density to the amount of affordable housing. If a third of a proposed project consists of affordable units, nine units are allowed per acre; 13 units are allowed if the entire project is affordable.
Neighborhood opposition kept Mr. Janeczko's application pending for two and a half years. Now that the houses are on the market for under $200,000, public interest is "astronomical," he said.
Despite its willingness to consider affordable housing, Farmington has been the target of both developer and resident suits. Residents are suing the town because they think a proposed 34-unit development is too large, while the developer is suing because he wants greater density. The developer's suit is being brought under the state's six-year-old Affordable Housing Land Use Appeals statute, enacted in 1989, which requires that each town insure that 10 percent of its housing supply is affordable. A community that denies a zoning change to a developer who agrees to make 20 percent of his housing units affordable must prove that its zoning is not exclusionary.
In the six years since the law was enacted, 22 court cases have produced victories for both sides. "The result has been evenly split," said Timothy S. Hollister, a Hartford attorney who brought the case. The court's even-handedness, he said, has helped reduce community fears that "developers would march like Sherman through Atlanta."
But Jeff Ollendorf, Farmington's town planner, said state legislation has dampened local support for affordable housing. "We stimulated affordable housing on our own initiative and on our own terms," Mr. Ollendorf said. "The law is too much of an intrusion on a town's ability to determine its own future."
That sentiment is echoed strongly across the border in New York State where the rustic and affluent Westchester County town of North Salem has spent eight years in court battling a developer. The case, involving the Continental Building Company of White Plains, tests the town's zoning code and its refusal to allow multifamily housing, a code which a State Supreme Court judge has called "exclusionary."
Both sides appealed the decision. The town challenged the ruling that its zoning code was unconstitutional; the developer wants the town to pay a greater portion of its legal expenses. A decision by the Third Department, Appellate Division, in Albany is expected in a few weeks.
MEANWHILE, North Salem has permitted its first moderate-priced housing under the density bonus provision of its zoning code. Five moderately priced single-family homes will be mixed in a 53-unit luxury home development called Salem Chase now under construction by Toll Brothers, a Huntingdon Valley, Pa., development company. The luxury four-bedroom units on the 133-acre site will sell for $400,000 to $500,000.
"It's a hot lot," said Tom Hausle, the Salem Chase project manager, said of the three-quarter-acre site at 5 Cider Mill Lane designated for the first moderately priced three-bedroom home. "I could have sold it like that," he added, snapping his fingers. The five moderately priced houses, on sites designated by the Town Housing Board, will sell for $165,000.
There had been "some concern about how the other homes would sell," Mr. Hausle said, but that proved not to be a problem. Houses adjacent to the first moderately priced unit are on similar "premium lots" backing onto the woods and bordered by a stone wall. Their new owners have paid Toll Brothers an extra $2,500 above the house price to secure them, Mr. Hausle said.
The moderately priced houses are standard Toll models more modestly outfitted, Mr. Hausle said. Each will have a two-car garage, a two-story foyer, two and a half baths, hardwood floors and ceramic tiles. The model sells in other communities, including Green Hills in Budd Lake, N.J., for $290,000, he said.
Throughout the region, the building of affordable housing is proceeding slowly. Business leaders fear that the growing gap between median income and median housing prices threatens the broader economy.
"We support density bonuses because we have to have more affordable housing," said Robert Yaro, executive director of the Regional Plan Association. "Ten years ago, we identified the lack of affordable housing as the Achilles' heel in the region's economy. It's still the largest factor in the cost of living and doing business here."

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES;
A Word to the Wise for Co-op Owners: Participate!

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
SWEET are the uses of adversity, and also of ignorance, in building a successful co-op. Both must be overcome. In the process of overcoming, co-op owners acquire the cohesion and wisdom that makes for good housing.
Charles Rappaport, who is 72 years old, found these principles to be true in his own building and others built as co-ops in the 50's and 60's because they led to shareholder participation in building governance. And participation is the theme he has hammered at for 30 years as president of an organization known now as the Federation of New York Housing Cooperatives. 
 Aided by his wife, Eva, Mr. Rappaport has made a cause of strengthening co-op housing and helping newer co-ops learn to govern themselves.
"I preach it wherever I go -- it rolls off my tongue: the rights and obligations of shareholders," he said. "People should not be afraid to get on the board because they don't know anything. When we started, we learned very fast, because we had to. We changed our attorney and our managing agent. We got good counsel. We attended seminars. Little by little we learned."
Mr. Rappaport, a retired pension and insurance consultant, is in a wheelchair at present recovering from a leg amputation caused by diabetes. ("Soon I'll be driving again with my left foot," he says.) His views have special relevance at a time when most news about co-ops has to do with the difficulties of buildings recently converted from rentals in achieving the almost mystically appealing status of a "true" co-op.
The older generation of co-op disciples gradually built that mystique from their adversity and ignorance -- adversity because of trials with builders, and ignorance because few of the initial buyers knew much about building management.
Mr. Rappaport's co-op in Queens -- the 193-unit, 16-story building at 138-10 Franklin Avenue in Flushing -- was one of many built under a Federal mortgage-insurance program known as Section 213. These unsubsidized garden apartments or midrise or high-rise buildings, 31,582 units in 161 developments, are to be found throughout New York City.
Most of the 213's are in the final years of a 40-year fixed-rate federally insured mortgage held at interest rates of 4 percent to 6 percent. It is a form of financing that has promoted stability through the vicissitudes of the mortgage market. With debt costs fixed, inflation has made debt service an ever-shrinking component of monthly maintenance charges. Buildings have been able to keep maintenance increases moderate while keeping pace with rising operating costs. The 213 co-ops provide some of the city's best low-cost, unsubsidized multifamily housing.
THE boards of the insured co-ops formed a a council of presidents, out of which developed the Federation of Section 213's in 1956. Mr. Rappaport became its president in 1968. Ten years later it adopted the name Federation of New York Housing Cooperatives. In its educational and lobbying activities it works closely with the Manhattan-based Council of New York Cooperatives, formed mainly by the directors of co-ops converted from privately owned rentals.
The issues of governance faced by the pure co-ops -- built as co-ops with all the initial sales going to owner-occupants -- and mixed-occupancy co-ops, with a large percentage of nonpurchasing renters, are often similar. But the mixed-occupancy buildings have the added challenge of building a true co-op culture.
John K. Stewart, head of the John Stewart Company in San Francisco, a co-op development and housing-services company that manages 129 co-ops in California, says that steady board participation in governance and a fairly stable personnel on the board work in the end to enhance the value of co-op apartments on the sales market.
"The effect of the quality of the board on the value of the co-op cannot be overstated," Mr. Stewart said. He also thinks it is a good idea for buildings to have some degree of underlying debt, to make apartments somewhat more affordable for buyers.
Another specialist, Stephen B. Parliament, head of The Parliament Company, a co-op development and management company based in Minneapolis, called stable debt service "a key economic advantage" for co-ops. Because of resident participation in operations, they are also slightly less expensive to operate than rentals, he said.
Mr. Rappaport's co-op is known as Carlyle Towers Co-op B. It was one of two similar buildings developed on the site by the Jonathan Woodner Company, now based in Washington. Some of its governance principles reflect an insistence on placing common building needs ahead of individual needs. For example, the building doesn't allow shareholders to sublet. It also sets a minimum acceptable price for a resale.
The co-op always has the first right of purchase at the minimum price, but it can waive the right and usually does. The minimum price, set four years ago, is $110 a share, which translates to about $50,000 for a two-bedroom and $60,000 for a three-bedroom in a building that has almost all family-sized units.
"In the down cycle people begged us to cut the minimum acceptable price," Mr. Rappaport said, "but we held fast and now we are getting more than the minimum in most sales." He advises co-ops that do decide to permit subletting to assure themselves of the financial capacity of the sublessee and to put time limits on the permissible sublet period.
Lately, prices have been rising again. Ruth Rosenbloom, a 25-year resident who is vice president for sales, said a 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath corner apartment sold last year for $72,000. A few years ago a similar apartment would have sold for $125,000. "It was a highly inflated market then," she said.
Neither Mr. Rappaport nor Mary Ann Rothman, executive director of the Council of New York Cooperatives, advocates a specific policy on sublets. Sometimes there is a gradually escalating fee for subletting, said Ms. Rothman, or a time limit. Lenders' requirements often enter into the decision.
Wearing his advocate's hat, Mr. Rappaport has various campaigns under way. One is for an extension of the senior citizens' rent-increase exemption program, or Scrie, to co-ops. This program gives buildings tax relief that makes it possible for buildings to forgo rent increases for low-income tenants. The benefit is available in rentals and government-assisted co-ops, but not private co-ops, although many longterm co-op residents, he says, also have low incomes.
He also says that the J-51 program of tax relief for building improvements needs to be updated. The Legislature has authorized expanded coverage, but the Department of Housing Preservation and Development has not revised its regulations, he said.
ANOTHER Rappaport campaign has been for lower property taxes on co-ops, benefiting them as owners of one- to three-family home owners are benefited in New York City. At present they are assessed at the higher level applicable to rental property. The homeowners are in Class 1, which gets a special legislative dispensation to hold assessments down, while the larger co-ops are in Class 2 with rental property.
"Our taxes are three to four times higher per unit than the homeowners' taxes," Mr. Rappaport said.
Many of the problems of converted buildings Mr. Rappaport attributes to a Legislature that was too lenient in its requirement on the percentage of apartments that must be sold -- 15 percent -- before a rental building can become a co-op. He also believes that the Attorney General's office was too lenient in accepting plans for filing -- the technical term that means sponsors could begin sales. "The hand of the Attorney General must be strengthened," he said.
"You know how much assets a sponsor has to have to convert a building?" Mr. Rappaport said. "Only $5,000! There has been a proposal for $50,000. Even that's too little!"

GRAPHIC: Photo: Charles Rappaport, head of the Federation of New York Housing Cooperatives, at home with his wife, Eva. (Adam Fernandez for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 9; Page 7; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Salaries;
As Growth and Hiring Resume, the Pay's the Thing

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
NEWMARK & COMPANY, like most real estate firms, used to delegate research to clerks who were good with computers. This month, Newmark hired a research director with a bachelor's in economics and a master's in statistics.
"Of course we're paying him a lot," said Barry Gosin, Newmark's chief executive. "We need someone to forecast conditions, not regurgitate what's happened." 
 Sumitomo Realty & Development (N.Y.) just hired a building manager at 666 Fifth Avenue, at 53d Street. The new hire has less experience than his predecessor, but more financial education and savvy.
"I paid more than I had expected to, but less than we historically had to pay," said John Marazzo, a Sumitomo vice president.
After five years of downsizing and red ink, the real estate industry is growing -- and thus hiring -- again. But now it has a new problem: No one can quite figure out what to pay for what.
"Compensation goes as the industry goes -- it was down, and now it's going up," said Arthur Zabarkes, director of New York University's Real Estate Institute.
That is obviously true for brokers, whose compensation is tied directly to the size and quantity of deals they do. But for salaried people it is more complicated than that.
"There's a real need to understand what compensation packages you need to get and keep good people," said Karen L. Frank, vice president of marketing for the Building Owners & Managers Association International, which has hooked up with the Arthur Andersen accounting firm to do an annual real estate compensation survey.
The confusion is understandable. The skills needed to do a decent job have multiplied exponentially. Brokers must navigate the financial details of complex deals. Property and asset managers must file intricate reports to institutional owners. Building managers must be as handy with tenant relations as they are with a wrench.
THE result is that M.B.A.'s now reign where high school graduates once ruled.
"Companies are asking for sophisticated numbers crunchers who are equally comfortable with the languages of math and of sales," said Mary Ward, president of MacInnis, Ward, the New York recruiting firm. Even for property managers, who are often responsible for the workings of several buildings, knowledge of building mechanics has become secondary.
"It's easier to tell an M.B.A. how to cool a building than it is to explain financial goals to a building engineer," said David E. Schenkel, Cushman & Wakefield's new manager of asset services in New Jersey, who is looking to hire managers.
All other things being equal, such educated people should be making much more than their predecessors. But all things are not equal: The persistent recession dumped a huge number of qualified people onto the job market. The big, as yet unanswered, question remains which of the two competing forces -- the growing demand for good people versus the growing supply of such people -- rules the compensation numbers.
Outside New York, it still seems to be a buyer's -- translation: hirer's -- market.
"There are a lot of talented people looking to change jobs, but we have not really had to pay a lot more for them," said S. Kenan Manson 3d, senior vice president of national operations for Compass, Equitable Real Estate's leasing and management arm.
Gerard V. Schumm, a vice president of the Stamford, Conn.-based Axiom Real Estate Management, agrees.
"You can certainly get better people for $85,000 today than you could get before the recession," he said.
As in so many other things, though, the drum beats a different rhythm in New York. "Five years ago you could get a property manager for $35,000 to $70,000," said Edward A. Riguardi, chairman of the real estate firm Colliers/ABR. "Today that range is $65,000 to well into the six figures."
BOMA's numbers do indicate that for most job classifications, New Yorkers command richer pay packages. One example: The median cash compensation for a senior property manager in New York was $89,225 last year, the highest in the nation. The median for senior property managers for the real estate industry nationwide was just $65,600.
When commissions are involved, though, comparisons get knocked askew. Leasing was the only job category BOMA looked at in which New Yorkers lagged behind some other cities. One reason, suggests Ellen Valles, an Arthur Andersen compensation specialist, is that New York landlords often hire salaried leasing agents, rather than commissioned consultants, and people on fixed salary do not benefit as quickly from a recovering market.
Commercial Real Estate Women-New York, a professional association of women with at least 10 years' experience, recently did its own compensation survey. It found that 79 percent of those members who responded to the survey made over $100,000 last year; in 1993, only 32 percent topped the six-digit mark. Since much of CREW's membership is made up of commissioned brokers, those numbers reflect a recovering market more than they do any change in base salaries.
OF course, most industries pay their New York people better than their counterparts elsewhere. But there is more to the real estate compensation discrepancy than just geography. Property managers and leasing agents are generally running larger buildings here. Moreover, employers other than landlords and brokerages are competing for their services.
Financial services firms are hiring real estate specialists as security analysts to evaluate Real Estate Investment Trusts -- publicly traded entities that invest in real estate and pay at least 95 percent of their taxable income as dividends. The REITs themselves are vying for analysts to evaluate properties they might buy. And they are looking for managers who can deal with the voluminous reporting requirements of the public market.
"Our leasing director must also deal with the Wall Street analysts," said Thomas A. Rizk, president of Cali Realty Corporation, a New Jersey-based REIT formed by the Cali family last year. "Of course he expects a bigger bonus than when we were private."
As public entities, REITs like Cali also can give their managers stock options, and private companies competing for the same talent must up the salary ante to stay even.
Real-estate service firms, facing increasing competition for building-management and leasing contracts as well as for tenant representation assignments, are among the ones most readily paying the higher tariffs.
"The number of people available has held back compensation a bit, but it's certainly not a wash," said Mr. Schenkel of Cushman & Wakefield. "There is substantial money available for the best skills."
INDEED, executive recruiters say that service firms are paying as much as $65,000 for an M.B.A fresh from Wharton, and $100,000 for a financial analyst who can back up brokers on complex deals. And they are paying senior asset managers upward of $175,000 -- not to mention hefty bonuses for bringing in new business.
"So many buildings are owned by institutions today, and institutional owners are more likely to put management contracts out for bid every few years," Ms. Ward said.
Those asset and property managers who spent the recessionary years keeping sinking buildings afloat are getting the highest pay of all. "People with a distressed asset will pay heavily for someone who will make the problems go away," Mr. Manson said.
People who are not willing to pay the higher numbers are simply not finding the talent. Ms. Ward speaks of one client that wanted to upgrade its accounting staff. "They wanted us to find them C.P.A.'s for the same $55,000 a year they've been paying their general accountants," she said. "They won't find anyone for under $75,000."
In the public sector, where pay traditionally lags, jobs are already going begging. Earlier this year the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey put out a search for a new leasing person for the World Trade Center. It was not prepared to pay above $100,000 for that person, and it was not satisfied with the applicants who were willing to work for less.
"I was surprised that there was so little interest from dynamic people," said Charles A. Maikish, the Trade Center's director, who took someone without much commercial experience from another Port Authority department. "A few years ago we would have had a lot of takers."
Lower-level, but trainable, hires have their allure in the private sector, too. The Edward S. Gordon Company has been hiring college graduates for as little as $21,000 and putting them into areas like market research to learn the business.
"Real estate, even in down times, has a certain cachet," said Joseph R. Harbert, Gordon's senior managing director. "Young people come in at bargain prices because they perceive a good career path."

GRAPHIC: Charts: "On Location, Too, It's Location, Location, Location" shows pay for various real-estate positions in New York City. "Same Job, Different City, Different Pay" shows total conpensation for various job titles. (Source: BOMA International/Arthur Anderson)

SECTION: Section 13CN; Page 1; Column 3; Connecticut Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1265 words

HEADLINE: Newspaper Wars: Old vs. New

BYLINE: By BILL RYAN 

 BODY:
IS the state heating up for a newspaper war? Some knowledgeable followers, and sometime-critics, of Connecticut's news media say that seems to be the case following the announcement that the aggressive Journal Register Company of Trenton, N.J., is raising its stake considerably in Connecticut journalism.
The Journal Register, which already owns The New Haven Register, the state's second-largest daily newspaper, and smaller dailies in Bristol and Torrington, now is buying more than 45 publications, mostly weekly newspapers and mostly in Connecticut, from Capital Cities/ ABC Inc. 
 "It's our firm belief that we can provide better service to advertisers and readers through these acquisitions, which will provide more reach for advertisers and more information for readers," said Robert M. Jelenic, president and chief executive officer of the Journal Register, in a prepared statement.
Ten of the weeklies, known as the Imprint Newspapers, are clustered in towns south, west and north of Hartford, which puts the Journal Register in direct confrontation, particularly for advertising dollars, with The Hartford Courant, the state's leading daily in both circulation and advertising for several decades.
On one day in the middle of March, The New Haven Register and The Hartford Courant, not surprisingly, put different spins on the Journal Register news. The Register ran the story on its front page, saying that the new acquisitions would "greatly increase" the presence of the Journal Register Company in Connecticut and then quoted a newspaper broker from Rochester, N.Y., to back up that claim. The Courant ran the story on the first page of its business section, including a statement from a financial analyst in Washington, D.C., that owning community newspapers is a tough business.
The Courant story also said that, after adding the Milford Citizen, the only daily involved in the transaction, to its three existing daily papers, the Journal Register Company would have a daily circulation in Connecticut of only 143,088 and Sunday circulation of 146,108. The circulation of the Courant, "the state's largest newspaper," the story added, is 241,102 daily and 317,767 Sundays. (Two days later, however, The Courant ran a correction, noting that the paper's circulation as of last Sept. 25, according to the Audit Bureau of Circulations, was 226,553 daily and 314,166 Sunday.) Dennis Schain, the spokesman for The Courant, has not downplayed the significance of the Journal Register's new acquisitions in Connecticut. "It has the potential to heat up the competitive environment," he said. "We're confident we will remain the state's leading newspaper. We're taking a look at our entire operation and will consider any changes that would be necessary given the new situation."
In Trenton, N.J., Diane Pardee, the spokesperson for Journal Register, indicates that the new situation may even become newer. "We're a young, growing company," she said, "and we're looking at additional acquisitions."
According to the Journal Register's 1994 annual report, the company has "arranged a credit facility of $645 million, which is available to us to continue to make strategic acquisitions."
What makes the square-off more intriguing is that it pits one of the country's newest newspaper groups against the paper that takes pride in being the oldest. The Journal Register was founded in July of 1990, created out of some of the newspaper properties of Ingersoll Publications. The Courant, now owned by Times Mirror Corporation of Los Angeles, was established in 1764 and is described as "the oldest continuously published newspaper in America."
Maureen E. Croteau, head of the Department of Journalism at the University of Connecticut, said she believed that The Courant "will have to pay attention now that Journal Register has a good block of dailies and weeklies in the state."
The day of traditional newspaper wars, "two big papers in a city going head to head, fighting it out on page one," is long gone, however, she said. Most medium-sized cities no longer have competing papers. Newspaper wars are now fought in board rooms, in how many acquisitions newspaper chains can make to swell total circulation, in advertising incentives they can offer. The real casualties of a new-style newspaper war in Connecticut, she said, would not be the big papers but the smaller ones.
The case of the Journal Register papers competing against The Courant, she said, "is like two big fierce dogs walking around." Both big dogs are well able to take care of themselves, but papers like The Middletown Press and The New Britain Herald, both already wafer-thin for lack of advertising, could be in danger of being acquired, or just ceasing to exist. She said she doesn't take any comfort from the idea that the Journal Register Company may be looking around for more small papers in Connecticut, citing a well-known case from last year. That was when the Journal Register was establishing a new Sunday paper at its recently purchased Torrington Register Citizen and its management fired a reporter because she wanted to include the fact there were some delivery problems in her story about the first Sunday issue. Two other employees of the paper later quit in protest.
"That doesn't bode well for an organization that should care for its editorial product," Ms. Croteau said. She added that she doesn't believe that The New Haven Register has improved its local coverage, "or anything else," since it became part of the Journal Register Company.
Jerry Dunklee, the chairman of the journalism department at Southern Connecticut State University in New Haven, said he was concerned over what he calls the "monopolization issue, fewer and fewer companies controlling more and more newspapers."
What happens, he said, is that papers on which people in small towns depend for local news don't get much of such news because the emphasis turns to stories that can go in all the papers.
"You get all the news that's of general interest to a whole bunch of folks," he said. "That misserves and disserves each of the local communities. It waters down the news people have come to rely on."
Joseph Zerbey 4th had worked for The Bristol Press for 25 years, the last 8 as publisher, when the paper was acquired by the Journal Register Company in 1993.
He could have stayed on, but elected not to, and is now president of the York (Pa.) Newspaper Company, which prints morning, afternoon and Sunday papers in that city.
Mr. Zerbey says he has no rancor toward the Journal Register and that he feels that Robert Jelenic "runs a good company and, no question, is going to be a major competitor for print media in Connecticut. Bob will turn the heat up. And I think other papers will be absorbed."
One person watching the evolving situation a bit closer than most is one of the few family publishers left in the state.
He is William Pape 2d, representing the third generation of Papes to run The Waterbury Republican. He indicates he is somewhat mystified by the sale by Capital Cities/ABC of its weekly newspapers to the Journal Register Company.
"It's interesting," he said. "Capital Cities/ABC are pretty sharp operators. I thought that maybe they got sick and tired of doing business in Connecticut, a state going dead slow, and everyone holding their breath for the economy to turn around."
Meanwhile, Mr. Pape said he is not too concerned. "We turn out good papers," he said.
"We give readers and customers a lot for their money and we have a lot of loyal readers."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
Dairy Farms Drying Up in the Town of Washington

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

DATELINE: TOWN OF WASHINGTON

 BODY:
A HUNDRED years ago there were about a hundred dairy farms in the Town of Washington. Soon there will be only two.
By mid-September Davie's Hollow Farm, operated by John Nye, a 34-year-old native of the town, a 4-H Club member in his youth, an agriculture major in college and a tenant dairy farmer since 1981, will move his family and 600 Holstein cows to 80 acres in Delta, Utah. 
 For John, his wife, Maria, and their children -- Gregory, 9; Peter, 6, and Katharine, 3 -- leaving their hometown, families and friends will be a wrenching experience.
The exodus of farmers from the state and sometimes from the dairy business, said Shirley Ferris, the state's Commissioner of Agriculture, results from "the low price of milk, the high cost of equipment and doing business, and residential development that created a scarcity of land."
Her own family's dairy farm in Newtown, one of 10 left in Fairfield County, operates with 145 cows. "We are fortunate," she said. "Our neighbors value the idea of a farm."
That has not been the case in Washington, where the majesty of the hilly landscape is being preserved by people wealthy enough to buy huge farms and convert them to elegant private residences, or by cluster housing development.
"We are surrounded by residential neighbors," said Mr. Nye. "They complain about the smells, or don't like the look of dry corn stalks, or object to herbicides that might contaminate the water. I try, but I haven't been too successful at peacefully coexisting with an increasingly suburban population."
Michael J. Cherniske, one of the two remaining farmers in Washington, is also thinking of moving. "I thought I would be here forever," he said, "but I can make $5,000 a month more in Virginia or Tennessee, or maybe in Utah." His 230-acre, family-owned farm was started by his grandfather.
Over the years, as Mr. Nye's business grew, he rented more and more land, until now he has 35 landlords for 247 fields within a 20-mile radius in nine towns. Rents run from zero for mowing abandoned lots (he keeps what he mows for feed) to $20 an acre for growing corn.
"Cost control is a problem chasing around to all those places," he said, "especially in heavy snow." The price of milk will be $1 per hundred pounds lower in Utah, he said, but the cost of doing business will be much lower than it is in Connecticut.
Milk prices, controlled by the Federal Government since the 30's to protect farmers from unscrupulous middlemen, have fluctuated in Connecticut between $12 and $14 per hundred pounds since the 70's. In the last five years the lower figures have prevailed. But at the same time, farms disappeared and farming costs rose.
"Fewer farms mean higher prices charged by fewer equipment dealers and repair services," said Douglas J. Di Mento, spokesman for Agri-Mark, a New England dairy co-operative based in Methuen, Mass., to which Mr. Nye belongs. The members' milk is sold to Hood, Sealtest, Stew Leonard's and Baskin-Robbins, among others.
According to the state's Department of Agriculture, there are 302 farms in the state today, 70 of them in Litchfield County. In 1970, there were 1,127 statewide and 127 in Litchfield, where 6 went out of business last year alone.
"You can't afford to buy land here just to farm it," said John Potter, who with his brother, Timothy, runs Washington's second remaining dairy farm. "We own 100 acres and farm 600 more. John Nye doesn't own any land, his growth couldn't be sustained."
MR. POTTER plans to stay, "but our income is mostly from selling frozen cattle embryos to France, England, Holland and Japan," he said. "Other farmers have diversified into selling hay, sweet corn, fruits and vegetables. And most wives are working."
Another form of diversification is renting houses to weekenders from New York City, said Robert M. Seymour, owner of Spring Hill Farm, near the Nyes's home. "It's as profitable as farming," he said.
He sold his dairy herd in 1974, but keeps about 20 head of beef cattle. He has been approached often to sell his land, but he resists. "A rich buyer will take over a big place, put a lot of money into it and after a year or two put it up for sale," he said. "That inflates our land values and makes taxes high for everybody."
Carolyn Klemm, co-owner with her husband, David, of Klemm Real Estat here, said: "Occasionally we go out and solicit farms for very rich buyers. In the 80's we sold a lot of large dairy farms as residences. Linda Allard, the fashion designer, bought one, and Ivan Lendl bought 875 acres in Goshen. There are also people who moved their businesses from New York to Greenwich and live out here now. And sometimes several people get together and buy land to put into a land trust."
The farmers cannot compete for the large land masses that they need to grow feed for their herds. "Thirty percent of our income goes for growing corn and hay," said Mr. Nye, and for the purchase of soybeans, oat hulls, cottonseed, bakery and potato waste products.
The feed is kept in enormous three-sided cement bunkers and hauled out as needed by payloaders. Runoff from the bunkers, and from animal waste and feed cultivation is a constant problem on the hilly land.
State laws forbid polluting water from any source, whether farming or industrial. Noncompliance can trigger fines of $1,000 to $25,000 a day, although the higher figure has never been imposed on a farmer. Correcting a violation can be extremely expensive, and on rented land it is not worth it.
"If Connecticut follows Vermont in banning manure spreading in winter because of runoff during thaws, I would have to spend about $200,000 on building and maintaining a storage bunker," said Mr. Nye.
HE estimates that his investment in Utah will be $1,000 per cow compared with $5,000 per cow in Connecticut. "In Utah we will be going out of dairy farming," he said, "and into dairying only -- strictly tending and milking cows. We will buy all our feed."
The land in Utah is flat and dry. The annual seven inches of rain produces negligible runoff, and prodigious amounts of alfalfa and other feeds are grown by irrigation with water flowing from the Wasatch and Rocky Mountains.
Alan Rindlisbacher, Director of National Business and Economic Development for Utah, said the state would "welcome the Nyes with open arms," adding that "Millard County, where they are moving, has been targeted as a marketing niche for dairy farmers."
Utah's crops are the beginning of an economic chain that the state wants to link with farmers who produce milk that in turn produces cheese and butter, "keeping more jobs and dollars in the state," Mr. Rindlisbacher said.
Between now and September, Mr. Nye will sell off 200 of his 800 cows, settle up with all his landlords and arrange for the $70,000 he invested in the Agri-Mark Cooperative to be refunded over a customary 7-year period. He will pick up the option on his Utah land and start building his new house, barn, milking and storage units. During construction his family will rent a house and space for the cows on somebody else's farm.
"No more growing of feed," he said. "More specialization is the trend -- putting all the eggs in one basket."

GRAPHIC: Photo: John Nye at Davie's Hollow Farm in the Town of Washington. He is moving his family and cows to Utah. (Stephen Castagneto for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: ROAD AND RAIL: Getting There (and Paying for It) in the Year 2000;
In Bergen County, A Plan to Create Rail Commuters

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
Few public officials are more involved in questions of road design, traffic congestion and public transportation than Chester Mattson, the planning director of Bergen County, which has one of the nation's most heavily traveled grids of Interstate and commuter highways.
Mr. Mattson has been a busy man. Since the last 21-mile stretch of Route 287 was completed in 1992, cutting acoss the northwest corner of the county, he has spearheaded a campaign to expand the access ramps at one of New Jersey's most congested interchanges, the intersection of Routes 4 and 17 in Paramus. 
 Now he is turning his attention from the county's roads to its railroad tracks, some of which are used only by freight trains. In an interview, he described his vision of the future for Bergen County transportation.
Q. The access ramp improvements planned for the interchange at Routes 4 and 17 can move forward only if an agreement is reached to acquire part of the site of a vacant Alexander's department store, which is to be demolished for a new retail complex. Do you expect problems?
A. The project has been approved and budgeted by the state at $102 million, and construction is to begin in 1998. The state is now negotiating with Alexander's, and I don't expect any snags. That is because the state could, if it had to, condemn the property. For me, this is just a necessary beginning in a large-scale transportation and planning effort.
Q. Why is public transit so important now?
A. Our economy can't function without the access we have to major roads, most of which pass through the county on the way to somewhere else. But we have come to a point where the cars and trucks that pass through us, combined with those that remain, threaten to overpower the system.
All our roads are used as local roads. People get on the turnpike to go two or three towns. They forget that a highway like the Garden State Parkway was designed for regional travel, not local travel. We have to come up with the means to relieve the congestion that has resulted from a sea change in our economy.
Q. What has caused the sea change?
A. Part of it has been what planners call the crashing together of the baby boom generation and the interstate highway system. There are just more people and more cars. And there has been an explosion of employment in the suburbs. In fact, 67 percent of the country's employment growth since 1960 has been in the suburbs of the major cities, Bergen County among them.
Q. What kind of public transportation do you have in mind?
A. We would build on the existing rail lines. There are three passenger lines, the Bergen, the Main Line and the Pascack Valley, going through the county, and we have 28 stations on those lines.
We also have two lines, the West Shore Line and the Susquehanna, that were designed to carry either passengers or freight, but now carry only freight. We need to add stations, and find a way to revive them as passenger and freight lines.
All of this -- five different lines -- should be integrated with the Secaucus Transfer Station, which is scheduled to open in the year 2001. Then we could also integrate the Hudson-Bergen trolley, the electrified light rail system that is planned to start in Bayonne, go to Hoboken in its first phase, then be extended to Weehawken and Ridgefield.
Q. What stands in the way of putting passenger trains on the freight lines?
A. The difficult part is trying to find the right balance of freight and transit on a limited amount of tracks. Rail freight has been growing rapidly because of the Pacific Rim trade that weighs in at Northwest ports and is sent by train to Port Elizabeth, Newark and Kearny.
Q. What role would the new Secaucus Transfer Station play in the system?
A. It will be crucial, since it is being designed to serve intra-suburban commuters. It will also mean that anybody getting on a train in Bergen County can transfer in Secaucus to get to midtown Manhattan, instead going to Hoboken as they must now do.
Q. Where would the money come from for changes to the five existing lines?
A. Both the state and New Jersey Transit have bonding authority, which could be used. There is a very large Federal transit program in New Jersey called the Urban Core that has money to invest. Not long ago it would have been inconceivable to spend public money on rail lines, but now I think we've reached the point where we have to invest to protect our economic assets.

GRAPHIC: Photo: To Chester P. Mattson, the planning director of Bergen County, rail commuting is the answer to traffic congestion. (Marilyn K. Yee/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: UP FRONT: ON THE MAP;
Teterboro, Where One of Every Four Residents Is a Councilman

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

 BODY:
By day, Teterboro has a working population of about 15,000; it's home to more than 90 companies, and Teterboro Airport is New Jersey's second largest, after Newark International. But after business hours, the population drops to the 22 residents of Huyler Street, the only residential block in the square-mile industrial community. The other day, the Borough Manager, Peter T. Neillands, agreed to talk to us about Teterboro, a place that "everybody has an opinion on and nobody has a solution for."
Q. Who lives in Teterboro?
A. There's only 10 or 11 dwelling houses, two of them multiple-family and the rest single-family homes. Most of the people are tenants; some of the houses are owned by real-estate conglomerates and other ones by industry. Most of the residents are blue-collar workers, largely retired. I would say the average tenure of people living here is 25 years or so. 
 Q. Does everyone know everyone else in Teterboro?
A. Oh yeah, but they're not people that sit on their front porch every night and talk about everything else in the world. They're private people; they go about their business. Somebody needs help, they put out their hand and try to help them out.
Q. How does Teterboro function with only 22 residents?
A. We have five councilman elected at large, and they choose one among themselves as the Mayor. For services, we have an agreement that's going into effect pretty soon, with Moonachie and Little Ferry, for police service. Moonachie takes care of the south half of the borough; Little Ferry takes care of the north. We contract for garbage removal. We contract with Hasbrouck Heights for fire and ambulance services.
Q. Periodically, officials from neighboring municipalities have charged that Teterboro is a tax haven for companies that, because of the borough's small demand for services, pay only a fraction of the property taxes paid by businesses in other towns. They contend that this is unfair to the rest of Bergen County, where many of Teterboro's 15,000 workers live. Hoping to change that, Rose Heck, the local Assemblywoman and Mayor of Hasbrouck Heights, wants the State Legislature to adopt a bill to dissolve and divide Teterboro between neighboring South Hackensack and her own Hasbrouck Heights. What do people in Teterboro think of this?
A. They would like to consolidate all their services, but they want to retain an independent government. In the towns that are contiguous to us, the valuation of properties is much higher than ours, and the tax rate is much higher.
If we merged, the companies here would be affected. And the residents would be affected because these companies that own the properties would pay more taxes -- so now your rent's going to go up. The maintenance of the properties has to go up. The idea would be to say, "Hey, maybe we'll kick these people out. We'll build apartments."
Now the rents are from $500 for multiple-family homes to $750 for single-family. They're old houses with little box rooms, pre-war vintage, with windows that come to up your knees. You can't do too much with them. One problem people always encounter: you can't get a king-size or queen-size bed in them because the doors aren't wide enough.
Q. Has the mix of residents changed in Teterboro?
A. No, the residential aspect has never changed. It's always had between 20 and 28 people. Everybody always took a shaded view of these people, as some kind of nefarious folks there living off the land. I don't think it's quite like that. It isn't the best place to live. It's very noisy, with the planes and the truck traffic, and then with the influx of Route 80 in the 60's right on top of it.
Q. Why do people stay, then?
A. Some people are just locked in here by the economy, or their economy, and then some people just as a way of life. NORIMITSU ONISHI

HEADLINE: Readying Indian Point for the Long Haul

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: BUCHANAN

 BODY:
INDIAN POINT 3, shut for 25 months by management problems, is different these days: it smells of fresh paint, and it is crawling with inspectors from the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, as managers prepare to ask in a few days for permission to reopen the reactor in mid-May.
But the owner, the New York Power Authority, says the bigger challenge is still ahead: making the plant run right for the long haul. Unless it can run well, the Power Authority's president, S. David Freeman, insists, it will not run at all, and the big challenge will come after the plant reopens. 
 First, though, it must have Federal permission to run. When the authority shut the reactor, in February 1993, after various mechanical and procedural problems came to light, it did so voluntarily, but it also promised to get the Nuclear Regulatory Commission's permission before starting up again.
So on Friday, 10 inspectors and a team leader were to finish two weeks of examining the plant. Among the issues were the status of fire protection: some of the actions that operators plan to take in case of fire might not be possible, according to internal analyses, because lighting and ventilation systems would fail. Other items to be resolved include whether the diesel generators, which would power emergency equipment in a blackout, are reliable; whether all the water intakes are properly protected from being blocked by shellfish; whether the control room air-conditioning is adequate, and various other plant systems' performance. The inspectors are also looking at maintenance records, operator training and other "human factors."
Another question is whether managers are responding appropriately to engineers or other staff members who raise safety questions. Two supervisors were disciplined in December and January for comments to a fire engineer who was raising safety issues; the authority's president said that the comments could reasonably have been considered harassment.
But a key ingredient of success, Mr. Freeman, the authority's president, said, would be the staff's ability to question all aspects of operations freely and make improvements. In the months leading up to the shutdown, he said, no one questioned operations, and mechanical problems built up. "By failure to rock the boat, it was sinking," he said.
Tomorrow the Nuclear Regulatory Commission team plans to meet at its headquarters outside Philadelphia to evaluate what it found; if everything meets with the inspectors' approval, the plant could be running again by mid-May. The commission does not plan to say anything until a public meeting is held near the plant on April 27, but Diane P. Screnci, a spokeswoman, said last week, "I haven't heard any bombshells."
"We don't believe that there's any reason why they won't be able to re-start at some point," Ms. Screnci said.
"Whether the mid-May date that they're aiming for is possible, I can't judge at this point," he added.
The long shutdown may, in fact, have addressed most of the problems within the thick, steel-reinforced concrete walls. Outside, though, the environment is as hostile as ever; the state's demand for electric power is still damped down by economic slowdown and technological advances, and the price of the main competing source of energy, natural gas, is stubbornly low.
That means tough competition for a power plant with 1,000 employees. The staff of the Environment Committee of the State Assembly calculated last year that power was available on the open market for 3 cents a kilowatt-hour -- the amount of power needed to run 10 hundred-watt lightbulbs for an hour -- but that the cost for Indian Point 3 was 4.4 cents. In fact, the cost last year was substantially higher, because $148 million was spent, and no power was produced. It was a dismal year, but the reactor is among the worst-performing in the country; it has run only about half the hours it could have since it was commissioned 19 years ago.
Now, Mr. Freeman says, the plant will have to leapfrog in the rankings and run better than three-quarters of the reactors in the United States or it will be closed on the ground that it is uneconomical.
"We intend to be in that category or we will just have to shut it down," Mr. Freeman said to officials gathered at the plant for an open house at the end of last month.
"The toughest part of our job up here is ahead of us," he said. "The restart is just the start; having this plant run both safety and with minimum risk, and economically, is a giant challenge."
Charles Komanoff, a power plant performance expert in New York, said that getting into the top quarter of all plants is a difficult, ever-harder task, because nuclear power plant performance has been improving nationwide. Right now, he said, it means operating about 85 percent of the time, against Indian Point's lifetime average of about 50 percent.
Some plants, in fact, have returned to service after lengthy shutdowns and performed well. Indian Point 2, the near-twin adjacent and run by Consolidated Edison, had personnel and equipment troubles in the early 80's but recently set a world record for days of continuous operation, more than 500.
Others have not returned. Before Mr. Freeman came to New York, he was the head of the Sacramento Municipal Utility District in California, where the Rancho Seco reactor had operated fitfully for years; after an extended period for repairs and a trial run, it broke down again and was scrapped.
Mr. Komanoff said in a telephone interview last week that the plant might run at 85 percent of capacity, justifying its operation. "If the thing ran that high, and also you managed to lock in some cost cutting from the old operations and maintenance levels, you would undercut the grid," he said, referring to power that can be purchased off the electric grid in lieu of running the reactor. The saving, he predicted, could be a few million dollars a year.
But more likely, he said, is that old parts begin to fail, the plant does not run nearly that well and major costs would follow. With the future of the plant far from certain, Power Authority officials acknowledged that they must fight the tendency of some employees to try to hide problems that could cost the plant money. That may have been what happened to the fire protection engineer who raised safety problems, officials said.
Mr. Freeman said that the authority had responded appropriately, by having William Cahill Jr., the chief nuclear officer, discipline the supervisors. "Cahill has chewed out everybody and his uncle," Mr. Freeman said. One supervisor was removed from issues involving fire protection, and, Mr. Freeman said of the fire engineers, "We're putting our arms around these people.'
Indian Point will run well, the managers insisted, because the people who work there have embarked on a "culture change" of paying excruciating attention to detail and questioning the safety impact of every error. For example, in a conference room where plant executives briefed officials and reporters last month, they displayed a blackboard on which a committee had written an extensive diagnosis of why a team of technicians had recently been sent to fix two switches that control water flows in the plant, with a work order that specified the wrong switches.
In nuclear plants, which have multiple redundant systems, the mistake is common and serious: if the reactor has two valves for each job and one is faulty, if the technicians take apart the one that is working right and look for a problem, the plant may be forced to shut because the only one left is faulty.
In the bad old days, said Leslie M. Hill, the resident manager, no one would have bothered to analyze why the error had occurred.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MANHATTAN UP CLOSE;
How the Budget Bite Might Feel

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
Sometimes budget battles in Albany can seem no more urgent than the sound of distant thunder: a dull roar of name-calling, worst-case scenarios and best-case projections. But even Gov. George E. Pataki's supporters agree that his proposed budget cuts would cause some pain throughout the state, and opponents have organized protests. The Governor says the cuts are needed to close a budget gap of more than $4 billion and to pay for a $750 million tax cut that he insists is crucial for the state to have a competitive economy and attract businesses and jobs.
 Governor Pataki and legislative leaders are now wrangling over the severity of the reductions. To get a sense of how the city might be affected, the map below takes one borough -- Manhattan -- and details some ripples anticipated either directly from cuts in state aid or from belt-tightening by local agencies responding to reductions. Some of these scenarios are offered by the agencies themselves or by advocates for programs. In addition, reductions in state aid will be compounded by other cuts in city and Federal programs. 
 Many cuts proposed by the Governor are to agencies that operate throughout the city, so their potential effect on individual neighborhoods is hard to gauge precisely. For example, the planned 90-day limit on home relief -- welfare payments to some single adults -- could reduce state benefits $224 million out of $2.9 billion citywide. Manhattan Borough President Ruth W. Messinger estimates nearly $24 million of that would be in Washington Heights and Harlem. BRUCE LAMBERT
