HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Hollywood 1, Japanese 0

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
YOICHI MORISHITA, the president of the giant Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, finally ended a months-long silence last weekend and paid a chilly 35-minute visit to the Beverly Hills home of Lew Wasserman, the chairman of MCA Inc. With a minimum of small talk, Mr. Morishita confirmed to the legendary Hollywood chieftain that he had sold control of MCA to the Seagram Co. without consulting MCA's management.
With that, Mr. Morishita climbed back into his car, closed the door on this bitter chapter in both companies' histories, and jetted back to Japan nursing a big financial loss and memories of a failed strategy.
 
A Bitter End
 Matsushita's flight from a business it had entered with great optimism just five years before marked a humiliating conclusion to the single largest investment a Japanese company has made in the United States; Matsushita had acquired MCA, an entertainment conglomerate that includes Universal Pictures, for $6.6 billion and has now sold 80 percent for $5.7 billion, suffering a big loss in terms of yen because the dollar is far weaker now than it was five years ago. 
 But perhaps the most telling aspect of the story was this: Each side effectively admitted that despite the high hopes, huge sums and time committed to the relationship, they had learned almost nothing about each other, and were parting as strangers.
"They never really understood our business," said Sidney J. Sheinberg, MCA's president. "But the problems you had with this particular relationship were really about the changes they went through over the last several years."
When Matsushita made the investment it was flush with billions of dollars because Japan's economy was booming. It also believed (like its main rival, the Sony Corporation) that as a maker of hardware like audio and video tape players, it could overpower less wealthy competitors by seizing control of the "software" that ran on the machines.
It was a disaster. Executives in Hollywood, it turned out, believed that the future lay in linking the software not with the boxes that played movies and music (which were freely available), but with electronic systems for distributing the software, like cable systems and television networks. When MCA's executives sought to acquire such a system (they tried to take part in a joint bid for CBS), Matsushita failed to agree that the move was necessary -- and, in any event, Japan's economy had fallen into a steep recession that had left Matsushita weak.
The proposal was rejected, and the stage was set for last week's angry divorce. It was not because of the deep cultural differences that some had anticipated, but because of an unbridgeable chasm in business logic.
 
Getting It Wrong
 "We thought they would bring the capital we needed to expand," said Mr. Sheinberg. "It turned out to have the opposite effect. We ended up with money in our pockets personally but none of the strategic advantages. They ended up with none of the strategic benefits and less money in their pockets."
In a way, he might have been talking about the increasingly awkward relationship between Japan and the United States. Matsushita's purchase of MCA had marked the crest of the greatest flood tide of capital to wash across the globe in history. From 1985 through 1990, a highly confident Japan invested more than $650 billion abroad. Nearly half of that went to the United States.
On this side of the Pacific, the investments were often met with a fear that a resurgent Japan was undermining American economic independence. In Japan, theywere seen as symbols of that country's strength and the superiority of its economic strategy. Cooler heads saw signs of the growing interdependence of two countries.
What we now know is that in a great many instances the Japanese investors paid way too much, often got fleeced, and rarely understood what they were in for. (It remains to be seen whether Seagram, a spirits company, does any better with its investment in the mercurial entertainment business.)
As a result of the number of bad investments, many Japanese companies are now taking flight. According to Kenneth Leventhal & Co., a real estate concern that tracks Japanese investment, Japanese companies sold off nearly $5 billion of American real estate in 1994 and may sell as much as $10 billion this year, much of it at steep losses.
 
Lessons
 And while the investments entered the country with much hand-wringing and fear, many have left almost no visible marks on the American economic landscape, aside from making a few clever people rich.
"Will there be some lasting effect from all this?" asked Robert W. Dziubla, a lawyer here who has worked extensively with Japanese companies. "You bet, but it will be in Japan, not here."
However, a number of Japan experts warn that the investment debacle should not be seen as a long-term withdrawal of Japan from the international markets, or from the United States. "In retrospect it seems we blew the fears in this particular case way out of proportion," said Mark Mason, a professor at Yale University who studies Japanese overseas investments. "But there is legitimate cause for concern still, because Japanese multinationals do behave differently when they invest overseas.
"This is a short-term black eye for both the companies and the government," he added. "They both participated in a bad strategic decision. But in the long term I think they were right. Japanese industry has to move overseas. You can look at problems like these as tuition payments. I think they've learned quite a bit from all of this. At some point, we'll see how they apply those lessons."

HEADLINE: U.S. Is Critical Of Tokyo Plan To Rein In Yen

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: SANUR, Indonesia, Sunday, April 16

 BODY:
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin told his Japanese counterpart this morning that the emergency financial package Japan issued last week was so vague that it had failed to reverse the fall of the dollar against the yen. And the Secretary pressed for far more action before the currency gyrations threaten the economic stability of the world's biggest trading region.
The meeting with Japan's Finance Minister, Masayoshi Takemura, came at the opening of a meeting of finance ministers from around the Pacific on the resort island of Bali. A senior Administration official who took part in the session said that Mr. Takemura, a politician with no financial background prior to assuming his post last year, conceded that the package announced by Tokyo had "not been received favorably by the market and by market analysts." 
 The official said Mr. Takemura had promised more specific action to stimulate Japan's economy and deregulate its market in the next month or so. But American officials clearly fear that could be too little, too late, and that the dollar could fall even further in the interim.
Emerging from the meeting, Mr. Rubin also said that the Japanese had inquired whether the United States was interested in bolstering the dollar by issuing Treasury bonds denominated in Japanese yen rather than in dollars.
"He asked it rather than suggested it," said Mr. Rubin, who is on his first extended international trip as Treasury Secretary. "And I told him we had no intention of doing so."
The idea of issuing American securities in yen has been floated in recent days, by both Americans and Japanese, as a quick fix to the exchange rate troubles that are resounding around the world. The theory is that Japanese investors, as well as other investors around the world, would feel more secure buying a yen-denominated bond because it would insulate them from any further fall in the dollar. If the dollar did fall after the bonds were issued, the cost would be born by the United States Government, which would have to pay back the bondholders in more valuable Japanese yen.
But such a bond issue would be highly unusual and, in the eyes of many American officials, a bit demeaning to their own currency. It might also relieve the pressure on Japan to take some of the fundamental steps needed to bring the currencies back in line, including opening its markets, just when American officials are urging the rest of Asia to intensify that pressure.
There was no sign that the meeting had achieved agreement on how to correct the startling 16 percent fall of the dollar against the yen in recent months.
A brief statement issued by the two countries afterward said that Mr. Rubin and Mr. Takemura, who came to office in a political deal that brought the current, shaky Japanese coalition Government to power, agreed that the currency shift "by no means reflects the economic fundamentals." They promised to "consult closely and to cooperate as appropriate" in coming weeks, the code words used among finance ministers to try to convince the markets that the two Governments will act in concert to reverse any further fall of the dollar. But in recent weeks, that cooperation appears to have been spotty, and it has usually not worked.
Though Mr. Rubin described today's meeting as "in tone, cordial," it clearly came at a time of sharp tensions with Tokyo over what American officials term Japan's intransigence in opening its automobile and auto parts markets to far more foreign goods. Autos were supposed to be an important part of a broader agreement President Clinton negotiated in 1993, but last week the Administration publicly warned Japan that it would move to impose tariffs on billions of dollars in Japanese products if major progress was not made in the next three weeks.
The dollar's troubles and the yen's surge have loomed over this meeting. Many countries throughout the Pacific borrowed yen heavily from Japan throughout the 1980's and the first half of the 90's to pay for public works projects, and now find themselves paying far more on those loans then they had bargained for.
Moreover, the yen's surge seems bound to accelerate Japan's race into Southeast Asia, as Japanese companies -- struggling to regain their competitiveness as the costs of their products soar -- rush to move more factories out of Japan. For example, here in Indonesia, a boom in Japanese investments in assembly lines is under way, totaling $1.56 billion last year. It is a welcome development for many in this country, one of the 10 "big emerging markets" that the Clinton Administration has focused on to gain a foothold for American business.
The yen's rise also complicates the region's delicate power relationships, especially as many nations in Asia prepare to celebrate their liberation from Japanese occupation 50 years ago this summer. While countries in the region have always courted Japanese investors, they have usually kept their foreign exchange reserves in dollars, creating a strong link with the American economy. Now countries like Taiwan are rethinking the wisdom of that strategy, having watched their reserves dwindle in buying power compared with the yen.
The disagreement over what to do about the dollar mirrors a larger argument over which of the world's two largest economic powers bears more responsibility for the fall of the dollar. The Japanese have long argued that the fundamental problem lies in Washington's addiction to deficit spending and its unwillingness to act decisively to cut expenditures.
American officials counter that the real problem is an overly strong yen, not a weak dollar, and that it is only made worse by what they see as Japan's dithering on broad economic reforms that have been discussed for years. They contend that it is up to the Japanese Government to find ways both to stimulate Japan's economy and bring in a burst of imports. That, in turn, should cut Japan's $64 billion trade surplus and presumably bring the yen and the dollar back into each other's orbit.
But Mr. Rubin's aides grimaced when they saw the much-heralded new economic plan, because it included no numbers and few specific commitments. The markets were also unimpressed -- the dollar did not recover in Tokyo trading on Friday -- and an unusually large number of Japanese economists have denounced the effort as insufficient.
A large number of ideas put forth in the plan, like strengthening Japan's Fair Trade Commission to bolster competition, are chestnuts that have been around for years and that are discussed with renewed vigor whenever there is a re-eruption of American-Japanese trade conflicts.
The element of Japan's package that most pleased the United States was a reduction of its discount rate to 1 percent, from 1.75 percent, although American officials expressed skepticism about whether any changes in rates already so low could move the currency markets. The biggest element of the plan was an offer to speed up Japan's deregulation effort, as well as to spend more on public works and to allow the resumption of deficit spending in hopes that it will lift the Japanese economy out of its doldrums.
But the powerful Japanese Government bureaucracy managed to take any targets or numerical goals out of the plan, and the result was a patchwork that American officials regarded as little more than a restatement of unmet past commitments.
For Mr. Rubin, the trip to Indonesia, to be followed by four days in India, is an effort both to acquaint himself with America's challenges in Asia and to deliver some uncomfortable messages.
The challenge is to position the United States to help finance and build some of the world's largest public works projects. In a speech in Los Angeles on his way here, the Treasury Secretary estimated that Asia will need about $1 trillion in dams and power stations, new telephone networks and highways during the next five years.
But he is also facing growing skepticism about the speed with which the United States is pressing Asian countries to open their markets, liberalize their investment laws and let markets rule. Mexico's financial disaster has made many other fast-growing economies leery, and Mr. Rubin has said he wants to disseminate the lessons of those mistakes widely, so they are not repeated.

HEADLINE: Britain Is Streamlining Its Bureaucracy, Partly by Privatizing Some Work

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: LONDON, April 15

 BODY:
At a time when voters nearly everywhere are demanding more efficiency from government, Britain has undertaken one of the world's most comprehensive efforts to slash costs and improve services.
The Conservative Government transformed the nation's economy in the 1980's under Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher by throwing slow-moving, inefficient state-owned industries into the free-market fray. Now her successor, John Major, is applying the same market-oriented ideology to the Government bureaucracy by making it compete with the private sector and meet explicit performance goals. 
 Britain's program, which has been put into place gradually during the last several years, is being studied by Vice President Al Gore's staff as part of his program to reduce Government waste and red tape. The British program's breadth, the Government's strong commitment to it and early signs of success make it a fertile source of ideas for similar programs in the United States and elsewhere, experts say.
"There's a lot to be learned from their experience, and thematically the two efforts are very much linked around the notion of service to citizens," said Elaine C. Kamarck, the head of the program in Mr. Gore's office.
Like many countries, Britain has put a heavy emphasis on reducing costs by bringing in outside concerns for routine tasks. This effort was estimated to have saved 20 percent of costs for the agencies involved. It also serves as a warning to civil servants that they could lose their jobs unless they find ways to cut costs and improve quality.
But Britain's program goes farther by clarifying what is expected of agencies, requiring them to set and meet performance targets, and by giving them more flexibility.
In one of the sharpest changes, the Prison Service has hired outside contractors to run four of its 128 prisons, saving up to 25 percent a prisoner in operating costs. It is about to award contracts to private companies to design, build and manage two more prisons. It has also contracted privately for the job of transporting prisoners in some regions between jails and courts.
Civil service unions and the opposition Labor Party have attacked the program for creating hardships by eliminating or transferring to the private sector 27,000 of more than 500,000 civil service positions in the last three years. And they have criticized Mr. Major's administration for placing too much emphasis on what they consider dubious measurements of bottom-line savings and for diminishing direct Government accountability for public services.
Critics have also attacked the Government for spending too much in the drive to find more efficient ways of operating. The opposition Liberal Democrats calculated that the Government spent $1.36 billion last year hiring outside consultants. The level was 17 percent higher than the previous year, and few Government departments would or could identify any resulting savings.
"The Government record on management consultants is spend, spend, spend, in direct contrast to the cut, cut, cut they've imposed on the British people," said Malcolm Bruce, a Member of Parliament who conducted the Liberal Democrats' study.
Because the program is difficult to explain, the public has taken notice largely when something went wrong. But there is little question that the program has had an effect. The Passport Agency found that it could save $2 million a year by having outside companies print passports. The Inland Revenue Service, the tax agency, found that it could save up to $300 million during the next decade by contracting out the management of its data bases and computer systems. The Driver Vehicle and Licensing Agency met its goal of improving overall efficiency by 2.5 percent.
Smaller countries have also attacked Government waste and inefficiency. What sets Britain's program apart, experts said, is its progress in breaking a large bureaucracy down into smaller units, each with its own chief executive and its own contract with the Government that sets financial and performance targets.
"The U.K. has gone gone further in reinventing government than any country other than New Zealand," said David Osborne, who runs the Reinventing Government Network, a consulting concern based in St. Paul, Minn. "What they have in place in Britain is a very powerful framework."
The British efficiency effort has three major parts. The "citizen's charter" requires all agencies that deal directly with the public to publish service standards and quality goals and to announce each year how they have performed. The market testing program encourages agencies to buy goods and services from private companies when it will save money. And the "next steps" program has created more than 100 agencies out of the much larger Government departments, defined their jobs and required them to set measurable goals each year.
Although there are no immediate penalties for failure, the program increasingly ties the pay and promotion prospects of civil servants running the agencies to their success in meeting their targets. The Government is hiring more officials from the private sector to run the agencies, and putting them on fixed-term contracts that allow them to be dismissed if they do not get results. Some contracts provide for bonuses if they meet their goals.
The "next step" agencies operate under the umbrella of half a dozen major Government departments. In addition to the tax agency and the Royal Mint, the new agencies have functions as diverse as cartography, veterinary laboratory services, quality control for medicines and army base repair.
The Prison Service, for instance, technically remains part of the Home Office, the nation's biggest bureaucracy, but in practice has been reorganized under its own chief executive and its own board of directors and given more freedom to adopt new operating policies.
Last year, the Prison Service's goals were to reduce the number of escapes, to reduce overcrowding, to increase the number of prisoners with 24-hour access to bathrooms, to insure that prisoners spent more time in "purposeful" activity, to increase the proportion of prisoners able to leave their cells for at least 12 hours a day, to give a larger number of prisoners more than their minimum visiting rights, and to bring down per-prisoner costs. It met its targets in all but one area.
By the Government's accounting, the early stages of the program have yielded encouraging results in most agencies. In the 30 months that ended on Sept. 30, Government agencies had conducted 799 "market tests" to see whether using private contractors would save money.
The reviews covered nearly $3.2 billion of Government work, and resulted in more than $1.8 billion in contracts going to the private sector. The Government calculated the overall savings at nearly $650 million, or about 20 percent.
Of the 275 quality targets set by the 104 agencies taking part in the program last year, 214 were met, according to Government figures. Of 137 financial targets, 109 were met.
Critics argued that the statistics overstate the real savings, especially when job losses are taken into account. But the Government remains unswayed by opponents of its market-oriented approach.
"In the 1970's we said government should not be involved in making steel or cars or running the telephone system," Mr. Clarke said. "So it will be with the reform of the working of government. Ten years from now many people will be wondering what all the fuss was about."

HEADLINE: Public Radio, a Lifeline In Alaska, Facing Cuts

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: ANCHORAGE, Alaska, April 15

 BODY:
Corey Flintoff's voice reaches the remote corners of the nation's largest and most sparsely populated state every weekday, delivering the world's news from his desk in the nation's capital. As a newscaster for National Public Radio, Mr. Flintoff is heard in many out-of-the-way places, but none so isolated as the Yupik Eskimo villages of southwest Alaska.
In these tiny communities, where children still learn their native language before English and families subsist on fish, game and berries gathered near their homes, public radio is a lifeline, not just to the nation's capital but to family and neighbors. 
 Personal messages like birth announcements and grocery lists are commonly heard on Alaska's far-flung public radio stations. So are the latest commercial fishing openings and the occasional tsunami warning. And weather, always the weather.
These small stations are more essential to their communities than the average university station in the lower 48 states, said Mr. Flintoff, who started his career in Alaska public radio.
"It plays a central role," he said. "That's the beauty of it."
But it is a lifeline that may be cut. Across Alaska more than two dozen public radio stations are bracing for budget reductions that threaten to end their broadcasts, which are especially cherished in the rural areas where the residents are few and mainly native Alaskans.
The conservative mood that swept the nation in November also took hold in this politically independent state, giving the Republican Party control of both houses of the Alaska Legislature for the first time since the 1960's. Promising to shrink a state budget viewed as out of control, the majority is taking its knife to every program deemed a frill. Public broadcasting is one of those.
Last week the State House of Representatives approved a spending plan that cut the Alaska Public Broadcasting Commission's $6 million budget in half. The leadership informed the broadcasting agency that it intended to end support for the state's four public television stations and drastically reduce financing for radio in communities that have a commercial radio station.
Senate budget writers have made similar reductions, taking less from radio but entirely eliminating the broadcasting commission, which distributes the money. The differences will be worked out in a conference committee.
Representative Vic Kohring, chairman of the House committee that oversaw the public broadcasting budget, said he was merely carrying out the majority's pledge to reduce state spending by $70 million next year. Alaska's budget is $2.5 billion this year and the state faces annual deficits of $500 million for the next several years because of a continuing long-term decline in oil and gas royalties paid to the state. A decline in prices and production dates from the 1980's.
"I personally enjoy public radio and TV," said Mr. Kohring, a freshman Republican from Wasilla. "It gets down to basic and raw economics. We don't have enough dollars to fund everything."
Mr. Kohring's list of essential services includes roads, schools and programs for the elderly, but he all but eliminated state money for the arts.
Alaska broadcasters and legislative Democrats view the cuts as copycat politics, a mean-spirited, local version of the Contract With America in Congress. They said a state with a $15 billion savings account -- the Alaska Permanent Fund -- and no state income or sales tax does not need to cripple its information delivery system. The fund, financed by gas and oil revenues, provides dividends of almost $1,000 a resident a year. It is considered politically untouchable.
"What's happening in Alaska is the Republicans are trying to copy what the Republicans are doing nationally, what Newt Gingrich is doing," said Senator Jim Duncan, Democrat of Juneau. "I think it's a step back into the Dark Ages."
Alaska natives see the reductions as an attack on a group with no voice in a Legislature now controlled by conservative, urban Alaskans.
"People are really scared out here," said Russell Nelson, who lives in the Bristol Bay community of Dillingham. "If they can take away the statewide news and weather forecast that people use on a day-to-day basis, what else can they take away?"
Legislators of both parties say that support for public broadcasting has been overwhelming, with thousands of telephone calls, letters and faxes pouring into their offices from across the state.
The communities where public radio is most valued are the ones where it is also the most fragile. In these kinds of towns the only place you can get to by road is the garbage dump and the daily newspaper from Anchorage may not arrive for a week. Small stations that are barely hanging on now would lose all Federal financing if they have fewer than five employees, and broadcasters said several stations were likely to become repeaters, just relaying the signal from a larger station.
In Sitka, a coastal town of 8,000, Raven Radio, as station KCAW-FM is known, brings weather forecasts, fishing reports and news to six towns and a large fishing fleet in the eastern Gulf of Alaska.
"We're the daily newspaper and the information highway for southeast Alaska," said the general manager, Barnaby Dow. The station broadcasts to the Tlingit Indian villages of Yakutat, more than 250 miles up the coast, and Kake, 100 miles southeast, and tiny fishing settlements in between.
"We're the only source of news about what's going on in Juneau, other parts of the state and Washington, D.C.," Mr. Dow said. "In a rural state like Alaska, that's not window dressing. That's essential to us debating and dealing with public policy."
Mr. Flintoff got his start as a country and western disk jockey at station KYUK in Bethel, the largest town in the Yukon-Kuskokwim delta region of southwest Alaska. KYUK broadcasts many programs in the Yupik language, from the day's news to stories by village elders.
"For young people in the villages who are increasingly subjected to this onslaught of outside TV and movies, they need something that will validate their own culture on the air," Mr. Flintoff said.
"It's pretty wonderful to be out in a remote place and turn on the radio and hear a native voice speaking Yupik. That voice is not doing some kind of traditional museum performance. It's relaying immediate information."

HEADLINE: Soviet-Style Rule in Uzbekistan Provides a Bearable Life 'if We Are Quiet'

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER 

DATELINE: TASHKENT, Uzbekistan

 BODY:
Life in the countries of the former Soviet Union just keeps getting messier. There are civil wars and tentative stabs at democracy; there is economic mayhem and the political chaos that goes with it.
There are also many new freedoms. Not here, though. Here they rely on the old ways: simplicity, fear and repression. 
 Uzbekistan is a country locked deep in the Soviet past, where cars are constantly stopped and searched for no reason, and a cautious pedestrian's eyes are always focused on the ground. In March, 99.6 percent of the republic's 11 million voters turned out to extend President Islam A. Karimov's term to the year 2000. He was unopposed.
The only way to speak freely with someone here is to rendezvous on a park bench. Generals in the Interior Ministry -- the powerful police force that helps run the country -- are referred to, without irony, as commissars. It is a title that made Soviet citizens shudder for decades until it was discarded, along with the worst excesses of Communism.
The President's epigrammatic sayings are taught from kindergarten through medical school. There is even a little Mao-sized phrase book.
"We live in a police state that would have made the old Bolsheviks proud," said Shukrulla R. Mirsaidov, 56, a former Vice President and Prime Minister. He is among the last outspoken opposition figures who have not fled the country or been jailed, in part because he is under constant surveillance.
"Independence for us has been a cruel joke," he said in an interview in his apartment. "The people have been cheated. The state controls them all in the name of peace and stability -- and, of course, in the name of the state."
Stability has become a secular religion in Uzbekistan under Mr. Karimov, a former Soviet official and economist. He controls everything from the secret industrial production plans to the schedule for sweeping this sprawling capital's streets.
Mr. Karimov, the first leader of independent Uzbekistan, has stayed in power by locking up many of his opponents. Uzbeks and foreigners agree that his grip is absolute.
Gaudy posters with pictures and sayings like "Struggle for the future of the Motherland" appear on buildings and billboards at least every block. Critics say Mr. Karimov's country is rapidly on its way to becoming another China or, for those who are more charitable, Singapore.
The third-largest republic of the old Soviet Union, with 23 million people -- only Russia and Ukraine are larger -- Uzbekistan was transformed into a virtual cotton plantation during Soviet rule, and it still grows more cotton than any country except the United States.
It was settled in the 15th century by descendants of Genghis Khan, but its civilization stretches nearly 2,500 years to the legendary Silk Road cities of Samarkand and Bukhara. Conquered at various times by Alexander the Great, Muslim invaders, Mongols, Turks and Russians, it has always been a turbulent place -- the fiery crucible of Central Asia.
That has rarely been more true than now, with its current borders touching on the four other new countries in the region, Turkmenistan, Kazakhstan, Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan, as well as on Afghanistan.
It is hard to look at the geography of the country, which is the size of California, without at least partly understanding the overriding craze for order. Neighboring Tajikistan has been in flames almost since its independence in 1992. Its civil war has been particularly bloody, and people here have watched most of it on television.
The situation to the south in Afghanistan, where fundamentalist faction leaders and drug merchants roam unchecked, is even worse. Uzbeks quickly remind any visitor that nearly a quarter of the 13,000 Soviet soldiers who died in the long, fruitless war for Afghanistan were from their republic. It is a legacy nobody can forget.
"Take a good look around this region and tell me where you would rather live," asked Zafar Ruzeyev, a spokesman for the Foreign Ministry. "We see this problem of human rights and developing countries differently than you do in the West. You always talk about this abstract notion of freedom. But people are not prepared for democracy here. What they are prepared for, and what they want, is stability."
No one could argue that he is at least partly right. Compared with any of its neighbors, Uzbekistan is flourishing in many ways. And it is stable. A stroll across the main Charcu Market in the center of Tashkent is a delight for anyone who has visited similar markets in other countries of the former Soviet Union.
Lamb is fresh, plentiful and cheap enough at less than $1 a pound for most people to buy. Long wooden tables groan with the same spices that enticed Marco Polo: cloves, rosemary and basil. Peppers lie in enormous heaps. Stalls with many types of bread, all fresh, ring the market.
"We know that the President is not kind," said a 37-year-old merchant with a mouth full of tin teeth and a patch over his right eye, who sold roasted peanuts. Like most people in Uzbekistan, he spoke on condition of anonymity. "We know that the country is not always kind. But we can live well here if we are quiet. There is no war, no famine. If we are quiet we are left alone."
In this part of the world, that is a deal that is increasingly hard to come by and one that many people accept in the same spirit in which they used to accept Soviet rule. They go about their lives quietly nodding to power and doing what they want. It is the only way, for example, to explain the economy.
According to United Nations figures, this is one of the poorest developed countries in the world, where people earn less than $50 a month. Even during Soviet times it had among the lowest per capita incomes in the region.
Peasants have an average of 10 children, the population growth rate is among the highest in the world and more than half of the people are younger than 15.
But it is also a country where everyone appears to eat well, and where from one end of the vast country to the next, food is always for sale at prices people can afford. Even now, few markets in Moscow have the diversity, quality and consistency of the items available in most of Uzbekistan.
"The Uzbek who lives in his house privately on what he grows is better off than many Russians," said Volodya Shatorov, an economist who works for the Agriculture Ministry here. "What is not reflected in income levels is that this is an agrarian society, where people know how to live off the land. Factories that close or do not pay their wages -- while a problem here, too -- do not have the same impact as they do in many Russian cities."
Mr. Karimov manages to keep 115 different nationalities from butchering each other -- with heavy-handed tactics, of course. But compared with what is going on in many former Soviet republics, it is an achievement. His rejection of Islamic fundamentalism is as welcome in the West as his human rights record is deplored.
Many Westerners feared that Central Asia, particularly Uzbekistan, would embrace Islamic fundamentalism after the dissolution of the Soviet Union. That has not occurred, although there are pockets of extremism. A more secular form of Islam predominates.
"The people who run this country see Islamic fundamentalism as something approaching a return to the Middle Ages," said an official of a Western organization that has long been based here. "This is way off their personal values. They don't want ties to those societies where a return to Islam is a great development. As long as Mr. Karimov can keep the mullahs from sweeping across the steppes, the West will find some way to deal with him."

HEADLINE: Use of Hydrogen as Fuel Is Moving Closer to Reality

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 15

 BODY:
Buoyed by renewed political interest and technological promise, efforts are being stepped up to make hydrogen an important source of energy in the United States.
For decades, advocates of hydrogen have promoted it as the fuel of the future: an abundant, environmentally clean source of energy for power plants, airplanes, automobiles, homes and just about everything a modern society finds essential. 
 Advocates of a hydrogen economy say that unlike gasoline and other fossil fuels, with their noxious combustion byproducts, hydrogen produces nothing worse than water when it burns. And it can be used to produce electricity directly through chemical reactions in a device called a fuel cell.
Surely hydrogen would be the preferable fuel in many cases, its supporters have argued, if only a few problems could be overcome, like finding a cheap method for extracting it from water or natural gas, and setting up a storage and distribution network.
Although the technical problems remain, hydrogen's political future suddenly seems brighter. One of the gas's leading advocates is Representative Robert S. Walker, Republican of Pennsylvania, who became chairman of the House Science Committee in January. He is sponsoring a bill to increase the Department of Energy's $10 million annual budget for hydrogen research by $100 million over the next three years.
"Hydrogen has amazing potential and it should have its chance," Mr. Walker said in an interview. "We have the ability to overcome a lot of the problems other people see with hydrogen and, if we can make it work, it would fundamentally change the country." Mr. Walker, who is also vice chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, said his bill had a good chance of surviving the new, budget-cutting Congress because it would redirect Energy Department money from other projects and calls for no new spending.
The advantages of hydrogen as a fuel include energy independence and perhaps dispensing with many antipollution regulations, "and that's something that's attractive to conservatives like myself," Mr. Walker said.
Representative George E. Brown, the California Democrat who formerly headed the Science Committee, said he previously supported work on hydrogen but opposed the bill because it would drain money from other energy research. "I don't think you can justify that rapid an increase in funding," he said, "particularly since everything we do siphons money from something else. There will be some increase in funds for hydrogen, but I don't think the Appropriations Committee or the House will vote for all the money he wants."
Senator Tom Harkin, a Democrat from Iowa, said he would be promoting a similar bill on the other side of the Capitol, but could not guess what its prospects were. "I don't know if it's high on anybody's agenda except mine right now," he said. Generally, the Government should support only basic research, he said, but in the case of a few technologies like hydrogen, it should assume a more active role, like sponsoring demonstration projects with industry and purchasing hydrogen-fueled vehicles to help create a market.
Hydrogen researchers from universities, Government laboratories and private companies say their incipient industry has already produced cars and trucks that would be ready to market if problems of fuel supply and distribution could be solved. At an annual meeting sponsored by the National Hydrogen Association, held last month in a Washington suburb, participants rode in a modified golf cart powered by electricity from a new type of fuel cell and cruised around in a Ford pickup with an engine that engineers at the University of California at Riverside had modified to burn compressed hydrogen.
Edward Trlica, president of Energy Partners, a company in West Palm Beach, Fla., that makes the modified cart, said such vehicles were ready for fleet use now in places where there could be an assured hydrogen supply, like bus and shuttle routes that operate from fixed depots. By the end of the year, he said, the company expected to be operating five of the 11-passenger carts as a test at the airport in Palms Springs, Calif.
John J. Kennedy, an executive at Allied Signal Inc., who is chairman of the board of the association, said hydrogen work was being pursued aggressively in Japan and across Europe, where gasoline prices are three to four times as high as in the United States. "In this country, people are in a wait-and-see mode because oil prices are so low," he said, "and that's why we still need some Government assistance to move the technology until the market here is ready."
Economics and concerns about hydrogen's safety could limit its wider use for decades, others contend. Current ways of producing hydrogen from water or natural gas are expensive and require large amounts of energy, said Dr. Saifur Rahman, director of the Center for Energy and Global Environment at Virginia Polytechnic Institute and University in Blacksburg. In addition, he believes people will probably balk at having hydrogen pipelines or storage tanks put in their communities because of concerns about cost and safety.
Advocates say hydrogen, even when stored under pressure, can be handled safely. The fuel in the tank of a hydrogen-powered car, for instance, is far less volatile than gasoline and, if the tank is ruptured, hydrogen gas would dissipate quickly into the air. Even if a spark ignited the gas, proponents say, it would burn away rapidly and cause less damage than gasoline. "People are used to gasoline and forget how dangerous it can be," said James Heffel, an engineer working with the University of California hydrogen truck.
Neil P. Rossmeissl, manager of the hydrogen program at the Energy Department, said the nation spent about $10 million a year on hydrogen research through the National Renewable Energy Laboratory in Golden, Colo. In addition, he said, the Government spent more than $110 million on research related to hydrogen work.
"We are working on the production, storage and infrastructure for distribution of hydrogen," Mr. Rossmeissl said. "Hydrogen has been considered the long shot for the country's energy needs, something that wouldn't be ready until 2030. But we have fuel cells and engines now that can use hydrogen, and should have other end-user technology ready by 2000 or 2005. A problem is getting production technology ready at the same time."
Hydrogen is an extremely abundant element, since there are two atoms of it in every molecule of water. Unfortunately, the atoms are so firmly locked that present methods use more energy to extract hydrogen than can be produced by the fuel. This cost inefficiency makes it suited only for specialized needs, like fueling space rockets or running fuel cells on spacecraft.
Advocates hope the production cost can be brought down with methods like photoelectro-chemistry, a technique developed at the University of Hawaii. In the procedure a thin semiconductor suspended in water produces hydrogen using only the energy of sunlight. This method is being scaled up from laboratory size and could produce a working system in five years, Mr. Rossmeissl said.
Another promising approach, under development at the Government hydrogen laboratory in Colorado, the University of Miami and elsewhere, is based on photobiology, and involves illuminating certain algae or bacteria suspended in water vapor. When exposed to sunlight, the organisms would function as part of a self-generating, living reactor that produced hydrogen and oxygen from the water.
Hydrogen advocates also have hopes for a method that could solve both the production and distribution problem: generating hydrogen from natural gas. Gas companies already make commercial quantities of hydrogen from natural gas in devices called reformers. Natural gas mixed with intensely hot steam produces hydrogen.
If small-scale reformers could be developed and installed at places like airports and the nation's more than 150,000 gasoline stations, the mechanical systems needed for a hydrogen economy could emerge by using the natural gas pipe system already in place, proponents say.
But current reformer technology was developed 25 years ago, Mr. Rossmeissl noted, and little work had been sponsored by the industry to improve it. "We want to develop some base technology in reformers that could be applied to large and small applications, but nothing is being done now," he said. "Some people have some ideas about this, but there is no money for it."
Hydrogen has another major problem: storage. Lightweight hydrogen contains less energy per unit of volume than gasoline or even natural gas, and it must be either compressed or liquefied at extremely low temperatures to be concentrated enough to be a useful fuel. Heavy, bulky vessels, which would consume extra space in vehicles, would be required for storage.
To overcome this problem, researchers have turned to solid-state storage methods that use materials like metal alloys and activated carbon to absorb and retain hydrogen. When containers of these materials are cooled and hydrogen is forced in, the scientists say, the carbon or the alloys, called metal hydrides, can hold concentrations of the fuel comparable to compressed gas systems, but with less weight and bulk. Heating these storage systems or decreasing their internal pressure causes the hydrogen to be released, they say.
Although prototype hydride storage systems are being tested in cars and for other uses, Mr. Rossmeissl said more research was needed on these solid-state storage systems to find the best materials, to see if they could be economically produced and to check whether they remained durable and maintained their storage capacity with repeated loading and unloading.
"Some of the best science being done right now is in hydrogen research," he said. "The biggest problem with hydrogen is still its costs, the cost of producing and storing it, and changing the infrastructure of society to use it."

HEADLINE: A Job Opening in Brooklyn: Poet Laureate

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON 

 BODY:
The Brooklyn poet laureate's study is unused now. There are an old memo pad, books and photographs in the tiny, lamplighted Brooklyn Heights den. A walking stick, polished but untouched, stands in a corner.
And there is a poem taped to the bulletin board. It opens: 
 I have no soil but this hard ground,
Stone and subterranean quarry,
Underground rails, dynamos, steel
Beneath the granite rising, I inhale.
Brooklyn's poet laureate position became vacant March 11. Norman Rosten, poet, playwright, novelist, memoirist, died at age 81. There has already been a musical tribute to Mr. Rosten beside the East River, and there will be a poetry reading and memorial service at Borough Hall in Brooklyn next month.
And then there will be the matter of his title -- poet laureate of Brooklyn -- as well as the question of a possible successor. It is a title at once grand and modest, comic and appropriate and perfect. It is also a title not many in Brooklyn are aware exists.
"Some of you may say, who needs one? And I say we do," Borough President Howard Golden said with a smile when he bestowed the title on Mr. Rosten in 1979. "Someone reminded me that Walt Whitman would have been a better choice. But we wanted a live poet, and Norman was available."
There is no shortage of potential successors, for Brooklyn is deep in poets, people writing in all sorts of languages and voices, dialects, idioms, and, yes, occasionally even couplets. The poets of Brooklyn read their work in a couple of cafes and a lot of classrooms. They appear on the public access cable channels, reading poems about cultural imperialism and about the I.R.T. They sing the body electric, and write about paying the Con Ed bill.
There is an 80-year-old Dutch biologist in Sheepshead Bay who writes poetry on the side and who has published a collection called "Breuckelyn." There is the recently retired "Poet of the D Train," who said he would come out of retirement to accept the poet laureate title. There is Louis Reyes Rivera, a 50-year-old Puerto Rican who maintains that Congress, in a ceremony several years ago, officially named him the poet laureate of Bed-Stuy.
There is Anthony Vitale, the 20-year-old Italian-American poet prodigy in Marine Park who has studied under Allen Ginsberg at Brooklyn College. There is Konstantin K. Kuzminsky, who was born in Leningrad, but who now roams Brighton Beach reciting poems in, he says, 24 languages. And there is Enid Dame, who lives in Brooklyn with her husband and fellow poet, Donald Lev, publishing all sorts of poetry in the Home Planet News, a local literary quarterly.
One of her works ends with the ominously poetic Brooklyn warning, "Anything you don't see will come back to haunt you."
Brooklyn's song of itself, then, keeps being sung.
"In Brooklyn, there is a sense of real culture," said Dennis Nurkse, a poet who lived in Manhattan, Latin America and Europe before arriving in Brooklyn in 1972. "It is the culture of lived lives."
The lives include those of Whitman and Hart Crane and Marianne Moore. Brooklyn was muse to all of them, and to Mr. Rosten. He wrote a book, "Under the Boardwalk," about growing up in Coney Island, and crafted scores of poems informed or infiltrated in one way or another by Brooklyn. Of Brooklyn, he wrote: "At its mere mention, I have seen people smile, groan, look suspicious, back away a step, embrace me, threaten me, pass a hand unsteadily across their faces, weep, stutter, or fall into a trance."
Mr. Golden, aware of Mr. Rosten's output even if he hadn't read all of his works, broached the idea of naming a Brooklyn poet laureate over coffee and bagels one morning 16 years ago.
"Norman was one of the last Brooklyn poets with a secure ability to get published," said Matthew Paris, a poet who has organized readings, workshops and benefits in Brooklyn for decades. "I think Howard Golden invented the idea of a poet laureate of Brooklyn in a moment of caprice. And, I should say, inspiration."
There are no formal duties to the job, certainly no great benefits. And as recounted by Mr. Rosten in a published essay, not much was negotiable when he became the first and only person ever to hold the spectacularly uncompensated position.
"Not even a part-time salary?" Mr. Rosten asked Mr. Golden over coffee that morning.
"It would create problems, believe me," Mr. Golden said.
"Would I have the use of an office, a secretary?" he asked.
"Maybe a work space; no secretary. It's a question of protocol."
"What about a parking space?"
"Absolutely not," Mr. Golden said. "I couldn't even get one for my daughter."
Mr. Golden has remained mostly quiet on the question of a successor to Mr. Rosten.
"The Borough President," said Greg Brooks, Mr. Golden's chief of staff, "is not really focusing on the future."
If and when the Borough President does turn to face the future and contemplate naming a second poet laureate of Brooklyn, the choice will be from a much-changed borough. The tides of immigration and economics have stocked Brooklyn with a different population pool of poets.
There are Arabs in Bay Ridge, a Chinatown in Sunset Park, a small continent of island natives from the Caribbean in Flatbush. Whether moved by political persecution in a foreign country or the loss of a rent-stabilized apartment in Manhattan, the new poets have arrived looking for a place to work, a place to be moved by.
They have bumped into and and mixed with other poets from other places, including those from the old Brooklyn, which might no longer be.
"A real, real Brooklyn person, a real, real Brooklyn poet -- I have no idea what or who that would be," said Leo Vroman, the retired biologist who was born in Holland and has lived in Sheepshead Bay for 40 years, publishing a series of poems about Plum Beach. "It's an interesting question, and I suppose one worth asking."
Answering the question by formal proclamation could be delicate for Mr. Golden, said Richard Bartee, a self-described "public poet" who was known in his heyday as the "Poet of the D Train."
"I call it ego-nomics, because whoever gets the title, potshots will be taken," Mr. Bartee said.
Donald Lev, though, thought he might have a solution.
"Maybe Howard will name himself," said Mr. Lev, a former cabdriver whom other Brooklyn poets have proposed as a candidate. "I don't know, these days, the poet laureate probably would have as much power as the Borough President does. Or doesn't."
More than a handful of Brooklyn poets doubt there will be a successor. But if such a prospect makes them momentarily mournful, it does not exactly break their hearts. Brooklyn has already broken them, and is busy mending them again, as well. The poets are absorbing and distilling everything: the juvenile violence and economic disillusionment, the AIDS and police brutality, the wonders of Prospect Park.
"Brooklyn brings out a provincial side of me that I don't mind confessing to," said Louis Reyes Rivera, who grew up in Bushwick surrounded by Italians, Hasidic Jews, Puerto Ricans and blacks. "But what Brooklyn affords its poets is the opportunity to influence tolerance. Poets, or cultural workers as I call them, can help others understand the beauty of difference."
To other poets, the enduring poetic appeal of Brooklyn is a plainly, powerfully physical phenomenon. Enid Dame talks of "cracked sidewalks and screaming people and flowers growing among them all."
Kimiko Hahn, the daughter of a mother from Maui and a father from Milwaukee, moved to Brooklyn nine months ago and has already written of its gardens and their plum tomatoes "glowing back at the dusk like three firm hearts."
"There is a particular kind of light in Brooklyn -- different, European," said Phyllis Capello, who was born in Bensonhurst and who now lives in Windsor Terrace and who has published a long poem called "Walking into the Dream." "And the ocean is in your vocabulary."
There appears no dictionary large enough to hold the full vocabulary employed by Brooklyn's poets.
Linda Cousins, a poet, edited an anthology called "Black and in Brooklyn," and she said it was loaded with verse about "poverty and race, passion and love." Mervyn Taylor, a Trinidadian, said his poetry and the conversations along Ocean Avenue "have got beyond the nostalgia that came with our self-imposed exile."
"If I stayed too long, it must be for something," said Mr. Taylor, a 53-year-old teacher.
For others, as it has been for ages, Brooklyn, whatever it is, is simply all they know. Anthony Vitale, not yet 21, lives in Marine Park and writes about what he calls "an urban suburbia."
"It would be pretty impossible to find one voice for Brooklyn," he said. "But conversation is what Brooklyn is about because Brooklyn English is different than any other. How people talk to each other in Brooklyn is unlike any other place."
Jamez Nobles, a 16-year-old from Crown Heights, listened to the voice in his head for years, and then began to put that inner monologue on paper. A student at Metropolitan Corporate Academy, he participated this year in a program called Poetry in the Schools.
"I always had poetry in the back of my mind, but it never came out," said Jamez, the oldest of four boys. "Now it is. It's mostly about desires, wants. Brooklyn is an interesting place. I go to Bay Ridge and it's like I'm down South. But I live on Utica Avenue, and Brooklyn can be hard. You see stuff. It's unavoidable. I'm writing it down now. People say it's good. I'm amazed."
Maybe Howard Golden could take a look.
"I hope it doesn't end with my father," Patricia Rosten said of the position of poet laureate. "As someone said when they first heard of the title, 'Oh, good, we in Brooklyn really are civilized.' "

he has a quadruple by-pass, vegetables

where he chats to neighbors

that I'll line up on the sill

like three firm hearts. Who does he talk to
when he talks to himself among the corn stalks?
And who does he recall while he sets the table for one
under the circle of light the size of his plate?
I think to ask but accept the fruit and wave thanks.
The brick wall of our apartment leans against
his identical floor-through. One sunflower
is so tall he ties it to the fence for support. KIMIKO HAHN

Excelsior Fashion Products, Easter
They pay us time and a half
and they don't dare catch us
drinking: we're discreet,
don't pass a bottle, but each sips
a private pint, all sitting
in the narrow room with our backs
to each other, each facing
his work -- router, stain tray,
buffing wheel, drill press --
and with that sweet taste echoing
in our bones, we watch our hands
make what they always made
-- rosewood handles -- but now
we smile in delighted surprise
and when Marchaesi brings our envelopes
they record a full day's work
though it's a still noon,
the processions are still in the streets,
the choirs, the loudspeakers
bellowing Hallelujah: and we change
into our finest clothes in the locker room,
admiring each other's hatbrims, passing bottles
freely until all are empty, and at last
we separate in the brilliant street, each
in the direction of a different tolling bell. DENNIS NURKSE

when the intersection is crazy

Riding the D-Train
Notice the rooftops,
the worm-eaten Brooklyn buildings.
Houses crawl by,
each with its private legend.
In one, a mother
is punishing her child
slowly, with great enjoyment.
In one, a daughter
is writing a novel
she can't show to anyone.
Notice your fellow riders:
that Asian girl chewing a toothpick,
the boy drawing trees on his hand,
the man in a business suit
whose shoes don't match.
Everything is important:
that thin girl, for instance,
in flowered dress, golden high heels.
How did her eyes get scarred?
Why is that old man crying?
Why does that woman carry
a cat in her pocketbook?
Don't underestimate
any of it.
Anything you don't see
will come back to haunt you. ENID DAME

HEADLINE: MCA's Not So Excellent Adventure

 BODY:
No doubt Hollywood breathes easier now that MCA Inc. has come home after its star-crossed Japanese idyll. The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, which bought the entertainment conglomerate in 1990 and has sold it to Seagram, is also pleased. It is rid of a sinkhole that confounded its dreams of transforming the movie and music business. Happiest of all is Edgar Bronfman Jr., the Seagram president, who has a new $5.7 billion toy.
But it is worth noting that the saga of MCA's dealings with Matsushita was an exercise in hubris and self-delusion. Each side viewed the other as ripe for partnership without being clear about the details. Maybe it was racist for some Americans to be upset about the Japanese takeover of such cultural jewels as Columbia Pictures and MCA. The Seagram deal has not, after all, inspired articles about Canada's "invasion" of Hollywood. But there were clearly outmoded cultural stereotypes in the way the two sides dealt with each other. 
 In going after MCA, Matsushita talked of synergy and assumed it would effortlessly capture MCA's library of movies and programs for its video recorders, CD-ROM's, digitalized TV's and the like. Its naive view was that it had bought a well-run, consistently profitable Hollywood studio that would continue to produce international hits.
But instead of "Jurassic Park," Matsushita got "Waterworld," the new Kevin Costner film that looms as the biggest budget buster ever made, and a vortex of change in the world of communications that ruined its plans. Hit by a recession in Japan and a scandal that forced out its high command, the company shrank from the aggressive and risky strategies pushed by the Americans, though it retains 20 percent of MCA as a hedge so it can gain future tie-ins in Hollywood. In the end, Matsushita avoided losing its shirt, which is more than Sony can say about Columbia Pictures, which has run up losses in the billions of dollars.
For their part, the leaders of MCA bought into the illusion -- maybe from "Bridge on the River Kwai" -- that the Japanese would defer respectfully to a venerable corporate elder like Lew Wasserman, whose scheme had been to reap a fortune for himself and tap Matsushita's cash reserves for new company ventures. To their shock, Mr. Wasserman and his deputy, Sidney Sheinberg, had to commute back and forth to Osaka to meet with underlings, without ever persuading the parent company to embark on the projects that were a major reason for selling MCA in the first place. It seems never to have occurred to the Hollywood moguls that Matsushita would not give them carte blanche in acquiring a record company or allying with a television network. They compounded their error by throwing temper tantrums and threatening to take a walk when they did not get their way. Small wonder that Matsushita did not bother even to check with its Hollywood partners when it began negotiating with the Bronfmans.
Bigger than any other Hollywood drama in the offing is the question of which studio conglomerate will win the race to produce and market films, television programs and music in ways unimagined now. At least in the case of MCA the decision is out of the hands of a faceless corporation with no appetite for risk and adventure and in the hands of Mr. Bronfman, a onetime movie producer who will be anything but passive with his investment.

HEADLINE: McNamara's Retreat

BYLINE: By Max Frankel; Max Frankel, a columnist for The New York Times Magazine and a former executive editor of The Times, was a Washington correspondent covering diplomacy and the White House in the 1960's.

 BODY:

IN RETROSPECT
The Tragedy and Lessons of Vietnam.
By Robert S. McNamara with Brian VanDeMark.
Illustrated. 414 pp. New York:
Times Books/Random House. $27.50. 
 IN his 79th year, Robert S. McNamara at long last offers the public a glimpse of his aching conscience. The most willful Vietnam warrior in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations, he was also the first at the top to admit defeat, in private. He then stood silent on the war for a quarter-century and drowned his sorrow in good works at the World Bank. Mr. McNamara personified the slow maturing of America's foreign policy from cocky interventionism to cost-conscious realism, yet for a generation he refused to explain his conversion, explore his mistakes, judge his colleagues or instruct posterity. The pain, or the guilt, was simply too great. As he states in the preface to "In Retrospect": "This is the book I planned never to write."
Until now, he contends, the story of how "the best and the brightest" got it wrong in Vietnam has not been told. But David Halberstam, who applied that ironic phrase to his rendering of the tale 23 years ago, told it better in many ways than Mr. McNamara does now. So, too, did the Pentagon Papers, that huge trove of documents assembled at Mr. McNamara's behest when he first recognized a debt to history. The contemporary analyses in the papers, which were leaked to The Times in 1971, stand up so well that they now serve their patron as a major source.
What Mr. McNamara adds to the public record are some White House documents and tape transcripts revealing, most notably, his own agonized attempts in 1967 to persuade President Lyndon B. Johnson to stop sending more men to the slaughter: the Secretary of Defense who had come to tame the Pentagon with managerial wizardry ended up desperately begging for a fig leaf for withdrawal, in the form of a coalition that would inevitably give the Vietcong dominance in Saigon. Mr. McNamara says he does not know to this day whether he thus quit or was fired. "Maybe it was both."
But he left with a whimper, not a bang. So why speak out now? The main reason, he says, is that he has "grown sick at heart witnessing the cynicism and even contempt" with which so many Americans view their institutions and leaders. He knows how much Vietnam contributed to that disaffection; he would never deny the war's terrible damage. But he hopes to prove that the mistakes were "mostly honest," even if traceable to a ghastly ignorance of the Vietnamese people, culture and terrain, and the historical forces of that time.
Why should the rest of us relive his agony? Mr. McNamara, characteristically statistical, points to "11 major causes for our disaster in Vietnam" in a chapter called "The Lessons of Vietnam." But implicitly his book screams another lesson: Though cynicism and contempt for power are destructive of government, a respectful skepticism is essential, and rarely wrong.
BY delaying his war memoir so long, Mr. McNamara has greatly compounded the difficulty of his mission. Now that the Soviet Union lies in ruins and American corporations beg for business in China and Vietnam, no one under the age of 50 can be expected to fathom the fears and phobias of the 1960's to which he rightly ascribes the Indochina disaster. President Dwight D. Eisenhower, the most venerated American of the time, had taught -- and the Kennedy and Johnson teams never dared to doubt in time -- that if South Vietnam was "lost" to Communism, Laos, Cambodia, Thailand and Malaysia would fall like dominoes, imperiling India, Burma, Indonesia and the Philippines, if not also Japan, and emboldening the Russians and Chinese to extend Communist conquests by military force or subversion in ways that would sooner or later provoke a nuclear World War III, the very destruction of civilization.
Yes, that is how America's leaders spoke to each other and, all too persuasively, to the public. Mr. McNamara's book reminds us that they even repeated the litany in memos to their Presidents, to inoculate them against any temptation to retreat from Vietnam. And if all those dominoes were not cause enough, there were promises to be kept in order to preserve the value of America's other diplomatic threats and commitments.
Mr. McNamara and his generation came to power convinced that the "appeasement" of Nazi Germany -- the failure to block its early grasp for Europe's dominoes -- had led inevitably to a catastrophic World War II. Averting another such disaster, they were sure, required punishing anything resembling Communist aggression in its earliest stages, when the cost would be tolerable. That was their creed as they rebuilt Western Europe and stood toe to toe with the Soviet armies across Germany, fought to a bloody stalemate against China in Korea, threatened war over Berlin and risked war to force Soviet missiles out of Cuba. Thus "contained," the Soviets and Chinese took to endorsing "wars of liberation," thereby qualifying even distant uprisings as threats to American security. Mr. McNamara's first assignment from President John F. Kennedy was to augment America's nuclear power, whose use was unimaginable, with the forces and weapons they were sure would be needed to fight "conventional" wars.
From this bed of doctrine grew what Mr. McNamara considers his team's most fateful error: mistaking Ho Chi Minh's nationalist drive to unite Vietnam as the challenge of a monolithic Communist world. That misjudgment foreclosed any discussion of how an American withdrawal from Indochina could be made strategically tolerable. It even prevented analysis, before the plunge, of how high a price the commitment was worth. Mr. McNamara's dry rendering of those fateful tenets of containment fails to convey the passion with which they were embraced. And he mostly ignores their powerful resonance in domestic politics.
Kennedy, no less than Johnson, subscribed to these simplistic doctrines and the misjudgments they inspired, even though Mr. McNamara, without persuasive evidence, deems it "highly probable" that Kennedy would have pulled back from massive intervention in a second term. This presumes that had Kennedy lived, the same cast of senior officials would have avoided what Mr. McNamara describes as a second tier of error: the failure to live by the mantra that the battle in Vietnam was political, a fight for the "hearts and minds" of an abused peasantry, and that Americans could assist but never supplant the South Vietnamese.
In this pew, Mr. McNamara himself was a prominent sinner. His can-do spirit found no mission impossible, even as Saigon's governments and armies crumbled. His domineering intellect and predilection for systems analysis made him a pathetic victim of erroneous and deceptive military audits of bodies counted, weapons captured, sorties flown, supply lines ruptured. Soon enough, as the press decided, it became "McNamara's war," and certainly America's.
Mr. McNamara deplores the absence of political advice from old Asia hands who had been driven from Government service in the McCarthy purges. But as he proves again in this memoir, he did not easily integrate political wisdom and intuition into his analyses. Even in retrospect, he does not associate the drift into war in Vietnam with the Republican taunts that Democrats had "lost" China to Communism. (Kennedy was afraid to recognize not only China but even Outer Mongolia!) Mr. McNamara cannot bring himself to believe that the election calendar affected Johnson's willingness to escalate the war in 1965 but not in 1964 or, as Johnson eventually confessed to Doris Kearns, that he stayed the course in Asia because he feared losing effectiveness at home -- like Truman after the "loss" of China -- as much as he feared the repercussions of defeat abroad.
Finally, Mr. McNamara recounts a third tier of error -- an escalating pattern of military misjudgment. He is hard on the Joint Chiefs of Staff for their misplaced optimism in the early years, their always excessive faith in high-tech weapons and their later expectations that massive bombing and frontal battles could wear down the Vietnamese enemy. He is remiss in not fully rebutting the postwar claims that timid civilians had tied the military's hands with unreasonable limits on troop commitments and bombing targets. Mr. McNamara emphasizes how little was accomplished by bombings heavier even than those in World War II. And he explains Johnson's caution in target selection by recalling the fear that a more rapid escalation could provoke Chinese intervention. But Americans who cannot accept David's triumph over Goliath draw more belligerent "lessons" from this history, which Mr. McNamara should have engaged more directly.
Even more disappointing is Mr. McNamara's unwillingness to explore the human tragedies and political legacies of this longest American war. What was it like to send tens of thousands to their deaths in an increasingly dubious cause? How did the strain affect the men in charge? We get a glimpse of Jacqueline Kennedy beating him on the chest in protest against the war, and of angry insults hurled on the ski slopes, but no real introspection. Mr. McNamara says the war tore deeply at his own family, but quickly adds: "I am not comfortable speaking in such terms."
What then of the political legacy? How, without growing cynical, can citizens protect themselves against the stubborn ignorance and misplaced zeal of their leaders? In the darkest days, Mr. McNamara remembers, he watched the demonstrators from his Pentagon window and insisted that his subordinates show respect for the freedoms of speech and assembly. But he took refuge -- and takes it even now -- in opinion polls that recorded support from the majority of Americans who, as he well knew, had been misinformed and denied vital information at every major turn.
"Looking back," he writes, "I clearly erred by not forcing . . . a knock-down, drag-out debate over the loose assumptions, unasked questions and thin analyses underlying our military strategy in Vietnam. I had spent 20 years as a manager identifying problems and forcing organizations -- often against their will -- to think deeply and realistically about alternative courses of action and their consequences. I doubt I will ever fully understand why I did not do so here."
YET even now Mr. McNamara means he should have stirred debate only inside the small circle of Presidential counselors led by himself, Secretary of State Dean Rusk and McGeorge Bundy, the national security adviser (later succeeded by Walt Rostow). Mr. McNamara blames Johnson for going to war furtively, with no regard for the rights of Congress and the public, but he rejects any obligation to resign in protest or, once out of office, to share his policy disagreements with the country. Cabinet officers, he contends, should have a constituency of one: the President -- from whom they derive all authority and through whom alone they can be held accountable.
That is surely the right ethic for normal times. Unelected officials should not steal their President's mandate to pursue an independent course. But a thousand dead Americans a month create their own constituency. Even military discipline admits a higher duty than hierarchical loyalty when power is badly used and puts lives at risk.
Mr. McNamara relieved his private turmoil by reading poetry, and shared his misgivings with Robert F. Kennedy and a few other intimates. But he refused to abandon or attack the President whom he had helped to guide into quicksand. He and Johnson "loved and respected" each other, in a bond that even now, in retrospect, keeps the public at a distance looking on, with skepticism, I hope.

GRAPHIC: Drawing
