HEADLINE: U.S. Is Critical Of Tokyo Plan To Rein In Yen

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: SANUR, Indonesia, Sunday, April 16

 BODY:
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin told his Japanese counterpart this morning that the emergency financial package Japan issued last week was so vague that it had failed to reverse the fall of the dollar against the yen. And the Secretary pressed for far more action before the currency gyrations threaten the economic stability of the world's biggest trading region.
The meeting with Japan's Finance Minister, Masayoshi Takemura, came at the opening of a meeting of finance ministers from around the Pacific on the resort island of Bali. A senior Administration official who took part in the session said that Mr. Takemura, a politician with no financial background prior to assuming his post last year, conceded that the package announced by Tokyo had "not been received favorably by the market and by market analysts." 
 The official said Mr. Takemura had promised more specific action to stimulate Japan's economy and deregulate its market in the next month or so. But American officials clearly fear that could be too little, too late, and that the dollar could fall even further in the interim.
Emerging from the meeting, Mr. Rubin also said that the Japanese had inquired whether the United States was interested in bolstering the dollar by issuing Treasury bonds denominated in Japanese yen rather than in dollars.
"He asked it rather than suggested it," said Mr. Rubin, who is on his first extended international trip as Treasury Secretary. "And I told him we had no intention of doing so."
The idea of issuing American securities in yen has been floated in recent days, by both Americans and Japanese, as a quick fix to the exchange rate troubles that are resounding around the world. The theory is that Japanese investors, as well as other investors around the world, would feel more secure buying a yen-denominated bond because it would insulate them from any further fall in the dollar. If the dollar did fall after the bonds were issued, the cost would be born by the United States Government, which would have to pay back the bondholders in more valuable Japanese yen.
But such a bond issue would be highly unusual and, in the eyes of many American officials, a bit demeaning to their own currency. It might also relieve the pressure on Japan to take some of the fundamental steps needed to bring the currencies back in line, including opening its markets, just when American officials are urging the rest of Asia to intensify that pressure.
There was no sign that the meeting had achieved agreement on how to correct the startling 16 percent fall of the dollar against the yen in recent months.
A brief statement issued by the two countries afterward said that Mr. Rubin and Mr. Takemura, who came to office in a political deal that brought the current, shaky Japanese coalition Government to power, agreed that the currency shift "by no means reflects the economic fundamentals." They promised to "consult closely and to cooperate as appropriate" in coming weeks, the code words used among finance ministers to try to convince the markets that the two Governments will act in concert to reverse any further fall of the dollar. But in recent weeks, that cooperation appears to have been spotty, and it has usually not worked.
Though Mr. Rubin described today's meeting as "in tone, cordial," it clearly came at a time of sharp tensions with Tokyo over what American officials term Japan's intransigence in opening its automobile and auto parts markets to far more foreign goods. Autos were supposed to be an important part of a broader agreement President Clinton negotiated in 1993, but last week the Administration publicly warned Japan that it would move to impose tariffs on billions of dollars in Japanese products if major progress was not made in the next three weeks.
The dollar's troubles and the yen's surge have loomed over this meeting. Many countries throughout the Pacific borrowed yen heavily from Japan throughout the 1980's and the first half of the 90's to pay for public works projects, and now find themselves paying far more on those loans then they had bargained for.
Moreover, the yen's surge seems bound to accelerate Japan's race into Southeast Asia, as Japanese companies -- struggling to regain their competitiveness as the costs of their products soar -- rush to move more factories out of Japan. For example, here in Indonesia, a boom in Japanese investments in assembly lines is under way, totaling $1.56 billion last year. It is a welcome development for many in this country, one of the 10 "big emerging markets" that the Clinton Administration has focused on to gain a foothold for American business.
The yen's rise also complicates the region's delicate power relationships, especially as many nations in Asia prepare to celebrate their liberation from Japanese occupation 50 years ago this summer. While countries in the region have always courted Japanese investors, they have usually kept their foreign exchange reserves in dollars, creating a strong link with the American economy. Now countries like Taiwan are rethinking the wisdom of that strategy, having watched their reserves dwindle in buying power compared with the yen.
The disagreement over what to do about the dollar mirrors a larger argument over which of the world's two largest economic powers bears more responsibility for the fall of the dollar. The Japanese have long argued that the fundamental problem lies in Washington's addiction to deficit spending and its unwillingness to act decisively to cut expenditures.
American officials counter that the real problem is an overly strong yen, not a weak dollar, and that it is only made worse by what they see as Japan's dithering on broad economic reforms that have been discussed for years. They contend that it is up to the Japanese Government to find ways both to stimulate Japan's economy and bring in a burst of imports. That, in turn, should cut Japan's $64 billion trade surplus and presumably bring the yen and the dollar back into each other's orbit.
But Mr. Rubin's aides grimaced when they saw the much-heralded new economic plan, because it included no numbers and few specific commitments. The markets were also unimpressed -- the dollar did not recover in Tokyo trading on Friday -- and an unusually large number of Japanese economists have denounced the effort as insufficient.
A large number of ideas put forth in the plan, like strengthening Japan's Fair Trade Commission to bolster competition, are chestnuts that have been around for years and that are discussed with renewed vigor whenever there is a re-eruption of American-Japanese trade conflicts.
The element of Japan's package that most pleased the United States was a reduction of its discount rate to 1 percent, from 1.75 percent, although American officials expressed skepticism about whether any changes in rates already so low could move the currency markets. The biggest element of the plan was an offer to speed up Japan's deregulation effort, as well as to spend more on public works and to allow the resumption of deficit spending in hopes that it will lift the Japanese economy out of its doldrums.
But the powerful Japanese Government bureaucracy managed to take any targets or numerical goals out of the plan, and the result was a patchwork that American officials regarded as little more than a restatement of unmet past commitments.
For Mr. Rubin, the trip to Indonesia, to be followed by four days in India, is an effort both to acquaint himself with America's challenges in Asia and to deliver some uncomfortable messages.
The challenge is to position the United States to help finance and build some of the world's largest public works projects. In a speech in Los Angeles on his way here, the Treasury Secretary estimated that Asia will need about $1 trillion in dams and power stations, new telephone networks and highways during the next five years.
But he is also facing growing skepticism about the speed with which the United States is pressing Asian countries to open their markets, liberalize their investment laws and let markets rule. Mexico's financial disaster has made many other fast-growing economies leery, and Mr. Rubin has said he wants to disseminate the lessons of those mistakes widely, so they are not repeated.

HEADLINE: A Job Opening in Brooklyn: Poet Laureate

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON

 BODY:
The Brooklyn poet laureate's study is unused now. There are an old memo pad, books and photographs in the tiny, lamplighted Brooklyn Heights den. A walking stick, polished but untouched, stands in a corner.
And there is a poem taped to the bulletin board. It opens: 
 I have no soil but this hard ground,
Stone and subterranean quarry,
Underground rails, dynamos, steel
Beneath the granite rising, I inhale.
Brooklyn's poet laureate position became vacant March 11. Norman Rosten, poet, playwright, novelist, memoirist, died at age 81. There has already been a musical tribute to Mr. Rosten beside the East River, and there will be a poetry reading and memorial service at Borough Hall in Brooklyn next month.
And then there will be the matter of his title -- poet laureate of Brooklyn -- as well as the question of a possible successor. It is a title at once grand and modest, comic and appropriate and perfect. It is also a title not many in Brooklyn are aware exists.
"Some of you may say, who needs one? And I say we do," Borough President Howard Golden said with a smile when he bestowed the title on Mr. Rosten in 1979. "Someone reminded me that Walt Whitman would have been a better choice. But we wanted a live poet, and Norman was available."
There is no shortage of potential successors, for Brooklyn is deep in poets, people writing in all sorts of languages and voices, dialects, idioms, and, yes, occasionally even couplets. The poets of Brooklyn read their work in a couple of cafes and a lot of classrooms. They appear on the public access cable channels, reading poems about cultural imperialism and about the I.R.T. They sing the body electric, and write about paying the Con Ed bill.
There is an 80-year-old Dutch biologist in Sheepshead Bay who writes poetry on the side and who has published a collection called "Breuckelyn." There is the recently retired "Poet of the D Train," who said he would come out of retirement to accept the poet laureate title. There is Louis Reyes Rivera, a 50-year-old Puerto Rican who maintains that Congress, in a ceremony several years ago, officially named him the poet laureate of Bed-Stuy.
There is Anthony Vitale, the 20-year-old Italian-American poet prodigy in Marine Park who has studied under Allen Ginsberg at Brooklyn College. There is Konstantin K. Kuzminsky, who was born in Leningrad, but who now roams Brighton Beach reciting poems in, he says, 24 languages. And there is Enid Dame, who lives in Brooklyn with her husband and fellow poet, Donald Lev, publishing all sorts of poetry in the Home Planet News, a local literary quarterly.
One of her works ends with the ominously poetic Brooklyn warning, "Anything you don't see will come back to haunt you."
Brooklyn's song of itself, then, keeps being sung.
"In Brooklyn, there is a sense of real culture," said Dennis Nurkse, a poet who lived in Manhattan, Latin America and Europe before arriving in Brooklyn in 1972. "It is the culture of lived lives."
The lives include those of Whitman and Hart Crane and Marianne Moore. Brooklyn was muse to all of them, and to Mr. Rosten. He wrote a book, "Under the Boardwalk," about growing up in Coney Island, and crafted scores of poems informed or infiltrated in one way or another by Brooklyn. Of Brooklyn, he wrote: "At its mere mention, I have seen people smile, groan, look suspicious, back away a step, embrace me, threaten me, pass a hand unsteadily across their faces, weep, stutter, or fall into a trance."
Mr. Golden, aware of Mr. Rosten's output even if he hadn't read all of his works, broached the idea of naming a Brooklyn poet laureate over coffee and bagels one morning 16 years ago.
"Norman was one of the last Brooklyn poets with a secure ability to get published," said Matthew Paris, a poet who has organized readings, workshops and benefits in Brooklyn for decades. "I think Howard Golden invented the idea of a poet laureate of Brooklyn in a moment of caprice. And, I should say, inspiration."
There are no formal duties to the job, certainly no great benefits. And as recounted by Mr. Rosten in a published essay, not much was negotiable when he became the first and only person ever to hold the spectacularly uncompensated position.
"Not even a part-time salary?" Mr. Rosten asked Mr. Golden over coffee that morning.
"It would create problems, believe me," Mr. Golden said.
"Would I have the use of an office, a secretary?" he asked.
"Maybe a work space; no secretary. It's a question of protocol."
"What about a parking space?"
"Absolutely not," Mr. Golden said. "I couldn't even get one for my daughter."
Mr. Golden has remained mostly quiet on the question of a successor to Mr. Rosten.
"The Borough President," said Greg Brooks, Mr. Golden's chief of staff, "is not really focusing on the future."
If and when the Borough President does turn to face the future and contemplate naming a second poet laureate of Brooklyn, the choice will be from a much-changed borough. The tides of immigration and economics have stocked Brooklyn with a different population pool of poets.
There are Arabs in Bay Ridge, a Chinatown in Sunset Park, a small continent of island natives from the Caribbean in Flatbush. Whether moved by political persecution in a foreign country or the loss of a rent-stabilized apartment in Manhattan, the new poets have arrived looking for a place to work, a place to be moved by.
They have bumped into and and mixed with other poets from other places, including those from the old Brooklyn, which might no longer be.
"A real, real Brooklyn person, a real, real Brooklyn poet -- I have no idea what or who that would be," said Leo Vroman, the retired biologist who was born in Holland and has lived in Sheepshead Bay for 40 years, publishing a series of poems about Plum Beach. "It's an interesting question, and I suppose one worth asking."
Answering the question by formal proclamation could be delicate for Mr. Golden, said Richard Bartee, a self-described "public poet" who was known in his heyday as the "Poet of the D Train."
"I call it ego-nomics, because whoever gets the title, potshots will be taken," Mr. Bartee said.
Donald Lev, though, thought he might have a solution.
"Maybe Howard will name himself," said Mr. Lev, a former cabdriver whom other Brooklyn poets have proposed as a candidate. "I don't know, these days, the poet laureate probably would have as much power as the Borough President does. Or doesn't."
More than a handful of Brooklyn poets doubt there will be a successor. But if such a prospect makes them momentarily mournful, it does not exactly break their hearts. Brooklyn has already broken them, and is busy mending them again, as well. The poets are absorbing and distilling everything: the juvenile violence and economic disillusionment, the AIDS and police brutality, the wonders of Prospect Park.
"Brooklyn brings out a provincial side of me that I don't mind confessing to," said Louis Reyes Rivera, who grew up in Bushwick surrounded by Italians, Hasidic Jews, Puerto Ricans and blacks. "But what Brooklyn affords its poets is the opportunity to influence tolerance. Poets, or cultural workers as I call them, can help others understand the beauty of difference."
To other poets, the enduring poetic appeal of Brooklyn is a plainly, powerfully physical phenomenon. Enid Dame talks of "cracked sidewalks and screaming people and flowers growing among them all."
Kimiko Hahn, the daughter of a mother from Maui and a father from Milwaukee, moved to Brooklyn nine months ago and has already written of its gardens and their plum tomatoes "glowing back at the dusk like three firm hearts."
"There is a particular kind of light in Brooklyn -- different, European," said Phyllis Capello, who was born in Bensonhurst and who now lives in Windsor Terrace and who has published a long poem called "Walking into the Dream." "And the ocean is in your vocabulary."
There appears no dictionary large enough to hold the full vocabulary employed by Brooklyn's poets.
Linda Cousins, a poet, edited an anthology called "Black and in Brooklyn," and she said it was loaded with verse about "poverty and race, passion and love." Mervyn Taylor, a Trinidadian, said his poetry and the conversations along Ocean Avenue "have got beyond the nostalgia that came with our self-imposed exile."
"If I stayed too long, it must be for something," said Mr. Taylor, a 53-year-old teacher.
For others, as it has been for ages, Brooklyn, whatever it is, is simply all they know. Anthony Vitale, not yet 21, lives in Marine Park and writes about what he calls "an urban suburbia."
"It would be pretty impossible to find one voice for Brooklyn," he said. "But conversation is what Brooklyn is about because Brooklyn English is different than any other. How people talk to each other in Brooklyn is unlike any other place."
Jamez Nobles, a 16-year-old from Crown Heights, listened to the voice in his head for years, and then began to put that inner monologue on paper. A student at Metropolitan Corporate Academy, he participated this year in a program called Poetry in the Schools.
"I always had poetry in the back of my mind, but it never came out," said Jamez, the oldest of four boys. "Now it is. It's mostly about desires, wants. Brooklyn is an interesting place. I go to Bay Ridge and it's like I'm down South. But I live on Utica Avenue, and Brooklyn can be hard. You see stuff. It's unavoidable. I'm writing it down now. People say it's good. I'm amazed."
Maybe Howard Golden could take a look.
"I hope it doesn't end with my father," Patricia Rosten said of the position of poet laureate. "As someone said when they first heard of the title, 'Oh, good, we in Brooklyn really are civilized.' "

he has a quadruple by-pass, vegetables
in the back, zenias and sunflowers in front
where he chats to neighbors

Notice the rooftops,

SECTION: Section 13WC; Page 1; Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1597 words

HEADLINE: First Amendment Rights vs. Zoning Laws for Topless Bars

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

DATELINE: PORT CHESTER

 BODY:
IT has been two years since Goldie Solomon began her nightly vigil outside a topless bar here, and the 68-year-old retired nurse still carries a homemade sign with a message for the young women dancing inside and the male patrons who come to see them.
"No porno here," Ms. Solomon's placard reads. "Sex and liquor don't mix. Go home." 
 When the weather is good, Ms. Solomon -- a village gadfly who twice ran for mayor on the Common Sense Party line, "like Thomas Paine," she said -- is joined by other residents who also object to having a topless bar in their neighborhood. They maintain that the bar, the Diamond Club, does not belong in a small shopping center where an ice cream store, pet shop, chicken and ribs restaurant and Laundromat cater to family trade.
But their objections may have little to do with the legal rights of the Diamond Club or any other topless bar. Spokesmen for the American Civil Liberties Union and lawyers for the bar say they are digging in their heels for the fight that lies ahead -- against what they assert are restrictive zoning laws and other ordinances that deny people or businesses their First Amendment rights.
In a lawsuit in United States District Court for the Southern District of New York in White Plains, lawyers for the Diamond Club, also known as LaTrieste Restaurant and Cabaret, claim the village is selectively enforcing laws in a discriminatory fashion to eliminate topless dancing. They are also seeking $11 million in compensatory and other damages, which they say includes loss of business and violation of Constitutional rights.
"The fight we're fighting goes beyond topless dancing," said Gerald Padian, a lawyer for the Diamond Club. "If Port Chester were to succeed in its efforts against the nightclub, there would be nothing to stop it from doing the same thing to any other business in town or even an ethnic group it found undesirable."
"These are the kinds of actions that lead to book burning," said Mr. Padian of the Manhattan-based firm Tashjin & Padian.
The suit maintains that when the topless bar operated before 1993 as a restaurant and cabaret, the village ignored laws that required live entertainment to be offered only after 10 P.M. but later sought to implement the rules when topless dancing began. The suit alleges that the village began "a pattern of harassment," including summonses, arrests, fines and sudden enforcement of a variety of ordinances and regulations.
Port Chester, meanwhile, is seeking dismissal of the suit, denying in a document sent to Judge Charles L. Brieant of United States District Court in White Plains that it sought to enforce the the laws to drive out the bar's owners.
James L. Fischer, a lawyer for Port Chester, said personal values had nothing to do with the matter. "There's no discrimination involved," he said. "The only issue here is illegality. If the club began at 10, there would be no trouble."
Until the court case is settled, Mr. Padian said his clients would continue to feature topless dancing at the Diamond Club as early as lunchtime.
As for Ms. Solomon and the other picketers, they may continue to protest, although in February the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in White Plains enjoined them from doing so on private property.
The conflict is expected to have broad implications for municipal officials elsewhere in the county, many of whom are considering restrictive zoning to confine the activities of topless bars. At present there are only four or five topless bars in the county.
Owners of the bars are also watching the case closely. One proprietor said a victory for the Diamond Club could mean fewer restrictions in the future for his bar.
The American Civil Liberties Union, too, is monitoring Port Chester's conflict, and Norman Siegel, a spokesman for the New York Civil Liberties Union, based in Manhattan, said his organization would consider joining the plaintiffs in the suit.
In Westchester, Robert David Goodstein, legal director of the county's chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union, said that topless bars were "legal and legitimate types of businesses."
He added, "These places are allowed to exist, and you can't use zoning or other means to censor them."
He also said that the State Liquor Authority permits topless dancing in bars where alcoholic beverages are served, and that in establishments where no alcohol is served, nudity is allowed.
In North Tarrytown, Mayor Sean Treacy said that although his village had not outlawed topless bars, it "had made it impossible for them to open within 500 feet of a residential neighborhood, churches, social clubs and schools, and that's a very large area." The restrictive zoning was also intended to prevent existing bars from becoming topless, he added.
Villagers feared that a topless bar would bring with it prostitution and other crimes, Mayor Treacy said.
In Yonkers, Mayor Terence Zaleski reported that his city had imposed a six-month moratorium on establishing adult-entertainment businesses pending enactment of laws to regulate them.
According to a city ordinance, adult-entertainment uses include bookstores, video stores, theaters, peep shows, massage parlors and public or private establishments providing dancers, strippers or other forms of entertainment that involve sexual activities.
A topless bar in Yonkers known as the Body Shop was closed last winter after the New York State Liquor Authority revoked the bar's liquor license for violation of exposure rules, lewd and indecent conduct and sale of drinks during prohibited hours. Another establishment, the Fantasy Club, closed after the city prevailed on the building's landlord to end the bar's lease, Mr. Zaleski said. A third topless bar, City Lights, has been in business nearly 10 years.
The Mayor said topless bars and other forms of adult entertainment "have a deleterious effect on the quality of life and are not conducive to economic development, because many times their activities are not behind closed doors."
In the case of the Body Shop, he said, "undesirables spilled out on to the sidewalk."
The city now bans topless dancing within 500 feet of a residential area. Legislation before the City Council would broaden the definition of adult entertainment and ban the operation of such businesses within 500 feet of a school, place of worship, day-care center or playground.
Mr. Goodstein at the Westchester chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union said, "Zoning can only be done for zoning purposes, not as a subterfuge for a ban."
At New York Civil Liberties Union headquarters in Manhattan, Mr. Siegel, the executive director, said:
"We recognize that many people are offended by these kinds of businesses, but if we allow governments to serve as the arbiters of good taste, we might as well abolish the First Amendment. The fact that a topless bar is not popular is not reason enough to close it down."
He said the effort to shut down or severely restrict topless bars was a matter of "certain people trying to impose their morality on everyone else, and that's un-American." Mr. Siegel, a lawyer, predicted that many more suits would be fought in coming months to protect "major First Amendment challenges."
In New York City, the City Council is considering two bills, one aimed at video stores and bookstores and the other involving topless bars and nude clubs. The bills would prohibit such businesses from opening within 500 feet of a residential zone, a house of worship or a school or within 500 feet of a similar business.
Mr. Siegel said that a coalition of business owners and citizens was planning to challenge the 500-foot law if it goes into effect. Like the suit in Port Chester, the New York City conflict could become another "very important test case," he said.
Mr. Siegel and Mr. Goodstein observed that the crime rate does not necessarily increase near topless bars and other adult-entertainment enterprises, a fact borne out in interviews with several police departments.
In New Rochelle, Lieut. Dominic C. Locatelli said there had been "no problems" with Billy Budd's Pub, a topless bar in that city. In Mount Vernon, Chief Michael J. Craparo reported "only sporadic incidents of under-age drinking and disorderly conduct" at Sue's Rendezvous.
One proprietor of a topless club said he had hired extra staff members to maintain law and order.
"As a topless bar, we're being watched more because people don't like us," said Robert S., a co-owner, who agreed to be interviewed only on the condition that his last name not be used. "Publicity in the past only awakened people to something they're not in favor of."
He said his business had experienced resistance from religious leaders and local officials when it first opened but that there has been "very little crime here, probably less than the local gin mill or rock bar."
"We try and mind our own business and give the customers what they want within the legal limits of the law," he said.
One of the club's dancers, Skye Ajuirre, said she and the other performers also work "strictly by the books."
"No offers, no trips, no extra money," she said.
Ms. Ajuirre, who is 28, works as a secretary by day and a topless dancer two or three nights a week. The club pays her $8 an hour to perform, but "on a good night," she said, she earns another $300 in tips.
Under state law, topless dancers must perform at least six feet from patrons and on a stage that is at least 18 inches off the ground. Typically, the stage is inside a circular bar.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 20; Column 3; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1096 words

HEADLINE: Straight Talk

BYLINE: By Carol Tavris; Carol Tavris, a social psychologist, is the author of "The Mismeasure of Woman."

 BODY:

THE INVENTION OF HETEROSEXUALITY
By Jonathan Ned Katz.
Foreword by Gore Vidal.
291 pp. New York: Dutton. $22.95. 
IF you are heterosexual, you will probably be inspired to make a joke or two about "The Invention of Heterosexuality" ("Well, it's about time someone invented it," you'll want to say, or "So that's what I've been doing all my life"). Go ahead; Jonathan Ned Katz won't mind. He's got a swell sense of humor, and he appreciates the irony that a gay historian -- his previous book was "Gay American History" -- would be tackling the history of heterosexuality.
Heterosexuality, according to Mr. Katz, was invented in the 1860's in Germany. He is not, of course, talking about the invention of sexual feelings or acts between women and men, which presumably occurred a few times before 1860. He is talking about the invention of the categories "heterosexual" and "homosexual": the idea that sexual behaviors clump into two "opposite" types. Mr. Katz shows how heterosexuality, as an idea and as an ideal, has changed over time, signifying "one particular historical arrangement of the sexes and their pleasures."
"Heterosexuality," he says, made its American debut in a medical journal in 1892, where it referred not to desire for the other sex, but to desire for both sexes. It was considered a perversion, one of several "abnormal manifestations of the sexual appetite." The association of heterosexuality with perversion continued for several decades; as late as 1923, Merriam-Webster's called it a "morbid sexual passion for one of the opposite sex." But by 1934 it had become a "manifestation of sexual passion for one of the opposite sex; normal sexuality." (Note the term "opposite sex," itself a relatively new way of regarding men and women.)
Mr. Katz traces the evolution of heterosexuality from its origins as a perverted desire to its present incarnation as normal sexuality. As the medical establishment claimed hegemony over sexual matters at the end of the 19th century -- influenced by Krafft-Ebing and Freud -- it transformed the discussion about sex from what was "natural" and "moral" to what was "normal" and "healthy." (At first this seemed like progress.) That done, physicians and psychiatrists sought to explain, and cure, those who were "abnormal" and "unhealthy." In the first decades of the 20th century, Mr. Katz shows in a chapter called "The Heterosexual Comes Out," the mass media seized on and validated the concept of "the" heterosexual.
Scholars who study the origins of sexual orientation, like those who study the differences between men and women, generally fall into two kinds: those who think there are two kinds of people in the world, and those who don't. Are men and women opposite sexes? Are homosexuality and heterosexuality opposite orientations? The essentialist school holds that there is something fundamental, unchanging and biologically wired in women and men, gay people and straight people, that causes their differences. The constructionist school holds that differences are largely due to economics, power inequities and cultural forces, and that theories of difference have powerful social consequences. To illustrate this argument, constructionists like Mr. Katz have begun to examine the categories we consider normal instead of forever focusing on those who are different (women, blacks, Jews and so forth). "By making the sex-normal the object of historical study," Mr. Katz observes, "we upset basic preconceptions." And so he does.
For readers unversed in social constructionism, this lively and provocative book will be a good introduction, especially to the ideas of Michel Foucault, whose monumental "History of Sexuality" challenged essentialist assumptions about sex. Unfortunately, Foucault also gave academics a new language -- excuse me, medium of discourse. From time to time Mr. Katz's prose runs aground in befogged Foucaultian swamps: "Heterosexuality, I now think, is invented in discourse as that which is outside discourse. It's manufactured in a particular discourse as that which is universal."
In spite of these lapses and various arguments that readers may disagree with, Mr. Katz's overall message is important. It is not accidental that theories of difference flourish precisely when the differences in question are fading. Just when studies find that men and women are far more alike than different in abilities, nurturance, nastiness, wisdom and foolishness, we get theories and television shows about how different our brains, psyches and archetypes are. If the "gender gap" is narrowing, Mr. Katz argues, so is the "sexual orientation gap": even as the media emphasize biological differences between homosexuals and heterosexuals, the evidence shows a convergence in life styles, sexual practices, consumer values, diverse family arrangements and endorsement of an ethic of sexual pleasure.
THIS convergence, of course, is precisely what is causing such apoplectic spasms from the right wing, which is determined to reinforce the "naturalness" and "superiority" not only of heterosexuality but also of masculinity. And that is Mr. Katz's point: the terms "heterosexuality" and "homosexuality" do not simply describe variations in sexual behavior, but suggest that one way is right, healthy and superior. "If homosexuals were to win society-wide equality with heterosexuals, there'd be no reason to distinguish them," Mr. Katz concludes. "The homosexual/heterosexual distinction would be retired from use, just as it was once invented."
Perhaps not. People in every culture and era have noticed variations in sexual orientation, whether they had labels for them or not. Moreover, such variations are pretty interesting, and I see no need to retire useful terms that describe them. Nor do I think it is necessary to perpetuate the dichotomy between biological contributions to behavior and social and cultural ones, as long as we heed the social constructionists' warnings against biological reductionism.
What we can and must dispense with are the value judgments that difference means deficiency and that numbers confer health or superiority. Left-handed people were once stigmatized, seen as abnormal and subjected to all manner of supposed cures by right-handers convinced of their natural superiority. Today we regard left-handedness as a normal variation; it's no big deal. No reason we can't one day have the same attitude toward the extraordinary variation in human homosexualities -- and heterosexualities. Jonathan Katz's book will help us get there.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: April 16, 1995

SECTION: Section 7; Page 3; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1460 words

HEADLINE: Too Many Foreigners

BYLINE: By Nicholas Lemann; Nicholas Lemann is a national correspondent for The Atlantic Monthly and the author of "The Promised Land: The Great Black Migration and How It Changed America."

 BODY:

ALIEN NATION
Common Sense About
America's Immigration Disaster.
By Peter Brimelow.
327 pp. New York:
Random House. $24. 
IMMIGRATION is one of those issues that split American conservatism in two. In the libertarian wing of the conservative mansion can be found the only people anywhere in our political debate who favor completely open borders -- like Robert L. Bartley, the editor of The Wall Street Journal, and the economist Julian L. Simon. But the most intense opposition to immigration is also located in the conservative movement, over in the cultural and populist areas, whence came much of the impetus for California's Proposition 187, denying most government services to illegal immigrants. Although there is an anti-immigration tradition within liberalism too, in the main liberals seem to have settled into a sentimental, optimistic, celebratory view of immigrants.
It is this view that Peter Brimelow aims to pick mercilessly apart in "Alien Nation," which is an expanded version of a 1992 cover story in National Review and a book-length articulation of an anti-immigration position that has been bubbling up in more obscure places for several years. Mr. Brimelow, a senior editor of Forbes and National Review, treats his fellow conservatives who support immigration, especially Mr. Simon, as admirable but sadly mistaken -- while he goes after the liberals with scornful glee.
One by one he sets up the liberal arguments and knocks 'em down. The United States was not originally conceived of as a nation of immigrants, or even as multiethnic: Mr. Brimelow reminds us that the Declaration of Independence contains a rarely quoted attack on "the merciless Indian Savages." Rather than having been continuous, large-scale immigration to the United States has come in concentrated bursts, which have been followed by long, relatively immigration-free adjustment periods. Rather than being fundamentally multiethnic, the United States was, as late as 1960, just short of being 90 percent white (though how Hispanic Americans were counted at that time seems to be ambiguous).
Today, immigration is at one of its historic highs: counting illegals, well over two million people a year come to the United States, and, compared with past immigrants, far fewer of them ever leave. Immigration accounts for 37 percent of our population growth. Instead of generating economic growth and tax revenues, immigrants, Mr. Brimelow says, are a net drain on the country, crowding public schools, welfare rolls, jails and hospitals. And by their mere presence they exacerbate ethnic tension.
Mr. Brimelow describes this situation in the direst language imaginable: "There is no precedent for a sovereign country undergoing such a rapid and radical transformation of its ethnic character in the entire history of the world," he writes. Possibly the result will be "the snuffing out of the American nation -- like a candle in a gale." If that doesn't happen, at the very least, during the next century "American patriots will be fighting to salvage as much as possible from the shipwreck of their great republic."
Buried within the apocalyptic rhetoric is a much more specific complaint, namely, that the 1965 immigration law (the Immigration and Nationality Act Amendments) led to a much higher level of immigration than its authors anticipated and needs to be corrected. In an uncharacteristically calm passage, Mr. Brimelow suggests that legal immigration be cut by about two-thirds.
Passed at the height of the civil rights era, the 1965 law was meant to undo the Quota Act of 1921 and the Immigration Act of 1924, which severely restricted immigration and also gave most of the slots to people from northern and western Europe. Much of contemporary conservatism revolves around the idea that some time in the 1960's the country took a disastrous wrong turn. Mr. Brimelow believes that the wrong turn was specifically the 1965 law, which he blames for ills ranging from the long-term slowdown of the economy to the creation of the urban underclass.
One could hold the position that the nondiscriminatory spirit of the 1965 law was laudable, but that its emphasis on admitting immigrants on the principle of family reunification as well as skills was misguided, and that the sheer number of people coming in now has moved beyond our capacity for absorption. Mr. Brimelow, however, takes an extra step. He wants to keep the immigration flow not just limited, and not just higher-skilled, but also mostly white. A waiting room of the Immigration and Naturalization Service reminds him of the New York subway: he finds each to be "an underworld that is not just teeming but also is almost entirely colored."
Most industrial nations are essentially monoethnic states that allow hardly any immigration at all. Mr. Brimelow admits that the United States has been more successfully multiethnic than any other country, but at bottom he just doesn't believe in the "American idea" that people here can transcend ethnicity through allegiance to abstract national principles like democracy and opportunity. What is required for the successful functioning of a nation, he insists, is "a link by blood."
Even "model minorities" that aren't white arouse Mr. Brimelow's suspicions. Reports of the success of Asian-Americans may be "just another immigration myth." Recently arrived Cubans "in fact participate heavily in welfare." West Indians? "It must be said that nowadays part of their enterprise goes into drug 'posses' and car-theft rings." Judging from a couple of asides, Mr. Brimelow doesn't consider Jews to meet his definition of "white" either; for example, he refers to the Clinton Administration as "a black-Hispanic-Jewish-minority white (Southerners used to call them 'scalawags') coalition." Elsewhere he points out that Jews played a major role in the passage of the hated 1965 immigration law. On the other hand, he calls it "a profound tragedy" that we don't relax our immigration restrictions to let in hundreds of thousands of eastern Europeans.
Mr. Brimelow is more an energetic pamphleteer than a reporter. He has done a good job of assembling printed material but, aside from one nocturnal visit to the Border Patrol station south of San Diego, he has not gone out in search of firsthand, irrefutable evidence that immigration actually is eating away at the very core of the country in the way he says it is. At one point he brings up a few pro-immigration arguments and then concludes, disarmingly, "I'm sure I'm right." The reason he's so sure is that it seems impossible to him that any society can remain strong for very long while allowing in large numbers of immigrants from a wide variety of ethnic groups.
When Mr. Brimelow tries to provide tangible details (as opposed to statistics) about the deteriorating fabric of life here caused by immigration, they often have an exaggerated or unproved feeling. He takes it as a given that immigrants no longer want to assimilate. In the near future, he says, Atlanta, Miami and San Antonio "will be communities as different from one another as any in the civilized world." Bilingual education is to him so obviously a program to keep people from learning English that he doesn't even bother to bring up and knock down the official rationale for it, which is that it encourages non-English speakers to stay in school while they learn the language. He views the creation of a secessionist Mexican-American state called Aztlan, a favorite cause of Southwestern student radicals in the 1960's, as a live possibility. Mr. Brimelow is right when he says that there is more risk from too much immigration than from too little, but he doesn't establish that the current situation justifies his level of alarm -- and the reason is that he finds the simple fact of substantial nonwhite immigration to be sufficiently alarming.
Several times in "Alien Nation" Mr. Brimelow mentions as one of the dangers of immigration that a significant percentage of immigrants will feel alienated from America -- the implication being that we ought not to let in too many people who are going to run down the country. This from a man who is himself an immigrant, from England, and who accuses "the American political elite" of "a species of treason"!
Mr. Brimelow's definition of "alienated" is political (it applies to complaints from the left but not the right) and his definition of "America" is racial. The amazing absence of euphemism and disingenuousness in his book helps make it clear why the immigration issue is so difficult: there is often a lot more in the opposition to immigration than straightforward policy-wonk concerns about whether we are letting in the right number of people.
